fields.headline: West Indies recapture their pride
fields.standfirst:
West Indies 187 and 147
Zimbabwe 236 and 63
West Indies win by 35 runs

A 10th defeat in 12 Tests, with Zimbabwe setting out needing only 99 to win their first Caribbean showdown, seemed inevitable. No Brian Lara, a sum total of 84 paying customers at the start, and the people of Trinidad were braced for the ultimate indignity.
fields.byline: BC Pires in Port of Spain
fields.body:
For most of yesterday West Indies were faced with the unsavoury prospect of being dubbed the worst side in the world. A 10th defeat in 12 Tests, with Zimbabwe setting out needing only 99 to win their first Caribbean showdown, seemed inevitable. No Brian Lara, a sum total of 84 paying customers at the start, and the people of Trinidad were braced for the ultimate indignity.

Instead they were rewarded with the most exciting bowling seen at the Queen's Park Oval since Mike Atherton's England were bowled out here for 46. It may not have been pace like fire any more, but yesterday West Indies had all four bowlers firing for a change. Together they delivered one of the most unlikely victories in West Indies history by skittling Zimbabwe for 63 to win by 35 runs.

Jimmy Adams, successful in his first Test as captain, afterwards paid tribute to his players' spirit, saying: "What satisfied me most was that we never gave up, even though we were not happy with every performance.

"Throughout, the objective was always to come back the next day and make up for what went wrong the previous day.

"We have seen it before and we truly believed that Test matches can turn inside of a session - particularly when you have a bowling quartet like ours."

For a start, he had four bowlers yesterday: the second-string bowlers, Franklyn Rose and Reon King, who performed well enough to make it really difficult for Adams to decide between them and the giants, Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh.

The Jamaican Rose orchestrated the collapse with a magnificent spell in which he took three for eight in six overs. He finished with four for 19 off 13 overs, including the key wickets of Andy Flower, the first-innings century-maker, and Murray Goodwin.

Even so Rose still lost the man of the match decision to Ambrose, presumably because the veteran Antiguan bowled the reputedly in-form batsman, Alistair Campbell.

Adams did concede that it was "crunch time" yesterday morning. Indeed, there may have been other occasions on which West Indies tried hard and failed, but there could hardly ever have been a greater crunch. Coming on the heels of the New Zealand whitewash, a defeat by the lowest-ranked Test-playing country would have technically made West Indies the worst team in the world.

Some discount of the win must be made because it was, at the end of the day, against Zimbabwe. Undeniably, though, yesterday's 47 overs provided more excitement for the small crowd than all of the rest of the game.

Perhaps it is nothing more than the concentration that comes with the prospect of being hanged at dawn, but West Indies looked more like themselves than they have in years; and that was without Lara.

Lara himself appears to be damned if he does and damned if he doesn't. He was criticised for having the temerity to come to the ground and thus add even more disruption to that caused by his resignation of the captaincy. Had he stayed away, though, he would have been crucified in the Caribbean press. Headlines would have screamed "Lara fiddles on golf course while Windies burn".

Afterwards, though, Adams, speaking with great warmth, said the team was glad to have Lara with them all the time and appreciated his advice.

Another Trinidadian cricket entity that is often vilified for being elitist and not upholding the traditional spirit of cricket, the Trini Posse, received vindication from on high - upwards of six feet - yesterday.

The Posse, whose all-inclusive ticket price (which translates as "pretty exclusive") entitles its patrons to unlimited food, drink and extremely loud blasts of soca music, is often criticised by those claiming to represent the "grassroots" of West Indian cricket - but, at the end of the game, Ambrose and Walsh ran directly to the Trini Posse stand to shake hands and slap high fives.

Zimbabwe's dream start became the West Indies dream end. Ten wickets for 63 runs in 47 overs are the most heartening numbers the West Indies have had for a long time. Reports of the death of Caribbean cricket remain, at least for now, premature.

fields.headline: Valencia 0 - 0 Manchester United
fields.trailText: Valencia: Canizares, Carboni, Pellegrino, Djukic, Angloma, Kily Gonzalez, Gerard, Farinos, Angulo, Lopez, Sanchez. Subs: Bartual Molina, Bjorklund, Oscar, Ilie, Vlaovic, Fagiani, Gerardo.
fields.body:
Valencia: Canizares, Carboni, Pellegrino, Djukic, Angloma, Kily Gonzalez, Gerard, Farinos, Angulo, Lopez, Sanchez. Subs: Bartual Molina, Bjorklund, Oscar, Ilie, Vlaovic, Fagiani, Gerardo.

Man Utd: Bosnich, Irwin, Stam, Berg, G. Neville, Fortune, Butt, Keane, Scholes, Sheringham, Solskjaer. Subs: Van Der Gouw, Cole, P. Neville, Cruyff, Yorke, Silvestre, Wallwork.

Referee: Michel Lubos (Slovakia)

United are without Giggs and Beckham for the match that will determine who Alex Ferguson's men can expect to meet as they progress. Fortune takes up residence of the left, while Paul Scholes moves over to the right.

1 United kick off and the game starts at speed as Valencia put early pressure on the United penalty area after a customary opening hoof upfield by the visitors.
2 Valencia again trying to push up as Claudio Lopez almost latches onto a sliding through-ball.
3 First chance of the match when Claudio Lopez puts over the bar after United are caught exposed at the back.
6 Valencia win a corner from the left, Gonzalez takes and launches the ball into a gaggle of white shirts from which Gerard rises to head down and force Bosnich to make a good save.
8 All Valencia in the opening minutes as United soak up the pressure.
9 Fortune makes up ground on the left and almost gets past Angulo to give United an opening.
12 United are lacking service from their midfield and are still finding it hard to do little more than hold Valencia at bay.
14 Claudio Lopez, looking dangerous down the right for Valencia, releases Angloma who carries the ball to the line. His whipped-in cross almost finds Sanchez at the near post but Berg makes a great blocking challenge to squeeze the ball wide.
16 United's best chance yet. Fortune breaks down the left before delivering a perfect cross for Sheringham to head down and force Canizares to make a diving save at the near post.
20 United win a free-kick to the right of the Valencia area. The ball finds Scholes who lofts it towards Berg in the area but Valencia clear. Keane crosses back in for Sheringham head behind. Goal-kick.
22 United really getting back into it now and the wings are providing the best route for their fightback. Sheringham charges off down the right and slides in a centre that is worthy of Beckham at his best; Solskjaer meets it ten yards out and although he gets on top of the ball and cannot get in a clean shot, Canizares is left to scramble clear from the line. Almost as if Solskjaer was surprised to have received such a great ball.
27 United put together some tidy moves as Solskjaer releases Scholes with a perfectly weighted pass deep in the Valencia area. Scholes tracks across goal and winds up with his right before watching a deflection by Pellegrino put his shot marginally wide. Valencia make a meal of clearing the resulting corner.
32 After a first 15 minutes that was dominated by Valencia and a second 15 in which United had the upper hand, both teams now appear content to share the fame factor and indulge in some end-to-end play. Solskjaer clearly relishing his rare start and Fortune keen to show that there need not be just one man in mind for this position as he makes the most of his battles with Angloma down the left.
35 Valencia almost open the scoring. Claudio Lopez delivers a deep cross from the left that floats just wide of the far post. Angulo is on hand to head back into the six-yard box but United's clearance goes only as far as Angloma who drills in a 25-yard, right-foot shot that flies off the right-hand upright in front of a relieved Bosnich.
40 Valencia again in the ascendancy as Claudio Lopez and Sanchez break to leave United exposed at the back. After a swift exchange of passes, Claudio Lopez appears to baulk at the opportunity to go one-on-one with Bosnich and the move breaks down.
44 United now making efforts to slow the game down from the break-neck pace at which it has been played until now.
45 United tap it around at the back and Irwin plays a somewhat hopeful long ball towards the lonely looking Solskjaer up front. Half-time. Both teams should have had goals by now, but it is impossible to say who has had the rub of the green such has been the pace of play.

46 Both teams looking eager to pick up where they left off, but content to play out the first encounters in the vicinty of the centre circle.
48 Valencia win a free-kick after Fortune wrestles Angulo to the ground 25 yards out. Claudio Lopez takes but shoots straight at the wall before picking up the rebound and rifling in a shot from 30 yards that only just goes wide.
53 United wake up to the second half after playing a tight first 10 minutes or so. Fortune finds Solskjaer on the left edge of the area; he plays back for Butt who then switches play to the right. Neville and Keane exchange passes and probe the Valencia defence before Neville delivers a cross that goes harmlessly behind the goal.
56 United doing a good job calming things down and changing the nature of their game as they search for an opening.
57 Valencia win a free-kick from 25 yards out when after Stam goes in from behind like a steamroller. Claudio Lopez takes and lofts the ball into the danger area at the far post but no Valencia player has made up ground to meet it. Claudio Lopez gets a second chance as when he fires a deep centre from the clearance that finds Gerard beyond the far post; he heads back in for Angloma to head into the hands of Bosnich.
58 Good chance for Valencia when Kily Gonzalez makes a run on the left, cuts inside the area and shoots from a tight angle to force a fine save from Bosnich.
59 Valencia win a corner; comes to nothing.
65 United now trying to hang on to the ball as if their lives depended on it. Valencia, aware that Fiorentina are beating Bordeaux 3-1 in the other Group B fixture, now know that a point will be enough to keep them in front of Fiorentina. The Spanish side seem content to play a dangerous game of relying on Claudio Lopez up front to break down a United side that, knowing they probably have the group sown up, are content to bide their time and await their chances. Only a goal from United can deny Valencia qualification.
68 Substitution Man Utd Cruyff on for Solskjaer.
71 Substitution Valencia ILie on for Sanchez.
73 Not much of a game to speak of. The home fans are getting frustated that their team are happy to settle for a point, while Fortune gamely tries to inject some life back in to the match by taking all of his chances to race away down the left.
75 Claudio Lopez screams at his players in an attempt to motivate them towards a fighting result, or perhaps he is just pointing out that should United go for a customary late winner, they will be stuffed.
79 Fortune continues to niggle at the Valencia defence and do his bit to remind the home side that it isn't over until it's over. That said Team United also appear content to do the minimum.
80 Valencia win a corner but both teams are happy return the ball to the centre of the park as soon as possible. A more crashing contrast to the first half there could not have been.
87 No change. Still 22 players who show no signs of being bored at passing the ball around aimlessly for 20 minutes. Kily Gonzalez is the only Valencia player who appears to have any sense of glory in his mind when he cuts inside the United area and lays on a shooting opportunity that bears more resemblance to a rocket launch. Stunning stuff!
90 Barely no extra time played as referee Lubos, able to take the excruciating tedium no longer, blows for time. Valencia 0 - 0 Man Utd. The other match in Group B finished Fiorentina 3 - 3 Bordeaux. Valencia finsh the group two points clear of Fiorentina and therefore join United in the quarter-finals.

webTitle: Scots ban Wright and rile Burnley

fields.headline: Scots ban Wright and rile Burnley
fields.trailText: Ian Wright's cross-border trouble caught up with the 36-year-old striker and Burnley yesterday when he was banned for two games for his tunnel clash with a fourth official after a match for his former club Celtic.
fields.body:
Ian Wright's cross-border trouble caught up with the 36-year-old striker and Burnley yesterday when he was banned for two games for his tunnel clash with a fourth official after a match for his former club Celtic.

The punishment, imposed by the Scottish Football Association for "exceptional misconduct", applies across Britain and means that Wright misses two Burnley matches, starting this weekend.

That infuriated his manager Stan Ternent, who argued there was no reason to punish the promotion-seeking Lancashire club as well as the player.

Wright left the Glasgow hearing without comment but Ternent, who was not allowed to attend, launched an immediate attack.

"I'm disappointed the Scottish FA have found it necessary to punish Burnley football club. If they wanted to penalise Ian Wright, they should have fined him instead of penalising us as well. It isn't right because, although he was a Celtic player then, he is now an integral part of this club."

The SFA disciplinary chairman Chris Robinson denied Wright had been treated leniently and refused to put the offence in the same category as Paolo di Canio's infamous push on Paul Alcock which earned the Italian an 11-game ban.

Robinson said: "I cannot comment on the punishments by the English FA but what I will say is Paolo di Canio pushed the referee on to his backside in a very high-profile case."

Yet Robinson revealed the committee "were of the view that Willie Young [the fourth official] had been quite serverely pushed" by Wright in the clash in the Rugby Park tunnel after Celtic's 1-1 draw at Kilmarnock on January 23. The former England international had also been involved in a running argument with the home defender Jim Lauchlan.

Tranmere's manager John Aldridge is in triple trouble with the FA after being hit with a third misconduct charge in the last four months. The latest charge follows Aldridge's alleged remarks to the fourth official Ian Bentley in the game at Portsmouth on March 1 which Tranmere won 2-1.

Aldridge still has to answer to the FA over alleged comments to the referee Jeff Winter surrounding the 3-1 defeat at Birmingham in November and the Wembley bust-up with a Leicester substitute, Theo Zagorakis, in the Worthington Cup final after Zagorakis appeared to applaud the sending-off of Tranmere's Clint Hill.

Don Hutchison, although conservatively valued at £5m, may well be allowed to leave Everton for Sunderland for less than half that before Thursday's transfer deadline.

Having fallen foul of his manager Walter Smith, Hutchison has been told he has no future at Goodison. Intriguingly the clubs meet on Saturday.

Peter Reid is believed to be ready to bid around £2.5m and Sunderland's manager also hopes to sign Wimbledon's full-back Ben Thatcher this week in a £3m package deal which would see Michael Gray move to Selhurst Park.

Darren Anderton is set to sign a one-year extension to his Tottenham contract which was due to expire this summer. The deal is worth a reputed £24,000 a week.

webTitle: Babayaro to turn back on Chelsea again

fields.headline: Babayaro to turn back on Chelsea again
fields.trailText: Only four weeks after Celestine Babayaro returned late from the African Nations Cup, Chelsea face losing the defender again after Nigeria called up the 21-year-old for an Olympic qualifier on Saturday
fields.body:
Only four weeks after Celestine Babayaro returned late from the African Nations Cup, Chelsea face losing the defender again. Nigeria have called up the 21-year-old for an Olympic qualifier on Saturday and, although Chelsea were fighting to keep him last night, they look like losing the battle.

Nigeria are insisting that Babayaro plays for the Under-23s against Zimbabwe in Lagos as they seek the win they need to stand any chance of reaching Sydney. Chelsea are determined to use the player against Southampton on Saturday.

"This is an under-23 game and not a full international, so we've written [to the Nigerian FA] asking if it's possible for him not to be released," said Chelsea's assistant manager Gwyn Williams.

But Nigeria will not back down and can expect Fifa's support. An Nigerian FA spokesman accused Chelsea of a "sudden change of mind", claiming Babayaro had assured him he would fly out after tomorrow's Champions League tie against Lazio.

"He has special permission to come after Wednesday instead of on Monday and as soon as the game ends we will put him on the next available flight," the spokesman said. "He should be back in London on Sunday.

"We know Chelsea need him but we are trying to get them to appreciate our situation. This will determine whether we go to the Olympics." Babayaro was not involved in the earlier qualifiers. Lazio's defender and captain Alessandro Nesta misses tomorrow's game with a pulled leg muscle.

The Leeds captain Lucas Radebe is considering quitting international football with South Africa. He missed five domestic games to play in the African Nations Cup and said: "I love playing for South Africa but I want to do my best for Leeds because they pay my wages. It's not fair on them that I miss so many matches."

webTitle: Digital evolution points up a player's prowess

fields.headline: Digital evolution points up a player's prowess
fields.trailText: New research posits the most unlikely link between a player's digits and his performance since David James blamed Nintendo addiction for a shambolic goalkeeping display.
fields.body:
Those of us who believed that the only important thing a footballer's fingers were ever likely to indicate was the belief that those barracking him should go forth, be fruitful and multiply, may have to think again. New research posits the most unlikely link between a player's digits and his performance since David James blamed Nintendo addiction for a shambolic goalkeeping display.

A joint (or perhaps that should be knuckle) study at Liverpool University by the School of Biological Sciences and the Football Research Unit suggests a direct correlation between success on the field and the relative sizes of the third and index finger.

Male hormones are the key. Men whose ring fingers are larger than their pointing fingers apparently had more testosterone when they were in the womb than those with the more usually proportioned digits. Testosterone is said by some scientists to be linked not just to strength and cardiovascular fitness but also to spatial awareness. This latter has always been an opinion championed by certain people, usually those graduates of the University of Life who insist that women cannot park cars properly, though there is about as much conclusive proof on the subject as there is that oestrogen levels affect the human ability to concentrate on Meg Ryan movies.

The theory is that the whole football-finger thing may be to do with sexual selection. Why the notoriously quirky Mother Nature should have chosen this strange digital formation to indicate alpha males rather than something more obvious to passing females such as a huge nose or feet the size of flippers is anybody's guess. Though, given the behaviour of top soccer stars of the 1970s, the help it would provide in twisting the wire from a champagne cork while simultaneously unlatching the brassiere of a top actress/model cannot be discounted.

To those of us who are totally inept at sport the notion that success might simply rest on a quirk of biology while we were as yet unborn is, of course, a comforting one. Despite this my knee-jerk reaction to such ideas is, well, to jerk my knee into them. For, as anybody who has ever been bearded by a saloon-bar philosopher will know, the phrase "It's only natural, innit?" tends to lead in only one direction, towards the far right.

It should be stressed that the research has absolutely no racial element. Sadly when it comes to theorising about the part physiology plays in sporting success this is not always true. The idea that a black sportsman's winning performance is based on the width of his hips, the length of his thighbone or whatever has been floated at regular intervals.

Strangely, though, the reverse never seems to happen. This is a pity in many respects. I for one would certainly be delighted if the University of Nairobi produced a report on how the peculiar structure of the British shoulder has stopped us producing a really fast bowler or a brilliant tennis player for so long. Until they do we shall just have to struggle on in the belief that it is all down to some terrible deficiency in our national character.

The other problem with the findings is that they completely ignore the ginger-counter-reactive principle. Red-haired people are often thought of as quick-tempered or prone to violence. Think of John Hartson, Alan Ball, Billy Bremner or any number of mercurial Scottish wingers. My mother has red-hair and she has a theory as to why this might be. "If you'd been called carrot-top since you were three years old, you'd be forever losing your rag," she explains between gritted teeth.

This might be a hypothesis worth testing out by researchers. For many years now I have been puzzled by the unnatural percentage of top sportsmen who combine muscular physical stature with high-pitched voices. Graham Gooch, Tony Adams, Emlyn Hughes, Mike Tyson and Herol Graham spring to mind. Is it not possible that it is not too much testosterone that propels men to the top in sport but too little?

Surely even an elementary knowledge of human psychology would suggest that it is more likely to be those individuals deprived of sufficient male hormones who would be the ones running about kicking one another and overcompensating like mad, while those of us with testosterone coursing around our veins by the tanker load, sit in darkened rooms all day trying to figure out why our modem is not working and repeatedly clicking the send button with our really remarkably long index fingers?

webTitle: Ferguson mission to pour cold water on Spanish passions

fields.headline: Ferguson mission to pour cold water on Spanish passions
fields.trailText: Spanish skies may have wept for Manchester United yesterday but it will be a major surprise should Valencia manage to rain hard enough on United's parade this evening to deny them a place in the Champions League quarter-finals as winners of their second-round group.
fields.body:
Spanish skies may have wept for Manchester United yesterday but it will be a major surprise should Valencia manage to rain hard enough on United's parade this evening to deny them a place in the Champions League quarter-finals as winners of their second-round group.

Having ensured a place in the last eight by playing inspired football to beat Fiorentina 3-1 at Old Trafford last Wednesday, Sir Alex Ferguson's European champions now have only to avoid defeat by three goals or more to retain their lead in Group B and steer clear of the other top teams - Barcelona, Bayern Munich and possibly Chelsea - in Friday's draw.

Under the tournament rules the group winners meet runners-up in the next stage but cannot play opponents from the same group. This means that, assuming all continues to go well for the two English teams, United will meet Porto, Sparta Prague, Lazio, Feyenoord, Real Madrid or Dynamo Kiev for a semi-final place.

First, however, Ferguson's side must address the task of denying Valencia the kind of start which would kindle serious hopes of overtaking United to win the group. The fact that Valencia have only to draw to go through in second place may well curb Spanish passions.

Fiorentina, by beating Marseille, could still finish level with Hector Cuper's team on 10 points but then the results between the two - Valencia winning 2-0 compared to the Italian team's 1-0 - would keep the Spanish side in second place.

"We've got to ensure we don't make mistakes against a team with a good home record," said Ferguson. "Winning the group is important to us. It means avoiding Barcelona and Bayern in the quarter- finals and, if we could meet Chelsea in the final, what a marvellous fillip for English football that would be."

Valencia at the Mestalla stadium are likely to prove a rather tougher prospect than the side which lost feebly 3-0 at Old Trafford in December. Adrian Ilie, their outstanding Romanian striker who missed that game through injury, will be playing up front alongside the Argentine Claudio Lopez with Francisco Farinos and Gerard challenging Roy Keane's attempts to dominate the midfield.

Neither David Beckham, suspended for this game, nor Ryan Giggs, resting a tweaked hamstring, travelled out yesterday. Ferguson intimated that Ole Gunnar Solskjaer or Quinton Fortune would play on the left flank. This could mean Paul Scholes switching to the right of midfield with Nicky Butt recalled in the centre alongside Keane.

Valencia (probable):Canizares; Angloma, Pellegrino, Djukic, Carboni; Angulo, Farinos, Gerard, Kily Gonzalez; C Lopez, Ilie.

Manchester United (probable) : Bosnich; G Neville, Berg, Stam, Irwin; Scholes, Keane, Butt, Solskjaer or Fortune; Cole, Yorke.

fields.headline: The man who sells United
fields.standfirst: While Sir Alex is in charge on the pitch, Peter Draper is the man doing the business
fields.trailText: While Sir Alex is in charge on the pitch, Peter Draper is the man paid to have broader horizons and to ensure United remain top of football's rich list.
fields.body:
Even by Manchester United's standards Peter Draper has had a successful debut season. In just six months the man responsible for selling the world's highest-profile club has seen its value pass £1bn on the stock exchange, helped negotiate a new shirt sponsorship deal worth £30m and watched a 13,800 sq ft superstore emerge beneath the new east stand at Old Trafford.

Tonight he will see the team celebrate qualification for the quarter-finals of the Champions League, a competition that could add as much as 10% to the value of the club should United repeat the success of last season.

But, while Sir Alex Ferguson plans another successful campaign in Europe, Draper, the club's first group marketing director, is paid to have broader horizons. Last week in Singapore a three-storey United megastore and cafe opened, the first step in a march that will see the Manchester United experience franchised globally. (Stores in Indonesia, Brunei and Thailand are planned.)

As a brand, United are unmatched. They are the richest, most successful club in the world, blessed with some of the most bankable talent in football. Most encouraging of all for the man charged with ensuring the club stays on top of the rich list, there is a huge untapped market of United supporters on four continents, countless millions who all want to buy into it.

"We're only just realising how huge this club's support is," Draper says. "In Thailand and China they've been watching games live for years. There were people saying, 'That's my team, Manchester United'. Once they say they're a supporter, there's not a lot you can do about it. We can't stop them saying 'I am one'."

"We did a promotion with Pepsi last year in Thailand," Draper explains. "The dream prize was to come here to Old Trafford to see a game. We had 10 million entries - one in five of the Thai population entered that competition.

"That one stat alone shows how many people are interested in Manchester United. What are we supposed to say, we're not interested in them? I think we are interested in them. It gives us a problem of scale but, on the other hand, scale is an opportunity."

It is an opportunity Draper knows how to exploit. In his previous job as marketing director at Umbro he toured the world with Pele, negotiated kit deals with Brazil, Ajax and United and individual agreements with Alan Shearer and Michael Owen. "After Pele, the glitz and glamour here won't distract me," he says, grinning.

Sitting in Old Trafford's Red Café, a bottle of Man Utd tomato ketchup at his elbow, Draper clearly relishes a job that encompasses sponsorship, merchandising, publishing and broadcast operations as well as a café and a museum. He will also oversee the development of the club's internet presence, the potential of which forced United's shares through the £1bn mark last week. The sight of Arrows formula one cars sporting manutd.com logos this month at the Australian grand prix merely emphasised the value of this arm of the company.

"New media is definitely the future of the business," Draper says. "In the short term it means we can for the first time communicate with all our fans properly, they can log on and we'll tell them what they want to know. Beyond that the possibilities are enormous."

Draper's immediate concern, though, is to turn round a 16% decline in the merchandise sales that normally account for a quarter of the club's revenue. A new home strip, scheduled for next season, and the impending renegotiation of the kit manufacturing deal with Umbro should arrest the slide.

At the same time he must also placate United fans who suspect the club has become more interested in far-flung customers than match-going fans. Andy Walsh, chairman of the Independent Manchester United Supporters Association, summarises local discontent: "Rather than being a company whose sole aim is to support the club, the company now exploit the club for their own purposes," he says.

Draper rejects the criticism: "I can honestly say there isn't anyone here who isn't interested in those 11 men kicking a pig's bladder. The heart and soul of this organisation is football, and our job is to create an environment that allows Sir Alex to build the team in the best possible way."

As for the accusation that the club neglects its local fans, Draper is emphatic: "The bum on the seat is fantastic - they generate the excitement and passion. That's why we're going up to 67,500 capacity."

As well as placating the fans, Draper has to avoid the wrath of Ferguson. Increasing demand for United means increasing demands on the players, a conflict that threatened to boil over on United's pre-season tour of Asia, which Ferguson did not join. As with everything else at Old Trafford, says Draper, the final call remains with the manager.

"We don't make the team go anywhere they don't want to go," he says. "This is a partnership and we just want to improve on the relationship. After they won the World Club Championship in Tokyo I saw Alex and said, 'Thanks for winning that trophy, you've made my job that much easier'. Alex puts the stake in the ground and it's up to the rest of us to try and match his standards."

fields.headline: Cambridge expel striker
fields.trailText: Cambridge United have sacked one player and fined and warned two others for what their manager Roy McFarland called "totally unacceptable behaviour" at the club's sportsman's dinner.
fields.body:
Cambridge United have sacked one player and fined and warned two others for what their manager Roy McFarland called "totally unacceptable behaviour" at the club's sportsman's dinner.

Steve Guinan, the "main culprit" according to McFarland, has been sacked after only six weeks at the club, and for most of that period he has been out of action with a hamstring injury. Scott Eustace and Neil MacKenzie have been fined the maximum two weeks' wages and warned that any more misbehaviour would meet with instant dismissal.

"What made this incident so much worse," McFarland said, "was that it took place on our premises in front of our supporters and sponsors."

An unnamed supporter, quoted in yesterday's Cambridge Evening News, said that a number of players at the dinner last week "were throwing food around and were rowdy when the guest speaker Duncan McKenzie was giving his talk".

Cambridge are fifth from bottom of the Second Division after losing 4-3 at home to Wrexham on Saturday. "What went on had a bad effect on our build-up," McFarland said.

Guinan, 24, has now been released or thrown out of three clubs this season. Nottingham Forest let him go six weeks ago. And the Scunthorpe manager Brian Laws stripped him of his club tracksuit in the Glanford Park car park after he refused to stay on loan at the club.

 Gordon Strachan has agreed a new five-year contract to continue as manager of Coventry City.

fields.headline: Boost for small e-companies
fields.trailText: Axon, an e-commerce company based in Surrey, was yesterday celebrating a potential £1m gain from the Budget after the chancellor promised action to remove a catch-22 problem which has left start-up companies creaking under huge national insurance liabilities.
fields.body:
Axon, an e-commerce company based in Surrey, was yesterday celebrating a potential £1m gain from the Budget after the chancellor promised action to remove a catch-22 problem which has left start-up companies creaking under huge national insurance liabilities.

Until yesterday Axon was facing a £1m bill to pay for employers NI when its staff exercise share options. Last year its NI liability was just £200,000, but as Axons share price has jumped 500% over the past year, the liability in the next tax year would be £1m, making a huge dent in its profits of £4.5m.

The company, which started in 1995 and now employs 200 people, designs B2B solutions for blue chip clients such as Orange and BP Amoco. The issue has hit thousands of small net start-ups which have used share options to incentivise staff and have seen their share prices soar.

Accountants have warned that many are effectively insolvent as a result of having to put aside reserves for future NI payments on options when they are exercised. But the chancellor said yesterday that he will begin an urgent consultation exercise to reduce the NI burden.

Early indications are that employers will be allowed to transfer their NI liability on to employees. An employee exercising an option is likely in future to have to pay not just the marginal tax rate but also their employers NI bill of 11.7%, producing a maximum tax bill of 51.7%.

Axon finance director Robin Halliday said: It sounds like very positive news for employers, but the devil is in the detail. NI has been a huge issue for us; its been like a tax on success. Were excited about what hes promising, but you often find with Budgets that when you look at the fine print, what you originally expected is not there.

But the extra tax burden on staff means that employers are likely to be forced to grant extra options to compensate, warned tax specialist Rose Edmunds of accountants Grant Thornton. Ernst & Young also warned that some companies could still be bankrupted if employees exercise their share schemes before any new rules come into force. The NI problem is going to go through a lingering death. If employees sell their shares tomorrow, some companies are still going to face enormous bills.

fields.headline: Budget 'will encourage internet start-ups'
fields.trailText: E-commerce was one of the first areas the chancellor turned to as he outlined policies to reward enterprise and entrepreneurship.
fields.body:
E-commerce was one of the first areas the chancellor turned to as he outlined policies to reward enterprise and entrepreneurship.

Mr Brown said he wanted to make Britain the best environment in the world for e-commerce, catching up with the US in the shortest possible time.

To encourage one million small companies to go online, Mr Brown announced he would introduce a special tax reduction - so that for the next three years, any small business buying computers, or investing in e-commerce and new information technology, will be able to immediately write off the cost in full against tax.

Alongside this, Mr Brown said the small business service would begin to offer consultancy, advice and planning to help small businesses get online and become e-companies. "We are determined to lead in e-commerce and the internet," he said.

Mr Brown said he was to introduce new rules for work permits in areas of highly-skilled information technology where there is a global shortage. To promote internet use Mr Brown announced a £100 tax cut for electronic filing of tax and VAT returns, and a further £50 tax cut for for those paying the working families tax credit, should they choose to file payment electronically.

His e-commerce measures were immediately denounced for "not going far enough" by Conservative leader William Hague. He accused Mr Brown of being the first man since Denis Healey to create a brain drain as a result of the policies he announced.

The chancellor also declared that any high-tech firms recruiting essential personnel will be able to offer share option incentives of £100,000 for up to 15 employees. Mr Brown unveiled a range of measures which he said would help not only e-companies but all business, including capital gains tax cuts which would average at 25% per company.

fields.headline: £1bn lift for health, schools
fields.standfirst:
Brown plans emergency package in Budget

Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The chancellor will announce an emergency cash injection for schools and hospitals in today's Budget after Tony Blair backed demands from spending ministers for extra investment to reassure sceptical voters that Labour can deliver improvements in key public services.
fields.byline: John Carvel, Mark Atkinson  and Larry Elliott
fields.body:
The chancellor will announce an emergency cash injection for schools and hospitals in today's Budget after Tony Blair backed demands from spending ministers for extra investment to reassure sceptical voters that Labour can deliver improvements in key public services.

With official figures out yesterday showing the Treasury on course for a surplus of around £10bn this year, Downing Street supported calls by David Blunkett, the education secretary, and Alan Milburn, the health secretary, that the package should include extra money for the NHS and education as well as modest tax cuts.

Health will be the biggest beneficiary of the top-up spending following the morale-sapping crisis in the NHS over the winter. With the NHS confederation warning that at least £600m is needed to get the health service through next winter, the government is anxious to avoid damaging headlines in the run-up to an expected spring 2001 general election.

However, schools will also get a surprise top-up worth more than £500m after the prime minister supported Mr Blunkett in an 11th-hour tussle with Gordon Brown.

For the first time, the extra cash will be channelled directly into state school budgets, bypassing local authorities whose leaders have irritated Downing Street by insisting they should be able to divert spending into other services if they see fit. The injection comes on top of the £3.5bn extra for education already promised for the coming financial year.

With negotiations going on between ministers right up until yesterday, the prime minister is understood to have warned the Treasury that it would be politically unwise to release more resources to the hard-pressed health service without providing a substantial uplift to schools. He feared the government would be perceived to be rewarding a service in difficulty at the expense of one that was meeting its manifesto targets.

Mr Brown has been keen to link extra cash to reforms of the public sector, and is also concerned that excessive spending increases would put upward pressure on inflation and prompt the Bank of England to raise interest rates.

However, figures released by the Treasury yesterday showed that spending this year has been lower than planned and tax revenues more buoyant, leaving the chancellor with plenty of scope to loosen fiscal policy without risk of overstimulating the economy. The government had a budget surplus of £1.3bn in February and £17bn in the first 11 months of the current financial year. City economists said that even allowing for the traditional high spending in March, Mr Brown's surplus was likely to be around £10bn for the whole year, compared to a projection of a £4bn surplus at the time of last November's pre-Budget report.

According to calculations for the Guardian, by the US investment bank Goldmans Sachs, Mr Brown could afford to cut taxes and/or increase public spending by up to £4bn in 2000/2001 without putting upward pressure on interest rates or jeopardising the health of the public finances. If he decided to be more generous, he would run the risk of overstimulating the economy.

Goldman Sachs added that if the chancellor limited himself to a £4bn giveaway in 2000/2001, he could afford to inject another £5bn into priority spending areas in 2001/2002 - election year - without prompting an adverse reaction from the Bank of England or breaching his tough rules for borrowing and debt.

The increase for education is likely to include money for failing schools given a fresh start with a new name and new head. The departure last week of three of the first 10 "superheads" in charge of "fresh start" schools raised questions about whether they were getting enough support.

The spending boost will also provide resources for city academies, new schools to be built in the inner cities in partnership with businesses, churches and charities.

However, the bulk of the extra education spending will be paid directly into school accounts. Ministers have been frustrated by the complaints of headteachers who say that much of the money promised for education - described by the government as its "number one priority" programme - is not getting through to schools.

Although the government has previously paid schools for delivering specific initiatives, such as boosting literacy and numeracy, this will be the first time ministers have channelled funds not earmarked directly to mainstream state schools for their normal work.

The decision will alarm local authorities ahead of a review of their funding being conducted by the department for the environment, transport and the regions.

fields.headline: The budget: key points
fields.trailText: The chancellor hit smokers hard to finance extra health spending, but other punitive taxes were minimal. The 1p cut in the basic rate of income tax, announced last November, comes into force in April. Targeted education spending was up and Mr Brown introduced several tax breaks for small businesses, especially e-commerce start-ups. Capital gains tax is to fall sharply and the lower limit for inheritance tax eligibility rose. Poorer families and pensioners benefited from a drive to cut poverty, and working families are now guaranteed an income of £214 a week. Charities will also benefit.
fields.body:
The chancellor hit smokers hard to finance extra health spending, but other punitive taxes were minimal. The 1p cut in the basic rate of income tax, announced last November, comes into force in April. Targeted education spending was up and Mr Brown introduced several tax breaks for small businesses, especially e-commerce start-ups. Capital gains tax is to fall sharply and the lower limit for inheritance tax eligibility rose. Poorer families and pensioners benefited from a drive to cut poverty, and working families are now guaranteed an income of £214 a week. Charities will also benefit.

 The basic tax rate is, as announced in November, cut by 1p to 22p in the pound. Charities will benefit from the announcement that the government is to add an extra 28p for every pound given by a taxpayer to charity. For individuals who contribute via their pay packets, the add-on will be 50p. All companies will shortly be able to receive tax relief on charitable donations.

 NHS spending is to increase by 6.1% in real terms next year to £54.2bn, or £2,800 per household. Ten thousand more nurses will be recruited.

 There were few surprises in education. As widely predicted, the chancellor increased spending by £1bn. In a further drive to improve literacy and numeracy, every primary school is to receive between £3,000 and £9,000 each year to spend on books. Secondary schools will get £30-50,000. Many 16-year-olds will receive a £40 a week incentive to continue studying.

 Fuel duty will rise by 2p per litre - "not a real-term increase" - said the chancellor, and one which took into account the rise in world oil prices. Standard car tax is frozen, while a lower rate for vehicles with engines of less than 1200cc will be introduced. The chancellor is spending £280m on transport.

 The cost of 20 cigarettes will rise by 25p and the extra revenue will, Mr Brown promised, go straight to the NHS. There will be further measures to combat tobacco smuggling.

 There are small rises in alcohol taxes. A pint of beer will cost 1p more, a litre of cider 1p more and a bottle of wine 4p more. Spirits duty is frozen.

 The Individual Savings Account (ISA) ceiling remains at £7,000 - a boost for savers since it had been expected to drop to £5,000.

 Capital gains tax is to be radically reformed. In the first instance it will fall from 40% to 35% and subsequently to 10% after four years. All employee-shareholders will benefit from this cut.

 The threshold for paying inheritance tax rises from £231,000 to £234,000, making 96% of the population exempt.

 The chancellor wants to encourage more competition in UK banking. This means abolishing the withholding tax on the interest paid on international bonds. Initiatives involving the Post Office will make it easier for people to open bank accounts.

 Small and medium-sized businesses will benefit from permanent 40% capital allowances. Thirty per cent of research and development costs will be met by the treasury. A regional innovation fund will be launched to encourage new businesses.

 Mr Brown wants Britain to "catch up with America" on e-commerce as soon as possible. All small businesses will be able to write off tax on computer purchases during the next three years. If companies file tax returns electronically, they will receive a £100 tax cut.

 The New Deal will be extended to include long-term unemployed adults. There will be tighter rules and penalties for the unemployed who "fail to respond" to job-finding initiatives. A new job grant of £100 will be introduced.

 Sure-Start maternity grants will rise from £200 to £300.

 Child benefit for the first child is up to £15.50 a week from April 2001, although there is a maximum of £50 per family. Mr Brown described this as the "greatest reduction in child poverty in 50 years" and said it would lift one million children out of poverty.

 The Working Families Tax Credit will increase by 7% to guarantee a minimum income of £214 a week.

 IT workers, who are in short supply in Europe, will find it easier to obtain work permits.

 Tickets for charitable events will be exempt from VAT, and there will be tax relief on donations to charity and gifts of shares.

 "Thrifty" pensioners with an occupational pension will be an average of £250 better off each year. Some will receive up to £1,000 more. The chancellor announced a consultation on a new kind of pensioners' benefit and the television licence fee will be waived for every pensioner over 75.

 The cut-off point for savings that prevent people from claiming income support is raised to £12,000.

 The VAT on tampons and other sanitary products falls from 17.5% to 5%.

webTitle: Budget calculated to boost flagging Labour support

fields.headline: Budget calculated to boost flagging Labour support
fields.standfirst: Chancellor Gordon Brown unveils a string of measures targeted to appeal to Labour's traditional supporters without alienating middle England
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown today attempted to boost flagging support in Labour's traditional heartlands when he announced significant cash injections for health and education.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown today attempted to boost flagging support in Labour's traditional heartlands when he announced significant cash injections for health and education.

Delivering his fourth budget statement Mr Brown said an extra £2bn was to be spent on education and £1bn on schools. As part of a total £4bn additional investment in public services, there was also an extra £285m to tackle crime, he said.

Mr Brown confirmed last year's announcement that the basic rate of income tax would be cut by a penny, to 22p in the pound, and unveiled a package of measures designed to appeal to pensioners, including increasing the winter fuel allowance by £50 to £150.

As widely predicted, duty on a packet of cigarettes was increased by 25 pence but, in an unusual move, he pledged that all the extra money raised would go to the NHS. Beer is to go up a penny a pint, wine by four pence a bottle and spirits duty is to be frozen. He also announced new measures to tackle tobacco smuggling, which was costing the economy millions of pounds.

Mr Brown attempted to take some heat out of the housing market in the south east when he increased stamp duty to 3% for properties worth £250,000-plus and 4% on those with a price tag over £500,000. Southern house price inflation was a principal factor, which prompted the Bank of England to raise interest rates.

On the voluntary sector, Mr Brown said that for every £1 donated to charity the government would add 28p, and up to 50p for every £1 given through the pay packet. He also abolished VAT on charity events and introduced a new tax relief on corporate giving.

On unemployment, Mr Brown announced that the new deal was to be extended to the long-term adult unemployed from 2001, with four options: work, work-based training, work experience - including in the voluntary sector - and self-employment. But there would be "no fifth option, no staying at home on benefits doing nothing," he said.

He also announced new job grants for long-term unemployed, starting at £100, plus help with rent and mortgages. The long-term unemployed over 50 are to get a guaranteed minimum income of £60 a week.

He pledged tougher penalties for fraudulent social security claims from January 1, 2001, along with a confidential benefit fraud phone line to start in May.

Drivers were given a boost with the announcement that car tax was being frozen with lower tax for cars up to 1200cc.Vehicle excise duty for lorries was to be cut between £500 and £1,800.

The chancellor said that Britain was moving from a time where enterprise was a "closed circle for the few" to a country where enterprise will be open to all.

He told the Commons that he wanted to remove the old barriers of under-investment and neglect which had held the regions back for too long. Working with the new Regional Development Agencies and the Small Business Service, he said that the government wanted to create a balanced economic development across the nation.

Mr Brown announced that a partnership with the European Investment Bank and the private sector would be launched to finance a network of regional venture capital investment funds. He explained that the regional targets would be: £85 million for south west England; £120 million for north west England; £130 million for the north east and Yorkshire; £250 million for the Midlands and the east; and £250 million for London and the south east. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will have their own funds.

He also announced that in order to promote a modern regional policy the secretary of state for industry would be announcing a regional innovation fund to encourage local clusters in hi-tech industries. He pledged to encourage greater civic patriotism with a range of measures to reward charity giving.

The chancellor announced a new review of institutional investment, which will report in time for the next Budget. He declared: "By delivering employment opportunity for all we are making Britain both more enterprising and more fair, to the benefits not just of the high unemployment areas but the whole country."

Mr Brown also unveiled a string of measures to boost entrepreneurship and shareholding in what he called the "new economy".

In an upbeat speech, he pointed to healthy growth, continued low inflation, lower long-term interest rates and a 10% rise in living standards since he became chancellor in 1997.

He told MPs that prudent management of the economy had delivered reduced debt interest payments - down by £4 billion a year - lower unemployment, reduced social security spending - down by £3 billion - and a current surplus for this year; forecast to be £17 billion.

Mr Brown said: "This Budget is built on the realities of this new economy - that we will meet and master a new tide of unprecedented technological change by continuing to remove the old barriers to business investment and by continuing to expand employment opportunity for hard-working families."

Mr Brown outlined a healthy economy and said inflation was on target at 2.2%, reaffirming targets for the next three years at 2.5%. Unemployment, the chancellor said, was at its lowest level for 20 years.

He said the Budget was in surplus by £12bn - a larger figure than many experts had predicted - and he estimated a Budget surplus of £14bn by 2001.

The chancellor announced radical reforms of capital gains tax to help promote entrepreneurship. He said that within four years, company capital gains tax would be cut to 35% after one year, 30% after two years, 20% after three years and that it would be down to 10% in four years.

All barriers to a shareholding democracy would be removed, he said, announcing the biggest boost to shareholding the country has ever seen. Mr Brown announced £150 million for new research and development tax credit and tax reductions for small businesses investing in technology.

He pledged tougher penalties for fraudulent social security claims from January 1, 2001, along with a confidential benefit fraud phone line to start in May. Drivers were given a boost with the announcement that car tax was being frozen with lower tax for cars up to 1200cc.Vehicle excise duty for lorries was to be cut between £500 and £1,800. The chancellor said that Britain was moving from a time where enterprise was a "closed circle for the few" to a country where enterprise will be open to all. He told the Commons that he wanted to remove the old barriers of under-investment and neglect which had held the regions back for too long. Working with the new Regional Development Agencies and the Small Business Service, he said that the government wanted to create a balanced economic development across the nation. Mr Brown announced that a partnership with the European Investment Bank and the private sector would be launched to finance a network of regional venture capital investment funds. He explained that the regional targets would be: £85 million for south west England; £120 million for north west England; £130 million for the north east and Yorkshire; £250 million for the Midlands and the east; and £250 million for London and the south east. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will have their own funds. He also announced that in order to promote a modern regional policy the secretary of state for industry would be announcing a regional innovation fund to encourage local clusters in hi-tech industries. He pledged to encourage greater civic patriotism with a range of measures to reward charity giving. The chancellor announced a new review of institutional investment, which will report in time for the next Budget. He declared: "By delivering employment opportunity for all we are making Britain both more enterprising and more fair, to the benefits not just of the high unemployment areas but the whole country." Mr Brown also unveiled a string of measures to boost entrepreneurship and shareholding in what he called the "new economy". In an upbeat speech, he pointed to healthy growth, continued low inflation, lower long-term interest rates and a 10% rise in living standards since he became chancellor in 1997. He told MPs that prudent management of the economy had delivered reduced debt interest payments - down by £4 billion a year - lower unemployment, reduced social security spending - down by £3 billion - and a current surplus for this year; forecast to be £17 billion. Mr Brown said: "This Budget is built on the realities of this new economy - that we will meet and master a new tide of unprecedented technological change by continuing to remove the old barriers to business investment and by continuing to expand employment opportunity for hard-working families." Mr Brown outlined a healthy economy and said inflation was on target at 2.2%, reaffirming targets for the next three years at 2.5%. Unemployment, the chancellor said, was at its lowest level for 20 years. He said the Budget was in surplus by £12bn - a larger figure than many experts had predicted - and he estimated a Budget surplus of £14bn by 2001. The chancellor announced radical reforms of capital gains tax to help promote entrepreneurship. He said that within four years, company capital gains tax would be cut to 35% after one year, 30% after two years, 20% after three years and that it would be down to 10% in four years. All barriers to a shareholding democracy would be removed, he said, announcing the biggest boost to shareholding the country has ever seen. Mr Brown announced £150 million for new research and development tax credit and tax reductions for small businesses investing in technology.

fields.trailText:
"The chancellor is like a mugger who grabs your money, then wants you to thank him for giving you the bus fare to get home."
Tory party leader William Hague
fields.body:
"The chancellor is like a mugger who grabs your money, then wants you to thank him for giving you the bus fare to get home."
Tory party leader William Hague

"You stood up to address the House as a tax-raising chancellor and you sat down as a tax-raising chancellor. You sat down as the stealth chancellor who taxes more and delivers less."
William Hague

"It's spending for a second term."
Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy

"Once again the chancellor has missed the opportunity to tackle excessive tobacco taxes. We are extremely disappointed, but not surprised, that the chancellor has put up tobacco taxes in real terms. This will only serve to further encourage the cigarette smugglers."

"The chancellor is a step nearer to winning the war against child poverty, but much more remains to be done."
The Child Poverty Action Group

"It's what you expect from a traditional Labour chancellor in good times."
Andrew Dilnot, Institute for Fiscal Studies

"They're very pleased at the very prudent policies."
Marian Bell, economist with Royal Bank of Scotland, on City reaction

fields.headline: The Budget speech - part one
fields.trailText: A year ago the Government forecast the British economy would grow at 1-1.5 per cent.
fields.body:
A year ago the Government forecast the British economy would grow at 1-1.5 per cent.

Today, I can report that in 1999, instead of the recession that many forecast, the British economy grew by 2 per cent.

And Britain has been growing steadily while meeting our inflation target.

Today inflation is 2.2 per cent.

For the third year running inflation is in line with our target. And the target of 2.5 per cent - which I reaffirm - will be met this year, next year and the year after that.

Because of the action we took in 1997 to stop inflation getting out of control, inflation in Britain has now been lower for longer than at any time since the 1960s.

For almost thirty years, Britain's long term interest rates were, on average, 3 per cent higher than Germany's. Now British long term rates are down to the levels in Germany and today lower than in the USA.

Amid the risks of an uncertain and often unstable global economy, we are determined to maintain our disciplined approach: determined not to make the old British mistakes of paying ourselves too much today at the cost of higher interest rates and fewer jobs tomorrow, determined not to make the old mistake of putting consumption before investment, the short term before the long term. Britain does not want a return to boom and bust.

That is why the Bank of England has been right to take pre-emptive action on interest rates and to be vigilant on wage inflation.

It is because the foundations on which we build are strong that the economy can meet our inflation target and achieve steady growth.

Our forecast is that growth this year will rise to 2.75-3.25 per cent, and next year and the year after it is forecast to be 2.25 to 2.75 per cent - in line with our view of trend growth.

Manufacturing is growing by 1.75 to 2.25 per cent this year and next.

And business investment grew by 7.7 per cent last year to 14.5 per cent of national income, with Britain since 1998 for the first time investing more of our national income than our major European competitors, and more than America.

This Budget is built on the realities of this new economy - that we will meet and master a new tide of unprecedented technological change by continuing to remove the old barriers to business investment and by continuing to expand employment opportunity for hard working families.

I can report that unemployment today is at its lowest for 20 years, that there are 800,000 more people in work since 1997 and that there are one million vacancies on offer. Take-home pay is rising - by next year, for the typical family, a real terms rise in living standards of 10 per cent since 1997.

Britain's economic success depends not only on monetary stability but on fiscal stability.

Today, I can report that because of tough decisions to cut the deficit in our first two years and lower long term interest rates, debt interest payments will be four billion pounds a year lower.

Because of the Welfare to Work reforms that have cut unemployment, social security spending on economic failure this year is a total of 3 billions less than the plans we inherited.

Today, Mr Deputy Speaker, the state of the public finances is sound. In 1997 we inherited a current deficit exceeding 20 billion pounds. A year ago I estimated that this year's current surplus would be 2.5 billion pounds. I can report that we have not only balanced the current Budget but our current surplus this year is forecast to be 17 billion pounds.

We have met and we will continue to meet, even on the most cautious of cases, our first rule of fiscal prudence, the golden rule. And we are also meeting our second rule, the sustainable investment rule.

This year debt as a share of national income will fall well below the 44 per cent we inherited - to 37.1 per cent. Last year we forecast that the overall budget would be in deficit for this financial year - that public sector net borrowing would be 3 billion pounds.

I can now report that due to the performance of the economy and to prudent management, the Budget is not in deficit by 3 billion but in surplus by 12 billion pounds.

Mr Deputy Speaker, we inherited a deficit of 28 billion pounds in 1997. This year we will make a debt repayment of 12 billion pounds. Too often in the past, at the first sign of a cyclical surplus, governments have fallen back into imprudent ways.

It is because we have learned from the mistakes of the last forty years that this Government will maintain its prudent and responsible approach. The figures I am announcing today show that we will meet our fiscal rules over the cycle. We will meet our fiscal rules even in the most cautious case, on the most cautious assumptions, including the most cautious view of trend growth at 2.25 per cent.

And Mr Deputy Speaker, I can announce today that I have decided to lock in a greater fiscal tightening next year and the year after than we promised in last year's Budget and Pre-Budget Report.

After the measures I announce today our projection is for a current surplus next year of 14 billion pounds and for the years after, surpluses of plus 16, plus 13, plus 8 and plus 8. Debt to GDP, which was 44 per cent in 1997, will fall to 35 next year, then 34, and then 33 in each of the next three years.

Net borrowing will be minus 6.5 billions next year, that is, we will make a debt repayment next year of 6.5 billion pounds.

Then net borrowing in 2001-2 will be minus 5, a debt repayment of 5 billion pounds, with net borrowing for the years after 2002-3 of plus 3, plus 11, plus 13, well within our fiscal rules. So from this stable platform of sound finances I am able to set out today our prudent and responsible approach for future years. Having met all of our fiscal rules, paid off 18 billions of debt this year and next, and locked in a greater fiscal tightening, we are able both to set a new envelope for public spending and investment for the years from 2001 and to cut taxes for hard working families.

I can report that our fiscal rules enable us to increase current public spending by 2.5 per cent a year in real terms for the 3 years from 2001 and double net public investment as a share of national income from 0.9 per cent next year to 1.8 per cent in 2004.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have always said that our prudence is for a purpose.

And in this Budget, because of our continuing prudence, we can now take the next steps towards that purpose - a Britain of opportunity and security not just for a few but for all:

- with stability locked in, and enterprise growing, we can meet our prosperity goal - closing the productivity gap;

- with 800,000 more in jobs and the work ethic being restored, our full employment goal - employment opportunity for all;

- with 50,000 more students and standards rising, our education goal - 50 per cent of young people in higher education;

- with 800,000 children already lifted out of poverty and our civic society renewing itself, we can meet our anti-poverty goal - to halve child poverty by 2010 and end it by 2020.

First, I announce major reforms today to reward enterprise and entrepreneurship; open up competition in banking; promote new and growing businesses and e-commerce - and balanced growth across all the regions and nations of the United Kingdom.

To remove more of the old barriers to new investment, I have decided on radical reforms of capital gains tax - beyond the tax cuts I set out in the Pre-Budget Report.

When we came into Government capital gains tax was fixed at 40 per cent and we cut the long term rate of capital gains tax for business assets held for ten years or more. I have now decided to radically cut rates.

I am announcing that from 6th April this year the new capital gains rates for business assets will be cut from 40 per cent to 35 per cent after one year, to 30 per cent after two years, to 20 per cent after three years, and down to 10 per cent after four years.

I will make further tax cuts to remove the barriers that hold small and growing businesses back. Today business investors who own between 5 per cent and 25 per cent of a new and growing business do not benefit from the 10p rate.

I will now cut their rate to 10 per cent for all investments above 5 per cent held for four or more years. I will make a further radical change - this time for Britain's unquoted companies. All investments held for four years will benefit from the 10 per cent rate.

With both the lowest corporate tax rates for businesses ever and the lowest ever capital gains tax rates for long term investors, Britain is now the place for companies to start, to invest, to grow and to expand.

I have a decision about one other tax on capital - inheritance tax.

The threshold for inheritance tax is 231,000 pounds. I will next year raise it to 234,000 pounds. 96 per cent of people will be exempt from inheritance tax.

I have one further cut in capital gains tax to be introduced from 6th April.

So that millions more hard working people have a stake in the businesses whose wealth they create, we will remove the old barriers to a new share owning democracy.

The all employee shareholding scheme which starts on 6th April has one defining requirement: that shareholding should be open to all employees.

I can confirm that the 1.7 million people now in the 'Save As You Earn' scheme will continue to enjoy its benefits.

I have also decided that high tech firms recruiting essential personnel will be able to offer share option incentives of 100,000 pounds for up to 15 employees.

And the Financial Secretary will now consult on a technical solution to the tax treatment of share options in unapproved schemes.

I can go further. In future all employee shareholders will secure all the benefits of the 10 per cent capital gains tax rate.

Taken together, our measures are the biggest boost for employee shareholding our country has seen.

The next step on our road to a wealth-owning democracy.

fields.headline: The Budget speech - part two
fields.trailText: Yesterday in response to the Cruickshank Report, my Rt Hon Friend the Secretary for Trade and I referred small  business banking to the Competition Commission.
fields.body:
Yesterday in response to the Cruickshank Report, my Rt Hon Friend the Secretary for Trade and I referred small business banking to the Competition Commission.

Mr Cruickshank estimates that competition can reduce banking costs and charges by up to 10 per cent or 3 - 5 billion pounds a year.

The money transmission system affects every cheque, every credit card and every debit transaction and reaches from every local cash dispenser to every corporate inter-bank transfer. Today I am announcing that we will legislate to ensure the UK payments system is open to new competition.

The international competitiveness of the bond market in the City of London depends upon a level playing field. That is why today I am announcing the abolition from April 2001 of the withholding tax on the interest paid on international bonds. We will legislate so we can proceed on the basis of exchange of information nationally and internationally. This change should be widely welcomed in all parts of the house. There is no clearer indication of our determination to stand up for what is right for Britain.

Since 1997 the number of small businesses in Britain has risen from 1.2 million to 1.3 million - a 100,000 increase.

Today I continue to remove the old barriers to small business growth.

Having already cut small business corporation tax from 23 per cent to 20 per cent and, for the first 10,000 pounds of their profits, to just 10 per cent, I am today making a further tax reduction. For all small and medium sized businesses the 40 per cent capital allowances - which I introduced in my 1997 Budget - will be made permanent.

This will be of special help to manufacturing companies. Half manufacturing employment is in small and medium sized firms. So manufacturing will derive further benefit from the 150 million pounds I am allocating to our new research and development tax credit, introduced on 6th April, to finance 30 per cent of their R and D costs.

I want to make Britain the best environment for e-commerce and catch up with America as swiftly as possible. To encourage one million small companies to go on line, I will introduce a special tax reduction. For the next three years any small business buying computers, or investing in e commerce and new information technology, will be able to immediately write off against tax the full 100 per cent of the cost in the year of purchase.

Side by side with this incentive, the small business service will offer consultancy, advice and planning to help small businesses get on line and become e-companies, and with the additional resources the Secretary for Employment is providing the University for Industry, which starts this Autumn, will offer small business employees training on the Internet

We are determined to lead in e-commerce and the Internet. Today we are introducing new rules for work permits in areas of highly skilled information technology where there is a global shortage.

And to promote the use of the Internet we will legislate for other tax cuts - a 100 pounds tax cut for electronic filing of tax and VAT returns, and a further 50 pounds tax cut for electronic filing for those paying the working families tax credit.

Tax cuts since 1997 are worth one billion pounds a year for small businesses alone.

After today's measures, Britain now has the lowest small business corporation taxes we have ever had, the lowest in the industrialised world: since 1997, for small companies an average tax cut of almost 25 per cent.

And to encourage the next generation of entrepreneurs, we are forming a partnership with the CBI, the Institute of Directors and the Chambers of Commerce to encourage enterprise in all communities. Two new enterprise funds will target business loans and management scholarships to high unemployment areas.

Stage by stage we are moving from the Britain where enterprise was a closed circle for the few, to a Britain where enterprise will be open to all.

We must also remove the old barriers of under-investment and neglect that for too long have held our regions back. Working with the new Regional Development Agencies and the Small Business Service, our aim is balanced economic development across all the regions and nations of the United Kingdom - a modern regional policy supporting local innovation, more investment and improved infrastructure.

To finance a network of regional venture capital investment funds, we are today announcing a partnership with the European Investment Bank and the private sector - with a target of one billion pounds for new economic development for our regions and nations.

The regional targets will be 85 million for the South West, 120 million for the North West, 130 million for the North East and Yorkshire, 250 million for the Midlands and East, 250 million for London and the South East. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will have their own funds.

To further promote a modern regional policy, the Secretary for Industry will be announcing a regional innovation fund to facilitate the formation of local clusters in hi tech industries.

For years Britain, as a whole, has lagged behind America in business access to venture capital investment. Here only half as much is invested per head.

I am grateful to Mr Paul Myners, who has agreed to head a review of institutional investment, to report to me in time for the next Budget.

Our goal for the whole of the United Kingdom is to remove the old barriers to full employment. We know that greater opportunity for all means greater prosperity for all. Since 1997 the number of unemployed on benefits has fallen by 30 per cent.

Youth unemployment is down 70 per cent and nearly 200,000 more young people have now found jobs. Long term youth unemployment, which in the mid-eighties was at 500,000 and even in 1997 was as high as 200,000, is already down to 50,000.

The New Deal demonstrates how false was the old choice between enterprise and fairness, between efficiency and equality. By delivering employment opportunity for all, we are making Britain both more enterprising and more fair, to the benefit not just of the high unemployment areas but the whole country.

And because we have succeeded in this Parliament in removing the old barriers to employing the young, I can announce that starting from April next year we will extend the opportunities and the obligations of the New Deal to the long term adult unemployed - with four options of: work, work-based training, work experience including in the voluntary sector, self-employment. But no fifth option, no staying at home on benefit doing nothing.

The relationship we are forging between rights and responsibilities is firmly rooted in both economic opportunity and individual responsibility.

Instead of being left to draw benefit at a social security office, the unemployed who are able to work will sign up to seek work, with the long term unemployed offered the help of a personal employment adviser.

To ease the transition back to work, the Government will introduce a new job grant for long term unemployed starting at 100 pounds and help with rent or mortgage.

Instead of benefits paying more than work, work will now pay. And I can announce that we will extend the principle of the working families tax credit.

As a first stage, from 1st April, all long term unemployed over 50 who want to return to work will be guaranteed a minimum income for their first year back - for wages up to 15,000 pounds a year, an extra payment of 60 pounds a week.

And building on the forthcoming rise in the national minimum wage, I am today increasing the working families tax credit. It is already being paid to one million families in our country. And with today's family tax cut, the minimum family income will rise next April - from 200 pounds a week by 7 per cent to 214 pounds a week.

Full employment is not just about the right to work, but, where there are jobs, the responsibility and the requirement to work.

We will implement the Report of Lord Grabiner QC.

Starting in May, a confidential phone line will advise claimants on how to move from the hidden economy and end fraudulent benefit or tax claims; how to get work, register as a business, or become self employed. After six months, from 1 January, for those who fail to respond, tougher rules and penalties will be imposed.

From October, in the 20 highest unemployment areas of Britain covering 127,000 unemployed, local special action teams will be set up to help local unemployed people into nearby vacancies.

The number of lone parents on income support has fallen by almost 100,000 since 1997. But the employment rate among lone parents in Britain is still only 45 per cent, far below the 70-80 per cent rates of America, France and Scandinavia.

In this Budget we remove old barriers to work and I can today announce an extension of the New Deal in a new way to half a million lone parents.

Piloted from this Autumn, and starting nationally from next April, lone parents with children over five will be invited to work-focussed interviews - and encouraged to take up new choices:

- the choice to train for work with a new cash payment of 15 pounds a week on top of benefits;

- the choice of a few hours work a week, with the first 20 pounds of earnings allowed with no reduction in benefit;

- the choice of part time work with a guaranteed 155 pounds for 16 hours or the choice of full time work on a guaranteed 214 pounds a week;

- and on every rung of this ladder of opportunity, help with back-to-work costs and with child care.

Just as we remove old barriers to lone parents working when their children go to school, so too we will help mothers who want to be at home in the first months of their child's life.
