Today I am announcing that we will legislate to ensure the UK payments system is open to new competition. The international competitiveness of the bond market in the City of London depends upon a level playing field. That is why today I am announcing the abolition from April 2001 of the withholding tax on the interest paid on international bonds. We will legislate so we can proceed on the basis of exchange of information nationally and internationally. This change should be widely welcomed in all parts of the house. fields.headline: The Budget speech - part three
fields.trailText: A strong civic society is built not by rights alone but by rights and responsibilities and by the shared pursuit of the common good - which every year enlists the energies and realises the idealism of more than 22 million British citizens.
fields.body:
A strong civic society is built not by rights alone but by rights and responsibilities and by the shared pursuit of the common good - which every year enlists the energies and realises the idealism of more than 22 million British citizens.

It is time for Government to do more to encourage and extend this civic patriotism.

All voluntary organisations and charities will benefit from the tax reforms I am announcing to make it easier to give money and time. From 6th April this year for every pound any taxpayer gives to charity, the Government will add an extra 28 pence. And to encourage payroll giving, for every pound contributed through the pay packet, the Government will add up to 50 pence worth of tax relief.

Tax relief will be available not just for cash donations, but for gifts of shares.

To encourage corporate giving, any company can, from 1st April, receive tax relief on the full amount of any donation.

Within prescribed limits, I will go further in exempting ticket sales for charitable fund raising events from VAT, so that the contributions people make will go straight to the charities they support.

Each of these measures will also help those charities and non-governmental organisations who, with the churches, have, for decades, led the crusade to combat Third World poverty and secure debt relief.

With these reforms, this Government matches their commitment because it shares their cause - a virtuous circle of debt reduction, poverty relief and economic development for the poorest countries.

A strong civic society takes seriously its obligations to our elderly:

- to the very poor pensioners whom we must help out of poverty;

- to those just above benefit levels whose lifetime savings should not, as in the past, be a barrier to securing a better retirement income;

- to those who, while better off, are on fixed incomes.

The Secretary for Social Security is to launch a consultation on how, for the next Parliament, we can develop a new pensioners credit - designed not only to lift the poorest out of poverty, but also to do more for those with modest occupational pensions and savings who should not be penalised for having worked hard all their lives and saved for their retirement.

Under the framework on which we will consult, an older pensioner with income, for example, of less than 100 pounds a week, or a couple with less than 150 pounds a week, would qualify for a pension credit to raise their income.

As we consult on this reform, we are making immediate changes.

The pensioners tax allowance will be set this year at 5,790 pounds and for those over 75 at 6,050 pounds. Nearly 6 million pensioners will not pay any income tax at all.

And with the new 10p rate on savings, 1.5 million pensioners will, for the first time, pay tax at half the rate of the past, at 10p not 20p.

And I have decided to do more today for elderly citizens with modest savings whose very thrift has perversely and unfairly debarred them from receiving the income they need.

For years any pensioner with savings over 3,000 pounds has lost out on income support. The last Government froze the limit at 3,000 pounds in 1988. I have decided from next April to double the limit - raising it from 3,000 pounds to 6,000 pounds.

The cut off point for income support was frozen at 8,000 pounds of savings in 1990. We will raise that to 12,000 pounds.

As a result, 500,000 elderly people - previously penalised for their thrift and savings - will be on average 250 pounds a year better off, many better off by 1,000 pounds a year.

Fuel poverty scarred our country for too long. That is why in our first Budget we cut VAT on fuel; why in our second the winter allowance was introduced at 20 pounds and then in our third Budget raised to 100 pounds, available to all 8.5 million households with a resident over 60. Under this Government the winter allowance will be paid this year and paid every year.

I have considered whether to raise the allowance in line with inflation, which would put it up to 103 pounds, or in line with earnings, which would raise it to 104 pounds fifty.

But I have decided in this Budget not to raise it by 4 or even 5 pounds but to raise it by 50 pounds to 150 pounds. This winter allowance, at 150 pounds, will now cover up to four winter months of a hard pressed pensioner's fuel bill.

I can further announce that 600,000 of our elderly will benefit from the new 'affordable warmth' programme to install fuel efficient central heating in one million homes throughout Britain.

Beginning on 1st November all pensioners over 75 will receive the free TV licence, worth 104 pounds. And I can announce today that any pensioner over 75 who has an unexpired licence which runs beyond 1st November will also be eligible for a refund for every unexpired month.

Of all the measures to lift our poorest pensioners out of poverty, the minimum income guarantee is the most essential. We will raise the minimum income guarantee in line with earnings next year.

For a single pensioner it will be worth 82 pounds a week, and for pensioners over the age of 80 it will be 90 pounds a week. For a couple it will be 127 pounds a week and for over-80s, 137 pounds a week. Taking these measures together - the winter allowance, the TV licence and the higher minimum guarantee - by

April next year 1 million pensioners will be, compared with 1997, 20 pounds a week, or 1,000 pounds a year, better off.

As we look to the future, I want all to be able to achieve the security of a wealth-owning democracy, with prosperity reaching the people and places the economy has too long forgotten.

So we want to do more to help people start a bank account and start saving, more to help people invest in their pension, more to help people get on to the first rung of the savings ladder and make provision for their future.

Today in Britain up to 3.5 million adults have no bank account. The Cruickshank Report has revealed that a basic affordable bank account for everyone would be profitable for the banks and that using banking facilities - and not the cash economy - just to pay gas and electricity bills could save families 50 pounds a year, or one pound a week.

I am now inviting the banks to work with the Post Office to offer this basic banking service to all. And I want working families to be able to move seamlessly from starting an account to starting to save. I have already announced measures to reward pensioner savings.

This year 6.5 million individual savings accounts have already been started. For the coming year, the ceiling was announced at 5,000 pounds of savings. Instead, for one more year I will keep the ceiling at 7,000 pounds.

I said last November that I would, in future, make an annual Budget decision on real term rises in road fuel duties - the money to go to a new ring-fenced fund for roads and public transport. Since the Pre-Budget Report world oil prices have risen rapidly from 23 dollars to 30 dollars a barrel. So, in this Budget I have decided that, beyond the automatic inflation rise of two pence a litre, there will be no real terms increase in road fuel duties.

And to encourage the use of ultra-low sulphur petrol, I will set fuel duty at 1p per litre below other petrol from 1st October. An extension to the new lower rate vehicle excise duty comes in on 1st March next year. Until that date I have decided - for all cars - to freeze vehicle excise duty. At present the lower rate - at 55 pounds below the standard rate - is available for 1.5 million cars.

From next year I will extend the reduced rate of vehicle excise duty to cars at 1200 ccs or below. This will cut vehicle excise duty to 105 pounds for 2.2 million additional cars, the reduced rate will now cover almost 4 million cars.

I am also introducing from 1st March next year, for newly purchased cars, a four band vehicle excise duty rewarding the most environmentally friendly vehicles.

Under the rates I am publishing today, 95 per cent of new cars will pay less than they would under the current system, half of them at least 30 pounds less.

We will also cut the vehicle excise duty for forty thousand 38 tonne and 41 tonne lorries by 500 pounds; the 40 tonne class lorries will have their rate cut by 1,800 pounds; for all other heavy lorries rates will be frozen.

The environmental impact of these tax cuts - taken together with the revenue neutral proposals for company cars - will be a reduction in carbon emissions of one million tonnes by 2010. This is on top of the 5 million tonnes reduction in carbon emissions by 2010 as a result of the climate change levy which is also revenue neutral and on which the Financial Secretary is publishing further details today.

To further cut pollution we will legislate the aggregates levy, which will again be made revenue neutral through a further 0.1 per cent cut in employers' national insurance.

These two measures will together cut employers' national insurance contributions by 1.35 billion pounds.

There is also a strong environmental case for reducing stamp duty for development of brown-field sites, as recommended by the Rogers Report. The Paymaster General will now consult in detail on the measure.

For the property market, in addition to the previously announced withdrawal of mortgage interest tax relief, stamp duty on property sales will be raised for sales above 250,000 to 3 per cent and for sales above 500,000 to 4 per cent. But for properties below 250,000 I propose no change. And I also propose to freeze insurance tax.

Last year I froze duties on all spirits.

This year an inflation rise would push the price of whisky up by 22 pence a bottle. Because of the competitive position of the industry I will this year continue to freeze duty on all spirits. Beer will rise only by inflation - by 1 pence a pint- and wine only by inflation, by 4 pence a bottle.

Now that the return-leg exemption for air fares has been found in breach of Single Market law, I am taking the opportunity to introduce a new, fairer and lower air passenger duty - at an overall cost to the Exchequer of 80 million pounds a year. The tax on economy flights within the UK will be the same or lower. For economy flights outside Europe the rate will remain at 20 pounds and there will be a new business class rate of 40 pounds.

30 million economy passengers travelling to Europe will have air passenger duty cut in half - from 10 pounds to 5 pounds. And on flights from the Scottish Highlands and islands I will abolish air passenger duty altogether.

On tobacco, the Paymaster General will tomorrow announce tough new measures to tackle smuggling. Cigarette taxes will rise by 5 per cent above inflation from tonight - by 25 pence a packet - with every penny of the extra revenue going - as I promised - to funding our hospitals and the National Health Service.

And I am also commissioning a long term assessment of technological, demographic and medical trends over the next two decades that will affect the Health Service, to report to the Treasury in time for the start of the next spending review in 2002.

I have a number of other fiscal decisions to make.

Debt interest payments are down by 4 billion pounds a year. And because we have not spent and we will not spend more at the expense of being prudent, we have also made the tough decisions to tackle benefit fraud, to move people from welfare to work, and to control the social security budget.

I am also introducing from 1st March next year, for newly purchased cars, a four band vehicle excise duty rewarding the most environmentally friendly vehicles. Under the rates I am publishing today, 95 per cent of new cars will pay less than they would under the current system, half of them at least 30 pounds less. We will also cut the vehicle excise duty for forty thousand 38 tonne and 41 tonne lorries by 500 pounds; the 40 tonne class lorries will have their rate cut by 1,800 pounds; for all other heavy lorries rates will be frozen. The environmental impact of these tax cuts - taken together with the revenue neutral proposals for company cars - will be a reduction in carbon emissions of one million tonnes by 2010. This is on top of the 5 million tonnes reduction in carbon emissions by 2010 as a result of the climate change levy which is also revenue neutral and on which the Financial Secretary is publishing further details today. To further cut pollution we will legislate the aggregates levy, which will again be made revenue neutral through a further 0.1 per cent cut in employers' national insurance. These two measures will together cut employers' national insurance contributions by 1.35 billion pounds. There is also a strong environmental case for reducing stamp duty for development of brown-field sites, as recommended by the Rogers Report. The Paymaster General will now consult in detail on the measure. For the property market, in addition to the previously announced withdrawal of mortgage interest tax relief, stamp duty on property sales will be raised for sales above 250,000 to 3 per cent and for sales above 500,000 to 4 per cent. But for properties below 250,000 I propose no change. And I also propose to freeze insurance tax. Last year I froze duties on all spirits. This year an inflation rise would push the price of whisky up by 22 pence a bottle. Because of the competitive position of the industry I will this year continue to freeze duty on all spirits. Beer will rise only by inflation - by 1 pence a pint- and wine only by inflation, by 4 pence a bottle. Now that the return-leg exemption for air fares has been found in breach of Single Market law, I am taking the opportunity to introduce a new, fairer and lower air passenger duty - at an overall cost to the Exchequer of 80 million pounds a year. The tax on economy flights within the UK will be the same or lower. For economy flights outside Europe the rate will remain at 20 pounds and there will be a new business class rate of 40 pounds. 30 million economy passengers travelling to Europe will have air passenger duty cut in half - from 10 pounds to 5 pounds. And on flights from the Scottish Highlands and islands I will abolish air passenger duty altogether. On tobacco, the Paymaster General will tomorrow announce tough new measures to tackle smuggling. Cigarette taxes will rise by 5 per cent above inflation from tonight - by 25 pence a packet - with every penny of the extra revenue going - as I promised - to funding our hospitals and the National Health Service. And I am also commissioning a long term assessment of technological, demographic and medical trends over the next two decades that will affect the Health Service, to report to the Treasury in time for the start of the next spending review in 2002. I have a number of other fiscal decisions to make. Debt interest payments are down by 4 billion pounds a year. And because we have not spent and we will not spend more at the expense of being prudent, we have also made the tough decisions to tackle benefit fraud, to move people from welfare to work, and to control the social security budget. fields.headline: The Budget speech - part four
fields.trailText: Compared to last year's Budget forecast, social security spending is lower this year by 2 billion pounds and will be another 2 billions lower next year, a saving of 4 billions in all.
fields.body:
Compared to last year's Budget forecast, social security spending is lower this year by 2 billion pounds and will be another 2 billions lower next year, a saving of 4 billions in all.

Because we have cut borrowing and reformed the welfare state, cutting the costs of social and economic failure, and because we have been financially disciplined, extra resources are now available for our priorities.

And, Mr Deputy Speaker, a Budget is about priorities.

In my Pre-Budget consultations I have read carefully detailed Budget representations and examined proposals from all sides of the House.

I have examined proposals for transferrable tax allowances at 4.25 billion, private health insurance tax reliefs at half a billion and for abolishing capital gains tax at 3.9 billion and top rate tax cuts at 690 million for every 1p. And I have established that, for these last two alone, 75 per cent of the tax cuts would go to the wealthiest five per cent of the population, leaving us nothing extra for public services like the NHS.

And because the proposals are made irrespective of economic circumstances, they would risk a return to boom and bust.

I have decided instead on a prudent and responsible approach that allows us to repay debt and lock in an even greater fiscal tightening, and that allows us even after meeting our fiscal rules, to target tax cuts on hard working families and to release for our public services in the coming year alone additional resources of four billion pounds.

These extra resources are not at the expense of our prudence, they arise because of our prudence.

I can announce an immediate new investment of 280 million pounds in transport, 250 million of it to a ring fenced fund for improving roads and public transport including transport in rural areas. The Deputy Prime Minister will be making a statement on individual allocations for the coming year later this week.

I am able to announce an additional 285 million pounds to be spent from April for fighting crime. Later this week the Home Secretary will announce further details.

And I am also announcing additional investment in UK education starting on 1st April of 1 billion pounds.

Under the Secretary for Education and Employment's leadership, class sizes for 5 -7 year olds in primary schools are being cut and significant improvements in reading, writing, and maths achieved. Last year he made a payment to every primary school for books of 2,000 pounds. Now this year more cash will go directly into the classroom.

To support the Secretary of State's drive for literacy and numeracy, every one of these 18,000 primary schools will from 1st April receive a new payment of 3,000 pounds for the smallest school and rising to 9,000 for the largest. The money will go straight to the head teacher.

And schools offering special tuition to help the weakest pupils catch up will be able to draw on an extra 20 million pounds to boost pupil results.

The Secretary of State is proposing to back up reforms in our secondary schools with new measures to boost the performance of those falling behind and to raise the performance of all pupils by the age of 14.

To support these reforms in our secondary schools he will now make a payment to every head teacher for books, equipment and staffing.

Last year he was able to make an extra payment for books and equipment of 2,000 pounds. This April every one of these 3,500 secondary schools will receive a minimum payment of 30,000 pounds and the largest schools will receive 50,000 pounds.

A total of 300 million in new investment through these measures alone, money paid direct to the school and to the head teacher for use in the classroom.

And to advance our goal of 50 per cent of young people in higher education, the Secretary for Education will also announce that three times as many 16 year olds will, from this Autumn, benefit from education maintenance allowances - worth up to 30 pounds a week and that next month he will launch a national campaign to raise staying on rates.

Further announcements on the full allocation of additional money for education will be made by the Secretary of State on Thursday, and by the Scottish and Welsh Administrations and the Northern Ireland Secretary. I can announce today that for the year from 1st April the real terms rise in the UK education spending will be 8 per cent.

After these new spending decisions, I have a decision to make on income tax. Our prudent approach allows us to repay debt, invest in public services, and cut taxes for hard working families. . I will proceed from 6th April with our one pence cut in the basic rate of income tax from 23 per cent to 22 per cent, the lowest basic tax rate for 70 years.

I am also combining the cut in income tax with a further tax cut - this time for families. Next April for 5 million families with children, the new children's tax credit will be increased from 416 pounds to 442 pounds a year. For these families this credit will now be worth twice as much as the old Married Couples Allowance it replaces. And it reduces the family tax bill from April next year by a total of 8.50 pounds a week, on top of the 60p rise in child benefit this April for every mother.

Taken with the 10p income tax rate and the 22p basic rate, and the normal indexation of tax allowances and thresholds, next year's tax burden for the working family will be the lowest since 1972 - a fall from the 21.5 per cent we inherited to 18.8 per cent.

As I said a Budget is about priorities.

A choice has been posed between investing in a National Health Service financed by public expenditure with access based on need, and privatised health care dependent on private insurance. This Government is committed to a publicly funded National Health Service true to the original principles of its founders.

Securing the long term future of the NHS is one of the great challenges this country must and will meet.

Tomorrow the Prime Minister will make a statement to this House on the work he and the Health Secretary will lead over the next 4 months to reform and modernise the Health Service.

The Government's plan, to be published in July alongside the detailed public spending allocations, will address long standing variations in efficiency performance and health outcomes, and the right balance between preventative, primary and hospital care.

And now that the overall public spending total is set for the years until 2004, I have decided that I can back long term reform with long term resources for the Health Service by today announcing the NHS allocation not just for one year but for the next four years.

Since its creation, National Health Service spending has risen by an average 3.3 per cent a year above inflation.

Under the last Government it rose by 2.9 per cent.

We have decided that in the years from now until 2004 the NHS will grow by twice as much - by 6.1 per cent a year over and above inflation, by far the largest sustained increase in NHS funding of any period in the 50 year history of the Health Service.

Last year the equivalent of just over 1,850 pounds per household was spent on the NHS. By 2004 more than 2800 pounds per household will be spent on the NHS. Half as much money again for health care for every family in our country.

In the UK there has been an increase of 4,000 in the number of nurses working in the Health Service. That was just a start. With today's extra resources, and the reforms still to come, we can plan to recruit and train up to 10,000 more nurses.

Let me emphasise that more resources must mean more reform and modernisation .

The Prime Minister, in his statement to the House tomorrow, will set out how with the guarantee of sustained investment, the Government, the professions and the NHS can together rise to the challenge of delivering better health care for all.

I can make one further announcement.

In 10 days time at the beginning of the new financial year the NHS was scheduled to have a 2.9 billions addition on last year.

I have decided to raise that figure with immediate effect by allocating not only the 300 million in tobacco revenues I promised last Autumn, but by adding to that to achieve in total an extra 2 billion pounds - making a rise next year of 4.9 billion pounds - extra money the NHS can start using from 1st April.

So health spending will rise from last year's 45.1 billion, and this year's 49.3 billion to next year: 54.2 billions; the year after 58.6 billion; then 63.5 billion; and then from April 2003, 68.7 billion pounds - over these five years a cash increase of over 50 per cent, a real terms increase of 35 per cent.

New money we can provide because we have made our choice: a Budget that unites the whole country, a Budget for all the people.

We have been prudent for a purpose: a stronger fairer Britain. And I commend this Budget to the House.

fields.headline: Is Brown's brew special enough?
fields.standfirst: Chancellor Gordon Brown's 2000 Budget is calculated to appeal to everyone but David McKie asks if it will it hit the required targets in time for the general election expected next year
fields.trailText: For nearly an hour today, the Labour benches at Westminster bathed in bliss while the Tories sat in apprehensive silence as the chancellor of the exchequer lit up the lights all over the fruit machine.
fields.body:
For nearly an hour today, the Labour benches at Westminster bathed in bliss while the Tories sat in apprehensive silence as the chancellor of the exchequer lit up the lights all over the fruit machine.

There seemed to be something for everyone; imposing increases in spending on health, a lot more for education, good news for pensioners - all playing to the Labour heartlands which have latterly been withholding their favour at elections, and where big defections have been feared in the local elections in May.

Families with children were singled out for special attention. But the middle England of the Tory tabloids had pleasing news too, especially its motorists and drinkers (although not its smokers - a pariah group nowadays and so ripe for the clobbering).

Even more extraordinary were the measures designed to galvanise and enthuse business - and in some cases the well-to-do - as the chancellor, to apparent Labour approval, signalled changes in capital gains and inheritance tax which would have had its benches howling had any Tory chancellor announced them a decade ago. It's conventional these days to say that budgets which play well on day one lose their lustre thereafter, whereas budgets uneasily received take on a posthumous glory. And maybe, as the experts crawl over Gordon Brown's figures, opinions will change.

It may come to be argued that Mr Brown's much applauded handiwork was, to an extent he cannot feel comfortable with, forced on him by events. The pre-eminence of health, from a government which named its first priority as education, education, education, was especially striking, not least when the chancellor declared that Thursday's further announcements on the government's NHS strategy would be made, not by the secretary of state, but by the PM himself.

That puts the lid on a process which has been developing ever since the NHS crisis at Christmas. There was Tony Blair's promise on the Frost programme - apparently cleared with the chancellor - to raise standards in Britain to the European level. There was his confrontation with angry health service professionals on Newsnight when he told them: "I understand what you say and will act on it. This is a listening government."

It is also a sharply reactive, sometimes even panicky government when the media plays badly or sharp verdicts emerge from focus groups.

There are two target audiences: the people who left the Conservatives and swung, often to their own surprise, to New Labour in 1997. They have to be kept on board if Labour is to win again. They will have approved of the talk about opportunity and enterprise. They will have liked the record of a thriving economy as a consequence of PRA - the 'Prudent and Responsible Approach' on which the chancellor repeatedly congratulated himself. Then there are the Labour heartlands, which must be kept sweet. Labour needs them too.

The Budget brew had been mixed to appeal to the taste buds of both. But will it work?

Whatever the fuller inquests reveal, it was difficult listening to Gordon Brown today - as he talked of what this government planned to do through much of the present decade - to take issue with his confidence that Labour would still be there to carry its plans to fruition by winning - perhaps substantially - the election expected next year.

webTitle: Win hundreds of new TV channels

fields.headline: Win hundreds of new TV channels
fields.standfirst: Devise a way to bring foreign-language TV into the national curriculum and win state-of-the-art digital satellite receivers and dishes
fields.trailText: Devise a way to bring foreign-language TV into the national curriculum and win state-of-the-art digital satellite receivers and dishes
fields.body:
Liven up your foreign language lessons by wqinning one of four £600 Nokia digital satellite TV receivers and dishes to give you free access to hundreds of foreign-language TV stations.

In a joint competition launched today, Nokia Multimedia Terminals and the Guardian are offering four state-of-the-art Mediamaster 9800S receivers that can beam into class hundreds of "no subscription" digital satellite TV channels from France, Germany, Spain, Italy, Russia, China, Turkey... the list goes on. Many channels offer teletext, and the Mediamasters can also receive hundreds of foreign radio channels.

What you have to do to enter

You need to create a lesson plan explaining how you would use foreign-language television to bring the national curriculum to life and involve your students during the summer term. Plans must be received by no later than 30 June 2000 and submitted by post to the following address:

Nokia/ Guardian competition
Lexis Public Relations
PO Box 2760
London W1A 6BD

The Nokia Mediamaster 9800S is an ideal language teaching resource and can also be used to help bring lessons to life in political science and media studies.

Call 01793 556046 for more information.

Special features

The Nokia Mediamaster 9800S can store up to 2000 TV and radio channels and offers nine favourites lists (each able to contain 99 channels) to allow you to categorise the stored channels as you wish; store by teacher name, language, class, subject or satellite.

fields.headline: "No threats" learning
fields.standfirst: Mick Reedman is headteacher of Clough Hall technology school, Stoke-on-Trent
fields.trailText: Mick Reedman is headteacher of Clough Hall technology school, Stoke-on-Trent
fields.body:
We have 200 pupils on the SEN register, pupils whose reading ability is below their actual age. To tackle the problem, we use SuccessMaker, an integrated learning program designed to build up basic skills in a methodical, non-threatening way.

We have two SuccessMaker rooms, with 15 workstations in each one. They are used for literacy and numeracy. Our approach works well because we do not single out children with literacy or numeracy difficulties. We've had excellent results, and have even started SuccessMaker clubs so pupils can improve their reading and maths skills in their own time. We've tried to create a culture of ICT for everyone. SuccessMaker is not just for the least able, because this would only cause an image problem for those pupils. That's why we've gone for a completely inclusive approach.

ICT is used across the curriculum, helped by the fact that we have broadband internet access and a school-wide -network. Administrative data is accessible by all our teachers. Not only is the school now a centre for Cisco training; but we are also an accredited NOF training provider.

fields.headline: Confidence booster
fields.standfirst: Paul Kelly is headteacher of Monkseaton High School, Whitley Bay. Its 900 pupils aged 13-18 years enjoy a computer:pupil ratio of 1:7
fields.trailText: Paul Kelly is headteacher of Monkseaton High School, Whitley Bay. Its 900 pupils aged 13-18 years enjoy a computer:pupil ratio of 1:7
fields.body:
It's 3pm, and instead of children leaving school, we can't get them to leave. They are working away at computers, searching on the internet; one child is taking pictures with a digital camera; and there are teachers talking to the kids.

These students have special educational needs, such as dyslexia, dyspraxia and attention deficit disorder. They are involved in research and development work with BBC and Granada Learning, and regularly use a range of multimedia materials.

A student may, say, be good at maths but have trouble reading the question. Software programs can read aloud the question, not only enabling the child to overcome the barrier, but showing the important need to work on their English skills.

IT boosts confidence, even, or especially, when the teacher is not confident with computers because the child feels less humiliated and they have a new way to do things. You just have to do it in a non-intrusive way that doesn't say there is something wrong with them.

fields.headline: Money matters
fields.standfirst: Anne Robinson is the ICT co-ordinator at Lowry High School, Salford, where dealing with money matters using IT has given taxation a new dimension
fields.trailText: Anne Robinson is the ICT co-ordinator at Lowry High School, Salford, where dealing with money matters using IT has given taxation a new dimension
fields.body:
We used spreadsheets - Excel - to model issues to do with spending money with year 7 pupils, and taxes and related issues with GCSE groups.

This kind of financial literacy has until recently not been clearly defined in the curriculum - but it's a vital part of children's preparation for life.

For the spending money exercise we did a paper questionnaire. It was an added bonus to type it up on the machines - all the children loved doing that. Some of the background came from the Walls Ice Cream pocket money survey.

On the Taxes exercise we used parents' payslips. It introduces all kinds of things which they either take for granted or know nothing about.

We have schemes of work for PSHE, but this was an example of how you can develop PSE themes in an ICT lesson; and it's nice to be able to teach a skill which goes beyond the lesson.

fields.headline: Primary education in action
fields.standfirst: Alison Gent, ICT coordinator at Morgans junior and infant school, Hertford, finds it is becoming easier to deliver PSHE in a primary situation.
fields.trailText: Alison Gent, ICT coordinator at Morgans junior and infant school, Hertford, finds it is becoming easier to deliver PSHE in a primary situation.
fields.body:
Primary schools are becoming less cross-curricular, but it's still easier to deliver PSHE in a primary situation. Generally PSHE is taught face-to-face. We do circle time and discussion and that's terribly important, but ICT provides other ways of looking at things. It's an extra dimension to what we do already. We use Drugsense in year six where you have the factual information supported by real-life situations which are quite down to earth.

With a computer the children can get into a situation and make decisions - there's no one else there, no one watching them. They can concentrate on the situation they're in. In an ordinary classroom environment it's easy for some children not to take part - they might be shy or have a personal story they'd rather not talk about.

Using ICT, each child gets to take part, they get an opportunity to think about the issue individually - then it can be followed up in circle time.

This is a difficult area for teachers and it helps to have a resource which they can have confidence in. It's easy for me, I'm the coordinator, but it's difficult for teachers to find the time to get to know the software.

We're pretty well resourced here, with PCs in every classroom. I've plans for a network. The children use ICT to produce certificates to celebrate achievement. A child who finds it difficult to work may make a real effort and the other children recognise it and produce a certificate on the computers to congratulate the pupil. That's PSHE in action.

Children use the internet for research - that has to be very structured, otherwise they waste time and don't get a great deal from the exercise. And, of course, a teacher needs to have looked at the site first. A network would make all that easier.

fields.headline: Across all abilities
fields.standfirst: Diane Wallace is senior teacher at Norham technology college, an 11-16 school in an inner-city area of Tyne and Wear
fields.trailText: Diane Wallace is senior teacher at Norham technology college, an 11-16 school in an inner-city area of Tyne and Wear
fields.body:
Many of our pupils have very poor literacy skills, including some with dyslexia and dyspraxia. All pupils learn keyboarding in their first year, which especially benefits dyspraxic pupils. We use a range of software, including text-to-speech software, standard applications, and integrated learning systems - not just for the bottom end of the ability range but for the top end, too. We integrate ICT into the curriculum as much as we can. We also have laptops and portable word processors for children with SEN.

Much of the curriculum is on our intranet, and this is particularly useful for KS4 pupils. We have developed our internet site and now have links with with a school in New Jersey.

We're proud of our online assessment program. Developed by our network manager, Chris Currah, it gives students immediate feedback and has raised their motivation levels.

The funny thing is, we take this for granted: it's just basic good practice. We have 210 computers for 852 pupils, and we try to improve what we do by, for instance, redeploying computers around the school. We also have one-year internal appointments for innovation and internet development, and this has really stimulated development.

The key is to be brave about letting pupils use the internet, because it can help them soar.

fields.headline: Using what you've got
fields.standfirst: Ian McNiff is headteacher of St Thomas More primary school, Coventry
fields.trailText: Ian McNiff is headteacher of St Thomas More primary school, Coventry
fields.body:
Here at St Thomas More we believe in using what we've got - not only the technology but also our pupils' ability to think.

It's important that children are intellectually challenged, so we use ICT to access specialised websites.

But we also explore what we can do in the computer programs we already use. For example, we use Microsoft Word for teaching the children the mathematical concept of the transformation of shapes - an idea given us by a pupil!

So why buy a specialised program to do this?

We are currently setting up mathematics and science "challenge" areas and are already doing work which some people would regard as quite advanced.

For example, pupils from years five and six have been working on the problem of how to market the Millennium Dome, and on modelling using ICT.

ICT will help you extend the children's thinking abilities if you have very focused questions. It's no good being vague, and setting loose tasks.

fields.headline: Literacy website
fields.standfirst: Andy Tromans is headteacher at Ockerhill junior school, Tipton
fields.trailText: Andy Tromans is headteacher at Ockerhill junior school, Tipton
fields.body:
Our children do not have what you would call severe special education needs, but for example reading difficulties. We've used ICT to provide such children with motivation in literacy by setting up a magazine website between Finland, Portugal, Holland and the UK. We wanted to make the curriculum more accessible to those children whose lack of reading skills effectively excluded them.

The next stage is for the pupils to access information, and compare cultural differences. Our approach enables pupils with literacy special needs to play an active part in the learning process.

Children also use a digital camera to take pictures. Then they agree on the sentences to be used in the descriptions with the photos. These are all in the pupils' home languages.

We've found that the digital camera is exceptionally inspirational because of its "instant-ness". At the moment we link it to a laptop, but what we really need is a camera that stores the photos on disk, and a dedicated desktop computer for editing. When we've bought that we will also use the camera's video facility to help the pupils say what they want to say in 45 seconds.

To make this kind of scheme work, planning is essential. Paradoxically, you cannot just rely on email and so on: you must have face-to-face meetings to build deep professional relationships.

fields.headline: To each one a plan
fields.standfirst: Peter Hicks is headteacher at Broadclyst community primary school, Devon.
fields.trailText: Peter Hicks is headteacher at Broadclyst community primary school, Devon.
fields.body:
We have children coming here with severe emotional and behavioural difficulties, or learning difficulties - and it takes about three weeks for them to become "normal". That's because we operate what we call the "boundary-less classroom". This means inclusion, which ICT can make a reality. We don't differentiate children with special educational needs from other children.

ICT is not taught as an end in itself, but we show children how to reason with ICT, which we regard as a means to an end. It's about inclusion, which pervades the school: all computers are linked to the internet, and all pupils have their own email address. We also use ICT in a way that involves every member of staff.

Every child has an individual education plan, and each plan includes performance graphs, target-setting and attainment gained, all linked to planning. We would never have been able to be so detailed at an individual pupil level without using ICT, and in particular the Educator website, which has saved us loads of time and energy.

We will be providing every child with home computers linked to the school intranet, offering them an irresistible deal to buy the computer when they leave the school. The only thing slowing us down is the need for more funds.

We've been successful because we've addressed the need for each child to be successful: ICT includes all, and demands nothing from you except a willingness to participate. It's important to make all children successful, not just some.

fields.headline: CD-Roms to make you think
fields.standfirst: Phil Revell checks out software that helps children cope with problems they face in modernday life
fields.trailText: Phil Revell checks out software that helps children cope with problems they face in modernday life
fields.body:
Sixth formers with a driving ambition will enjoy the Driver Awareness CD-Rom produced by BMW in association with BP Amoco. It portrays realistic simulations which allow students to test their reaction times in urban and rural driving situations, in adverse weather conditions and the effect of speed on stopping distances, even experience the effects of incorrect eyesight on driving ability. It also tackles the effects of alcohol and drugs on driving behaviour. BMW Education Programme Helpline: 0870 333 0427. BMW educational website www.bized.ac.uk, for orders online, or call BP Educational Service: 0870 333 0428.

Drugsense is a drugs education resource pack divided into four sections: D-Street, D-Stories, D-Tools and a teacher's section.

In D-Street, clicking on the chemist's shop gives access to information about drugs as medicine; the pub, to information on alcohol; and the library contains a database of basic information about a range of drugs, including caffeine, tobacco, solvents, cannabis, amphetamines, cocaine and heroin.

The teachers' section provides password-protected information, allowing teachers to filter what their pupils see. Aimed at years five and six, it's a bright, clear resource with comic-book style illustrations. New Media Press: 01491 413999; www.new-media.co.uk or sales@new-media.co.uk

Growing Up Together comes on two CD-Roms. Disk one is aimed at KS1 children, and covers a wide variety of topics including making new friends, a new baby in the family and personal hygiene. Disk two is aimed at KS2 children and covers topics such as religious attitudes, including Christian, Muslim and Jewish, and sex education. Growing up Together (por) from Granada Learning/ Semerc: 0161 827 2927

AOL and Maxis have teamed up to offer schools a chance to develop PSHE and geographical skills using the one of the most successful games of the 1990s.

SIM City 3000 is a real-world simulator which allows players to construct and manage whole cities, right the way down to the plumbing. The schools version simplifies and speeds up the game to allow teachers to use the resource in lessons. Schools will receive letters this month inviting them to apply for the CD which links up with AOL's exclusive online Sim City zone to present a schools challenge.

Family breakdown is the focus of the Family Change CD produced by NCH Action for Children with the support of Rotary International. It's a free resource which attempts to deal with the consequences of family changes which have resulted in one in three children across the UK experiencing family breakdown. It offers simple explanations of the legal background to divorce and separation. Family change is distributed by local Rotary groups.

Cromwell the Firefighter is a CD-Rom which tells the story of what happened when Mrs Jones's chip pan caught fire and how the firefighters put out the fire. Children can also learn about the fire brigade, and what to do if there is a fire at home. It's aimed at children in key stages 1 and 2 who are offered the choice between easy or hard text for each page. By clicking on an icon in the top left corner of the screen, they can have the text read out to them.

Sound clips and video were all recorded "warts and all" by the Durham fire brigade, and give a realistic effect. Illustrations are clear and of reasonable quality. All the screens can be printed out and children can use Notepad to make their own notes as they go through the program. Cambridgeshire Software House: 01487 741223; cshsoft@compuserve.com

The TEEM project (Teachers Evaluating Educational Multimedia) offers objective assessment of multimedia CD-Roms to save teachers time and money. The Drugsense CD has PSHE elements and is currently being evaluated by Teem. Teem is a Cambridge-based project supported by a number of organisations, including the Guardian: www.teem.org.uk

fields.headline: Education on the web
fields.standfirst: Phil Revell surfs the net for the best PSHE resources
fields.trailText: Phil Revell surfs the net for the best PSHE resources
fields.body:
www.trashed.co.uk
The Health Education Authority's drug information site is an excellent information site for schools. There's a search facility where the effects, origins, composition and risks of drugs are presented. Unlike some of the other HEA sites this is quick and easy to access.

www.thesite.org
This offers well-presented information for older teenagers across a range of issues. Onscreen factsheets are available on work, the job seekers' allowance and accommodation.

www.ncb.org.uk/sexed.htm
The Sex Education Forum site is one for teachers who need the latest information and guidance on the subject. It offers a charter for effective sex education, factsheets and a framework for sex and relationships education.

www.bbc.co.uk/health/kids
For PSHE issues this offers a choice between questions about body matters and mind matters. Both offer simple information presented in an attractive way with links to TV programmes which address related issues.

www.samaritans.org
Two young people kill themselves every day. The Samaritans' response has been to launch their popular youth pack on their website. The discussion points, role plays and workshops should help young people come to terms with some of the issues they find difficult to cope with.

www.petepayne.com
This follows on from the success of Diary of a Teenage Health Freak. Teenagers desperate to avoid embarrassment and humiliation can log on to this site to keep up with the gossip about our hero's girls, family, friends and his uncooperative body.

www.tacade.com
The charity Tacade is an expert in PSHE with a useful website dealing with lifeskills, health, and alcohol and drugs information. Its Skills for Life manual is a complete programme for PSHE in secondary schools. Other resources include a Drug Deal card game offering a fun way for teenagers to check on the information and misinformation about drug use. Tacade also offers training for teachers and youth workers who want to be better equipped to deal with these issues.

Dos and don'ts

 Software can offer a new dimension to a PSHE lesson, but make sure you have thoroughly reviewed the programme first.

 Websites can be useful but don't allow children to surf in an uncontrolled way. Apart from the risks of accidentally coming across something unsavoury, there is the time element. Check out sites in advance and give children a site list. Better still, set up the favourites section of the browser with the URLs you would like the children to follow.

 Discourage printing off. If children want to keep something they find, encourage them to cut, paste and save to a format like Word.

 Recruit helpers. See if you can get older children or sixth-formers to come in and help children with the software. Not only will this lower your stress levels, but the older kids may also act as mentors to the younger ones.

fields.headline: Elementary,  my dear...
fields.standfirst: Computers have become integral to police detection work. Now pupils can enjoy solving crimes, as Phil Revell discovers
fields.trailText: Computers have become integral to police detection work. Now pupils can enjoy solving crimes, as Phil Revell discovers
fields.body:
The police visit has been a regular feature of the school year for some time. In the past it used to be a matter of a near-to-retirement officer who came into the classroom to give a fatherly talk about the need to be good boys and girls. Bold and imaginative PCs used to hand their truncheons around the room or demonstrate their handcuffs.

Children brought up on a diet of The Bill demand more from the experience and schools are keen to use the liaison visit to target areas of the curriculum where teachers have little knowledge. The result has been a flurry of resources aimed at facilitating the visit.

One of the most imaginative is the Language in Evidence CD-Rom developed by the Thames Valley force in and Cambridge Software House. Thames liaison officer Cheryl Hunter helped in the development of the CD and delivers the programme in schools across North Oxfordshire.

"They live and breathe the police while they are doing this," she said. The CD is a simulation which can be used as a basis for an extended project - which is how Thames Valley use it - or as a reference tool to show the way a modern police force operates. Aimed at years five and six it turns a class of children into police officers with a number of scenarios to solve.

In the missing person scenario, children receive a report then interrogate databases to find the missing child's contacts, friends and likely hang-outs. They take witness statements and receive reports from other officers. In the end the child is discovered safe and well - but not where his parents thought he was: "Very much like in real life," said PC Hunter.

In theory the programme could be used without the police presence, but it would "lose an edge," says teacher Mark Yeowell at Brookside school in Bicester.

The school used two computers for the class exercise. "Children had just 10 minutes at a time on the machine," said Yeowell, "which meant that they had to discuss and plan what they were going to do. It was absolutely brilliant - we thoroughly enjoyed it."

fields.headline: A nugget in every byte
fields.standfirst: Upgrade to DVD, says John Bald, and benefit from a whole new world of software
fields.trailText: Upgrade to DVD, says John Bald, and benefit from a whole new world of software
fields.body:
Digital Video Device, or DVD, is the latest example of ICT's ability to get more out of less, as Tony Benn once put it. A single disk holds up to 4,700 million items of information, compared with a mere 680 million on a CD-Rom. Yet DVD is not prohibitively expensive - it cost me £100 to upgrade from CD to DVD with a major supplier. The DVD unit fitted straight into the slot left by the CD drive. DVD units will also play CDs.

This enormous capacity can be used either to do much more of the same in a smaller space, or to do different things. Eurotalk's brilliant series of DVDs for language learners (approx £30 each, tel 0207-371 7711) uses the medium to create unique learning opportunities which can be fine-tuned to meet individual needs and preferences, and to be approached from several different angles.

Different editions are being produced for French, German, Italian and English, each based on a popular detective series: Au Coeur de la Loire for French, Morse for English.

Users can watch the series without any help, or call up the script for subtitles. They can take on one of the parts, recording their own version of the script into the DVD, and can listen to their version alongside the original.

Other ingenious learning tricks are embedded in the program - for example, recalling the next line in a given situation, and playing virtual reality games to reinforce vocabulary.

These DVDs suit advanced students who can handle natural dialogue with relatively little assistance, and we badly need something of the same quality for beginners.

The DVD of Britannica makes a good foil for the Eurotalk discs, as it uses DVD simply to compress information rather than to break new ground. As a piece of miniaturisation, it is remarkable - 83,000 substantial articles, five hours of video clips, 1,600 maps and a top-class dictionary on a single disk.

The only problem is that the whole content of the encyclopaedia, plus a superb network of supporting websites and an up-to-the-minute news service, is available free on the internet at Britannica.com or eBlast.com, while the DVD costs £69.99. This is a snip compared with the printed encyclopaedia at around £1,250, but it leaves the video clips and maps as the main reason for buying the DVD as opposed to the CD-Rom version. Some are excellent, particularly the wildlife clips, but others are not up to Britannica's normal standard. The clip of the Parthenon, for example, showed more of the rear ends of a party of tourists than it did of the building.

Finally, to gain internet access, you have to register the product online, and when you do that, it installs Britannica as your home website. Bit of a cheek, really.

The Complete National Geographic, 1888-1998 (around £95) benefits more obviously from the compression of DVD. The collection takes up 39 discs on CD- Rom, which creates problems if you are following a theme across several decades. Even the DVD version has four discs, covering 20-30 years each, but they are much easier to use and print. The content is a unique record of man's, particularly American man's, exploration and treatment of the world during the last century, and has as much to offer the history student as the geographer. A wonderful resource for secondary schools and sixth form colleges.

Dorling Kindersley has two DVDs, both with identical titles to successful CD-Roms. The Ultimate Human Body (£29) has the content of the CD-Rom, plus 60 minutes of good video. The CD is an excellent product in its own right, and the DVD version is only worth buying if you don't already have it. Eyewitness World Atlas (£29.99) offers a genuine, exciting innovation in a satellite-generated flight simulator that allows you to fly all over the world, either altering course as you wish, using compass, height and speed controls, or setting one in advance. Great practice in using a compass. A good buy for primary schools and secondary geography departments.

fields.headline: What they really, really want
fields.standfirst: An ongoing survey has given voice to a usually silent, put-upon group: ICT coordinators. Terry Freedman on his findings so far
fields.trailText: An ongoing survey has given voice to a usually silent, put-upon group: ICT coordinators. Terry Freedman on his findings so far
fields.body:
The school or college ICT coordinator is a put-upon breed. Download this, gissa password for that, fix my mouse the requests are often endless and time-consuming, particularly when the person concerned doubles up as a subject teacher or, often, deputy head. But over the last two months, the coordinators have struck back - they have been having their say in an ongoing, web-based survey about what they really, really want.

Responses have come in from far and near: UK (64%), USA (30%) and the rest from Australia, Canada, Holland, Malaysia and Nepal, at the latest count. Just under 20% say they want more time to do their job - although only 6% put this as their first choice. And more money - not for themselves, mind, but for equipment and software, and for technicians' salaries. Below are some of their responses.

On the job: "ICT needs a good teacher as a role model, not a good technician," urges Chris Wood, an advisory teacher from Greenwich. "Keeping up-to-date with new hardware and software is a full-time job in some industries," says JS Walter from High Tunstall School, Hartlepool. "In a secondary school this is just one sideline for an individual who often has a full-time teaching post!"

On technology in teaching: "Do we sit in our chair and raise our hand waiting for the boss to come by?" asks Rick Mislan from Newaygo County intermediate school district, US. "Most likely not yet we are still teaching our students this way!" He says one reason for this is that teachers aren't taught in a style that enhances their students' ability to learn with the new technologies. And when a teacher does get to their first school, the older teachers latch onto them and sink in their hooks, explaining the "way things are done here".

On home computers: "How well schools capitalise on and support home use of ICT will be a key difference between schools," according to independent ICT consultant Geoff Strackthis, who warns that in future "the lack of ICT outside schools could be a key feature of failing schools."

On special educational needs: "Several agencies work with ICT in schools, yet leave SEN out of the picture until it's pointed out to them," says David Fettes, ICT coordinator at a school for children with severe learning difficulties. If teachers were consulted and asked for feedback on the quality of product equipment and training in schools, expensive mistakes would not be repeated, he said.

 Terry Freedman is an ICT adviser and author of Managing ICT (Hodder & Stoughton) and Make Time with IT (Questions Publishing). Take part in his survey at http://fastlink.to/ict which carries classroom hints and advice on ICT, or email him at: survey@etfreedman.easynet.co.uk

fields.headline: Progress report
fields.standfirst: In a poll, teachers were asked their views about the importance of computers in the future of teaching. John Carvel reports
fields.trailText: In a poll, teachers were asked their views about the importance of computers in the future of teaching. John Carvel reports
fields.body:
Teachers are overwhelmingly persuaded of the importance of computers and the internet in education. But, according to the findings of an ICM poll commissioned by the Guardian, they are sceptical about their colleagues' ability to use information technology competently in the classroom.

The poll of 500 teachers and 100 lecturers was part of a wide-ranging review of the state of schools and universities. In a section on ICT, teachers were asked their views about the importance of computers and the internet for the future of teaching. The replies appeared to leave no doubt that staff in schools and universities are committed to change.

In both primary and secondary schools, two thirds of teachers said computers and the internet were "very important", an extraordinarily strong response. The response from university lecturers was even more positive, 76% saying computers and the internet were "very important".

The next question was: how well qualified and competent are most teachers/ lecturers you know to use computers and the web in lessons? Among primary teachers, 46% said their colleagues were "not very well qualified" and another 10% said "not at all qualified".

Perceptions of competence increased in secondary schools and universities. Half the secondary teachers and nearly three quarters of the lecturers thought colleagues they knew were at least reasonably well qualified.

In spite of the generally positive attitude to computers shown by our poll, a harsher message emerged from focus groups of teachers that were run by ICM on the urban fringes of Birmingham and London. The technique allows themes to be explored in more depth and the reaction of these secondary teachers became extremely negative. Computers were a "nuisance", imposed by headteachers and the government. Others spoke of "brownie points" for teachers integrating computers into lessons.

The group appeared to agree about the uselessness of computers teaching children anything. "They could be good if there were enough of them but they are so expensive and out of date so quickly. They should not be used as a surrogate teacher."

These secondary teachers thought computers were becoming something of a god, with little thought given to the actual contribution to children's education.

The group agreed that teachers tend not to know enough about computers to teach teenagers who know rather more. Yet they exhibited decided antagonism towards going on courses.

In other areas of our research, the focus groups tended to amplify the results of the quantitative polling. Here the views were contradictory. Our secondary teachers may have been a rogue group, but the government and computer firms may want to explore whether there is an underlying resistance in the profession that may get in the way of expected progress.

They would take more comfort from our group of primary teachers who welcomed developments in computer technology. They said children in their schools were actively engaged in using computers. "We've got a computer suite which all the children use and they learn fast, even the internet," said one. "Our nursery children at four have a regular session on the computer," said another.

Results of poll

ICM interviewed a random sample of 505 parents of primary and secondary schoolchildren, 501 primary and secondary school teachers and 101 university lecturers drawn from nationally representative samples. Interviews were conducted by telephone on February 8-15 2000. Focus groups were conducted at Sunbury-on-Thames and Sutton Coldfield on February 15-16 2000.

How important are computers and the internet for the future of teaching?

fields.headline: The moral in the tale
fields.standfirst: PSHE is a difficult subject with not enough time in the curriculum devoted to it. Phil Revell looks at ICT resources which might help make the job easier for teachers
fields.trailText: PSHE is a difficult subject with not enough time in the curriculum devoted to it. Phil Revell looks at ICT resources which might help make the job easier for teachers
fields.body:
It's the "touchy-feely" end of the curriculum - relationships, drugs, sex, abortion, divorce, crime. The kind of subject matter which could lead to an outraged parent invading the school to berate the hapless teacher who dared mention abortion in a sex education lesson. PSHE (personal, social and health education) is controversial, difficult to teach and avoided like the plague by many teachers.

Martin Buczkiewicz, the new director of alcohol education charity Tacade, describes chatting to a teacher at an airport on return from holiday.

"Oh no," said the horrified teacher on discovering Buczkiewicz's job, "PSHE - that's a disaster."

And is ICT the best way to deal with these issues anyway? Some teachers argue that teaching about moral issues and relationships is not best progressed by plonking a child down in front of keyboard, but Dave Hassall, head of curriculum projects at Becta (British Educational Communications Technology agency), disagrees.

"If you're talking about a difficult issue," he says, "tools which help kids develop their knowledge and then test their understanding are a useful complementary resource to the traditional discussion lesson."

But teachers who want to use ICT to give the subject some oomph face a paucity of suitable resources.

"If we do a search on our database," says Hassall, "it's thinly populated with resources for PSHE." Sadly, when I searched the National Grid for Learning database maintained by Becta, I could not find any resources for PSHE.

The DfEE's national curriculum site (www.nc.uk.net/) gives the curriculum orders with a detailed explanation, but a trawl for the kind of resources and links available for other subjects reveals nothing for PSHE.

"It tends to be the same in PE where it's fundamentally about kids doing things actively," said Hassall. But ICT resources do exist - and more are on the way.

The starting point for those interested in using the web for PSHE should be the Health Education Authority's www.wiredforhealth website which offers advice, information and contacts on a whole range of issues. Aimed at teachers, it covers issues ranging from accidents, to mental health, to sun safety. All the links and references have been checked for content and a look at the site will allow other net resources to be approached with more confidence.

WiredforHealth is the top level of a series of sites aimed at each key stage. Mindbodysoul is the key stage 4 site with information for the 14-16 age group, with links to over 100 other health websites.

Mindbodysoul gives details about a wide range of medical conditions including acne, ME, diabetes, asthma and anaphylaxis. Launched in November it averages 30,000 hits a week.

This week the key stage 3 site, Lifebytes, will be launched at the Education Show (March 23-25) at Birmingham's National Exhbition Centre - and sites for key stages 1 and 2 are under development.

"We're trying for a different look and feel for each age group," said Cath Herman at the Health Education Authority.

"We wanted these sites to be as accessible as possible for teachers. The internet is not a substitute for the kind of discussion lesson that many schools use to deliver PSHE. But using the net really excites children. It reinforces their learning and, for these kinds of sensitive issue, there's the added benefit of anonymity."

The authority argues that online learning communities can be very successful, and it is hoping that the WiredforHealth sites, designed by Alison Milne, will become genuinely interactive.

"For PSHE that would be crucial," said Ms Herman.

 More information on www.wiredforhealth.gov.uk, www.mindbodysoul.gov.uk, www.lifebytes.gov.uk (live on Thursday March 23)

webTitle: Overseas links can be cheap at the price

fields.headline: Overseas links can be cheap at the price
fields.trailText: Chris Drage speaks to a video-conferencing veteran
fields.body:
Ever tried fitting a maths lesson into the school timetable thousands of miles from your class? And doing it with an electronic camera under £50 and free internet software? Maths teacher Gerald Cort at City of London school owns up to this claim, not once but several times when he has linked up with students from four continents.

Central to a "Cort conference" is an Intellicase Cruiser laptop that doubles as a data projector. For as little as £1,400 he does away with a room full of computers. Instead he uses just one Cruiser to project his prepared work on to the screen in his (ordinary) classroom through a conventional overhead projector. He uses several tools in spreadsheet programs to manipulate material he has written himself as a core maths text.

In a typical class, he will hand out six remote infrared keyboards to each of six small groups of pupils, and then control their input on to the shared master screen. The atmosphere is electric. Pupils concentrate and their understanding level rises rapidly. Each student can see the others' input, they can comment immediately on mistakes and take over the control of the master system through their own keyboard. They are scarcely able to wait their turn.

Flexibility is the key to the Cruiser's success, says Cort. It looks like an ordinary laptop, and he uses it to and from school to prepare all his lessons without the hassle of having to transfer work on disk to the school intranet before he can teach with it. He can even share the box with colleagues - the Cruiser allows him to remove his own personal disk drive and pass on the Cruiser, which has a modem card, camera and software for internet links such as video conferencing. International link-ups between schools when teaching is shared with children overseas always spice up the maths lesson.

Cort uses NetMeeting, free software downloaded from the net plus a cheap electronic camera under £50 to teach joint lessons with colleagues in the US, Argentina and South Africa, all from his classroom with his own pupils present. He even taught one lesson in London from a conference venue in China with a group of pupils at a Chinese middle school: he used just two machines with cheap cameras, one at each end. He appeared on his London pupils' screen right on cue in the allotted lesson - they were talking about it for weeks after.

He has also developed video conferencing to suit a girls' state school in south-east London, in response to a teacher's request to motivate her year 10 maths class of disaffected pupils doing the GCSE foundation course. Cort and a colleage rewrote part of his interactive maths material to suit these pupils. Cort then demonstated the materials himself in the first few lessons, integrating the computer with his teaching.

Meanwhile, the girls regained their interest. Cort put their names up on the net using his own web page which contained materials they could access. Absenteeism fell and a year later the teacher told him all but one had passed maths GCSE in the subject - three had gained the highest grade within their level.

A north London mixed school is next on his hitlist.

 Intellicase, tel: 07001 999 999; email: info@icase.co.uk

He even taught one lesson in London from a conference venue in China with a group of pupils at a Chinese middle school: he used just two machines with cheap cameras, one at each end. He appeared on his London pupils' screen right on cue in the allotted lesson - they were talking about it for weeks after. He has also developed video conferencing to suit a girls' state school in south-east London, in response to a teacher's request to motivate her year 10 maths class of disaffected pupils doing the GCSE foundation course. Cort and a colleage rewrote part of his interactive maths material to suit these pupils. Cort then demonstated the materials himself in the first few lessons, integrating the computer with his teaching. Meanwhile, the girls regained their interest. Cort put their names up on the net using his own web page which contained materials they could access. Absenteeism fell and a year later the teacher told him all but one had passed maths GCSE in the subject - three had gained the highest grade within their level. A north London mixed school is next on his hitlist.  Intellicase, tel: 07001 999 999; email: info@icase.co.uk

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Louise Goldsbury brings the latest news from the National Grid for Learning
fields.trailText: Louise Goldsbury brings the latest news from the National Grid for Learning
fields.body:
 A virtual community for headteachers has been set up as a forerunner to the National College for School Leadership to be established in Nottingham next year. 1,200 selected heads are being supplied with portable computers, allowing them to log on to Talking Heads. This is a web-based forum where they can share expertise and ideas, and ask questions of each other and guest experts. Managed by Ultralab, based at Anglia Polytechnic University, it needs registration and a password to enter. The rest of us can peek at public sections of the site, or join the waiting list at: www.headteachers.ac.uk.

 The New Opportunities Fund has launched a £200m Community Access to Lifelong Learning (Call) programme, which aims to help more adults acquire information and knowledge through computers and other technologies. Half the cash is to support the People's Network, which will connect every public library in the UK to the internet, community websites and the NGfL. Funds will also be used to create community grids for learning to provide better local content for adult learners. The programme fits in nicely with government plans to set up 700 new ICT learning centres in disadvantaged areas over the next two years. Find out more at www.nof.org.uk or www.dfee.gov.uk.

 The Victoria and Albert Museum is the latest museum to link its website to the grid. The first phase of the service provides an image-browsing device to allow you to view over 2,000 objects from the V&A collection. Curators will progressively add more of the museum's 10 million pieces, and say they hope to move away from their traditionally dry captions to a more narrative style. A teaching resource is also available, offering online versions of existing educational booklets, and students' activities related to the exhibitions. The site (www.vam.ac.uk) is intended as an introduction for classes before making a museum visit.

 As further evidence that industry is taking note of the grid, Yorkshire Electricity Group has switched on to the site. Its Fun and Education section employs characters such as Vic Voltage and Claude the Sheep to teach children about the history and uses of electricity through activities such as safety quizzes, crosswords and a meter reading test. Primary, middle, secondary and home students can feel the energy at www.yeg.co.uk.

 Primary teachers can now download a vast range of free resources from RM's new Window Box Online website - a full-scale venture into providing lesson content. Self-contained activities designed primarily to complement software installed in RM Window Box computers can be downloaded for immediate use in the classroom - try the art activity where you colour in beetles to match their environment or design an Islamic carpet. Just download WorkBox from the site at www.wbol.co.uk. Even if you are not a Window Box user, you can still visit the site for lesson plans and other activities.

 The grid is due to receive a "little gentle shaping" from Becta, which hints at taking a more proactive role in recruiting contributors of NGfL material. A team of people from education, publishing and technology will soon set to work to ensure only the best content is admitted.
