webTitle: A plan for all those seasons

fields.headline: A plan for all those seasons
fields.standfirst: The BT FutureTalk scheme encourages pupils to incorporate ICT into their school projects.   Louise Goldsbury reports on the latest winners
fields.trailText: The BT FutureTalk scheme encourages pupils to incorporate ICT into their school projects. Louise Goldsbury reports on the latest winners
fields.body:
The idea of the 2001 Banbury Calendar may not inspire as much excitement as the Sports Illustrated version, but it's sparked a stream of excited emails across England. As the winners of the BT FutureTalk School Awards, Frank Wise School, Banbury School, Brockworth Comprehensive and Abbey Wood's School have been awarded £25,000 to create a local calendar in their classrooms.

The FutureTalk Awards programme, now in its second round, called for schools to submit proposals for literacy and geography projects incorporating ICT in a bid to receive funding. Two other school groups were each awarded runners-up prizes of £5,000.

One More Year, as the winning project is titled, will be coordinated by Sean O'Sullivan, deputy head at Frank Wise, a special school for pupils with severe learning difficulties. They will work with six teenage special needs students from the local comprehensive, Banbury school, where integrated classes are held every week. Brockworth School, in rural Gloucester, and Abbey Wood School, in inner London, will serve a support role, providing feedback and ideas from two very different points of view.

"We want to make sure that this calendar is as unique to Banbury as possible," says O'Sullivan, "so we will regularly check with the other schools if they have any similar monuments or events in their towns. The pupils can also share comments and thoughts by email and fax. With this funding, we can communicate with outside schools and produce a high-quality, commercial project."

The calendar will link a topical or historical aspect of the Banbury area to each month, researched on the internet by the students. They will take digital photographs, assist the design and image manipulation, and write the accompanying text. Others will help choose graphics and photos on modified laptops loaded with symbol software.

"Most of our students have profound difficulties and are not able to use verbal communication, while others have very basic levels of reading, writing and speech," says O'Sullivan. "The project will use motivation to push them to realise they can do much more than they give themselves credit for. When pupils know it matters, it motivates them, and this gives them a huge boost. "By selling the calendar to friends, residents and tourists, they'll put far more into it."

Each student will be set individual literacy-skills targets to meet through the drafting and editing of the calendar's text. The ongoing project will be featured on Frank Wise School's website.

In second place, Lea junior school, in Berkshire, and Hawkes Farm primary school, in East Sussex, received £5,000 for their "Poetry Talks" proposal.

The project will involve both schools' year five pupils writing a narrative poem as a group, culminating in a live reading of the finished piece by video conferencing. Its coordinator and teacher, Helen MacDonald of Lea School, believes "this makes it real. Kids can see the relevance of literacy by using the internet and computers and having a real audience."

The second runners-up award went to a group of seven schools in Wiltshire, where over 1,000 pupils plan to observe and record the seasonal, ecological changes in a working wood environment.

Throughout the year every child will spend a day at the Westonbirt Arboretum, starting with a celebratory assembly, led by the local vicar, and ending with a tree-planting ceremony. There will be workshops about conservation, tree classification and related crafts. The pupils' reports, artwork, photos and video clips will then be displayed in linked websites.

Ken Morey, project coordinator and headteacher of Oaksey CE VC primary school, explains: "The kids will have a floppy disk each to save graphs, tables, pictures and small video clips of the woodland, and the teachers will be trained to show them how to put them on a website. Then it can be shared and used as a resource by everyone."

The subjects for next term's projects are numeracy, and design and technology. The closing date for applications is April 7 2000.

BT FutureTalk Awards programme

Launched in January, in conjunction with the Guardian, the BT FutureTalk Awards programme is providing £600,000 over two years to groups of schools working on joint projects that promote the best use of new technologies.

Every half-term the winners receive the main prize of £25,000, with up to five further school groups awarded £5,000 each.

Richard Hamer, implementation manager of BT FutureTalk, says: "We are looking to build a portfolio of good projects applying ICT in the curriculum, so that all schools can be inspired. The Guardian's involvement will help extend the programme's reach."

To link up with partner schools or to obtain an application form, visit the FutureTalk website. Details are also available on the Guardian website

fields.headline: Entering the main stream
fields.standfirst: Integrating children with special needs into non-specialist schools provides unique challenges to class teachers. John Davitt looks at how ICT can make a difference
fields.trailText: Integrating children with special needs into non-specialist schools provides unique challenges to class teachers. John Davitt looks at how ICT can make a difference
fields.body:
Government plans for most children with special needs to be educated in mainstream schools are now moving centre-stage as a White Paper on inclusion grinds its way through parliamentary committees.

But before this aim is met, schools have to get it right for those pupils with special needs already in mainstream schools. It's a big challenge for teachers and parents but one that new technology can help them meet.

Many estimate that up to 20% of children in mainstream classrooms may have some special needs. According to Jeff Hughes, head of Semerc's education service, "The largest hidden group are the kids with bits of this or that, maybe a bit of dyslexia and some hearing problems. "For these children, the cumulative effect is disabling. The best thing about ICT is that it can be used for the whole class and all will benefit, not just those with special needs."

Last week a one-year pilot trial into voice-recognition software ended with some glowing reports from the 12 schools involved. Several said they had seen dramatic improvements to students' overall motivation and use of language as they trained the computer to turn their voice into text on screen.

"There is no doubt that the technology works and can no longer be used as an excuse," said Mick Thomas, project officer at the British Education and Communications Technology agency (Becta). "But the other ingredients of time and training are also vital for success."

During two national conferences to announce the research findings, teachers were spellbound by the accuracy of IBM's ViaVoice and Dragon Dictate software. Students who, because of particular need are given an amanuensis to write for them in exams, tend to outperform those of similar ability who do their own writing. Soon it will be possible for any student to have a computer to understand their voice and dictate their answers. How long before exam boards permit such practice? For them the floodgates of opportunity will open.

Yet voice recognition will only suit a certain group of learners and teachers; the greatest value of ICT is in using different tools for different needs. The internet and, more particularly, the national grid subset of online resources gives parents, teachers and students increasing access to resources and discussion groups. Over time this will mean the virtuous circle of learning from each other will accelerate and the sense of isolation felt in the past will diminish.

Once learners have made their corrections in the humblest word processor, nobody will ever know how many errors they started with. "The professional quality of the typeface negates the concern over poor handwriting and the child can feel proud and enthused about their efforts," says Amanda Peck, head of special educational needs at RM.

RM's Window Box computer and software aims to cater for a wide range of pupil needs and abilities through a structured environment and colour-coded access.

Generic families of key software have emerged in the form of spellcheckers, talking word processors and predictive software which makes a guess of the word you intend to write as soon as you enter the first few letters. The new Dyslexia and ICT Building on Success booklet from Becta provides an excellent overview, and details the range and application of all these software support tools. "The final key question to ask is are students using their intellectual resources for getting round a problem or for learning the subject at hand," says Semerc's Jeff Hughes. "So many kids spend so long avoiding the problem, they don't achieve their potential."

Karen is the subject of one of the case studies on the new inclusion website managed by Becta: "Like many of our pupils, Karen has some learning difficulties. She's got lots of good ideas but she finds spelling difficult so, without help, her written recording doesn't reflect her capabilities. Her handwritten work can also look untidy with lots of crossing out."

The answer for her teacher was to provide a grid of words on screen from which Karen could produce her own report simply by clicking on the words using the software known as Clicker. (www.cricksoft.com).

This type of work is a perfect example of the scaffolding ICT can provide for learners who have known only failure with the written page.

According to Nikki Jones, a classroom teacher and ICT specialist, "What works best is good software used by imaginative teachers." For schools moving forward in this area her advice is: "Take it a step at a time. We have loads of software in our school, but flinging it at staff doesn't work. I have picked one or two based on sound educational principles and got staff involved during the literacy hour.

"And software that pupils can use independently and that scaffolds their learning has to have a very sound design. So much stuff fails for the kids I teach, because the design is boring or restrictive."

The message is clear for teachers and parents: dare to be different, foster creativity and consider the wide range of support and communications tools available. The new inclusion legislation will strengthen the special educational needs framework and give children with disabilities rights in the classroom. And using ICT creatively will be vital.

Dos and don'ts

Do
 Carry out controlled trials of new opportunities so that you can report back to other colleagues along the line of: "We tried voice recognition with three members of the learning support group over a two-month period and this is what we found"

 Set up a PowerPoint presentation of student work in the school foyer at parents' evenings. Use the "rehearse timings" option so that each screen displays work for a set period of time so that parents can see examples of a wide range of work.

 Consider using some technical support: someone who is keen to learn how to set up software and build web pages. Share with them your curriculum aims for ICT in the school so that they can work alongside you effectively. Many women returners have made excellent contributions to ICT work in primary schools by working in this role.

 Consider setting up a central presentation area with good sound and video resources. Sound is often the poor relation in the use of ICT, so make sure students can hear as well as see. A speaker system, such as the VideoLogic Sirocco Crossfire, gives surround sound, fine bass and an amplifier with two spare inputs - ideal for filling the whole class with sound (VideoLogic 01923 277488).

Don't
 Try to do it all alone. When trying something new, arrange a time with a colleague to work with you on a new project or piece of software. Taking a friend on a journey works better whether it's on a train or the internet.

 Focus too tightly on text editing and word processing. Think about the use of scanners and microphones so that students' artwork and spoken comments can become a natural part of their work.

 Invest too much in computer hardware which has one fixed purpose in one fixed place in the school. A laptop and a data projector can be used in any classroom and the school hall - wireless networking means that portable machines can access the network wherever they are within the school.

 Dyslexia and ICT - Building on Success is available from Becta

fields.headline: Q&A: ICT for special needs
fields.trailText: John Davitt answers the questions most frequently asked by ICT co-ordinators looking to improve their provision for special needs pupils
fields.body:
How can I find out about the work other teachers are doing using ICT with students with special needs?

The new Inclusion website from Becta contains many useful links. From the front page follow the link for SEN and Inclusion discussion areas. The Senit group has around 400 members enabling you to share in the expertise and experience of fellow professionals. To join, just send an email with a simple message (see the joining guidance). Becta's Voice Recognition Project reports may also be found on this site.

How can I get animations on my web page?

Go to www.tucows.com and download some image animation shareware. Start with GIF MovieGear. Just click on the "download now" button and it will be copied to your hard disk. Then use a scanner or a digital camera to capture a series of small images which you wish to animate. The software will ask you what order you want the images in and how long you want to delay between each frame.

How might voice-recognition software help my students?

The Becta trials showed that, if students have some success with voice-to-text work, the knock-on effect was often to improve performance generally. One student with illegible handwriting now writes well and legibly, mainly because he was able to use voice to make that initial breakthrough and get his words down on paper.

How can I make my own digital movies of work in school?

The easiest way is via a DV (digital video) camcorder, such as the Canon MV20. First write your storyboard and film some short clips. Next, use a computer that can be linked directly to the DV camera using a FireWire cable and some software to carry out the editing. Apple iMac DV machines come with all this as standard and they seem to work well straight out of the box. PC users will need to fit a DVcard, such as the Pinnacle, and some editing software, such as Adobe Premiere. If you save your final movies as QuickTime files, you can send them around the school network.

If you save your final movies as QuickTime files, you can send them around the school network.

fields.headline: Long-distance mathematics
fields.standfirst: Video conferencing gives an added dimension to teaching, allowing students access to the experts. Richard Doughty sits in on an A-level maths class
fields.trailText: Video conferencing gives an added dimension to teaching, allowing students access to the experts. Richard Doughty sits in on an A-level maths class
fields.body:
A babble of nervous voices a quick call to order and then the immortal "and it's over to you at Cambridge". Thus begins a unique video conference.

The nervous voices belong to 25 first-year A-level maths students from five inner London schools. "You at Cambridge" is Dr Helen Mason, one of the UK's sharpest minds in mathematics and 100 miles away on the end of a phone line. She is giving the first part of a video conference on her specialist subject: the sun and waves.

Do they know, for instance, that the sun emits more energy per second than humans have used since the beginning of civilisation? Or that a mass ejection of energy and gases from the sun once knocked out the Telstar satellite while it was used to broadcast Star Wars.

The 90-minute two-way session at John Kelly Girls' Technology College, Dollis Hill in north-west London, is sponsored by Nesta (National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts). It is part of the Millennium Maths "Motivate" project, an education through video conferencing scheme that links top mathematicians with secondary schools to inspire pupils to aim for the top in their subject.

In an initial 20-minute session, Dr Mason talks about her work and how she became a mathematician, mentions her part in the recent discovery of solar tornados and how maths has enabled her to estimate how hot the sun is.

Diagrams, pictures and movies are projected on a wall screen via two dedicated ISDN lines linked to a video-conferencing machine at each end of the link.

Questions flow from the floor: "How did you overcome difficulties as a woman student and will it be easier for us now?" asks Lila Harrar, 17, from John Kelly.

The answer: "What I did find difficult was people thinking I was strange doing maths, because I didn't find it strange. It's something I enjoy doing. If you enjoy doing maths and science you should do it."

"Why does the sun move at its poles and equator at different rates?" asks another.

"I'll have to check on that," says Dr Mason. "See if you can find out before next time."

At the end of the session, interposed with short breaks, the magic of face-to-face contact is already working. "You see what she's achieved, how far she has gone in her career, how motivated she is," says Lila, who was seriously considering medicine before the conference, but is now contemplating maths at university.

"I thought it would just be teaching and not such deep research. Now I think I should look at this area."

In the month between the initial session and a talkback conference, the real work is done when each group of pupils goes away to complete maths challenges set by Dr Mason, including work on the internet, and then present them to her and the other pupils. (A video is made of the conferences to be used as a teaching aid with other pupils at the participating schools.)

Four hectic weeks of work later, results of investigations into waveforms and wave motion using trigonometric equations have been pulled together and presented at the talkback conference. Here, students from each of the five schools make a 10-minute presentation in their teams, via a video-link to Dr Mason in Cambridge.

Second time round, the pupils seem unaffected by the eminent mathematician's virtual presence. Poonam Gokal, 17, from John Kelly is typical of many of her peers. "It was good to work with physics students who helped me understand the application of the mathematics. I could put that together with my maths knowledge.

"It's great to have such a strong link between John Kelly Girls and Cambridge University." For Dita Patel it was a more personal experience: "I have become more confident in talking in a group. The whole thing has been a terrific opportunity for real team work."

The John Kelly team's PowerPoint presentation with the help of A-level IT colleagues is a real hit. "It was impressive and would be the envy of many a corporation executive!" the schools ICT coordinator, Chris Drage, says later.

And the project is not only benefiting A-level students. Following the inaugural video conference last November on fractals for GCSE students given by Cambridge's Dr Alan Beardon, 14-year-old Noor Al-Naseri says she has been "inspired a lot. Alan is really famous and he's linked with his maths. You could do the same thing."

John Kelly's head of maths, Nigel Martin, has noticed a marked change afterwards at a school that has half its intake on free school meals and 70% with English as a second language. "There was an incredibly improved motivation among the GCSE pupils, reflected in the amount of work they actually produced.

"The project adds glamour to maths, allowing the students to see it as having real purpose, not just learning routines to pass exams."

For more details on the project and the remaining three pilot conferences, see www.mmp.maths.org.uk/ mmp-motivate.html The website is full of advice and includes an Ask a Mathematician answering service to help pupils with their set tasks. See also Dr Helen Joyce, Cambridge University School of Education, email: hjj24@cam.ca.uk or tel: 01223 472600.

 Additional research by Chris Drage

fields.headline: It's the latest thing
fields.standfirst: George Cole reviews some of the innovative developments to be found at this year's Education Show
fields.trailText: George Cole reviews some of the innovative developments to be found at this year's Education Show
fields.body:
The recent flurry of announcements on free internet phone charges will throw the spotlight on online resources as never before at this week's Education Show, to be held at Birmingham's National Exhibition Centre (March 23-25).

The main focus for the latest ICT developments will be in the show's ICT village, where you cmight kick off your visit by joining a virtual tour of the National Grid for Learning website, courtesy of the British Educational Communications and Technology Agency (stand P32). The tour also includes the Virtual Teachers Centre (VTC) site, where teachers can exchange ideas and resources. And if you are creating your own website, entry forms will still be available for the 2000 Becta/Guardian UK School and College Website Awards - over 200 institutions have applied already (see our competition page 19 for entry details).

Online services

RM (IT76) will be showing its internet access service, Internet for Learning, which now has more than 10,000 school subscribers. RM Eduweb provides resources for using the internet, and RM Living Library - used by over a third of UK schools and colleges - is an online resource service with more than two million articles that subscribers can download and use. Also there will be RM's Window Box Online, a new service offering free resources designed for the company's Window Box PC - they can also be adapted for other computers. Anglia Multimedia (IT104) will be showcasing the Anglia Campus online service it runs with BT Education Services (J50). Tag Developments (IT49) has launched Tag TeacherNet, a free internet service for teachers, while internet service provider DIALnet (IT45) will be demonstrating learnall.net, an online community which offers news, content and management resources to teachers, pupils and parents.

Software

Crick Software (IT72) says it's pleased with the response to its Clicker Grids for Learning Online service, which offers free resources for its range of access software. The resources have been developed by Crick and by teachers.The word processor in Crick Software's Clicker 4 converts text to HTML, the computer language used to create internet content. As a result, pupils can easily create content for a school website. Clicker 4 also includes a new type of spellchecker which offers synonyms, and can be customised by teachers.

SCET's (IT100) SCETNet series puts web resources on to a CD-Rom, saving schools online costs. One new title, Food Technology, has proved to be very popular. SCET will also have classic titles such as Writers' Toolkit and Let's Go with Katy.

Sherston Software (IT138) will be showing three new CD-Roms developed with Oxford University Press. The titles are aimed at infant literacy lessons and have stories and activities which use multimedia.

Granada Learning's (IT65) Primary Branch is a binary branching database program, which helps pupils classify and sort information. Among the offerings from BlackCat (IT73) is the Number, Words and Pictures infant toolbox, which has five components including a word processor, data handling software and a graphics program.

InSound, which can be seen on Inclusive Technology's stand (IT74), is a phonics program which uses a computer to print out worksheets and mark them. Inclusive is also showing UltraKey4, a video-quality typing tutor program.

Network management

Europress (H48) has a new network management system, which enables teachers to customise software to suit their pupils' needs.

Semerc (IT65) has launched a revised version of its popular Microworlds program, which offers a wide range of educational activities and exercises.

The popular multimedia authoring package HyperStudio will be on Tag's stand, along with the company's IT Matters packages. These are designed to help teachers get to grips with topics such as the internet and multimedia, and use CD-Roms and printed material.

And don't forget E-beam, claimed by its manufacturer, Xerox (F35), to digitise writing and images automatically from a flip chart or whiteboard and transfer them to a PC. The information can then be used in processors, spreadsheets and email. In schools, E-beam lecture notes can apparently be broadcast in real time to remote students, easing distance learning via the web. Xerox says the software enables people to take part in a meeting held anywhere and then contribute by annotating or editing text and drawings online.

Training

ICT teacher training is a hot topic and the New Opportunities Fund (L43), which is managing the IT training initiative, will be present, as will some of the companies offering teacher training programmes, including RM and Anglia Multimedia.

Some companies involved in the Computers for Teachers scheme, which offers teachers a rebate on computer purchases, will also be at the show including Akther (M23) and Viglen (IT 90). The latter will also be demonstrating the Incepta PC, which conforms to the Easy PC standard. These machines are smaller than standard desktop PCs, offering faster start-up times and plug-and-play connectivity with devices such as printers and scanners.

Teem (Teachers Evaluating Education Multimedia) will be running a series of first-come, first-served, 10-minute "multimedia in practice" training sessions, on the hour from 11pm to 3pm each day. Visitors will be able to try out software being evaluated by Teem and find out how to become a software evaluator themselves.

The future

If you want tomorrow's software today, check out Immersive's stand (IT47). The stand has been designed by the creator of the Red Dwarf sets, and the company is promising to unveil some highly sophisticated products.

fields.headline: Integrated learning
fields.standfirst: New developments in ICT allow special needs students to become involved in whole-class teaching, as John Davitt finds out
fields.trailText: New developments in ICT allow special needs students to become involved in whole-class teaching, as John Davitt finds out
fields.body:
There comes a moment in the lives of many students with learning difficulties when they feel they will never understand the subject under discussion. They often switch off, shut down or go "mentally absent" from future lessons. And they will form most of the 12% who will leave education with no exam qualifications. New targets set for failing schools may isolate these children still further as the focus tightens on a narrow cohort of potential D-graders who can be nudged up to a grade C.

Faced with such difficulties, you could simplify work, reduce amounts and use larger text. But in reality these students may benefit from an alternative approach. At times it might be better not to make it simpler but different.

If ICT is to help us make a real difference for students with learning difficulties, it won't be through the increasing provision of printed pages or websites stuffed with text. The future learning environment must give the oral and graphical an equal place alongside text if these students are to benefit.

Until now it's been difficult to include these resources in normal work, but things are improving. Voice-recognition software has finally come of age and certain students will be liberated by the opportunity to speak their thoughts. After 12 minutes' training, the new IBM software, ViaVoice, was returning stunning levels of accuracy. At a recent conference, I gave a short opening address into the machine and counted only two errors.

There are also many examples of electronic writing frames and support software where students can compose written work by clicking on a storehouse of words and phrases. This moves them forward from the blank page and gives them the confidence to get started as well as a sense of achievement.

Crick's new Wordbar, leading on from the excellent Clicker, is one of the most powerful recent additions to this stable. Wordbar sits across the bottom of the computer screen and offers instant point and click access to banks of words and phrases.

Teachers also need the chance to experiment with graphical tools which will give students alternative points of access in a text-ridden curriculum. Software such as Inspiration allows visual mapping to replace text, allowing you to build boxes to represent key points. These boxes can then be filled with pictures and text and links established to other ideas. It's an ideal summary device, and linked to a large screen display it provides a whole-class thinking and review tool.

Some headteachers and advisers in Hammersmith recently used the software as part of a course on 21st-century learning. "Absolutely brilliant" was the verdict as the key issues of the training were displayed along with images and comments from the day in one easy-to-follow concept map.

Perhaps the most innovative alternative to text-only learning is being pioneered by Little Heath school in Redbridge where they have set up their own radio station to run across the school network. Students act as disc jockeys and splice dedications between digital move files in standard MP3 format. These can be broadcast live or saved for later transmission. Teachers are recording two-minute "homework help" programmes to which the students listen avidly. The aim is to move towards a talk-radio format where staff and students will prepare talk shows on curriculum areas.

All the tools to get you up and running are available free on the internet. Visit www. shoutcast.com and follow the guidance on setting up your own digital radio station.

Clicker & Wordbar from Crick Software, Inspiration from iANSYST Ltd, predictive writers, writing frames and speech software from Semerc, and Inclusive Technology.

fields.headline: Getting equipped for real action
fields.standfirst: Computers aren't necessarily a short cut to teaching students with special needs. Here John Bald reviews hardware and software that can really make a difference
fields.trailText: Computers aren't necessarily a short cut to teaching students with special needs. Here John Bald reviews hardware and software that can really make a difference
fields.body:
If you want to use ICT to help children with special needs, the last thing you need is a room full of computers loaded with someone else's solution to their problems. What you do need is a clear understanding of what is preventing these children from learning, a knowledge of successful teaching strategies, some useful software and free access to a machine you know will work. Adding a small section to Individual Education Plans for notes on ICT support puts the whole exercise on a systematic footing.

The computer need not be sophisticated - you can do a great deal with a BBC, the Folio word processor (LDA) and a concept keyboard. But you need a printer, and it often helps with group work to have a device to connect the computer to a television set. The VGA adaptor from Pineapple Software (020-8500 1476, £150) works well, though it can be fiddly to set up first time.

The single most useful item is the word processor. You can type in children's work, use the arrow keys or mouse and enter key to isolate errors or points for development on the screen, and then work on them so that pupils understand their error and how to avoid it in future.

Next, put the text back together again and print it off. The word processor, in effect, allows you to mould text on the screen like clay, smoothing and shaping as you go, and explaining all the time.

You can add words with similar spelling patterns to the foot of the sheet, to help children who do not perceive patterns in spelling without support. The print-out gives children a psychological boost, and the whole process allows you to correct work thoroughly without covering it in red ink.

Clicker (Crick Computing, 01604 671691, for Mac and PC) uses the bottom half of a computer screen as a grid, into which you can insert any words you choose. Clicking on the words inserts them into a word processor on the top half of the grid, and children form sentences by clicking on the words. They do not have to write each word by hand, and so can focus entirely on meaning. This has been used successfully to teach early writing in modern languages. Clicker will read words or sentences back to you, and you can record your own voice as an alternative to an artificial one. If you have time to prepare the overlays, though, you can obtain similar results from a simpler computer and a concept keyboard. Concept keyboards are versatile, and can also work with later computers.

Voice-operated software is now a viable option for people with the most difficult writing problems, though it still takes longer to tune in to individual voices than the "out of the box" recognition routinely claimed by the manufacturers.

The millennium version of IBM's Via-Voice (widely available, from £39.99) has reduced training time to around 20 minutes, and includes a new and amusing training story based on a teenager who is not enjoying doing his homework. This is still too sophisticated for children who have problems with reading as well as writing, though, and we need additional training routes with simpler vocabulary.

Given time and determination, you can bypass the training system on most voice-operated systems by having the child dictate one word at a time into the word processor from scratch, and accepting an intensive period of correction in the early stages.

Specialist keyboards produced by PCD Maltron (see left) (020-8398 3265) plug into a desktop computer, and have enabled many adults to hold down jobs which require IT skills, and should be more widely used to help children with physical disabilities.

For children who are clumsy at writing, including those with dyspraxia, a touch-sensitive pad with Claude and Maude (Granada/Semerc, 0161 827 2887, £36, pad extra) teaches letter formation by demonstrating good shapes for letters without penalising children when they stray. The limited research evidence available suggests that literacy programs are best used in conjunction with a teacher or adult, who can discuss work and explain it, but that children can reinforce their maths skills independently, provided they start at the right point.

The best thought-out program for special needs is Numbershark (020-8748 5127, £60), which offers 30 games covering all combinations in arithmetic, supported by a good system of rewards. The style is basic, but children enjoy using the program, and the timer really helps sharpen up mental arithmetic. Numbershark supports most of the learning targets in the National Numeracy Strategy (its companion Wordshark, £60, has good word-level work for literacy).

Broderbund's Maths Workshops (01429 273029, £15) and the maths games in Microsoft's Home Tutor 5-7 (widely available, approx £30) also have attactive and effective games, though you need to run each program through carefully first to make sure that they are working at the right level. Having these programs set up permanently, perhaps in the library or special needs resource centre, with regular 20-minute sessions for each pupil, can make a real impact on problems with basic maths.

Philip Teare, the creator of Instines (0771 5725090, CD-Rom £50), describes himself as "severely dyslexic", and considers the main problem most people in his position face is having their condition identified. He has therefore put together a series of tests and activities typically used to assess patterns of reading and spelling difficulty associated with dyslexia, and published it in two formats - one for adults, already sold to institutions including GCHQ, and this version, for children aged 12 upwards.

The activities consist of patterns similar to those in IQ tests, word and spelling recognition, and some puzzles. The digit span test, in which you have to remember sequences of numbers which are either called out to you or flashed on to the screen, is particularly consistent in this format, and you can improve your score by grouping the numbers together as they are called out. Users may answer three levels of questions, depending on how specific their query is. If the search proves fruitless, users can email an expert or are pointed towards a suitable online discussion group.

Adding a small section to Individual Education Plans for notes on ICT support puts the whole exercise on a systematic footing. The computer need not be sophisticated - you can do a great deal with a BBC, the Folio word processor (LDA) and a concept keyboard. fields.headline: U-turn over tax
fields.standfirst: Fierce criticism has made the government alter plans to tax its Computers for Teachers scheme. Report by Jack Schofield
fields.trailText: Fierce criticism has made the government alter plans to tax its Computers for Teachers scheme. Report by Jack Schofield
fields.body:
Teachers who buy computers for home use under the government's Computers for Teachers scheme will not have to pay tax under the "benefit in kind" rules, the DfEE announced on Friday.

The £20m project was launched by learning and technology minister Michael Wills in January. It covers half the cost of buying a computer for home use, up to a maximum of £500. The scheme is open only to teachers in state schools in England who are being given training in information and communications technology and newly-qualified teachers.

However, not all teachers taking up the offer appreciated that the tax authorities would regard the grant as a taxable benefit and claw back some of the cash. This also meant the government was giving cash with one hand and taking it back with another.

The DfEE has now decided to pay the tax bill directly - though the government will still get some of its money back through the VAT included in the purchase price.

Michael Wills said: "Computers for Teachers was set up to provide a worry-free way into new technology for teachers. We are now building on this success: taking out any worries about tax by paying tax and National Insurance liabilities centrally will help ensure the scheme fulfils its original aim of providing teachers with a worry-free way in to new technology."

Becta, the British Educational Communications and Technology Agency, confirmed that the scheme was running successfully. Becta maintains a website offering information about the scheme and lists accredited computer suppliers. While details about the brands and models are not being divulged - it's commercially confidential - the agency says more than 7,000 computers have so far been bought under the scheme.

Suppliers have now broadened the range of models on offer. It includes both desktop and portable computers, and Apple Macintosh computers as well as PCs running Microsoft Windows. The list is updated each month.

The scheme is "cash limited" and will end in 2002. But a DfEE spokesperson said if funds were exhausted before the end of the scheme, the department would look at the situation again. Many commercial companies have encouraged staff to use computers at home, often by selling them obsolete office computers for nominal sums. This is usually not an option in British schools where obsolete machines may be kept in use beyond their give-away date.

However, in the US, companies are starting to see the value of supplying workers with up-to-date machines suitable for use on the internet. On March 7, Intel, the world's largest maker of computer chips, announced a Home PC programme to provide every employee world-wide with a "high end" PC.

Intel plans to start delivering PCs to the homes of more than 70,000 employees in the autumn, and will run a "refresh" programme to keep them up-to-date.

fields.headline: Report jeopardises RBS-NatWest deal
fields.trailText: The Cruickshank banking review could throw a spanner in the works of the £21bn Royal Bank of Scotland-NatWest merger announced last month.
fields.body:
The Cruickshank banking review could throw a spanner in the works of the £21bn Royal Bank of Scotland-NatWest merger announced last month.

Don Cruickshank, head of the review team, yesterday called on the government to clamp down on "anti-competitive mergers" in the banking industry, and indicated he believed the RBS-NatWest link-up should be referred to the competition commission.

Both institutions are leading players in the provision of banking services to small businesses, a market which is already very concentrated - NatWest, Barclays, Lloyds TSB and HSBC hold more than 80% of all small and medium-sized enterprises accounts.

NatWest and RBS have a especially strong presence in the north-west of England.

Mr Cruickshank said he would expect the merger "to be of particular interest to the competition commission" if the government decided to follow his recommendations.

The review document recommends "a stronger policy framework for government's approach to banking services which prevents anti-competitive mergers in the banking industry". In their reform of merger law, ministers should ensure that the proposed new competition-based test for assessing mergers takes full account of a range of factors so as to ensure consumers receive a fair share of the benefits.

In the meantime, the government should refer all mergers between financial institutions to the competition commission.

Main points

The Cruickshank review also recommends:

1. Regulating the payment systems operated by the banks such as cash machine networks, and the clearing scheme for cheques. The review proposes that banks wishing to be part of a payment system would have to obtain a licence from the Treasury. It suggests the creation of a new regulator, PayCom, which would be independent of the industry and other regulators, whose job it would be to monitor compliance with this new regime.

2. That the government should consider setting up an independent "financial services consumer council" covering all financial services. "There is a need for a strong, independent consumer voice at the heart of the regulatory system," it states.

3. Improving the complaint-handling procedures both for personal and small business customers, with "clear and objective standards" for banks to be judged against.

webTitle: Prepare to land the right place

fields.headline: Prepare to land the right place
fields.standfirst: Thinking about university? Try a Guardian/UCAS fair, advises  John Beckett
fields.trailText: Thinking about university? Try a Guardian/UCAS fair, advises John Beckett
fields.body:
The Exeter higher education convention this week is one of a network of 50 events, coordinated by Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS) and the Guardian in association with the Higher Education Liaison Officers Association. Last week there was another two-day event in London, all part of a nation-wide trek for many of the schools and education liaison officers from universities and colleges.

At Exeter, a major event, over 125 unis and colleges will be represented and around 9,500 students are expected to arrive from all parts of the south-west.

They are important for higher education institutions, perhaps not so much for the vanloads of prospectuses handed out, but for presenting a welcoming face to prospective students and their parents.

But what about the student? How best can she/he use this event? It's a great way of getting important information about your future plans quickly but it can also be a daunting and somewhat overwhelming experience with the danger of your ending up more confused than when you started. The timing of the Spring fair in Exeter is good as it comes just at the time most advisers are encouraging their students to get their teeth into the research process. It is, after all, only six months until the completed UCAS application form has to be submitted.

The higher education adviser's nightmare scenario - "what not to do as a visiting student" - will no doubt be in evidence this week at Exeter. It goes like this: on arrival our keen student gratefully accepts some plastic bags from the sponsors and then stuffs them and personal rucksack with prospectuses. After a painful journey home, a personal higher education library is installed in one corner of the room. But sadly it may remain unread.

A much better approach is to prepare thoroughly beforehand. Try to concentrate on a small number of unis and colleges in which you know you have an interest. Collect the prospectus, sure, but have some questions ready to ask.

These could be about the course content, the entry requirements, the accommodation or graduate destinations from your chosen course. Even if you don't get a direct, immediate answer, you'll be put in touch with someone (usually the admissions tutor) who can give you the specific information you require. Often you will find yourself speaking to a recent graduate, now employed by the uni or college, who can give you the up-to-date picture of what student life is really like at that college. Think of questions you'd like to ask them - maybe about money, accommodation, the academic workload, student life in general.

A new innovation this year is the UCAS/Guardian Education Convention card, a kind of smart card. A number of schools and colleges are taking part in this pilot project. Pupils have already completed a registration form and have just received their individualised card. At the convention a member of staff from the university will enter the card into a card reader and magically, over the following months, provide the interested student with all the relevant, focused admissions information.

Around half of the unis at Exeter are participating and the scheme should allow them to inform students about such crucial events as open days but also enable them to send more targeted information to potential applicants. Organisers and sponsors will also be able to analyse attendance to help the planning of future conventions.

What are the big issues? Although the "new" curriculum or Curriculum 2000 doesn't actually start until September and will have a minimal effect on those applying for entry to higher education in 2001, there may well be queries for the higher education reps from year 11 visitors (and their parents) trying to plan what courses and subjects to follow during the two years of advanced level study.

Money is a heavy influence on course and institution choice and even on whether higher education can be afforded at all. Tuition fees and loans still confuse many and the question "what about grants?" is often heard. Seminars about student life and fees and loans will be well worth attending as well as those on the whole UCAS application process and specific subject-based talks. Many consider a "year out" before going to university, maybe working, travelling, resting or a mixture of all three! Visiting the Year Out stand is a must if you are planning to do that.

Student checklist

 Concentrate on 8-10 universities.
 Head straight for them.
 Prepare 2-3 questions to ask each
 Grab any recent graduates there
 Only spend 60-90 minutes doing this. Have a break or return later - it's tiring wandering around in circles.
 See the convention as part of your research, not as the whole answer.
 Follow up with phone calls/open days/interviews with your teacher or adviser over the following weeks.
 Don't let the dust settle!

 John Beckett is a higher education adviser.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our article about George Best, page 2, Sport, March 11, we mistakenly referred to "his former agent Murdo McLeod". Best's former agent was Bill McMurdo. Apologies for any confusion or embarrassment.
fields.body:
In our article about George Best, page 2, Sport, March 11, we mistakenly referred to "his former agent Murdo McLeod". Best's former agent was Bill McMurdo. Apologies for any confusion or embarrassment.

The sculpture to be unveiled on the former US air base at Greenham Common (our picture, page 8, yesterday) is by Michael Kenny (not Kelly).

In our report about the return of the Lindisfarne gospels to the north-east, page 5, yesterday, we said the gospels were exhibited in Newcastle in 1996, "for the first time since being seized in the 16th century". We should, perhaps, have pointed out that they had been shown in the late 1980s at Durham Cathedral.

In our obituary of Thomas Ferebee, page 22, yesterday, we said that President Truman had described the A-bomb as the "harmonising of the basic power of the universe". He said "the harnessing of the basic power ..." etc.

In our review of the weekend's television, page 22, G2, yesterday, we described [Vic] Reeves and [Bob] Mortimer as the Tyneside Two. The Teesside Two would have been closer (but not quite right either). Vic Reeves comes from Darlington (on the River Skerne) and Bob Mortimer from Middlesbrough (on the Tees). In the same review, the programme Correspondent was given to Channel 4 when it belongs to BBC 2. In reviewing it we referred to the jungle of southern Columbia when we meant Colombia.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Retreat over 'racist' bonds test
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Plans to test a controversial bonds scheme on visitors from the Indian subcontinent were dropped last night by the government.
fields.body:
Plans to test a controversial bonds scheme on visitors from the Indian subcontinent were dropped last night by the government.

The proposal to force visitors from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh to provide a guarantee of £5,000, if immigration officials believed they may be planning to settle illegally, has been bitterly criticised.

Though the government says the idea will still be tested in an undecided country, opponents hope this is the first step towards ditching what they regarded as a racist measure which would have discriminated against poorer visitors.

Critics ranging from leftwing Labour MP Jeremy Corbyn to Tory candidate for London mayor, Steve Norris, had attacked the plan, which emerged in January. Labour's mayoral team of Frank Dobson and running-mate Trevor Phillips have also voiced disquiet, until now in private.

Mr Phillips said last night: "In going around London people have expressed deep concern about the scheme to me, partly because they feel it would be unfairly targeted on the people from the subcontinent, partly because they feel it would be difficult to implement."

He hoped the change would give ministers "space to think very carefully about whether they want to apply it to anybody at all". There were alternatives, including some kind of guarantor scheme whereby relatives resident in Britain would agree to pay a fine if the visitor did not leave the country by the required date, Mr Phillips said.

Foreign Office minister Keith Vaz, who faced hostile questioning about the plan when it was revealed while he was on an official trip to India, announced the change last night.

There has been anger that the Indian subcontinent, from where thousands of visitors - often with very little money - come to Britain every year for weddings and other family ceremonies, were being singled out by the pilot scheme.

A Foreign Office spokesman said last night: "If the pilot scheme is successful we should consider whether it should go ahead or not. All we are considering at the moment is a pilot scheme."

Labour MP Barry Gardiner, who held a Commons adjournment debate on entry clearance operations last night, said he hoped the government would drop the idea "because it's flawed".

He said the decision on admitting someone should be decided by whether, on the balance of probabilities, they were likely to break the terms of their visa, regardless of whether or not they could afford to put up the bond.

Immigration officials would have to devote disproportionate time to considering borderline, complex cases under the plan, he said.

The money would have been returned to visitors if they left Britain on or before the date they were due to leave. Home Office minister Barbara Roche claimed earlier this year that the plan would allow some visitors in who might otherwise be refused entry.

The proposal to force visitors from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh to provide a guarantee of £5,000, if immigration officials believed they may be planning to settle illegally, has been bitterly criticised. Though the government says the idea will still be tested in an undecided country, opponents hope this is the first step towards ditching what they regarded as a racist measure which would have discriminated against poorer visitors. Critics ranging from leftwing Labour MP Jeremy Corbyn to Tory candidate for London mayor, Steve Norris, had attacked the plan, which emerged in January. Labour's mayoral team of Frank Dobson and running-mate Trevor Phillips have also voiced disquiet, until now in private. Mr Phillips said last night: "In going around London people have expressed deep concern about the scheme to me, partly because they feel it would be unfairly targeted on the people from the subcontinent, partly because they feel it would be difficult to implement." He hoped the change would give ministers "space to think very carefully about whether they want to apply it to anybody at all". There were alternatives, including some kind of guarantor scheme whereby relatives resident in Britain would agree to pay a fine if the visitor did not leave the country by the required date, Mr Phillips said. Foreign Office minister Keith Vaz, who faced hostile questioning about the plan when it was revealed while he was on an official trip to India, announced the change last night. There has been anger that the Indian subcontinent, from where thousands of visitors - often with very little money - come to Britain every year for weddings and other family ceremonies, were being singled out by the pilot scheme. A Foreign Office spokesman said last night: "If the pilot scheme is successful we should consider whether it should go ahead or not. All we are considering at the moment is a pilot scheme." Labour MP Barry Gardiner, who held a Commons adjournment debate on entry clearance operations last night, said he hoped the government would drop the idea "because it's flawed". fields.headline: BBC films moment of death
fields.standfirst:
Wildlife series uses sports technology to capture predator attacks in highlight of new TV schedule

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: First there was wicket-cam, then there was player-cam, now natural history producers have muscled in on the technological advances available to sports, and created eagle-cam, wolf-cam and cheetah-cam.
fields.body:
First there was wicket-cam, then there was player-cam, now natural history producers have muscled in on the technological advances available to sports, and created eagle-cam, wolf-cam and cheetah-cam.

The BBC's natural history unit has borrowed the techniques of television sport to harness miniaturised cameras to some of the world's most elusive animals. Using a combination of eagle-cam, slow-motion replay, computer animation and reverse-angle filming, producers can for the first time show exactly what occurs when a predator alights on its prey.

The footage will be screened in Predators, a five-part BBC1 series beginning in May. The highlight of the series is film which captures the split-second moment when the predator pounces or the prey escapes.

Producers and cameramen spent months experimenting with miniaturised cameras and lightweight harnesses, finally reducing the weight of camera, harness, transmitter, battery and two aerials to a mere four ounces, so that the animal would be able to act normally.

These second generation animal-cams are so light the wearer does not notice their presence - previous television experiments have attached a camera to an eagle, but it was so heavy the bird could do little more than fly.

David Wallace, the series producer of Predators, said: "It will be the first time you will ever see an eagle attack a mouse because the cameras are getting so small now that it's practical to do these things in a way that the animals don't notice."

Having got the shots, the team had to slow the footage by up to 100 times to be able to make out the moment of impact, such is the speed of the animals' movements.

"We have used multiple angles, slow motion and the on-board perspective of eagle-cam to tell the story," Mr Wallace said.

Predators forms part of BBC1's £242m spring and summer schedule, announced yesterday by the channel's controller, Peter Salmon.

Mr Salmon, who had asked for an extra £100m on the channel's budget, said he expected to have more money to spend on programmes.

"My hope, and the omens are good, is that in the very near future BBC1 will have more money and more resources for more seasons as original and diverse as the one we are launching today," he said.

"We have a new director-general, a new licence fee settlement and a new TV world," he added.

"There is a real and tangible sense of excitement and adventure at the BBC," he claimed. "Everything is possible."

Greg Dyke, the BBC director general, has made it clear in his first few months in charge that he intends to cut the costs of management and bureaucracy at the corporation and divert funds into programme making.

Spring highlights

Drama
Already dubbed the BBC's answer to Friends, the comedy drama Hearts and Bones follows a group of friends from the Midlands as they move to London. The cast of impossibly glamorous thirtysomethings includes Dervla Kirwan and Hugo Speer.

Border Cafe, a witty drama series set on the Welsh border, is the story of a pop star who quits her life of fame to run a cafe. It is written by Tim Firth, creator of Preston Front.

Comedy
The Radio 4 series Chambers transfers to BBC1 with Sarah Lancashire, John Bird and James Fleet as three barristers sharing offices.

Alistair McGowan gets his own series, impersonating, among others, Michael Owen and Pierce Brosnan.

Factual
The BBC pinches an ITV idea with 7 Up 2000, following seven-year-olds as they grow up in a long-running series.

Two new science and natural history programmes are Cousins - about primates - and Phobias, examining fear.

Sport
The BBC is pitching itself as the home of Euro 2000, though ITV shares the rights. Among the sports highlights is a new Sunday morning football show, Football Fever, aimed at children.

fields.headline: Microsoft to sell news site
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft and NBC, the American network television channel, are in talks to spin off MSNBC, their cable joint venture which provides an online news service.
fields.body:
Microsoft and NBC, the American network television channel, are in talks to spin off MSNBC, their cable joint venture which provides an online news service.

An MSNBC spokeswoman said yesterday that the idea for an initial public offering of the company had "been under discussion for quite a while". If the IPO goes ahead, the partners are expected to float the online part of the joint venture, which is far more popular than the cable television operations.

Microsoft and NBC, a wholly owned subsidiary of General Electric, are understood to have appointed investment bankers several months ago to look at "different ways to maximise their investments".

MSNBC was started in July 1996, well before the current vogue for partnerships between media and technology companies. An IPO could happen within the next few months if both sides agree to a new ownership structure.

However, analysts have questioned the timing of a spin-off at a time when online news providers have lost some of their early lustre. TheStreet.comT, a financial news site, is trading near 52- week lows amid signs of increased competition from traditional rivals. Other sites such as MarketWatch, which has been linked to TheStreet.com in takeover rumours, have also lost some of their earlier stock market momentum.

MSNBC.com is the most widely watched online news service, according to Media Metrix, the internet research group. It attracted 8.2m visitors in January while its nearest rival, CNN.com, attracted 4.7m.

The company offers links to content provided by other NBC services such as CNBC, the financial cable channel, and NBC Sports. Through a part nership with the Washington Post announced last year, the site also includes content from one of the US's leading newspapers and Newsweek. A sell-off would continue Microsoft's strategy of giving up total control of its web offerings. Last year, it sold Sidewalk and spun off Expedia, the travel site.

The company has also announced several partnerships to improve its online offerings in recent months.

Yesterday, it trumpeted a three-year partnership with Compaq to promote MSN, its internet service, on the computer manufacturer's Presario range of personal computers. The alliance with Compaq, one of the largest computer hardware companies, follows similar promotional arrangements with RadioShack and other retailers to promote the internet access service NBC has a separately traded online company called NBCi.

In a separate development, Microsoft's lobbying efforts have come under scrutiny from a New York-based watchdog. The Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, which is 24 years old, has asked the company to explain why it provided an inaccurate list of attendees at a dinner it hosted last November.

The guests at the Old Homestead steak house in downtown New York, who appear to have been left out of the official list sent to the regulator, included local politician John Faso and some staffers from New York mayor Rudolph Guiliani's office.

Microsoft said the issue was due to a human error about who had accepted the invitations and who had not. But the investigation underlines the fact that its lobbying efforts, stepped up last year as it faced anti-monopoly charges in court, have come under increasing scrutiny during an election year.

fields.headline: Sacking, Picking and Cooking
fields.trailText: OWL, THAT HURTS
fields.body:
OWL, THAT HURTS

"Danny's a lovely fellow, a wonderful fellow. But players know a manager, they can spot him in six matches. They know the good ones, the ones who can do it... It finished up with the players just playing how they liked." Bit too long for a motto, and you can't really imagine Danny Wilson hanging it over his fireplace, but this is the assessment of Wilson's tenure as Sheffield Wednesday manager by big-mouth MP Joe Ashton.

Wilson was sacked this morning after a fairly ignominious season was capped by Saturday's defeat at Watford. Despite repeated board backing, especially from recently-departed chairman Dave Richards, the highlights of Wilson's season include: verbal slanging matches with Paolo Di Canio, Benito Carbone and half the Houses of Parliament; the cut-price sale of Emerson Thome; an 8-0 defeat by Newcastle; a 3-1 FA Cup defeat by Gillingham; and an average attendance of just over 23,000 at 40,000 capacity Hillsborough.

Wilson is yet to comment on his dismissal. But, according to League Manager's chief John Barnwell, no less, he is "extremely distressed" at the decision. Peter Shreeves is thought to be more cheery. Shreeves, first team coach at Hillsborough under David Pleat, will, not for the first time in his life, take charge of first team affairs on a temporary basis. Rumours are already spreading (there goes one now) that Howard Wilkinson will step into the Owlseat in the summer. After all, he's got teams out of the First Division before.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

LOOK AT THIS

Economist.com - Forthright opinion and lively analysis of global politics and business, plus handy summaries of the week's news. www.economist.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HOWARD'S WAY

England Under-21 coach Howard Wilkinson understands international football alright. "If you have any aspirations to win anything at some stage along the line, you have to qualify for tournaments," he explains with a knowing nod and a wink. To this end, he's come up with the clever ploy of naming his strongest squad in an attempt to win the vital European Championship tournament qualification play-off match against Yugoslavia. He doesn't miss a trick does Wilko.

Despite looking like a right miserable get, Wilko loves a laugh and a joke as much as the next man - so he's named Emile Heskey, Rio Ferdinand, Kieron Dyer, Steven Gerrard, Michael Bridges, Gareth Barry and Frank Lampard in his squad for the March 29 match. Some of these lads may be in with a shout for Kelvin Koogan's Euro 2000 squad which will be named less than a fortnight later, but that doesn't matter. According to the perceptive Wilko, it's important to get to the U-21 finals so the players who don't make the grown-up squad get as much tournament experience as possible.

This new approach is very clever. How did you come up with such an enlightened plan of no little genius? "Experience in tournaments and winning tournaments is something we have not had a lot of in this country," the least dour Yorkshireman you're ever likely to meet elucidated. "It's invaluable. Tournament football is the ultimate test at international level. There is no other way of getting the experience you need." In other words, we've just decided that it's best for the future of English football if we try our best to win the games we play. Hold on... so what were we doing last season?

The rest of the squad: Ball (Everton), Carragher (Liverpool), Chadwick (Man Utd), Cole (West Ham), Cort (Wimbledon), Curtis (Man Utd), Harley (Chelsea), Hendrie (Aston Villa), Johnson (Derby), Mills (Leeds), Morris (Chelsea), Robinson (Leeds), Smith (Leeds), Weaver (Man City), Wright (Ipswich), Young (Tottenham).

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I reckon it is high time that women were given a go in the middle. As long as it's someone who can handle pressure situations, then why not?" An open-minded Ian Wright in The Sun. By "pressure situations" we presume he means petulant past-it strikers bawling in officials' eardrums.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE DELIA SMITH INSTITUTE

What a topsy-turvy world we live in. The Fiver's sister publication, the Spatula ("your tiffin-time take on the world of cuisine"), is reeling in shock this afternoon after Delia Smith dumped plans for a third series of her fantastic How to Cook television show in order to concentrate her attentions on Norwich City. The Fiver meanwhile is chuffed: it scalded its forearm the last time it boiled an egg the Delia way.

Delia is the majority shareholder in Norwich City, sharing a 58% stake in the club with husband Michael Wynn Jones ("Not roasted salmon with pecorino and pesto topping again darling!?!"). Up until now she has been relatively quiet, simply sticking a new poncey menu in the club's carvery and getting Bruce Oldfield to design a new strip (design, to the Fiver's mind, being somewhat immaterial when the kit is in yellow and green). But now she's decided to get hands on.

Not that that means handouts to buy new players. Oh no. Delia, who is "not a mega- or multi-millionaire, just an ordinary one", expects the club to generate its own income through enterprises like the club's proposed new conferencing facilities (expected to known as The Delia Smith Business Centre). Only once the club start turning a profit can they expect to climb into the heady heights of, say, the top half of the First Division. If only they had some kind of money-spinning recipe book they could sell...

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leicester have been linked with a £2m bid for West Brom striker Lee Hughes. However, West Brom chairman Paul Thompson has said, "Lee Hughes is not for sale."

Everton will bid £5m for Celtic defender Alan Stubbs. Kenny Dalglish is to hold urgent talks to try to keep hold of the 28-year-old player who supported Everton as a boy.

Leeds may offer Niall Quinn the salary increase he feels he is worth, but is unlikely to get at Sunderland. Meanwhile, Sunderland are chasing Honduran striker Milton 'Tyson' Nunez. The 5'5" striker is looking for an English club after PAOK Salonika terminated his contract.

West Ham are looking to sign Lyon striker Frederic Kanoute on loan. The 22-year-old would cost £3m should Harry Redknapp then decide to make the move permanent.

Nottingham Forest are poised to sign Chelsea's 19-year-old central defender John Terry on loan.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Matt Elliott and Kevin Gallacher have been recalled by Scotland boss Craig Brown for the friendly international against France on March 29. Hibs youngster Kenny Miller has missed out, however. The full squad: Douglas (Dundee), Gould (Celtic), Sullivan (Wimbledon), Boyd (Celtic), Dailly (Blackburn), Elliott (Leicester), Hendry (Coventry), O'Neil (Wolfsburg), Ritchie (Hearts), Weir (Everton), Burley (Derby), Cameron (Hearts), Davidson (Blackburn), Ferguson (Rangers), Hutchison (Everton), Johnston (Sunderland), McNamara (Celtic), Burchill (Celtic), Dodds (Rangers), Gallacher (Newcastle), McCann (Rangers).

Ajax have fired coach Jan Wouters and appointed sporting director Hans Westerhof in his place until the end of the season.

The Belgian city of Antwerp plans to install 30 surveillance cameras in its city centre to help with security during Euro 2000. No matches are scheduled to be played in Antwerp but the city is near the Belgian-Dutch border and the cameras will be situated in "sensitive" areas where large crowds could gather.

Derby goalkeeper Russell Hoult's proposed move to Portsmouth has broken down over personal terms. The teams had agreed a £300,000 fee. Meanwhile, Pompey defender Jason Cundy has been ruled out for the rest of the season with a knee injury.

Francis Jeffers has resumed training and could be back in action for Everton early next month after missing the last eight games with ankle ligament damage.

Manchester United defender John O'Shea has returned to Old Trafford following a two-month loan spell at Bournemouth.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (10pm)

Valencia v Manchester United, and Sideshow Bob Wilson is in a right state. "Apparently everyone's getting fed up with Des. So what in God's name will everyone think of me?"

The Big Match (2.05am)

By now, panic has set in. "Even Private Eye had a go at him! Christ! They'll crucify me!!!"

Nationwide League Football Extra (3.45am)

Calm down, Bob. Just be thankful you're not Dave Beckett.

Channel 4: Football Italia (1.30am)

This is the programme the Di Marco brothers are always pretending to watch on EastEnders. They're Italian, you see.

Channel 5: Argentinian Football (4.25am)

Don't know which soap character watches this. Deirdre Barlow, maybe?

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm)

Charlie Nicholas... expert opinion... no, it still doesn't sound right.

Soccer Special (7.30pm)

Jeff Stelling - bless him - politely manages to look interested as Marsh and McLintock gripe like teething babies.

***'** ** *** ******! (10.15pm, 3.15am)

Another posting on the McCaff Message Board: "Hazel: Herds of vomit shall sweep over thee. Half past two in the morning, fish and chips. Ben." Contact the McBoard at the.boss@theguardian.com.

Sky Sports 2: First Division Football - Live (7pm, 12midnight)

Barnsley play Fulham in what should be a fugging good game.

ONsport 1: Big Cup Magazine (6.15pm)

Is this about guns?

Ongoals - The High Points (7.15pm)

Is this about drugs?

Don't Mention The Score (11.45pm)

It's the Bundesliga, you see, so they've cleverly evoked World War II in the title. You couldn't call them ignorant, could you?

Valencia v Manchester United - Live (7pm, 9.55pm ONsport 1)

Ryan Giggs injured for meaningless match. Do you think he'll be OK in time for Saturday?

ONsport 2: Fiorentina v Bordeaux (9:55pm)

Don't bother with this. If you switch over to ITV you can watch the highlights of the game you've just watched.

British Eurosport: Football (6.30pm)

Europe's best right backs. Probably won't include Richard Edghill.

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)

They've certainly spent a lot of time writing well-rounded female characters, haven't they?

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

Alan Green looks for something to moan about.

talkSPORT: Football First Big Cup Special (7pm)

Perhaps he could moan about the adverts this is peppered with.

Alvin Martin's Big Cup Phone In (10pm)

Alvin Martin? But where are the Chipmunks?

Kenny Dalglish is to hold urgent talks to try to keep hold of the 28-year-old player who supported Everton as a boy.
