fields.headline: The beat generation
fields.standfirst: Listening to music may be therapeutic - but can playing it produce even more profound results?  Stephen Moss  joins a group of musicians and dementia patients at an extraordinary concert
fields.trailText: Listening to music may be therapeutic - but can playing it produce even more profound results? Stephen Moss joins a group of musicians and dementia patients at an extraordinary concert.
fields.body:
It was perhaps the most inspiring concert I had ever attended. An unusual quartet - flute, oboe, cello, harp - joined by five nurses and seven elderly dementia patients, sitting in a circle in a room at Acton hospital in west London, improvising, developing musical ideas, finding out about each other. It was a triumph for music, the NHS and simple goodness (why am I embarrassed to use that word?).

Sinfonia 21, the resident orchestra at London's Imperial College, has just embarked on a three-year research study at Acton, called the Shimmer Project, to assess whether musical interaction - there is no other satisfactory term to describe it - can benefit dementia patients. The idea is that, rather than play a conventional programme for patients, a group of professional musicians comes in each week and plays with them, letting the patients dictate where the music goes. The patients conduct, beat drums, pluck strings, sing, engage in any way they wish. The hope is that dementia sufferers who, in some cases, have lost the capacity for coherent speech can find a new outlet through music.

The scheme is rooted in the notions of empowerment and identity. At the beginning of the one-hour session, each of the patients - all of whom are resident at Acton hospital - is asked his or her name. Some lack the confidence to say it; others can no longer remember it. By the end, the whole group is reciting each name in turn, creating a mesmerising chant that overlays the musical theme. It is a striking assertion of identity - individual and collective.

The project is a collaboration between Sinfonia 21 (whose musicians have had two years of training for work in hospitals), Music for Life (which provided the training), and a medical research team led by Christopher Bulpitt, professor of geriatric medicine at Hammersmith hospital. "Music interaction involves the response of musicians to patients and vice versa," says Prof Bulpitt. "It must be contrasted with just playing suitable music. Music may help the confused elderly person in the short term, but the hope is that interacting with musicians and the music will also produce benefits long after the music stops."

Prof Bulpitt's researchers will log patients' behaviour during and after sessions to see whether there is any change. The hope is that the effects of being empowered, the confidence it engenders and the socialisation provided by this group activity will have a knock-on effect on the wards, providing a demonstrable improvement in dementia sufferers' quality of life.

Quantifying improvements may prove difficult, but there is no doubting the evidence of one's eyes and ears. At the session I attended, one patient was very reluctant to enter the room - she could be heard crying in the corridor outside - but as soon as she did join the group, she relaxed, embraced the harpist and took part in the music-making. Barriers were quickly broken down, wary silence gave way to laughter, and the music took shape.

It was both funny and moving to see patients conducting the musicians, with the latter following precisely their hand and eye movements in an attempt to give expression to their feelings. "Music is a natural form of communication that can perhaps be easier than language," says Katy Dent, development manager at Sinfonia 21, which combines educational and outreach work with concerts majoring in contemporary music (its role at Imperial College is part of an initiative to bring the arts and sciences into some degree of harmony).

"The aim is that the music should be affected by what is coming from the residents," says Linda Rose, director of Music for Life, which trains musicians to work with frail elderly people in an interactive way. "Untrained musicians might provide a straight performance. You wouldn't know whether the listeners had been affected or not; the relationship wouldn't build in the way that it does in this project. Here the music is affected by the patients. The musicians may take in a repertoire of four or five ideas, but these are only starting points, and what develops from those is a result of the interaction."

Rose emphasises the demands made on the musicians. "It can be very stressful just to walk into a room with people with dementia, to feel a reality that is different from our own reality," she says. "It's difficult to know how to respond, and it takes a lot of emotional stamina to do this work, just as it does for the carers. The relationship with the carers and with the patients' families [who can, if they wish, attend the sessions] is a very important part of the work. We are developing a sort of community."

"It is a way of seeing another side of somebody," says Sarah Dunn, a research nurse on the project. "It might have been thought that the more severely affected in the group would not have been capable of learning new things, of interacting, of communicating. This shows the carers a different side of their residents."

The Shimmer Project is an example of what Rose calls "person-centred care". "We are taking account of the person behind the dementia, rather than looking at dementia as a condition," she says. It isn't just the patients who need to be reminded of their identities; society too must be encouraged not to objectify and marginalise people with dementia.

"We want to say that these people should be treated with respect, not just hidden away and forgotten," says Katy Dent. "Other cultures seem to have more respect for the elderly. Developing emotional care for people with dementia is on the increase; there is now a move towards person-centred care and this project fits into that." Dunn agrees: "We live in an ageist society: young is beautiful, old is ugly, and you have double jeopardy if you are an older person with dementia."

Rose stresses the risks the musicians run in taking part in these sessions - there is nowhere to hide musically or emotionally - but she says the rewards can also be considerable. "The musicians benefit as artists: their music is developing and their perceptions are developing. They are highly motivated."

That is certainly true of flautist Tony Robb, who took part in the session I sat in on. "You have to treat this with as much respect and concentration as you do when you sit down to play a piece by Schoenberg," he told me afterwards. "There are two main points to doing this work. The first is to look after the patients and make sure they are never compromised or distressed. The second is to be true to oneself as a musician, so we try at all times to maintain the highest possible musical standards within an improvisatory framework, which is a tall order.

"The key is to be true to them and what they are doing. It's very easy to go into a situation like this, play a few pre-arranged pieces, get them all to clap or maybe beat time to it, and feel 'Right, we've done a bit of community work.' We don't try to impose our ideas on them, we try to get them to take control, and it's wonderful if they instigate the music. If we can get them to take control of some aspect of their lives, which most of the time they don't get the chance to do, then we feel we've done a good job."

webTitle: The definitive guide to treating common ailments

fields.headline: The definitive guide to treating common ailments
fields.trailText: No 23: Obesity
fields.body:
What works? No 23: Obesity

British adults and children are increasingly overweight - about 62% of men and 53% of women, according to latest figures. The rise is blamed on our increasingly sedentary lifestyle, as well as a more fatty diet. Children of obese parents are more likely to become obese themselves.

Health risks

Being overweight increases the risk of heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure, gallstones and other diseases. Obesity shortens life expectancy. Even a modest weight loss - around 5kg (10lbs) - has important health benefits.

Losing weight

Exercise, diet, behavioural therapy and drugs are all effective to some degree but work best when used in combination. Combining a low-fat or low-calorie diet with increased exercise is likely to be better than dieting on its own. Taking fibre supplements may also help. There is no miracle diet or ideal exercise, although the Health Education Authority recommends that adults do 30 minutes of moderate to intense activity such as brisk walking or dancing every day. Behavioural treatment in classes or individual counselling sessions is also of little use on its own.

Drugs can help but two of the most popular appetite suppressants, fenfluramine and dexfenfluramine, were withdrawn in 1997 following concerns about heart complications. Anti-depressants such as Prozac have been shown to help in the short term - although they are not licensed for that purpose here - but all weight-loss drugs may have unpleasant side effects. When other approaches have failed, surgery - usually to reduce the capacity of the stomach - is effective. There has been insufficient research to test whether alternative therapies, such as acupuncture and hypnotism, really work. For children, reducing sedentary activity like watching television and playing computer games, is more effective than enforced exercise.

Sustaining weight loss

Most people regain the weight they have lost within a few months. Enlisting family members for support, as well as continuing contact with health professionals or other advisers, can help.

 What works? is based on reviews of the most up-to-date and reliable evidence available. It is written in collaboration with the NHS Centre for Reviews and Dissemination at York University (01904 433 634) and verified by experts.

webTitle: Why vitamin pills may be bad for you

fields.headline: Why vitamin pills may be bad for you
fields.standfirst: A new study suggests high doses of vitamin C supplements may be dangerous.  Claire Wallerstein  says you might as well stick to fruit and veg
fields.trailText: A new study suggests high doses of vitamin C supplements may be dangerous. Claire Wallerstein says you might as well stick to fruit and veg.
fields.body:
Dietary supplements are one of our biggest growth industries - greedily embraced as an antidote to increasingly hectic lifestyles, abnormal eating habits, and sporadic efforts to keep fit.

Not so long ago, anything more exotic than cod liver oil was laughed off as mumbo-jumbo. But by last year we were spending £360m annually on the likes of pine bark, royal jelly, green-lipped mussels and ginseng in the hope of warding off everything from hangovers and spots to depression and lung cancer. However, behind skyrocketing sales and the bewildering expansion of product ranges, concerns are mounting over the safety of these " natural" products, which are classified as foods, and therefore undergo less rigorous testing than medicines.

Our knowlege of how and why vitamins and minerals work - especially in highly refined doses isolated from normal dietary intake - is still sketchy. Many studies have shown that, at best, supplements have no effect at all on our health. Others suggest they may be harmful. Most recently, a shadow has fallen over vitamin C supplements, regularly taken by 10m Britons, including Baroness Thatcher and Michael Portillo, and thought to boost the immune system and tackle free radicals, which play a role in heart disease and cancer.

Last week, results from a study at the University of Southern California showed the carotid arteries of middle-aged people taking daily 500mg doses thickened two and a half times faster than normal - among smokers the rate was five times faster. The study was relatively small (573 people) but the results are potentially alarming. Although no one suffered major illnesses during the trial, atherosclerosis causes poor blood flow, associated with heart disease and strokes.

The government recommends a daily 40mg dose of vitamin C, 12 times less than the amount used in the American study: 10 mg a day is enough to prevent scurvy. However, many people take much higher doses to ward off colds and flu.

Dr James Dwyer, the epidemiologist who led the American study, says: " When you extract one component of food and give it at very high levels, you just don't know what you are doing to the system. It may be dangerous. If a physician has pre scribed vitamin C, it is appropriate to be taking it. But if you are healthy and taking it in the hope of preventing cardiovascular disease, the American Heart Association does not recommend it."

Gail Goldberg, senior nutrition scientist of the British Nutrition Foundation, is surprised by the results "considering other evidence about vitamin C protecting against heart disease and high blood pressure". However, she points out that little is known about how refined vitamin C may act compared to vitamin C in fruit. "There are phytochemicals in fruit, for example, which may be a protective factor, but we don't know yet what they do or how they work.

"The interaction of vitamins and minerals is complicated, so it's difficult to take supplements in isolation. Many require other compounds for them to work properly: iron cannot be absorbed without vitamin C, and calcium cannot be absorbed without vitamin D. Vitamin C is an antioxidant like vitamin E and beta carotene, which are some of the most popular food supplements around. In America, US$2bn is spent annually on these alone."

However, the body makes its own antioxidants, and there is little evidence that taking large amounts of refined antioxidants has any benefit. A recent major study in Italy showed no heart benefits among 11,000 people taking 300 daily units of vitamin E over three and a half years, while a Finnish study in 1994 had to be halted after smokers taking beta carotene showed an alarming increase in cases of lung cancer. It is already known that high doses of vitamin C (more than 3,000mg) can cause diarrhoea and blood in stools, while high doses of vitamin E can interfere with blood clotting.

Dwyer says more research needs to be done on his findings, but he believes arterial thickening could have been due to the supplements causing a build-up of collagen in the artery walls, or causing the absorption of excess iron, which can damage the heart.

Goldberg says people taking vitamin C supplements should not panic or stop taking them." Most are formulated to make it very hard to take a dangerously high dose, and vitamin supplements have an important role to play for anaemic people, vegetarians, the pregnant and elderly."

She says many foods, such as breakfast cereals, margarine and flour, have been safely fortified for years, helping to cut down on deficiency diseases such as rickets which were still rife 50 years ago. But she adds: " Healthy people can obtain all the vitamins and minerals they need from a normal balanced diet, including five portions of fruit or vegetables a day. It's also important to cut out smoking, which drastically lowers the amount of vitamin C in the body.

"Trying to balance a poor diet with supplements or use them as food replacements is potentially dangerous, and never likely to be successful."

fields.headline: A very private grief
fields.standfirst: Doctors estimate that around a third of pregnancies end in miscarriage, but no one really knows how common it is - or even why it happens.  Joanna Moorhead, who has lost three unborn babies, reports
fields.trailText: Doctors estimate that around a third of pregnancies end in miscarriage, but no one really knows how common it is - or even why it happens. Joanna Moorhead, who has lost three unborn babies, reports.
fields.body:
Is miscarriage on the increase? In miscarriage awareness week, that's the most obvious question to ask, but the rather surprising answer is that no one knows. "There's no evidence," says Ruth Bender Atik of the Miscarriage Association.

Lamentably, it seems no one is counting. It's true that charting the true number would be difficult, since some women mistake a miscarriage for a heavy period, and others don't tell their GPs even when they know they've suffered one. But the rather surprising news is that even if you do present at your doctor's surgery or your local hospital casualty with an ending or ended pregnancy, your experience goes unrecorded.

The best the medical profession can tell us, based on small-scale studies, is that up to 30% of pregnancies are miscarried. In the absence of evidence, though, you could be forgiven for thinking that miscarriage may be a growing problem. It's certainly a common one: I have had three myself, and at least two of my closest friends have also had them. In the past week two high-profile women, Annabel Heseltine and Lauren Booth, the prime minister's sister-in-law, have written of their pregnancy losses.

So, are more of us losing babies, or are we simply more likely to talk about it? Atik believes that, although a minority of women do speak out, most still want it to be a private grief. For some there are practical considerations: if they don't yet have children, they may be unwilling to divulge that they're trying to have them now. For others, there's the problem of not knowing where to go; and of not knowing how far it's OK to mourn a baby who was maybe hardly a baby at all.

On top of that, there's the feeling of failure. All of us who have miscarried, at whatever stage of our reproductive lives, have felt it, and it's a particularly abject and stark failure. A few weeks before, you were laughing and crying over your positive pregnancy test, making plans, imagining the little person you would be cuddling a year from now. Your pregnancy is the first thing you think about every morning, the last thing you think about every night.

Then one day, without warning, there's the blood; for me, every time, it was just the tiniest drop, the merest hint of heart-stopping red. Then the terrible wait at the hospital for an ultrasound scan to check whether it was all over. Finally, in a scene almost too painful to recall, the frozen image on the screen of a baby whose tiny heart had for some reason ceased to beat.

Why? That's what you want to know, but if they can find a reason you're one of the lucky ones. Most women who suffer one miscarriage, and then two, are simply sent home to "try again": it's only when you reach three consecutive losses that you qualify for help, and even then the likelihood is that, like me, you will be told the tests show nothing abnormal.

According to Roy Farquharson, consultant obstetrician at the Liverpool Women's Hospital and an authority on miscarriage, a cause will be found in only around half of the women investigated. That's partly because it's under-researched. "It's always been a Cinderella cause," says Farquharson. "It hasn't attracted much grant money for research."

As a consequence, he believes, research into miscarriage and its prevention is around 20 years behind research into infertility which, by contrast, has attracted lots of funding. What research there is has uncovered two factors that are most significant in predicting whether a woman will miscarry: maternal age and previous history of losses.

The first, of course, is bad news at a time when many women postpone childbearing because although even a 19-year-old can have a miscarriage, a 40-year-old is at greater risk. The truth is, of course, that some pregnancies will always end in miscarriage, and indeed a proportion are due to gross abnormalities in the chromosomal make-up of the baby.

But, contrary to popular belief, these "abnormal" foetuses by no means account for all miscarried pregnancies. In many cases, doctors like Farquharson believe, the "mistake" is in the placenta, not in the baby itself. It's in this area that research has been concentrated and significant steps forward are being made, partic ularly with regard to blood clotting abnormalities which appear to interfere with the smooth workings of the all-important placenta.

For several years, doctors have believed that taking low-dose aspirin might iron out these clotting deficiencies, making a successful outcome much more likely. Although the studies have not conclusively proved the usefulness of aspirin, the evidence seems to suggest it is beneficial, and I am one of probably many thousands of women to put my baby's life down to the taking of low-dose aspirin.

There is another factor, too, harder to pin down, more difficult to describe. It's a kind of confidence that pregnancy will work out, a sort of self-belief. There's no medical reason why your psychological state should affect pregnancy outcome, but studies seem to back up the argument that it does.

Studies in Norway and elsewhere have shown that if women are given regular reassurance via ultrasound scans that their baby is alive and well, they are more likely to make it through the crucial 12-week barrier - and by that stage, if the baby's heart is still beating, there is a 99% chance of success.

In my most recent pregnancy, weekly trips to the local hospital for a scan became a kind of lifeline: in many ways I existed from one week to the next and, as the weeks went by and the news was always good, I started to believe, slowly, that this time my baby would survive - as indeed she did.

 The Miscarriage Association: 01924 200799

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Boils | Hair loss | Giving up smoking
fields.body:
On the boil...

Q Over the past four years or so, I have periodically developed large, painful boils. Each time they last for about two weeks each, from their onset to my skin more or less healing. When they are about to burst, the pain is almost unbearable. My personal hygiene is good - I shower every day and wear clean clothes. I am very fit and eat very healthily. Although I have noticed a correlation between stressful times in my life and the onset of boils, I can't believe this is the fullest explanation.

A You're in good company; Karl Marx suffered from excruciating recurrent boils, though any links between erupting skin and revolutionary politics can only be guessed at. Boils are pus-filled pockets of bacterial infection in hair follicles, so they crop up in any hairy part of the body like armpits, pubic area, and ears. The bacteria often live in our bodies; 60% of us carry staphylococcus aureus in our noses, 10% of us harbour streptococcus pyogenes in our throats. Why we can carry these bugs for years with no problems, and then suddenly get boils remains a mystery. Any condition that impairs your immunity, such as diabetes, may result in boils. Stress, anaemia, poor diet and lack of sleep probably impairs immunity in some people. I'd ask your GP to take swabs from your nose and throat; use an antiseptic skin cleanser eg chlorhexidine solution; take a suitable antibiotics orally (eg clarithromycin); use an antibiotic nasal cream eg naseptin if you carry bugs in your nose and ask to be tested for diabetes. If the boils keep coming back, ask for a referral to a skin specialist who may in turn refer you for immunological tests to check your immune system.

Will my hair grow back?

Q I recently found a small patch of hair loss on the back of my head near my left ear. I have heard that this is stress related. Will it grow back, and what is the treatment?

A You sound like you have alopecia areata. It's thought to be due to your body's immune system attacking your own hair follicles. It's most common in early adulthood and is more common among people with eczema and with other autoimmune diseases such as thyroid disease. It's not necessarily stress-related. Mostly it happens out of the blue to people who have no other medical problems. Usually hair starts to regrow after a few weeks. A minority of people is less lucky and may even go on to develop rapid and total hair loss. Steroid injections into the scalp can be tried but, unfortunately, there's no one treatment that guarantees success.

I just can't quit

Q I'm desperate to give up smoking but I think I'm a hopeless case. I've tried hypnosis, relaxation tapes, acupuncture, nicotine patches, gum, and tablets. I've frightened myself witless reading all the leaflets my GP gave me. I'm still getting through 40 a day on a bad day. Is there anything that can help me?

A Don't feel too demoralised about your inability to quit. You're dealing with one of the most highly addictive drugs known to mankind: 97% of smokers who try to quit fail. But hope may be on the horizon for you with a new drug called Zyban. It's claimed to curb addiction by working on neuro transmitter chemicals in the brain (dopamine and noradrenaline). You take it for seven to nine weeks, and aim to quit after the first week. It reduces craving and withdrawal effects apparently. Side effects are similar to those you get when you quit smoking: insomnia, dry mouth and headaches. You can't take it if you have epilepsy. It should be in the UK by the summer - though whether it'll be available on NHS prescription remains to be seen.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

webTitle: Brown hints at a prudent cash injection

fields.headline: Brown hints at a prudent cash injection
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has given the clearest signal yet that he is prepared to break into his celebrated war chest and inject money into health and education.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has given the clearest signal yet that he is prepared to break into his celebrated war chest and inject money into health and education.

As he put the finishing touches to his fourth budget, due to be delivered at 3.30pm today, Mr Brown indicated that he was prepared for a cash giveaway - albeit a careful one.

Mr Brown told cabinet colleagues this morning that his Budget speech, expected to last just over an hour, would "show the government working hard for the hard-working people of Britain".

He assured them that his Budget strategy would remain prudent, to continue his policy of locking in low inflation and stable growth.

A Downing Street spokesman said prime minister Tony Blair had praised Mr Brown at the cabinet meeting as a "radical, reforming chancellor".

The spokesman said Mr Blair had told colleagues that everything the government did depended on sensible economic management. "He paid tribute to Gordon as a radical, reforming chancellor who has established the government's economic credentials and won a deserved reputation for sorting out the public finances, building stability, promoting work and enterprise and investing in public services."

In an interview with the London Evening Standard an unusually upbeat Mr Brown said he said he would stick to his watchwords of low inflation and tough control of public finances.

"As a result of this prudent and responsible approach, I am able to bring forward measures to promote enterprise and fairness, build a stronger and fairer Britain and release resources for our priorities."

These words were interpreted as a signal that help is on the way in the form of extra money for health, education and the less well off, in a bid to regain support in Labour's increasingly disaffected heartlands.

The Treasury is reported to be heading for a record surplus of £14bn. Many experts believe that any giveaway will amount to no more than £2bn overall.

Mr Brown had breakfast this morning in the Treasury canteen. However, as he reached the till with a yoghurt, orange, banana and a cup of tea, the chancellor appeared to have forgotten his wallet. He urgently said "money" to an aide standing behind him, before being handed a £5 note and paying for his meal.

A Treasury official could not confirm whether Mr Brown had any cash on him when he went to the canteen. A department spokesman said: "We do not check his pockets before he goes for breakfast."

fields.headline: Death in Kashmir
fields.standfirst:
Former India correspondent Derek Brown delves into the background to the attack perpetrated last night in Kashmir, leaving at least 35 dead

Listen to Delhi correspondent Luke Harding on the aftermath of the massacre
fields.trailText: 21 March, 1pm: Former India correspondent Derek Brown delves into the background to the attack perpetrated last night in Kashmir, leaving at least 35 dead
fields.body:
At least 35 Sikh villagers have been brutally murdered in the Indian-controlled part of the disputed state of Kashmir. Prime suspects are pro-Pakistan Islamist fighters, although no one has yet claimed responsibility for the attack.

Indian police said that a group of uniformed gunmen entered Chati Singhpura Mattan village late on Monday night, separated adult males from their families and shot them in the street.

The motive for the mass killing - apart from the casual racism which underlies much of the violence in Kashmir - appears to have been to draw the world's attention to the conflict while President Bill Clinton is visiting India.

The president immediately declared his outrage at the bloodletting, and renewed his appeal to both India and Pakistan to respect the ceasefire line which divides Kashmir.

That line - more properly called the Line of Control - was fixed by a short and bloody war in 1947, when both India and Pakistan gained their freedom from Britain.

Kashmir was one of the semi-autonomous princely states whose rulers could decide which of the new countries their subjects should join. Kashmir is overwhelmingly Muslim, but its maharajah was a Hindu, who opted for India.

Pakistani irregular forces invaded the state, but were forestalled by an audacious Indian army airborne operation, which established control of the Kashmir Valley and the state summer capital, Srinagar.

Pakistan took control of a western sliver of Kashmir, plus the sprawling northern mountain territories of Gilgit and Baltistan. This territory is known today as Azad (free) Kashmir.

India and Pakistan have twice more fought all-out wars. In 1965, the issue was again Kashmir. In 1971, the main issue was the separation and transformation of East Pakistan into what is now Bangladesh.

Fighting in Kashmir again flared in the late 80s, when Pakistan armed and equipped a motley collection of Islamist guerrilla groups. The conflict has seen extreme brutality on all sides, with regular communal massacres, excesses by the Indian security forces, and frequent clashes between the regular army units on either side of the Line of Control.

There was a particularly dangerous artillery and infantry duel last year in the Kargil region, where Indian mountain troops wrestled back a slice of territory seized by the Pakistanis and their surrogates.

Most Muslim Kashmiris favour neither Pakistan nor India, but rather want their huge and spectacularly beautiful state to be independent. That is the aim of the biggest single group of political and armed radicals, the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front.

The issue is complicated by the existence of a significant Hindu minority, which mostly lives in the southern district of Jammu. The much smaller community of Kashmiri Sikhs is concentrated in scattered villages, where most earn a specialist living as truck owners and drivers. Until now, they had enjoyed a precarious immunity from the savage conflict around them.

webTitle: Clinton calls for end to violence after Kashmir attack

fields.headline: Clinton calls for end to violence after Kashmir attack
fields.standfirst: Listen to Delhi correspondent Luke Harding on the aftermath of the massacre
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton today called for an end to violence in Kashmir after at least 35 Sikhs were massacred in the province at the centre of a bitter territorial dispute between India and Pakistan.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton today called for an end to violence in Kashmir after at least 35 Sikhs were massacred in the province at the centre of a bitter territorial dispute between India and Pakistan.

Gunmen lined up and shot the villagers after dark, police said. Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee denounced Monday night's attack - the first in the 10-year separatist insurgency in Kashmir - calling it an act of "ethnic cleansing".

"We have the means and the will to eliminate this menace," Mr Vajpayee said. Mr Clinton also expressed outrage at "the brutal attack" that, he said, highlighted "the tremendous suffering this conflict has caused India".

It occurred at about 10pm local time, after Mr Clinton concluded a visit to Bangladesh and was aboard Air Force One bound for New Delhi. Gunmen in combat uniforms forced the residents of Chati Singhpura Mattan into the streets, announcing they were conducting a "crackdown", police said.

After separating the men from the women, the gunmen opened fire on the men. "They brought out the males from their homes and shot them dead, point blank," said AK Bhan, the director-general of police.

No one has claimed responsibility for the massacre, but Indian army officers had warned of violence by pro-separatist militants during Mr Clinton's visit to the subcontinent to calm tensions between India and Pakistan.

The killing marked an ominous twist to the conflict in Kashmir, the subject of a 50-year-old territorial dispute and the immediate cause of two wars between India and Pakistan.

In the past, Kashmiri militants conducted random killings of Hindus, but the Sikhs were considered neutral and had never been before a target in the campaign to split Kashmir from India.

Sikhs had been living mostly undisturbed in the Kashmir valley, the only area in predominantly Hindu India with a Muslim majority. Many Sikhs run the trucking companies that supply the valley.

India accuses Pakistan of sponsoring the militancy in Kashmir, but Pakistan says it provides only political and moral support to Kashmiri militants. Mr Clinton called for both sides to renew a direct dialogue over the disputed territory.

"The violence must end. This should be a time for restraint," he said, and promised to take the same message to Pakistan. Mr Clinton has offered to mediate in the Kashmir dispute, but only if both sides agree.

The United States and India on Tuesday signed a "vision statement" laying out the foundation for closer ties between the world's two largest democracies, whose relations have been strained because of America's past closeness to Pakistan.

The statement said the two countries would "resolve to create a closer and qualitatively new relationship" and hold regular summit meetings.

But US officials made clear there were limits to how close the two countries could be unless India agreed to restrain its nuclear programme by signing the comprehensive test ban treaty.

India and Pakistan shocked the world with tit-for-tat nuclear tests two years ago, making Kashmir an even more dangerous flashpoint.

Mr Vajpayee played down any threat of war. "We do not think in terms of war and nobody should think in those terms in the subcontinent," he said.

Gunmen lined up and shot the villagers after dark, police said. Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee denounced Monday night's attack - the first in the 10-year separatist insurgency in Kashmir - calling it an act of "ethnic cleansing". "We have the means and the will to eliminate this menace," Mr Vajpayee said. Mr Clinton also expressed outrage at "the brutal attack" that, he said, highlighted "the tremendous suffering this conflict has caused India". It occurred at about 10pm local time, after Mr Clinton concluded a visit to Bangladesh and was aboard Air Force One bound for New Delhi. Gunmen in combat uniforms forced the residents of Chati Singhpura Mattan into the streets, announcing they were conducting a "crackdown", police said. After separating the men from the women, the gunmen opened fire on the men. "They brought out the males from their homes and shot them dead, point blank," said AK Bhan, the director-general of police. No one has claimed responsibility for the massacre, but Indian army officers had warned of violence by pro-separatist militants during Mr Clinton's visit to the subcontinent to calm tensions between India and Pakistan. The killing marked an ominous twist to the conflict in Kashmir, the subject of a 50-year-old territorial dispute and the immediate cause of two wars between India and Pakistan. In the past, Kashmiri militants conducted random killings of Hindus, but the Sikhs were considered neutral and had never been before a target in the campaign to split Kashmir from India. Sikhs had been living mostly undisturbed in the Kashmir valley, the only area in predominantly Hindu India with a Muslim majority. Many Sikhs run the trucking companies that supply the valley. India accuses Pakistan of sponsoring the militancy in Kashmir, but Pakistan says it provides only political and moral support to Kashmiri militants. Mr Clinton called for both sides to renew a direct dialogue over the disputed territory. "The violence must end. This should be a time for restraint," he said, and promised to take the same message to Pakistan. Mr Clinton has offered to mediate in the Kashmir dispute, but only if both sides agree. The United States and India on Tuesday signed a "vision statement" laying out the foundation for closer ties between the world's two largest democracies, whose relations have been strained because of America's past closeness to Pakistan. The statement said the two countries would "resolve to create a closer and qualitatively new relationship" and hold regular summit meetings. But US officials made clear there were limits to how close the two countries could be unless India agreed to restrain its nuclear programme by signing the comprehensive test ban treaty. India and Pakistan shocked the world with tit-for-tat nuclear tests two years ago, making Kashmir an even more dangerous flashpoint. Mr Vajpayee played down any threat of war. "We do not think in terms of war and nobody should think in those terms in the subcontinent," he said. fields.headline: The Stephen Lawrence case
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown on a development in the story that began back in 1993 and has changed policing of race crime in Britain, but has yet to produce a single conviction
fields.trailText: Derek Brown on a development in a story that began in 1993 and has changed policing of race crime in Britain, but has yet to produce a single conviction.
fields.body:
Why is Stephen Lawrence back in the news?
His mother, Doreen, is to appear on BBC1's Crimewatch UK programme (tonight at 9.35pm) to make a fresh appeal for information on his murder.

Does the programme itself have anything new to say?
It will show a computerised reconstruction of the killing in Eltham, south London, on April 22, 1993. The Metropolitan police deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, head of the race and violent crime unit, will also appeal for witnesses or anyone with any other information.

Are there new suspects?
Not according to the BBC, which makes it clear in a news story about the programme that the police are concentrating on the five young white men arrested in the aftermath of the murder. "Seven years have passed since the racist murder of Stephen Lawrence, but we know several people out there can turn the keys to locking up those responsible. Allegiances change over time. We nearly have the full picture and I am relying on Crimewatch viewers to help complete it," Mr Grieve will say.

Who are the five and why have they not been convicted?
Neil and Jamie Acourt, Gary Dobson, David Norris and Luke Knight were all arrested within six weeks of the killing. Neil Acourt and Knight were charged with murder but the crown prosecutors dropped the charges, for lack of evidence. The Lawrence family started private proceedings against the five on the second anniversary of Stephen's death. The cases against Jamie Acourt and David Norris were again dropped for lack of evidence. The other three were committed for trial at the Old Bailey, but the case collapsed when the judge ruled that identification evidence was inadmissible.

Having been discharged, surely they can no longer be prosecuted for the same offence?
Possibly they can. The so-called double jeopardy rule, a cornerstone of English law for centuries whereby you cannot be tried twice for the same crime, is under review, precisely because such a review was recommended by the Macpherson report into the Lawrence case.

Any other outstanding legal business?
Doreen Lawrence and her estranged husband, Neville, are suing 42 officers of the Met, including its chief at the time, Sir Paul Condon, for damages.

webTitle: Serbs 'enslaved Muslim women at rape camps'

fields.headline: Serbs 'enslaved Muslim women at rape camps'
fields.standfirst:
A trial at the Hague and a new report show that women were abused as a method of war across Yugoslavia hears how soldiers brutalised girls as young as 12 during the Bosnian war

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The international war crimes tribunal at the Hague heard yesterday that "unimaginable horrors" including gang rape, torture and sexual enslavement were perpetrated against Muslim women and girls by Serb troops in the early days of the Bosnian conflict.
fields.body:
The international war crimes tribunal at the Hague heard yesterday that "unimaginable horrors" including gang rape, torture and sexual enslavement were perpetrated against Muslim women and girls by Serb troops in the early days of the Bosnian conflict.

Opening a landmark case against three former Bosnian Serb soldiers, UN prosecutors charged that they were the men whose individual brutality in their home town had made possible the wider project of ethnic cleansing.

Dragoljub Kunarac, Radomir Kovac and Zoran Vukovic are accused on 33 counts of crimes against humanity and crimes against the laws and customs of war.

"This is a case about the women and girls - some as young as 12 or 15 years old - who endured unimaginable horrors as their worlds collapsed around them," prosecutor Dirk Ryneveld said in his opening statement.

Mr Kunarac, 39, is further accused of "command responsibility" for crimes committed by his subordinates. The three, who face life imprisonment, deny all charges.

It is the first case in which sexual crimes alone have come before the war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.

In Bosnia's war, the accused were not "particularly major players", Mr Ryneveld, a Canadian, told the panel of three judges.

"But make no mistake: there would have been no ethnic cleansing if there were not individuals willing to turn on their neighbours, to unleash terror and hatred and to leave scarred victims.

"Unlike the policymakers who dealt in theories and plans, these were the individuals who rounded up innocent women and girls, then raped them or sexually assaulted them, tortured them, enslaved them and then... exchanged, sold or transferred them to other soldiers."

As the case began, an adjacent court continued hearing evidence against the Bosnian Serb General, Radislav Kirstic, accused of genocide in the 1995 Srebrenica massacre - the most senior officer to face the tribunal.

Mr Kunarac, Mr Kovac and Mr Vukovic were at the other end of the Serb chain of command when war came to the Muslim majority town of Foca, in the Drina valley close to the border with Montenegro.

Videos showed Foca as it was before spring 1992, a sleepy town of red-roofed buildings including the Partizan sports Hall, the high school and the Hotel Zelengora - all later used for rapes.

"This is not just a rape case like those in national jurisdictions," Mr Ryneveld said. "These crimes were committed during an armed conflict and were widespread and systematic. What happened to the Muslim women of Foca occurred purely because of their ethnicity or religion, and because they were women."

Mr Kunarac had his headquarters in a "rape house" to which he transported captive women, the prosecutor said.

Several women scheduled to appear as witnesses were warned that they and/or their children would be killed if they resisted sexual assault.

Mr Vukovic, 44, a waiter and driver before the war, repeatedly led gang rapes. Witness 48 was told she would have her throat slashed if she resisted. Mr Vukovic "bit her nipples until they bled and pinched her breasts until she fainted from pain".

Four of the 72 women held in the Partizan sports hall were raped almost nightly for a month. Witness 186 was raped for six months.

Another victim, described as AB, was just 12 when she was sold by Mr Kovac, 38, to a soldier for 200 Deutschmarks (£66). She is still missing.

Witness 50 was raped on the night of August 2, 1992 - the night the town's mosque was destroyed - after being taken away by Mr Kunarac. She was raped by a Montenegrin soldier who threatened to cut off her arms and legs and take her to a church to baptise her.

"Women and children, some as young as 12 years old, were detained and raped, vaginally, anally and orally; subjected to gang rapes, forced to dance nude with weapons pointed at them, and even enslaved," the court heard.

"Unlike many domestic rapes, the offences in this case were often done in the full view of others or in a room were several women were being raped simultaneously," the prosecutor said. "It will be difficult to fathom the depths of despair and the horror that these victims went through."

Up to 10 rape victims are expected to testify at the trial from behind screens or with voice scrambled to protect their identities.

fields.headline: Es España un país machista?
fields.standfirst: Are young Spanish men truly sexist?  Eulàlia Furriol finds out
fields.trailText: Secondary Spanish
fields.body:
El pasado miércoles 8 de marzo era el Día Mundial de la Mujer Trabajadora. En España miles de personas, la mayoría mujeres, se manifestaron para pedir igualdad de derechos entre hombres y mujeres.

Los sindicatos reivindicaban igualdad de derechos e igualdad salarial.

España tiene uno de los índices de participación femenina en el mundo laboral más bajos de la Unión Europea. La tasa de paro entre las mujeres dobla la tasa de paro masculina. Y las mujeres cobran de media un 22 por ciento menos que los hombres.

Al mismo tiempo, España es el país con el índice de natalidad más bajo de todo el mundo. Cada mujer en edad fértil tiene una media de 1,07 hijos. Algunos analistas atribuyen esta situación a una cultura machista de la sociedad española.

Son los jóvenes españoles machistas? Y tú, eres machista?

Diana Sánchez (17 años): Sí, creo que los jóvenes españoles son machistas. Pero es algo inconsciente, algo inculcado por la educación en casa y en la escuela. Yo soy feminista, y participo en las manifestaciones del Día Mundial de la Mujer Trabajadora desde hace cuatro años. Tengo muchos amigos que no son machistas, pero los amigos machistas son muy radicales.

Jordi Corbatón (14 años): La mayoría de jóvenes en España son un poco machistas. Y la mayoría de mujeres feministas. Cada uno critica al sexo contrario. Yo soy un poco machista, pero no mucho. En qué soy machista? Pues creo, por ejemplo, que hay trabajos que las mujeres no pueden hacer, porque requieren una fuerza física. Son el sexo débil. En los trabajos de la casa, en cambio, la mujer tiene más habilidades.

Qué es un machista? Cómo reconocer a un machista?

Diana: Es una persona que considera que los hombres son superiores. En realidad un machista es un hombre que tiene miedo a las mujeres, y por eso les niega los mismos derechos. Consideran que tienen autoridad sobre ti, y te dicen lo que puedes y lo que no puedes hacer. Son los típicos que dicen: "!Tú a la cocina!" o "!Tú dedícate a fregar platos!" O si te gusta el fútbol te tratan de lesbiana, pues dicen que es cosa de hombres. Son los que se quedan cortados cuando les invitas a tomar algo. Tengo un profesor que es el típico machista. Da mejores notas a las chicas que a los chicos. Pero si una chica tiene novio entonces baja la nota, pues dice que baja su rendimiento. El otro día dijó en clase que a las chicas las dejan entrar gratis a las discotecas porque así los hombres pueden escoger mejor, hay más variedad.

Jordi: Es una persona que sólo acepta la forma de pensar de los hombres. Se reconocen porque critican al sexo contrario, y dicen cosas como "la mujer en casa".

Qué tiene hoy más ventajas, ser hombre o ser mujer? Y en el futuro?

Diana: Ser hombre. El índice de paro es más alto entre las mujeres que entre los hombres. En el futuro será mejor ser mujer, espero. La revolución más silenciosa y que más ha progresado ha sido la de la mujer. Poco a poco estamos consiguiendo igualar los derechos.

Jordi: Actualmente tiene más ventajas ser hombre. Se dice que es el sexo fuerte. Los hombres, por ejemplo, cobran más dinero por hacer el mismo trabajo que las mujeres. Esto no debería ser así, y está cambiando.

Por qué tiene España el índice de natalidad más bajo del mundo?

Diana: Por cuestiones económicas. Las parejas que no tienen un trabajo fijo lo piensan mucho antes de tener hijos. También por las dificultades que tiene la mujer de combinar trabajo y familia. La mujer carga con el trabajo en casa y fuera de casa, con el cuidado de los niños y de los familiares mayores. Estamos en una sociedad machista donde no se reparte este trabajo ni con el hombre ni con los servicios sociales.

Jordi: Es una cuestión cultural. En India, por ejemplo, tienen muchos hijos. No tienen métodos para controlar la natalidad, y la mortalidad es también muy elevada. Es su cultura.

Crees que el Estado debería iniciar una política de natalidad?

Diana: Sí, debería dar mayores ayudas económicas, subvencionar guarderías, bajar impuestos a las familias, facilitar excedencias laborales pagadas tanto al padre como a la madre, facilitar el acceso a trabajos de tiempo parcial - hay muchas cosas por hacer. En España estamos por detrás de otros países europeos. En España no hay ayudas a la natalidad sino al contrario, más bien te perjudican.

Jordi: Hacer campañas de publicidad. Que la mujer haga sólo los trabajos de la casa y que el hombre trabaje fuera de casa, como antes. Así la mujer puede cuidar a los hijos.

machista sexist, male chauvinist

fields.headline: Wednesday sack Wilson
fields.standfirst: Danny Wilson factfile
fields.trailText: Danny Wilson has been sacked as manager of Sheffield Wednesday. Wilson leaves the club on the brink of the First Division, having taken only 21 points from 29 games.
fields.body:
Danny Wilson has been sacked as manager of Sheffield Wednesday. Wilson leaves the club on the brink of the First Division, having taken only 21 points from 29 games.

Wednesday this morning confirmed that the club's directors had terminated Wilson's contract with immediate effect. Former assistant manager Peter Shreeves will take control of first team affairs until the end of the season, although former manager Howard Wilkinson is already being talked of as Wilson's long-term replacement.

Wednesday chairman Howard Culley said: "I would like to thank Danny Wilson for his time as manager of Sheffield Wednesday. He has worked tirelessly and is hugely respected by everyone at the club."

Wilson arrived at Hillsborough in the summer of 1998 after winning plaudits, but not many points, as manager of Barnsley. His first season ended with a respectable 12th place in the Premiership, but this season Wednesday made the worst-ever start to a Premiership campaign and the blame was laid by many at Wilson's door.

Noone was more outspoken in his criticism of Wilson than local MP Joe Ashton, one of the group of four MPs who publically attacked the club in January. Today Mr Ashton claimed Wilson's departure was inevitable.

"Danny's a lovely fellow, a wonderful fellow...but he couldn't handle the big players in my opinion. We had a lot of foreigners, a lot of very experienced players. Players know a manager, they can spot him in six matches. They know the good ones, the ones who can do it and the ones who can't, and it finished up with the players just playing how they liked."

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Madonna and Ritchie announce pregnancy, Demme at work on Pat Barker adaptation, Michael Douglas gets messed up in the perfect murder, and what's The Boss doing in High Fidelity?
fields.body:
Madonna is three months pregnant by her boyfriend, British director Guy Ritchie. The singer-actress already has a three-year-old daughter, Lourdes, fathered by her fitness instructor Carlos Leon. For the past 18 months, the entertainer has been dating the 31-year-old Ritchie, who shot to fame with his hit gangster caper Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. The director is currently putting the finishing touches to his follow-up movie, Snatch, shot in London's East End. "We would be grateful if the media would kindly allow us some privacy at this special time, and we thank you for all your good wishes," said Ritchie.

fields.headline: Le salon du sandwich
fields.standfirst: Nicolas Veulikt plans his own 'sandwicherie'. He visits the European Sandwich Show in Paris
fields.trailText: Beginners' French
fields.body:
C'est étonnant. Je ne m'attendais pas à un salon d'une telle ampleur. D'ailleurs, je ne savais pas trop à quoi m'attendre en venant ici ! C'est une idée tellement étrange de consacrer un salon aux sandwiches ! En tout cas, ça marche car il y a un monde fou.

Toute l'industrie du sandwich est représentée: fabricants de pains, de garnitures, de salades, mais aussi de machines à emballer. C'est très hétéroclite. L'ambiance est bon enfant, tout le monde grignote beaucoup car les sandwiches sont variés, originaux et surtout très appétissants. Je visite ce salon car je projette d'ouvrir une sandwicherie à Paris, après avoir fini mes études. Je recherche de nouveaux concepts. On peut dire que je suis gâté !

Le sandwich le plus original est un sandwich aux fruits frais avec des tortillas aromatisées aux fraises. Il existe aussi des tortillas à la tomate et aux épinards. C'est spécial mais pas mauvais !

En outre, j'ai mangé un sandwich à la viande de renne. Le goût de la viande était étouffé par le fromage. Je n'en mangerais pas tous les jours !

Le pain de mie et le pain polaire ou pain suédois ont la cote. Mais on dirait que le sandwich traditionnel jambon-beurre ne fait plus recette. C'est dommage. Tout comme la disparition de la production artisanale. La fabrication des sandwiches est trop souvent industrielle. J'étais loin de me douter que tant de pains et préparations pour sandwiches étaient congelés ! Le goût doit en pâtir.

Glossaire/Glossary

l'ambiance est bon enfant there's a good atmosphere
d'une telle ampleur on such a scale
avoir la cote to be popular
c'est spécial mais pas mauvais it tastes strange but it's not bad
faire recette to be a winner
le goût the taste
le goût doit en pâtir the taste must suffer
on peut dire que je suis gâté in this context; I've found what I was looking for so I'm happy (literally: I'm spoilt)
je n'en mangerais pas tous les jours I would not eat that every day (i.e. I don't like it)

fields.headline: A quietly confident Budget
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown's reputation for ultimate prudence remains firmly intact, writes Observer business editor Emily Bell
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's reputation for ultimate prudence remains firmly intact, writes Observer business editor Emily Bell.
fields.body:
There were no major surprises in the budget - but there was a clear signal that the government has taken on board the need to spend on key public services and target families and the elderly as priorities for relief.

On public services there will be an extra £4bn this year, with health allocated £2bn, education £1bn, law and order £285m and transport £280m. This shows that the government is clearly trying to address the issues which, left unaddressed, look like vote losers.

But anyone expecting a tax giveaway - certainly in the higher rate groups - was disappointed.

Gordon Brown's reputation for ultimate prudence and redistribution from the rich to the poor looks intact. In this respect he appears to have pulled off a clever budget, by spending some of the income he has gathered in the past without further penalising earners and enterprise with a "stealth tax".

Perhaps one surprise was that Mr Brown did not even mention the word "Longbridge" or indicate any change in his attitude towards the strong pound or heavy industry. The micro-measure most obviously aimed at taking the heat out of the economy was his decision to raise stamp duty on house purchases above £250,000. However, the jury is still very much out as to whether this is an effective way of slowing down the housing market.

There was a glimmer of good news for entrepreneurs but not the wholesale tax bonanza some of them would have liked. Mr Brown's main concessions were on capital gains tax, which he lowered to 35% of the value of the transaction in the first year, dropping to 30% in year two, and further cuts in subsequent years. This is quite a change from the previous 40% levy and will help people who invest in their businesses.

Mr Brown has listened to some of the complaints from smaller businesses about the need to cut bureaucracy, encouraging them to file tax and VAT returns electronically, with further incentive cuts for those filing returns for Working Families Tax Credit.

Tax allowances for IT - largely computers and e-commerce expenditure - are now fully tax allowable to encourage businesses to join the internet revolution.

Overall today's announcement is what we commonly expect from Gordon Brown - a budget which is full of small detail rather than sweeping reforms. He is hoping that the traditional Labour supporters - working families with children, and pensioners - will feel the extra benefit before the general election, widely expected within the next 18 months.

What is most important, however, is that Mr Brown has not really given any sector particular cause for complaint and his spending splurge, particularly on health, will be a difficult measure for the Tories to spin against. Not the real rip-roaring Budget you might expect from a government going into an election - but perhaps exactly the kind of micro-measures you would expect from an administration which is confident it is going to get a second term.

webTitle: Slow progress at the Queen's Park Oval

fields.headline: Slow progress at the Queen's Park Oval
fields.standfirst: Following her recent columns on the struggle for membership to the Queen's Park Oval in Trinidad, Vaneisa Baksh argues that equality is still a long way off
fields.trailText: Some years ago, a female journalist went to the Queen's Park Cricket Club to interview Jeffrey Stollmeyer, the former West Indies captain and president of the QPCC. Stollmeyer allowed himself to be interviewed, and then left the female journalist to her own devices within the hallowed precincts of the Club.
fields.body:
Some years ago, a female journalist went to the Queen's Park Cricket Club to interview Jeffrey Stollmeyer, the former West Indies captain and president of the QPCC. Stollmeyer allowed himself to be interviewed, and then left the female journalist to her own devices within the hallowed precincts of the Club.

It was not a day of cricket, so the place was not full - there was just a sprinkling of stalwarts sunning their bones at the bar. Though, strictly speaking, it was off-limits to women, she had been seen talking to the Club president and so she was mostly ignored until she made a big mistake.

It was a hot day, and the poor ignorant woman, feeling thirsty, thought to quench her thirst with a Coke at the QPCC bar. She was told at the bar that they don't serve women. She asked for a drink of water instead, thinking that if they couldn't sell her a Coke, they would at least provide a glass of water to a thirsty person. Not only was her request denied, but it was accompanied by sneers and jeers from the gentlemen in the precincts of the bar. She left, feeling humiliated.

That was some years ago, and what the gentlemen of the Queen's Park Cricket Club would say is that they have come a long way since then. They now allow women to have lunch at the Club - that is if they are properly escorted; and of course, that is, when there is no all-male function there. I myself have had lunch there recently, and the food was as reasonable as the prices.

They also allow women who are wives or girlfriends of members to use the gym facilities at certain times. They even allow women to attend their family-day activities, and sometimes even their social events, that is, those which are open to the public.

As a matter of fact, there is one place where women can enter during cricket games: the President's Box. There, women who are the wives or escorts of those privileged enough to be invited by the President of the QPCC can enter in all their feminine finery. That would have been the only way a woman like Pamela Nicholson, who was once the Minister of Sport in this country could have been entertained by the Club. I would like to think that if she had been invited to sit in the President's Box that she at least complained about the discrimination against women at the QPCC.

Yet, although the President of the QPCC has the right to invite whom he pleases into his box, he cannot offer his hospitality or, as in the case of the female journalist, his protection to women stepping outside of that safe ground. Indeed, I have been told that current President Willie Rodriguez could not even sway the adamant members when his own wife applied for membership some years ago. She too, like me, was rejected.

Since Rodriguez has pointed out to me that my application's rejection was not based on my gender - though he could not tell me what it was based on - I wonder what he told his wife?

Still, it wouldn't be fair to say the boys are not crawling along towards some kind of progressive thinking. Think about it: a few decades ago, Brian Charles Lara, for all his cricket talent, would not have been accepted as a member because he would have been too black. Today, his name is proudly listed as one of the QPCC members. What a pity his mother, Pearl, to whom he has paid tribute for her support, cannot watch her son from the Members' Pavilion.

When I was seeking someone to propose me for membership to the Club three years ago, I was told by a member that there were much larger issues in our society for us to deal with than the mere question of female membership at a club. I had been confident that the issue of female membership had been neglected because it had not been raised, and thought that all it would need was a good airing and the matter would be settled. I was taken aback though because while there may be bigger issues in people's minds than the subject of gender discrimination, that is certainly no reason why we, as citizens, must not be vigilant about all the "small" issues that constitute our way of life.

International Women's Day was observed last week and it was an important moment for women to celebrate all the big and small battles they have fought, though not necessarily won. Undertaking to fight these battles, whether successfully or not, constitutes part of the process towards equality of rights.

It seems to me that the tired old adversarial positions of gender square-offs have served their purpose but are spent mechanisms in the quest for real and true positions of respect and support for each other. I am tired of listening to the triteness of arguments that seek to reduce women to creatures lacking "gender" and not knowing their rightful place in society when they raise the question of equality of treatment.

I am tired of seeing men seeking to belittle women via sexual attacks which evade answering the real questions posed by their sisters. But I will not let them draw me into that puerile game.

Vaneisa Baksh writes for the Express Newspapers in Trinidad and Tobago. This piece was taken from her weekly column, Firefly

webTitle: Ford links with rivals on net plan

fields.headline: Ford links with rivals on net plan
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive, believes the internet will fundamentally change the way Ford does business and make it a model of the "new economy".
fields.body:
Henry Ford never invented the assembly line. The man who became an icon of 20th century business simply adapted something he had seen at a local meat-packing plant to make his fledgling automobile factory one of the world's most efficient.

Almost 100 years on and Mr Ford's successors are hoping to pull off a similar feat. Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive, believes the internet will fundamentally change the way Ford does business and make it a model of the "new economy".

Such a strategy is enormously ambitious given the size and history of Ford and, according to many internet pioneers without such baggage, almost impossible to pull off. Since taking over at the beginning of 1998, Mr Nasser has announced several plans designed to drag his company into the new age of intangible realities. These include providing some 350,000 employees with a cheap home computer and creating a new internet-focused division with a new boss recruited from outside Ford.

Then last month, in its most ambitious plan to date, the company unveiled an online exchange for buying and selling supplies with its biggest rivals - General Motors and DaimlerChrysler. This new business claims a total annual market of one trillion dollars.

That such arch rivals could envisage working together reflects the fact that the internet is making their traditional sales methods through dealers look obsolete. It also reflects the speed of change within the industry: GM and Ford were far advanced on their own separate plans for online exchanges before the announcement.

Brian Buersemeyer, Ford's strategic planning manager in the group's e-business division, admits that the new venture was driven by "the penalties" of not participating as much as the benefits of pooling resources. Ford has insisted that the exchange will not be used to drive down suppliers' prices. Rather, it expects to remove the "waste" in the current system by cutting out duplication and by pooling costs. It estimates that such waste is worth about 20% of annual costs.

There is a lot of work to do before the global exchange is ready to make its first purchase later this year, admits Mr Buersemeyer. "We are trying to figure out how to collaborate with GM and use the exchange for our own competitive advantage," he says.

Some analysts agree with Ford that the exercise is about more than cost-cutting. David Cole, director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan, says: "People tend to look at it as taking existing processes and doing them more quickly. But the really important dimension to this is that it redefines the basic business model by which they operate."

To compete in a fast-changing market, Ford, and other car companies, have to change from the current two-to-four-year production cycle in which engineers think of a new car and then encourage people to buy them, to one in which the consumer can choose the type of vehicle and buy it almost immediately. In trying to explain Ford's ultimate ambitions, Peter Look, president of Ford's eConsumer group, recalls an episode from Star Trek in which a character thinks of what to eat, opens a trapdoor in the Enterprise and there it is. That's where Ford's efforts are taking them, he says.

Consumers will think of a car and, in spite of the practical and physical difficulties of finding it, there it will be. The problem is that technology allowing consumers to do this is some way off and investors, still wary of the capital-intensive old car giants, know it.

Ford's share price is trading just above a 52-week low. Many analysts either do not understand how Ford is to pull off its transformation or do not believe they will get there.

Even David Cole, who is generally enthusiastic about the car giants, says: "The industry is running 100 miles an hour with this technology. They don't know exactly where they are going but they are going to get there quickly." And even Mr Buersemeyer acknowledges that his employer has a long way to go to change such an entrenched culture.

webTitle: Douglas warns of nuclear anarchy in speech to MPs

fields.headline: Douglas warns of nuclear anarchy in speech to MPs
fields.trailText: Douglas warns of nuclear anarchy in speech to MPs
fields.body:
The full campaigning might of Hollywood was unleashed at Westminster last night as actor Michael Douglas urged Tony Blair to show leadership over nuclear disarmament or risk a world slide into "nuclear anarchy".

In a speech to MPs, the film star, a United Nations ambassador for nuclear disarmament, warned that three international treaties governing nuclear stockpiles risked "coming apart."

Making his appeal to the all-party parliamentary group for non-proliferation and global security, Douglas warned that the cold war threat from nuclear weapons was still present.

He said Russia and China had warned Washington's "prospective adoption" of a "Star Wars" missile defence system would cancel a missile treaty and could increase confrontation with the US.

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, last night said the US had not formally requested use of its bases in Britain for the new system, but said any such request would be "carefully considered".

Douglas urged Mr Blair to speak at the Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference in New York in May.

"This would send a message to other world leaders of the importance of saving that treaty," he said.

 Read Douglas's take on the meeting on his official website.

webTitle: Robin Williams will perform South Park song

fields.headline: Robin Williams will perform South Park song
fields.trailText: Robin Williams is to sing the controversial Best Song Oscar nominee Blame Canada live on television during ABC's broadcast of this year's Academy Awards
fields.body:
Robin Williams is to sing the controversial Best Song Oscar nominee Blame Canada live on television, it was announced yesterday. The comic-actor, whose singing has already been showcased in Disney's 1992 animation Aladdin, will croon his way through the tune during ABC's broadcast of this year's Academy Awards.

On the face of it, this seems a recipe for disaster. Blame Canada (lifted from South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut) has already run into hot water over its provocative content, and Williams is a notoriously loose cannon, given to wandering off-script and into improvised free-fall.

The original version of the song (co-written by Trey Parker and Marc Shaiman) features a rash of insults, expletives and references to children running off to join the Ku Klux Klan. ABC executives were reported to have a requested a PG-version of the song for broadcast, but Shaiman and Parker were reluctant to rewrite the lyrics. Whether they have since capitulated, or whether the offending lyrics will be bleeped out as Williams sings them (tricky in a live broadcast) remains to be seen. Academy organisers are currently keeping the exact state of the hot-potato song under strict lock and key.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.trailText: Daily Mail Arsene Wenger is ready to buy Ajax winger Jesper Gronkjaer - as a replacement for Barcelona-bound Marc Overmars. Gronkjaer, 22, is likely to feature in Denmark's Euro 2000 squad and could be available for £5m.
fields.body:
Daily Mail Arsene Wenger is ready to buy Ajax winger Jesper Gronkjaer - as a replacement for Barcelona-bound Marc Overmars. Gronkjaer, 22, is likely to feature in Denmark's Euro 2000 squad and could be available for £5m.

The Express Nigel Winterburn will leave Highbury this summer. The 36-year-old, part of Arsenal's famous five defence, will be available on a free transfer and wants to follow in the footsteps of former team-mate Steve Bould, now at Sunderland.

Everton will not allow contract rebel Don Hutchison to leave the club for less than £3m. Hutchison is a target for both Sunderland and Middlesbrough, and if either club can match the asking price, Everton boss Walter Smith already has a replacement in mind: AEK Athens' Icelandic midfielder Arnar Gretason.

The Sun Leicester are to turn to West Brom's Lee Hughes as a replacement for Emile Heskey. The Foxes hope to sign the £2m striker before Thursday's transfer deadline. The Worthington Cup winners also hope to tie up a deal for Coventry's Noel Whelan.

Aston Villa are chasing Milwall wing-back Lucas Neill. The Australian international defender, a close friend of Harry Kewell, would cost John Gregory £1m.

Wimbledon want Spurs' reserve keeper Espen Baardsen as a replacement for Neil Sullivan, who is expected to leave the club in the summer.

The Mirror Charlton hope to sign West Ham striker Paul Kitson today. The First Division leaders will take Kitson on loan until the end of the season with a view to making the move permanent in the summer.
