webTitle: Law inspires Queensland to Cup glory

fields.headline: Law inspires Queensland to Cup glory
fields.trailText: Australia
fields.body:
Australia

Queensland have won the inaugural Pura Milk Cup after drawing with Victoria in the five-day final at the Allan Border Field in Brisbane. Queensland only needed to avoid defeat to lift the trophy, after finishing top of the group stage. They were indebted to Stuart Law, who followed a first-innings 129 with a painstaking 84 as Queensland, knowing a draw would be enough, opted for crease occupation. Law was helped by Martin Love, who hit 100 in the second innings; the pair added 174 for the third wicket in almost 80 overs.

It was hard luck for Victorian stalwart and former Test bowler Paul Reiffel, who returned match figures of 9-130 to finish top of the competition's wicket-taking list, with 59 at 16.64. Second was Queensland's Andy Bichel, who claimed 6-47 in Victoria's first innings of 182, to end the season with 53 scalps at 18.67. Matthew Elliott, the Victorian opener, became the only man to pass 1000 Cup runs (he finished with 1028 at 68.53).

Queensland have now won Australia's first-class competition (until this year known as the Sheffield Shield) three times in the last six years, having failed to win it once in the first 68 years of their existence.

Queensland 285 (Paul Reiffel 5-65) and 343 (Reiffel 4-65)
Victoria 182 (Ian Harvey 50) and 31 for 1
Drawn. Queensland win by virtue of finishing top of the group stage

India

Test seamer Venkatesh Prasad had a match analysis of 11-96 to help reigning champions Karnataka overcome Delhi by eight wickets at Bangalore and qualify directly for the semi-finals of the first-class Ranji Trophy. Prasad began with 6-60 as Delhi totalled 342 in their first innings; Akash Chopra hit 101 and added 140 for the second wicket with Gautam Gambhir (73). Then, after Karnataka had replied with 359, thanks largely to 127 from Jagadish Arunkumar, Prasad claimed 5-36 to limit Delhi to 191. This left Karnataka needing 175 to win, but an unbeaten 101 from Mithun Beerala meant it was never a problem.

Delhi 342 and 191
Karnataka 359 and 175 for 2
Karnataka won by 8 wickets

A devastating double act between Ramesh Powar and Rajesh Pawar helped Mumbai thrash Bengal at Eden Gardens and claim the other automatic semi-final spot. Until the pair came together in Mumbai's second innings, the match had been a low-scoring scrap. But they added 104 for the seventh wicket, as Ramesh blasted 92 off 77 balls, with 14 fours and a six. This left Bengal needing 381 to win. But Powar and Pawar had the, er, power, and took five wickets each (Powar 5-46, slow left-armer Pawar 5-60) to skittle Bengal for 138.

Mumbai 182 (Utpal Chatterjee 4-48) and 315 (Wasim Jaffer 73)
Bengal 117 (Abey Kuruvilla 3-12) and 138
Mumbai won by 242 runs

Group A final placings (four matches each): 1 Mumbai 32 pts, 2 Karnataka 19, 3 Bengal 13, 4 Delhi 8, 5 Rajasthan 8
Mumbai and Karnataka qualify for the semi-finals.

Punjab wallopped Railways by an innings at Delhi to finish top of group B and make it through to the quarter-finals. Ravneet Ricky hit 97 as Punjab began with 355, despite 6-84 for Kulamani Parida. Railways then folded twice. Only Yere Goud (65) put up much resistance in their first innings of 195, but their second effort was even more supine: all out for 96, with Sharandeep Singh returning figures of 9-5-22-5.

Punjab 355
Railways 195 and 96
Punjab won by an innings and 64 runs

Hyderabad joined Punjab in the quarters with a 71-run win over close rivals Baroda. Himanshu Jadhav scored 84 to give Baroda a first-innings lead of 12. And when Hyderabad got 246 in second time round Baroda were set a manageable 235 for victory and a place in the next stage of the competition. But Satwalkar took 4-41 as they were dismissed for 163.

Hyderabad 204 and 246 (Valmik Buch 5-79)
Baroda 216 and 163
Hyderabad won by 71 runs

Group B final placings: 1 Punjab 24pts, 2 Hyderabad 21, 3 Baroda 18, 4 Railways 14, 5 Bihar 3
Punjab and Hyderabad qualify for the quarter-finals

Double-centuries from Sridharan Sriram and Sridaran Sharath at Kanpur ensured Tamil Nadu's place in the quarter-finals, as they drew with Uttar Pradesh, who also made it through. Sriram, who was later chosen for India's fifth one-day international against South Africa at Nagpur, compiled 288 in over 11 hours with 38 fours, while Sharath made 205, including 32 fours and a six. Sriram shared partnerships of 109 for the second wicket with Hemang Badani (62), 212 for the third with Jayaram Madanagopal (85), and 231 for the fourth with Sharath. Offspinner Musi Raza returned figures of 61-9-196-2. UP managed just 228 in reply, with Saurabh Shukla hitting 102, before TN, realising a draw would be enough to qualify, decided not to enforce the follow-on, and were bowled out for 264, as Badani notched up 104. UP, set 733, for a win, decided against a run-chase, and tamely settled for the draw, closing on 28 for 0.

Tamil Nadu 695 for 5 decl. and 264
Uttar Pradesh 228 and 28 for 0
Drawn

Haryana and Orissa played out a less remarkable draw at Paradeep, but neither side had much hope of qualifying anyway. The performance of the match came from Haryana's slow left-armer Sonu Sharma, who claimed first-innings figures of 26.3-14-32-7.

Haryana 206 (Padamjeet Singh 51) and 298 for 8 decl. (Jasvir Singh 82, Sanjay Dalal 62)
Orissa 165 and (set 340 to win) 210 for 6
Drawn

Group C final standings: 1 Tamil Nadu 26pts, 2Uttar Pradesh 22,3 Orissa 14, 4 Saurashtra 8, 5 Haryana 8
Tamil Nadu and Uttar Pradesh qualify for the quarter-finals

Line up for the quarter/semi-finals: Tamil Nadu v Punjab (winners to play Mumbai in the semi-finals), Hyderabad v Uttar Pradesh (winners to play Karnataka in the semi-finals)

South Africa

Gauteng and Eastern Province were left sweating it out after rain ruined their deciding match in the best-of-three semi-final of the one-day Standard Bank Cup. The score stood at 1-1 after two matches, with the winners of the third game due to meet Boland in the final. The third match is due to be replayed today, weather permitting.

In the first match at Port Elizabeth, Ken Rutherford struck 59* to steer Gauteng home by six wickets. Set 180 to win in a game reduced to 38 overs a side by the rain, Gauteng reached 182 for 4 with more than two overs remaining.

Eastern Province 179 for 8 in 38 overs
Gauteng 182 for 4 in 35.5 overs
Gauteng won by six wickets

But a rasping 107* off just 112 balls from Dave Callaghan helped EP gain revenge in the second match at Johannesburg. Batting first, EP were 23 for 3, and 81 for 5 but Callaghan, who hit 15 fours, lifted them to 225 for 8. Gauteng could muster just 201 in reply, with Callaghan chipping in with 3-32 to go with Meyrick Pringle's 3-24; Zander de Bruyn made 58.

Eastern Province 225 for 8 in 45 overs
Gauteng 201 in 44 overs
Eastern Province won by 24 runs

New Zealand

Seamer Glenn Jonas picked up 10-89 for Otago - but still finished on the losing side as Northern Districts triumphed by 65 runs at the Harry Barker Reserve in Gisborne to move top of the first-class Shell Trophy after four rounds. Jonas must have thought he'd done enough after taking 6-35 as ND were bundled out for just 84 in their first innings. Shayne O'Connor weighed in with 4-29, as ND collapsed from 32 for 2 to 35 for 7. Mark Bailey hit 47, but Extras, with 10, were the next highest scorers, and four men made ducks in the middle order.

Otago then fared even worse, bowled out for 77, with Joseph Yovich (4-19) and Daryl Tuffey (4-31) doing the damage. Chris Gaffaney made 32. ND decided to knuckle down (relatively speaking) and compiled a matchwinning 172, despite Jonas taking 4-54. Otago, left 180 to win, never got close: Gaffaney hit 43, and Tim Anderson 36, but no-one else reached double-figures. Scott Styris claimed a career-best analysis of 6-32 as Otago struggled to 114.

Northern Districts 84 and 172
Otago 77 and 114
Northern Districts won by 65 runs

How they stand (after four rounds): 1 Northern Districts 20 pts, 2 Auckland 18, 3 Central Districts 14, 4 Otago 8, 5 Wellington 2, 6 Canterbury 0.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Film freaks spook Blair Witch township

fields.headline: Film freaks spook Blair Witch township
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you thought The Blair Witch Project was scary, try real life in Burkittsville, where last year's hit horror movie was filmed. The locals reckon that it will turn your hair white in a month.
fields.body:
If you thought The Blair Witch Project was scary, try real life in Burkittsville, where last year's hit horror movie was filmed. The locals reckon that it will turn your hair white in a month.

Since the low-budget film was made, the Maryland town has been inundated with self-styled witch-hunters, trainee exorcists, exhibitionists and assorted weirdos with video cameras. Most were apparently unaware that the movie, about the mysterious disappearance of three film students in Burkittsville's wooded hills, was a work of fiction.

The story's cinéma vérité style seems to have convinced many that Burkittsville is a community riddled with satanic rites. The intruders, from all over the country, have daubed satanic symbols in the churches, cut down town signs with a chainsaw, pranced in the cemetery, urinated in gardens and followed the citizens about as if they were a 24-hour freak show.

All in all, this latest outbreak of cinema-driven hysteria has been a bit too much for the 214 people of Burkittsville. They are mad as hell, and they are not going to take it any more.

As artist Andrea Cox put it: "When you have a bunch of drunken teenagers, tripped out in their best Blair outfits, leaping around at 3am, screaming 'whoooooh' and stomping on grandma, it doesn't go down too well."

So it was not altogether surprising that when a group of producers came to discuss making a sequel to the movie, they were run out of town, in a now infamous showdown between rural earthiness and urban chic at a town meeting on Valentine's day.

"We thought we were going to talk about the trash pick-up," Ms Cox said. "But here were these people with cell-phones, silk scarves and mineral water. A little sleek line of folks who were too good to drink our water."

Cultural misunderstandings turned to abuse. As one of the would-be producers got up to speak about what Blair Witch 2 could do for the town, the mayor's irascible husband, Sam Brown, yelled: "We've already been raped. Now they want us to be prostitutes."

"Then a second person stood up and said pretty much the same thing - get out of town, so they left. Nobody was standing up and saying stay, so they left," said Michael Styer, who runs the Maryland Film Office. "It was not a pleasant thing."

Mr Styer's job is to attract film-makers to Maryland for the benefit of the local economy. In those terms, the Valentine's day verbal massacre was scarcely encouraging, and he does not believe that the Blair Witch producers, Artisan Entertainment, will be back.

"The mayor [Joyce Brown] wrote an apology to us and the company, and said she would like us to come back and reconsider. But I think it's too late. They have alternative spots," Mr Styer said.

If the mayor does indeed want the film-makers to return, there is a serious rift in her family. When Mr Brown answered their telephone this week, he refused to pass the line to his wife. "I hate to tell you but you just wasted your call," he shouted and hung up.

Mr Styer believes that the town, a cluster of 19th century brick and wood houses set in rolling farmland, is failing to make use of a golden opportunity offered by a sequel, which could generate up to $10m (£6.25m) for Maryland. But so far the only sign of entrepreneurial zeal is a couple of T-shirts hung in the window of a local art gallery, inscribed with half-hearted jokes like: "Witch way to Burkittsville?"

For most townsfolk, antipathy to the outsiders has overcome the profit motive. The cemetery where most of the locals have ancestors buried is under police surveillance, following incidents of desecration in which at least one tombstone was upended.

The African Methodist Episcopalian church on the outskirts of the town has been broken into four times since The Blair Witch Project emerged as last year's unexpected movie blockbuster. The church's pastor, Reverend Richard Dyson, said: "They painted a satanic circle on the floor and words on the wall like 'God is dead' and 'the Devil is alive', and things like that." Rev Dyson, however, is not easily spooked.

Curious to see what had driven people to such lengths, he rented a video of the film and watched in bewilderment as the hand-held camera pursued unseen witches and ghosts through the night forest.

"It's just people walking through the woods, talking and cussing, but that's just like life isn't it?" he said. What, he wanted to know, was all the fuss about?

"We thought we were going to talk about the trash pick-up," Ms Cox said. "But here were these people with cell-phones, silk scarves and mineral water. A little sleek line of folks who were too good to drink our water." Cultural misunderstandings turned to abuse. As one of the would-be producers got up to speak about what Blair Witch 2 could do for the town, the mayor's irascible husband, Sam Brown, yelled: "We've already been raped. Now they want us to be prostitutes." "Then a second person stood up and said pretty much the same thing - get out of town, so they left. Nobody was standing up and saying stay, so they left," said Michael Styer, who runs the Maryland Film Office. "It was not a pleasant thing." Mr Styer's job is to attract film-makers to Maryland for the benefit of the local economy. In those terms, the Valentine's day verbal massacre was scarcely encouraging, and he does not believe that the Blair Witch producers, Artisan Entertainment, will be back. "The mayor [Joyce Brown] wrote an apology to us and the company, and said she would like us to come back and reconsider. But I think it's too late. They have alternative spots," Mr Styer said. If the mayor does indeed want the film-makers to return, there is a serious rift in her family. When Mr Brown answered their telephone this week, he refused to pass the line to his wife. "I hate to tell you but you just wasted your call," he shouted and hung up. Mr Styer believes that the town, a cluster of 19th century brick and wood houses set in rolling farmland, is failing to make use of a golden opportunity offered by a sequel, which could generate up to $10m (£6.25m) for Maryland. But so far the only sign of entrepreneurial zeal is a couple of T-shirts hung in the window of a local art gallery, inscribed with half-hearted jokes like: "Witch way to Burkittsville?" For most townsfolk, antipathy to the outsiders has overcome the profit motive. The cemetery where most of the locals have ancestors buried is under police surveillance, following incidents of desecration in which at least one tombstone was upended. The African Methodist Episcopalian church on the outskirts of the town has been broken into four times since The Blair Witch Project emerged as last year's unexpected movie blockbuster. The church's pastor, Reverend Richard Dyson, said: "They painted a satanic circle on the floor and words on the wall like 'God is dead' and 'the Devil is alive', and things like that." Rev Dyson, however, is not easily spooked. Curious to see what had driven people to such lengths, he rented a video of the film and watched in bewilderment as the hand-held camera pursued unseen witches and ghosts through the night forest. "It's just people walking through the woods, talking and cussing, but that's just like life isn't it?" he said. What, he wanted to know, was all the fuss about?

fields.headline: Unknown bags 52 Oscars
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: And the winner of this year's Oscars is... Willie Fulgear. The laid-back, freelance salvage worker has managed to get his hands on more Oscars than Jack Nicholson, Katharine Hepburn and Meryl Streep combined after stumbling across the statuettes beside a rubbish bin in Los Angeles.
fields.body:
And the winner of this year's Oscars is... Willie Fulgear. The laid-back, freelance salvage worker has managed to get his hands on more Oscars than Jack Nicholson, Katharine Hepburn and Meryl Streep combined after stumbling across the statuettes beside a rubbish bin in Los Angeles.

Soon after Mr Fulgear's discovery on Sunday of all but three of the stolen Oscars - reported missing last week - the Los Angeles police revealed that they had arrested two suspects the day before. Both worked for the company that was transporting the statuettes from the manufacturers in Chicago to California for next week's Academy Awards.

The statuettes were still wrapped in their boxes, dumped beside garbage bins in Koreatown, not far from Hollywood. Mr Fulgear, who lives near by in a one-room apartment, was looking for cardboard boxes to pack his belongings for a move.

"My foot hit one and it was heavy," said Mr Fulgear, who stashed the Oscars in the boot of his car and headed home to contact a TV station and the police, in that order. "I wanted to make sure no one else got them," he said.

Now Mr Fulgear is waiting to see if he qualifies for the $50,000 (£30,000) reward offered by the shipping firm. He had not been aware that the Oscars were missing. Yesterday there were even suggestions that he might be in line to present one of the Oscars at Sunday's ceremony.

The Los Angeles police chief, Bernard Parks - whose force is mired in corruption allegations - was clearly delighted to have some good news to announce.

Replacement Oscars had already been ordered from the Chicago manufacturers last week and it was unclear if the lost ones would be used at the awards ceremony or would be held by the police as part of their investigation into how the statuettes went missing from a transport depot in Bell, California.

The finding of the Oscars is a relief for the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Earlier in the month, 4,000 ballots for academy members to cast their votes for the awards had gone missing in the mail and had to be re-sent.

Already fans wanting to get a glimpse of stars arriving for the awards have started staking out the Shrine auditorium where the ceremony will be.

About 30 people have pitched tents to be at the head of the queue to see the nominees walk down the red carpet. And maybe even cheer as Hollywood's latest celebrity, Willie Fulgear, gets out of his stretch limo.

fields.headline: Love and hate
fields.standfirst: In 1976, Shere Hite's report on female sexuality made her a household name - and a sitting target. Now she is hitting back.  Joan Smith reports
fields.trailText: In 1976, Shere Hite's report on female sexuality made her a household name - and a sitting target. Now she is hitting back.
fields.body:
Pale blonde hair, huge blue eyes, lips painted the same shade of red as the roses she holds against her naked body: Shere Hite is back in town. As well as appearing on the cover of her new book in this extravagantly romantic pose, her name appears twice: this is her autobiography, The Hite Report on Shere Hite. It is the story of a little girl from the Midwest who grew up to become a model, pose for Playboy, discover feminism and ask awkward questions about women and sex.

It is about a childhood as American, on the face of it, as apple pie. Hite grew up in St Joseph, Missouri, with its annual Apple Blossom Festival, in a devoutly Christian household. She was a girl scout who went to her senior prom with her first boyfriend, wearing a strapless dress with a full skirt. Yet under this smooth surface, another story bubbles: Hite had a disrupted childhood, barely seeing her mother, living with her grandparents until they separated, spending a year with an aunt in Florida. Real things happened somewhere else, she concluded: "Where I lived, things were only shadows."

The book is also about her bestselling reports on sexuality and love. It describes how she was driven from the US to Europe by attacks from rightwing politicians. It is (in passing) about her happy marriage to a younger man, a German concert pianist, and her crusading insistence that women can be beautiful and intellectual.

To prove her point, she posed six years ago for the photographer Iris Brosch, reclining like a water nymph in a Parisian fountain. "I don't want to have to appear as only intellect in order to be taken seriously," she wrote in her diary at the time. Even now, in her late 50s, she is willowy, gorgeous and apparently comfortable with her body at an age when, we are told, women have to accept they are invisible.

This is the up side of the Hite story. The down side is that her research methods have been attacked as unscientific; she has been accused of being egotistical, out of date, of manipulating the replies to her questionnaires to produce the answers she wants. And that is leaving aside the attacks of the American right, for whom she is a she-devil incarnate.

Somewhere in this melodramatic history is a real person, desperate to give her side of the story. There is no doubt Hite has been hurt by the assaults and that the autobiography is her attempt to put the record straight. It is, in part, an expression of amazement at the way people react to her vivid presence, their failure to recognise the liberating effect of both her books and her appearance. Don't we want to hear the message that a woman can be brilliant and sexy, long after the menopause?

As for her books, it was Hite whose original report on female sexuality in 1976 popularised the notion that most women need clitoral stimulation to reach orgasm. This assertion is so obvious now that its revolutionary impact at the time is almost forgotten. Hite was setting herself up against authorities on sex, from Freud to Kinsey, who insisted that women who didn't have vaginal orgasms were dysfunctional. When critics complained her conclusions were based on only 3,000 women, Hite responded that Freud's theories generalised from "three upper-class Viennese women".

Her next book, The Hite Report on Male Sexuality in 1981, stirred up more controversy with its claim that men had been conditioned to pursue penetration at the cost of sensuality. She expanded her sample to 7,000 replies - but has never been able to deflect the charge that there is no way of verifying the results of her anonymous questionnaires.

It was her third book, however, Women and Love: A Cultural Revolution in Progress, that really frightened the horses. It was, she now claims, the "first time human rights standards were applied to private relationships". Exposing the "emotional battering" some women endure in the name of love, Hite asked questions about its very nature and the kind of relationships women might want in future. She was attacked in articles, on the cover of Time magazine, on radio and TV. She became, she says, "a symbolic love-hate object, a fetishistic target for fundamental extremists... who acted as if I must be stopped at any cost."

If this seems hyperbolic it is because Hite is still being treated with a degree of contempt that is mystifying when you look at what she has actually said and done. The Daily Mail was at it again on Saturday, screaming: "A sex guru or simply a charlatan?" The article's author, Lesley Garner, struggled to be fair but concluded: "She is a beautiful, self-promoting narcissist who attempts to blind us with what she claims is science when her books are no more than an accumulation of anecdotes from a vocal, dissatisfied minority."

Beautiful? Self-promoting? Not like any of those male authors who are profiled in lads' mags and weekend newspapers, then. No wonder Hite is pissed off. In a sense, she is the victim of her own desire to be taken seriously. Her theories on sex and love ring true with so many women that it does not matter much to her readers whether she has proved them scientifically. Nor does it seem fair to criticise her methodology, yet accept at face value the findings of Alfred Kinsey, whose distorted samples have recently come to light (he generalised about male sexuality from the responses of men in prison, for instance).

Hite emerges from her latest book as someone who has, from childhood, questioned received wisdom, endlessly testing it against her own experience. "I had been waiting, waiting to be grown-up, free!" she says at one point. "I wanted to do everything - work, see the world, learn about love! Live!"

The mistake people make about Hite is to see her as a one-off, a single-minded narcissist with nothing on her agenda but her own advancement. On the contrary, Hite is a revolutionary in the sense 18th-century thinkers such as Olympe de Gouges or Mary Wollstonecraft would have understood. It is a depressing reminder of how far we have to go that a woman who sets out to defy sexism is still condemned as vain and attention-seeking. Strip away the sneers and what really scares people about Hite is the fact that she is a beautiful, clever, sexy, self-made woman.

fields.headline: Sat in your lap
fields.standfirst: Roger Frost reports on an initiative, first tried in the States and recently launched here by Microsoft, which aims to see every child owning a portable computer
fields.trailText: Roger Frost reports on an initiative, first tried in the States and recently launched here by Microsoft, which aims to see every child owning a portable computer
fields.body:
Imagine a class turning up to your lesson with a laptop computer apiece and then taking them home again at the end of the day to do homework.

Improving ICT skills would no longer be the main focus as the government's aim of "integrating technology with everyday teaching" would have been met.

Well, for one group of UK schools that time is here. The old, fixed computer suite now moves from room to room - while the teachers think up ingenious new ways to teach.

At Banstead junior school, Surrey, children use Microsoft Powerpoint - "the slideshow software flaunted on Inset days" - for literacy work. They turn a piece of reported speech into the direct speech they need to make a great slide presentation. Likewise, when given a presentation, they practise turning it into a report.

And at Les Landes primary school, Jersey, the teachers have put the text of the school play, Oliver, into Microsoft Word and got the children to pick out key words about the different characters, then write character studies. Headteacher Ann Renouf says the job would be impossible without word processing, and the children now seemed to "own" the production.

At Sawtry community college, Cambridgeshire, key stage three pupils used PowerPoint to give a talk in French. As vice-principal Alan Stevens says, there is more to this than good looks. "The content is better, their confidence in reading French is better and the situation is that much richer."

The schools, 28 in all, were part of a Microsoft project called Anytime, Anywhere Learning which appears to have fostered an explosion of creative teaching. The project, which aims to see every child owning a portable computer, was recently launched nationally in London by Microsoft's chairman Bill Gates.

Gates's presence, the work going on, the motivated pupils, reactivated teachers and some interesting parent-school partnerships hint of something "big" to come.

At Sawtry, what started with a single class equipped with two dozen laptops has grown so much that by this September half the school, and all the teachers, will have a laptop.

Funding all this has got to be interesting. For some pioneers, like Bowbridge junior school in Lincolnshire, it wasn't all easy, says headteacher David Dixon. "The money issue was the big stumbling block. Even though it felt against our principles, I looked at how the parents could finance it and we came up with £7.50 per week - the parents were excited about it, too.

"We tried to set up a credit union but the most workable model was a charitable foundation. As result we now have two groups with laptops."

Maybe the day will come when a laptop will be as ubiquitous as a pencil case, "were it not for the cost".

People are worried that not all parents will be able to afford tomorrow's battery-powered, hi-tech pencil-cases. But Mark East, manager of Microsoft Education, is confident that there are ways forward: "We've created a framework where schools or local education authorities can set up a charitable "e-learning" foundation, with deeds of covenant and tax-efficient ways of using money. We believe parents will contribute to technology for their child.

"For example, we know that 45% of families have bought a PC to help their children's learning, many over the last year, so we have a good base to work to. But we do see a need for a national charity which a local foundation could approach to request funds."

While Microsoft has pledged a first £1m to the collection tin, East points to a benefit for school fundraising. "Establishing a local foundation provides a vehicle for schools to generate funds. They have a process of going out to the local community with all the tax advantages from having a charitable foundation."

The community link has worked well for Bowbridge, adds David Dixon. "Before the laptops came about we had been trying to raise the profile of learning in our community via various other means. A big benefit of the laptops is that we've had more conversations about learning with our parents than we have ever had. The parents come in, we talk about laptops and why we want them for the school. It's generated a dialogue which we wouldn't have had normally."

With Anytime, Anywhere Learning and a government pledged to the ICT way, many will ask if technology is paying its way. The government agency, Becta, has led pilots with laptop handouts for schools, teachers and headteachers - and each time the vibes have been positive.

An evaluation programme run by Lancaster university tells of improving literacy, numeracy, community links and more. And then there are views from the chalkface: science teacher Andy Johnson says using ICT enables pupils to get through to the thinking part of the work far quicker.

"It's great for working in groups, great for children to put over their ideas and it's not so much me talking and chalking."

And after just a couple of terms, David Dixon could note that year four's ICT skills in laptop group were overtaking year six. And then there are no more Friday lessons: "We've seen an improvement in the motivation - you can do things on a Friday afternoon you would never attempt. And the special needs children also gain a lot in terms of self-esteem and motivation so the signs are very, very good."

 Useful contacts: www.microsoft.com/uk/education/aal. For an AAL action pack, call 0870 60 70 800

fields.headline: Pass notes: Mariella Frostrup
fields.trailText: Age: 39.
fields.body:
Age: 39.

Appearance: More appealing than Malcolm Bradbury.

Voice: Sexy, husky - "Could melt the elastic on men's underwear" (© Daily Mirror).

Status: Just-appointed judge for the Booker Prize 2000.

Who else is on the panel? Oh, various academics and literary types that no one's really interested in.

Try me: If you insist. Columnist Simon Jenkins, history prof Roy Foster, novelist Rose Tremain and literary editor Caroline Gascoigne.

Mariella is presumably the token blonde bombshell . . . How dare you!

Like Jerry Hall at this year's Whitbread. Jerry was a noted fan of James Joyce and famously preferred Hector Berlioz to Harry Potter.

Does Mariella like books? She adores Gabriel Garcia Márquez.

All three of them? You are beneath contempt.

What does she do? Writes film reviews for the News of the World and book reviews for the Mail on Sunday; presents TV programmes; runs a TV production company called Brazen Husky; sits on arts awards panels.

Tabloid tales: Born in Oslo; her Norwegian father and Scottish mother separated when she was six; headed for London at 16; short-lived marriage to punk rocker Richard Jobson; accused of poaching Anneka Rice's husband (denied).

Mariella on men: "They are bitterly disappointed when they meet me. They expect me to be sweetly flirtatious, only to discover that I'm a caustic old cow."

Mariella on misogyny: "It pisses me off constantly that women are judged by hair colour and looks."

Mariella on the muse: "The only thing that stops me writing is that I might not be as good as Márquez, Rushdie or Graham Greene."

Might? Ah, you remember her Sunday Times column, too.

Not to be confused with: Ulrika Jonsson (a shoo-in for next year's Whitbread award panel?).

Do mention: Fay Weldon.

Don't mention: Selina Scott.

Columnist Simon Jenkins, history prof Roy Foster, novelist Rose Tremain and literary editor Caroline Gascoigne. Mariella is presumably the token blonde bombshell . . . How dare you! Like Jerry Hall at this year's Whitbread. Jerry was a noted fan of James Joyce and famously preferred Hector Berlioz to Harry Potter. Does Mariella like books? She adores Gabriel Garcia Márquez. All three of them? You are beneath contempt. What does she do? Writes film reviews for the News of the World and book reviews for the Mail on Sunday; presents TV programmes; runs a TV production company called Brazen Husky; sits on arts awards panels. Tabloid tales: Born in Oslo; her Norwegian father and Scottish mother separated when she was six; headed for London at 16; short-lived marriage to punk rocker Richard Jobson; accused of poaching Anneka Rice's husband (denied). Mariella on men: "They are bitterly disappointed when they meet me. They expect me to be sweetly flirtatious, only to discover that I'm a caustic old cow." Mariella on misogyny: "It pisses me off constantly that women are judged by hair colour and looks." Mariella on the muse: "The only thing that stops me writing is that I might not be as good as Márquez, Rushdie or Graham Greene." Might? Ah, you remember her Sunday Times column, too. Not to be confused with: Ulrika Jonsson (a shoo-in for next year's Whitbread award panel?). Do mention: Fay Weldon. Don't mention: Selina Scott.

fields.headline: Rabbi Jesus
fields.standfirst:
For centuries, relations between Jews and Catholics have been poisoned by the Vatican's portrayal of Jews as God-killers. But as the Pope begins a historic tour of the Holy Land today, celebrated Israeli novelist Amos Oz says the key to reconciliation lies in seeing Christ for what he was - a great Jew
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: For centuries, relations between Jews and Catholics have been poisoned by the Vatican's portrayal of Jews as God-killers. But as the Pope begins a historic tour of the Holy Land today, celebrated Israeli novelist Amos Oz says the key to reconciliation lies in seeing Christ for what he was - a great Jew
fields.body:
Older members of my family, Jewish refugees from eastern Europe, turn their eyes the other way each time they walk past a church. Some of them tense up when they see a cross or even hear the sound of distant church bells. As a child, I used to ask many questions about Jesus, but I received only a few reluctant answers. In the presence of some of my aunts, talk about Jesus and talk about sex evokes an identical reaction: why don't we talk about something pleasant instead?

When I was eight or nine, I came home from school one day and revealed to my grandmother that Jesus was actually a Jew. I thought she would deny it on the spot, but she just commented sadly: "Well, I wish he weren't. For thousands of years, every one of us Jews gets blamed for the troubles he so eagerly brought upon himself." I grew up nursing a strange mixture of emotions concerning "them" and "us", finding myself siding with Jesus and the Jews, the underdogs, rather than with the Church and my aunts.

Many years later, I shared a second class compartment on a French night train with two young Catholic nuns. We passed the time in small talk, and it came out that I was from Jerusalem. As I mentioned it, they exchanged a look of alarm and then one of them asked me sheepishly, isn't Jerusalem full of Jews these days? I said that as a matter of fact I was myself a Jew. Silence. Then the younger of the two said: "He was so sweet; how could the Jews do it to him?" There was such piercing pain and sadness in her voice that I wanted to tell her that it wasn't me - I just happened to have had a dentist's appointment on that particular Friday. Suddenly, perhaps for the first time in my life, this Israeli-born Jew got a sense of what my aunts and my grandmother were not talking about.

And yet, the more I read about Jesus, the more I agreed with that nun on one thing at least: he was indeed sweet. That his name evokes such bitterness in members of my family, indeed in millions of Jews, has to do with his disciples, not with him. First and foremost, it has to do with the Catholic Church which for centuries portrayed the Jews as God-killers. How awesome and how gruesome the Jews must have seemed to generations of simple Christian believers: people who could and who would kill a God must be both more and less than human.

But my Jesus is neither. He is entirely human. As Pope John Paul II goes to Nazareth and to Bethlehem, to the Sea of Galilee and to Jerusalem, he will be travelling in the footsteps of one of the most genuine Jews who ever lived. I often call him Rabbi Jesus. Some of my Jewish friends as well as some of my Christian friends are uncomfortable with this title, yet Jesus's original followers often called him just that: "rabbi" - a Hebrew word that does not mean "father" or "prophet" or "holy", but simply "teacher". And a teacher he was; a non-orthodox Jewish teacher who wanted to take Judaism back to what he regarded as its pure origins, or forward towards what he regarded as its uncompromising consequences. Needless to say, he was no Christian: he taught and argued in many synagogues but could never have set foot in a church, nor ever crossed himself or kneeled before any cross, or icon or image, not once in his life. In modern-day terminol ogy, he lived as a reforming Jew and died as a non-conforming Jew.

I often wonder how Rabbi Jesus would have felt inside a cathedral or amidst earthly manifestations of Catholic might. I wonder how this blunt, ironic, barefoot, young Galilean poet would view the Vicar of Christ if he met him travelling these days across Galilee with his majestic retinue, surrounded by thousands of armed Jewish guards. Would Jesus regard himself as one of the guests? Or as one of the hosts? Would he be among the cheering crowds? Fall on his knees? Would the pontiff's visit to Galilee make him feel more like my aunts and grandmother or more like those French nuns?

Although every Christian calls him Saviour, to me he is simply Yeshu Jesus - son of Miriam and Yosef, who was absolutely right about the rigidity and the hypocrisy of organised religion, for instance, as well as about the universal need for compassion.

For centuries, the Jews have been on the receiving end of Christian love. They have been constantly told they must change. They have to love Jesus whether they love him or not. Since the Jews have usually had trouble loving Jesus, Spanish inquisitors or Christian pogrom makers, next-door anti-semites were always there to assist them in finding love. "The conversion of the Jews", in the vocabulary of the Church, has become synonymous with the Second Coming, and with the salvation of the world. By stubbornly rejecting Jesus and refusing to convert, the Jews have made themselves guilty of postponing Redemption, thus prolonging the suffering in the world. Therefore they belong on the cross.

This, of course, is not a summation of the entire Jewish-Catholic history. There have been bad times and worse times. In the 20th century came the lowest point in this relationship, at least since the days of the Spanish Inquisition, when Pope Pius XII failed to condemn unambiguously the mass murder of the Jews by the Nazi Germans, and refrained from calling upon his flocks to shelter the hunted Jews. On January 15 1964, Pope Paul VI came to visit the Holy Land. From the Jordanian West Bank, he crossed the next day into Israel and spent a few hours there, frequenting holy sites but never once mentioning the term "Israel". He was cautious not to say "Jews" either, but insisted on the term "the children of the Covenant of Abraham".

He made it very clear that he had come for a pilgrimage, not for a visit. Concluding his stay with a mass on Mount Zion, he avoided Yad Va'Shem, Israel's national Holocaust museum and memorial, and every other site with Jewish religious or national significance. In his farewell speech, as he was about to leave the country that he refused to mention by name, Paul VI nevertheless praised his mentor, Pope Pius XII, defending Pius's silence during the Holocaust.

After returning to the Vatican, he sent a polite telegram addressed to "President Shazar, Tel Aviv", evading not only the word Israeli but even any reference to Jerusalem as its capital city (de facto), thus adding insult to injury: even as recently as the 1960s, the Vatican treated Israel as a non-country, its people as a non-nation, and its government as a nonentity. Rabbi Jesus might have regarded such haughty papal conduct as Pharisean.

Much has changed since that unfortunate previous pontifical journey to the Holy Land. Even earlier, an initial breakthrough in relations between the Catholic Church and the Jewish people was accomplished by Pope John XXIII who acquitted the Jews of collective responsibility for the killing of Jesus. There followed a gradual, hesitant beginning of Church-sponsored Jewish-Catholic dialogue that eventually led to an official apology by the Catholic Church for its part in the historic ordeal of the Jews. Pope John Paul II is the living spirit behind the various reconciliatory steps that culminated the estab lishment of full diplomatic relations between Israel and the Vatican.

However, my one aunt who is still alive (though very old now) is not quite satisfied. She maintains that an apology is not enough, that the Catholic Church - and the Christian world in general - has yet to do some serious soul-searching and self-criticism about their historic treatment of the Jews. In her view, the least the Christians can do now to atone for their many sins toward the Jews is to side with Israel in its dispute with the Arabs.

I suspect that what my aunt really wants from the Pope is something that even Jesus could not supply: a river of unconditional love which she thinks the Christians owe the State of Israel and every single Jew. She wants the Pope and every other Christian to want Jerusalem to be full of Jews. After what the Church has inflicted on the Jews for thousands of years, my aunt will settle for nothing short of a Zionist Pope.

The Arabs, on the other hand, want him entirely on their side. They expect the Church and the whole of Christendom to see things their way. Moreover, various Arab publications often portray the Jews as the com mon enemy of both Christianity and Islam. In fact, some of the ugliest anti-Jewish Islamic manifestations are borrowed word for word from the vast arsenal of centuries-old Christian anti-semitism.

As Pope John Paul travels the Holy Land, through those parts which are the State of Israel and those that will soon become the State of Palestine, he might do well to turn his trip into more than just another pilgrimage to holy sites. He could turn it into an emotionally significant visit with two nations, Israeli Jews and Palestinian Arabs, deeply injured not only - and not primarily - by each other, but first and foremost by Christian Europe.

Perhaps the Pope's prime message during this visit could be addressed not to Jews or Muslims but to Christians: Christian Europe bears a long-standing responsibility for much of the suffering of both conflicting parties in the Middle East. It is therefore the moral duty of Europe to sponsor peace in the Middle East by assisting all parties in every way possible. Rather than constantly taking sides, wagging their fingers like an old-fashioned schoolmaster chastising an unruly pupil, it is time for the people of Europe to give all parties every possible form of moral and material support in their current attempt to reach a compromise solution that is destined to be painful and frustrating for everyone involved. It is no longer necessary for anyone outside the region to choose between being pro-Israeli or pro-Palestinian; it is now possible to be pro-peace by empathising with both.

When I was a small child, my wise grandmother explained to me in simple terms the difference between Jew and Christian (but her words of wisdom could well apply to any religious differences). "You see," she said, "the Christians believe that the Messiah has been here once and will one day return; the Jews maintain that the Messiah has yet to come. Over this, there has been endless hatred and bloodshed. Why? Why can't everybody simply wait and see? If the Messiah comes saying, 'Hello, it's nice to see you again,' then the Jews will have to concede. If, on the other hand, he comes saying, 'How do you do?' then the entire Christian world will have to apologise to the Jews. Until that time, why not just live and let live?"

"Forgive them," said Rabbi Jesus, "for they know not what they are doing." Well, I would go along with Christian wisdom about forgiveness, but not with the "know not" bit. Even as we ought to try to forgive one another for various past injustices, we should not do so on the grounds of moral infantility or ethical imbecility. We all know what we are doing whenever we inflict pain, cause humiliation or give offence, because at one time or another we all have been at the receiving end.

© Amos Oz 2000. English translation by Amos Oz and Maggie Bar-Tura

fields.headline: The king and I
fields.trailText: Would the Queen be more popular with Australians if she chowed down with them at barbecues? Matthew Engel in this newspaper certainly suggested recently that "ordinary guy", King Harald of Norway, could teach her a "thing or two".
fields.body:
Would the Queen be more popular with Australians if she chowed down with them at barbecues? Matthew Engel in this newspaper certainly suggested recently that "ordinary guy", King Harald of Norway, could teach her a "thing or two".

However, in my experience an ordinary royal is an oxymoron. They may ride bicycles, but they are always on pedestals - and they look to each other, not for lessons, but for a safety net when they fall off them. I studied with interest the Guardian's photograph of the previous King of Norway - Olav V - travelling on a tram. It was taken about a year before he came to lunch at my parent's terraced house in London.

It was an event that proved about as "ordinary" as a Martian landing. I was 14, an age when you are desperate to blend in with your peers. This proved difficult when, in the middle of a class, my teacher announced, "Leanda is now going off for lunch with a king." I concentrated very hard on piling up my exercise books as one of those peers goaded, "I didn't know you knew any kings, Leanda."

Indeed I hadn't made friends with any kings down at the local Wimpy Bar. However, from what I'd heard, my father had almost grown up with the Norwegian royal family. They had lived in his parents' house in Berkshire for much of the second world war. I didn't wonder at the time why this should be, since there is no accounting for the behaviour of one's parents or grandparents. Nevertheless, I did worry what our neighbours and the regulars in our street's five pubs, would make of the Rolls-Royce that drew up outside our front door.

The area we lived in - Brook Green in west London - is now so chic that it is difficult to believe that it was working class until less than 20 years ago. But it was so, and there were few cars there besides my parents' old Ford Cortina.

The image of the king's impossibly big, curvaceous and shiny Rolls-Royce still stays with me. When it arrived, it looked like a patent leather clad duchess parked on the dusty curb. On its bonnet a flag fluttered in the breeze. Clearly King Olav V had decided against visiting us incognito.

Why was he coming to visit? My great-uncle, Sir Cecil Dormer had been the British minister in Norway when the Nazis invaded in 1940. He persuaded King Haakon VII, together with the then Crown Prince Olav and the entire Norwegian cabinet to flee on the HMS Devonshire.

While at sea, the Devonshire received a message. The aircraft carrier Glorious and two escort destroyers, had come under German attack. The signal was ignored. The official story is that it had been too garbled for the captain, Admiral Cunningham, to make sense of. However witnesses have since said that it was perfectly clear. Not long after, Glorious and her escorts sank. There were 900 men who went into the water, but the Devonshire kept to her course and maintained radio silence. Three days later a passing Norwegian trawler rescued a mere 41 survivors.

I expect the lunches Admiral Cunningham attended at my grandparents' house were rather different from the one I served for the Norwegian king, squeezing my way around the chairs in our tiny London dining room.

However my father remembered the etiquette: he told me that I must not eat after the king had finished his food. Unfortunately by the time I'd sat down after serving each course, the king had had his fill and I was left staring forlornly at my plate.

The meal then concluded with him falling asleep. He appeared to be very old. It seems strange to me that his life might once have meant as much as that of 900 young men.

However, the lives of the Norwegian royal family were important not only to the British government, for whom they had propaganda value, but to George VI. Saving his uncle-in-law and first cousin might have helped expunge the memory of other royal cousins who had needed his family's help, but were left to die.

For both the British and Norwegian royal families, the other battleship that never came was the one that failed to rescue the Tsar and his family after 1917. King Haakon said to my grandparents that he offered to send a battleship for the Tsar, but George V, his brother-in-law, had told him not to bother: he would do so himself.

Documents about the 1917-18 imprisonment of the imperial family have been removed from the British royal archives. However, George V's campaign to refuse the Tsar asylum is well recorded. My grandparents always said King Haakon never forgave him for the Tsar's subsequent death. In 1940, King Haakon and Crown Prince Olav were not to be allowed to suffer the same fate.

fields.headline: Queen reignites republic debate
fields.standfirst:
Australia and the monarchy: special report
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The Queen officially kicked off her two-week tour of Australia yesterday with a speech that delighted even diehard republicans by hinting that further constitutional change was possible.
fields.body:
The Queen officially kicked off her two-week tour of Australia yesterday with a speech that delighted even diehard republicans by hinting that further constitutional change was possible.

Just four months after a referendum in which Australia rejected republican moves and chose to keep her as head of state, the Queen said the country had always been on the move and must look forward as well as back.

"Whatever the future may bring, my lasting respect and deep affection for Australia and Australians everywhere will remain as strong as ever. That is what I have come here to say," she said.

Earlier, larger than expected crowds braved the wet and dreary weather to wave their flags at Sydney Opera House, where the monarch was greeted by a 21-gun salute.

fields.headline: 'Bullies rule' at youth prison
fields.standfirst:
Inspector condemns treatment of inmates
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: The treatment of prisoners at a young offenders' institution in Dorset is condemned as "wholly unacceptable" in a report by the chief inspector of prisons published today.
fields.body:
The treatment of prisoners at a young offenders' institution in Dorset is condemned as "wholly unacceptable" in a report by the chief inspector of prisons published today.

As a result of his inspection of Portland young offenders' institution, Sir David Ramsbotham expresses serious concerns about the level of assaults and violence among prisoners and unauthorised "bullying routines" by staff. He also records resistance by officers to attempts to change its "militaristic" regime.

The chief inspector says that the governor, Kevin Lockyer, who arrived in autumn last year, has tried to end the "outdated militaristic systems for enforcing good order and discipline, such as the regimented labour parade".

But many staff approved of this as a way of controlling through fear, particularly in the segregation unit.

Mr Lockyer has made improvements but there were "strongly held feelings, freely expressed by staff, which were very critical of these changes". Staff complained that the changes had undermined officers' authority, the level of assaults had risen, and younger inmates were carrying weapons to protect themselves.

The chief inspector says any member of staff who feels unable to work by establishing a "pro-active relationship" with young prisoners should be removed.

Sir David says there is a culture at the prison known as the "Portland way" which "amounted to the belief that only certain young prisoners would be sent there - the more subversive - for disciplining. And disciplining by fear and shouting is what we mean by outdated militaristic systems."

Following his second inspection visit in two years, Sir David says that "no one, policy or line manager, should have tolerated the disgraceful squalor in which young prisoners are forced to live, in 1848 accommodation last renovated in 1932, which the governor accurately described to me as a 'moral outrage'."

The chief inspector adds that it is also outrageous that slopping out, which was supposed to have been abolished in 1996, continued in two wings and that 576 youngsters, aged between 15 and 21, are denied access to fresh air because the finest outside playing fields in the prison service have been fenced off for "security reasons".

The lack of care for young prisoners at Portland is characterised by the fact that at least half of those released are of "no fixed abode".

"This is a disturbing report revealing conditions which have been allowed to continue for far too long. The prison is, in effect, in limbo, lacking any coherent strategy for managing and disciplining a very challenging group of offenders. It is regrettable that good practice evident in other young offenders' institutions has not filtered through to Portland."

Martin Narey, the director general of the prison service, said that when he visited Portland a year ago shortly after taking over his job it was clear there were serious inadequacies in the regime: "I took immediate steps to ensure a process of change was implemented. This process, acknowledged by the chief inspector, is being driven forward by the new governor."

fields.headline: European revolution
fields.standfirst: Romano Prodi: The EU must deregulate and modernise to be competitive
fields.trailText: So loud is the clamour of the debate in Britain over membership of the euro that one would be forgiven for failing to notice a quieter revolution under way in the European Union: the growing awareness from the Arctic to Andalusia and from Greece to Galway that if Europe does not dramatically improve its economic competitiveness it will lose out as the world shifts to a digital, knowledge-based and truly global economy.
fields.body:
So loud is the clamour of the debate in Britain over membership of the euro that one would be forgiven for failing to notice a quieter revolution under way in the European Union: the growing awareness from the Arctic to Andalusia and from Greece to Galway that if Europe does not dramatically improve its economic competitiveness it will lose out as the world shifts to a digital, knowledge-based and truly global economy.

This seeping realisation of the need to act fast culminates in a special summit in Lisbon this week. If, as I hope, Mr Blair and his fellow EU leaders agree radical measures spearheaded by the European commission to turn this situation around, then even the most hardened Eurosceptics will have to admit not all that emerges from Brussels is bad.

The notion that Brussels is more interested in building a United States of Europe than in creating a dynamic economy is groundless. First, the US model cannot be applied wholesale to Europe, whose strength is in its diversity. Secondly, I have placed the need for economic reform as one of this commission's most pressing priorities.

Initiatives to make Europe more competitive have come and gone in the past. This time things look different. The creation of Europe's single market, followed by EU governments' drive to meet the tough entry terms for the euro, have generated the best macroeconomic outlook for years. Europe now enjoys low inflation, controlled public spending, a sound balance of payments and conservative estimates of 3% growth for this year and next, signalling that a strong and lasting recovery is round the corner. Employment remains unacceptably high, but it is starting to subside.

A consensus, too, is beginning to emerge on the shape of economic reform. Europe is no longer crudely divided between corporatists and free-marketeers, between the Anglo-Saxon or continental model, or between advocates and opponents of the welfare state. Few are any longer in denial over the need for tough structural reform, deregulation, flexible labour markets and the modernisation of pension systems. And many countries no longer shrink from publicly espousing the goal of full employment. How times have changed.

Lisbon is the perfect moment for Europe's nations to make a common analysis of their economic needs, agree common solutions and then set dates by which to resolve them. Brussels cannot force national governments to take tough decisions, but it can generate such peer pressure that momentum for reform becomes unstoppable. Furthermore, we are planting on fertile soil. Globalisation, budgetary pressures and - dare I say it - the single currency are already forcing governments to modernise their economies.

BMW's retreat from its involvement in Rover has come as a shock to British people, not least for its painful impact on the lives of Rover's workers and their families. It also reveals the sheer degree of interdependence between European nations as their biggest economic players fight for a place in Europe's rapidly restructuring, increasingly competitive market.

For my part, I will present a radical agenda designed to make Europe the most competitive economy in the world in 10 years. To do this, I will propose that we first resolve to close the remaining gaps in Europe's single market by 2004, improving all under-performing sectors like cross-border finance, energy and air travel. Europe must become a byword for cheap banking and cut-price airfares, not to mention cheap phone calls to boost internet access and mobile telephony.

We must create a business climate in which it pays to employ people, train them, lend them risk capital and bring their best ideas faster to the marketplace. And, as Britain's internet price war shows, that market is increasingly a digital one. I believe we should seek to make all Europeans digitally literate by connecting all schools to the internet by 2001, by training all teachers to use it by 2002, and by ensuring all citizens can do the same by 2005.

T he European commission can help ease public spending in Britain and elsewhere by increasing the pressure on public authorities to shop around the whole of the EU for the best deal when buying in goods and services, with tenders being broadcast on the internet to stiffen competition. At the same time, the EU's own financial resources should be reviewed by the end of this year, and used more intelligently if necessary.

The internet revolution gives us a golden opportunity to narrow the poverty gap in Europe, but it could go either way unless it is available to all, irrespective of wealth, colour, back ground, sex or social status. The commission estimates that 1,000 to 2,000 billion euros, or 12-20% of the GDP of EU countries, are wasted each year through ill health, crime and other side-effects of joblessness and poverty. Social exclusion, quite apart from being morally unacceptable, is a waste of money. And economic reforms will not succeed if the public is not behind them.

The commission will also use the Lisbon summit to urge European countries to modernise their welfare systems to ensure sustainable pension provision over the long term. This includes developing the market for private supplementary pensions, itself a lucrative source of liquidity for investment in the new economy. I will call, too, for more investment in education and training and for the restoration of full employment as a viable goal of economic and social policy.

There is always the risk that we European leaders will return from Portugal with a pocketful of platitudes rather than a solid platform on which to build. If so, it would be because domestic political pressure forced countries to play up the issues that divide them. It is time to break with the tradition of Europeans masking their differences over economic reform beneath elegantly evasive communiques. Those differences are being eroded anyway. What we need are targets, dates and deadlines by which to create the right climate for growth and to equip people with the skills to make the most of it. The new economy will not wait for us.

Romano Prodi is president of the European commission

fields.headline: The best cellphone scene
fields.standfirst: Three Kings
fields.trailText: Three Kings.
fields.body:
Kuwait, 1991. Having been taken captive by a rogue assembly of Iraqi troops, Troy Barlow (Mark Wahlberg) is thrown into a claustrophobic store-room full of cardboard boxes. In his frustration, he kicks over a stack: TVs, stereo systems and mobile phones spill across the floor. A glint in his eye, he drops to his knees and begins rooting through the bulky cellphones. Frantically, he presses buttons. He gets a dialling tone. A female voice answers.

"Hello?"

"Baby, it's me."

Back in California, Barlow's wife Debbie (Liz Stauber) screams in delight. She holds their baby in her arms.

"Oh baby! Oh my God! Troy!"

"Yeah, it's me, baby."

"Oh, the baby's crying."

"How's she doing?"

"She hasn't been sleeping too good, so I'm real tired, baby."

"I wish I could be there, goony bird."

"Oh, goony bird, when are you coming home?"

Barlow glances anxiously around the store-room.

"Well, I'm working on that right now, honey..."

"Listen baby, I saw an ad for a computer job. You want me to set up an interview? If I had an exact date, I could set one up."

"Baby, listen to me..."

Without warning, the store room wall blows up. Bricks scatter. Debbie shrieks in fright.

"Baby, what was that?"

"Ah, the wall just exploded."

A tone of annoyance enters Debbie's voice.

"I thought the war was over, baby."

See also: The Big Lebowski, Denise Calls Up, I'm Losing You

Don't see also: A Night At The Roxbury

Pointless trivia: Liz Stauber made her screen debut in the IMAX feature T-Rex: Back To The Cretaceous.

fields.headline: Horror, shock and impotence
fields.standfirst:
Labour's response to the Longbridge crisis has been to do nothing.

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's response to the Longbridge crisis has been to do nothing.
fields.body:
When Lord Acton wrote a hundred years ago that "power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely", he probably didn't expect the quotation to achieve such extraordinary posthumous notoriety.

He may have been right about his own class. But in the labour and trade union movement, the truth is the opposite. Impotence tends to corrupt, and absolute impotence corrupts absolutely. Contemporary proof can be found in the reaction to the decision of BMW to walk away from Rover, and throw the lives of some 50,000 people in and around Birmingham into turmoil.

Long years ago, there was a tradition that Labour governments should do something about such catastrophes. In his diaries, Tony Benn describes a meeting soon after Labour won the February 1974 election and took office without a Commons majority. The leaders of the shipbuilding and engineering unions were worried about press reports that British Leyland, Rover's predecessor, was cutting back on investment. "170,000 people were involved and they thought that government intervention was inevitable."

They were right. When British Leyland went to the wall, it was promptly nationalised by the Labour government. For the time being at any rate, at least until Thatcher's Tory government sold the firm back (for next to nothing, plus a cocktail of illegal bribes and sweeteners) to their favourite private enterprise company, thousands of workers went on making cars in the Midlands.

Now, from a Labour government backed by a parliamentary majority incomparably bigger than in the 1970s, there is horror, shock, even anger - and the most abject impotence. The Tories naturally have nothing to say about the Rover disaster. Anyone who doubts that should read the Commons speech last Thursday of their industry spokeswoman, Angela Browning. She attacked the government for, well, nothing at all really except utterly trivial details about the timing of government subsidies.

Such a Tory response to another collapse of their precious private enterprise was predictable, but from the secretary of state for trade and industry, Stephen Byers, and the Labour backbenchers who took part in the debate (Richard Burden, Geoffrey Robinson, Steve McCabe and Terry Davis), came not a single word of advice about what the government and the workers could do. Long gone, everyone rejoiced, are the days of "Red Robbo" and the militant shop stewards organisation at Longbridge.

The unions and workers have made sacrifice after sacrifice, and are now faced with the same miserable future that frightened them into sacrifice in the first place. In all the endless mourning and hand-wringing by an enormous range of experts, I could not find a single reference to the dreaded n-word, nationalisation.

Impotence tends to corrupt, and this ministerial impotence corrupts the entire parliamentary process. In the fever of workers' fury at Longbridge after BMW's announcement, one theme emerged clearly. What is the point, a worker asked, of having a Labour prime minister and a Labour secretary of state if they can do nothing to avert a crisis of the kind which has engulfed West Midlands? What is the use of the prime minister "shaking with anger" at the BMW board if he can't reverse the board's decision? What is the point of three years' ministerial grovelling at the feet of the rich and powerful if the rich and powerful continually use those feet to kick people who vote Labour in the teeth?

Indeed why not abandon the whole process of democratic government - with an open cheque to exploit and plunder - to a gang of greedy alchemists from the boardrooms or the investment banks?

The most tragic pastiche of the whole Rover tragedy featured the wretched Stephen Byers. He might have been tempted to turn the tables on the Tories by scoffing at the corrupt privatisation of Leyland in 1988. But where was Mr Byers on the night of the grim BMW announcement about the Longbridge sale? He was on his way to a celebration in Bristol of his government's decision to lob £500m of taxpayers' money into the coffers of British Aerospace, the beneficiary of that corrupt privatisation.

People still keep assuring me that in his youth, at Chester College of Technology, Steve Byers was, as I was, a supporter of the International Socialists. I don't recall ever meeting him then, but I'm sure he will remember the first-ever Right to Work march from Manchester to London in 1976. The chief slogan of the march had worked well and saved a lot of jobs at Upper Clyde Shipbuilders a few years earlier. It should now be reproduced in massive letters and draped over the whole of Longbridge: OCCUPY! NATIONALISE! FIGHT FOR THE RIGHT TO WORK!

What is the use of the prime minister "shaking with anger" at the BMW board if he can't reverse the board's decision? What is the point of three years' ministerial grovelling at the feet of the rich and powerful if the rich and powerful continually use those feet to kick people who vote Labour in the teeth? Indeed why not abandon the whole process of democratic government - with an open cheque to exploit and plunder - to a gang of greedy alchemists from the boardrooms or the investment banks? The most tragic pastiche of the whole Rover tragedy featured the wretched Stephen Byers. He might have been tempted to turn the tables on the Tories by scoffing at the corrupt privatisation of Leyland in 1988. But where was Mr Byers on the night of the grim BMW announcement about the Longbridge sale? He was on his way to a celebration in Bristol of his government's decision to lob £500m of taxpayers' money into the coffers of British Aerospace, the beneficiary of that corrupt privatisation. People still keep assuring me that in his youth, at Chester College of Technology, Steve Byers was, as I was, a supporter of the International Socialists. I don't recall ever meeting him then, but I'm sure he will remember the first-ever Right to Work march from Manchester to London in 1976. The chief slogan of the march had worked well and saved a lot of jobs at Upper Clyde Shipbuilders a few years earlier. It should now be reproduced in massive letters and draped over the whole of Longbridge: OCCUPY! NATIONALISE! FIGHT FOR THE RIGHT TO WORK!

webTitle: Future Network prepares new launch for Britain

fields.headline: Future Network prepares new launch for Britain
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Future Network, the magazine publishing group, is preparing its biggest ever launch in Britain when it imports the enormously successful US internet title Business 2.0 to this country.
fields.body:
Future Network, the magazine publishing group, is preparing its biggest ever launch in Britain when it imports the enormously successful US internet title Business 2.0 to this country.

The magazine, which this month was a hefty 450 pages, is on course for revenues of $50m (£32m) in the US this year and will be the firm's biggest single earner according to chairman Chris Anderson. The magazine, which focuses on the effect of the internet on the business world, booked advertising sales of $4m in this month's edition alone.

"The title has opened a major new business area for us and has moved into profit two years earlier than expected," said Mr Anderson. "We looked at where the excitement and the passion in the internet was and nobody else was really doing it."

The magazine will be launched in Britain in late May and then rolled out to Germany and France in the autumn. Far from replacing old media, Future has found the internet a fertile ground for magazines and last year established titles including Internet Advisor, Internet Investor, Computer Music, What DVD and Mobile Computer User in this country.

Mr Anderson said Future, which has the contract to produce the official PlayStation magazine, would also benefit from the launch of the second generation games console.

The group, formerly known as Future Publishing, yesterday announced its maiden results as a public company, reporting an 85% increase in pre-tax profits to £19.2m for 1999. Sales rose 24% to £199m.

Shares in Future though slid 36p to 835p following the disclosure that Apax, the ven ture capital group, plans to shed its 12% stake in the company this week.

Future made a number of acquisitions last year and Mr Anderson said it would be looking for further deals in magazines, the internet and conferences.

"It has been exciting seeing the business reach critical mass this year," Mr Anderson said.

"The range of opportunities out there has become dramatically greater."

webTitle: 'Rivals' give up hope as Putin rolls to victory

fields.headline: 'Rivals' give up hope as Putin rolls to victory
fields.standfirst:
They are meant to be running for the presidency of Russia. So why are they giving the favourite such an easy ride?

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: One challenger wants to bring back the Soviet police state. Another says that is precisely the direction in which Russia is heading under the acting president, Vladimir Putin. A third candidate is the first woman to run for Russia's highest office. Another is a millionaire Chechen businessman with shady connections.
fields.body:
One challenger wants to bring back the Soviet police state. Another says that is precisely the direction in which Russia is heading under the acting president, Vladimir Putin. A third candidate is the first woman to run for Russia's highest office. Another is a millionaire Chechen businessman with shady connections.

All four are half-heartedly challenging Mr Putin for the presidency. And all four, along with the other seven candidates in Sunday's election, give a convincing impression of not wanting the job.

Such is the popularity of Mr Putin - a former secret policeman and the architect of the war in Chechnya - that his 11 challengers are barely bothering to campaign. There seems little point.

And since officially at least Mr Putin has also eschewed campaigning and refused to take part in any television debates, Russia's democratic process has acquired an air of ritual and unreality.

"The most boring election ever," commented the newspaper, Argumenty i Fakty, on the campaign to succeed Boris Yeltsin in Russia's third direct presidential election. Not so much an election, more of a referendum on Mr Putin, the paper added.

"It's not an election," complains Konstantin Titov, 55, a liberal presidential candidate who is the governor of the Samara region. "It's a dynastic transfer of power clearly cooked up by the oligarchs in accordance with the constitution and federal law."

Mr Titov hopes to meet Mr Putin after the election to discuss policy because the acting president has not taken the trouble to issue a manifesto.

According to opinion polls, Mr Titov will do well to get 1% of the votes. He is further hamstrung by the fact that the leadership of his party supports Mr Putin, as, paradoxically, do several of the other presidential candidates.

The former communist MP, Aleksei Podberezkin, for example, is standing despite describing Mr Putin as "the sole candidate worthy of the office".

The ugly clown of Russian politics, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, also supports Mr Putin despite running against him. And Gennady Zyuganov, the wooden communist leader who is expected to come a distant second, is running such a lacklustre campaign that observers speculate he is going through the motions in order to confer legitimacy on a Putin triumph.

Such is the support for the man groomed by the Kremlin inner circle to assume the reins of power that a television satire portrayed the "anti-Putin" candidates as prostitutes vying for the custom and favour of the election winner.

With Mr Putin's support running at up to 60% in the opinion polls and his nearest challenger, Mr Zyuganov, at just over 20%, the only question hanging over the poll is whether Mr Putin will secure the Kremlin at the first try.

He needs half of the votes cast to win outright and avoid a second round with the runner-up a fortnight later. But if voters want to bring the Putin bandwagon to a halt, they have two other options: boycott the election or actively vote for none of the candidates.

Sunday's ballot is only valid if half the electorate of 108m cast their votes. But voters can mark their ballot papers for none of the 12 candidates. In the unlikely event that the vote for "none of the above" is greater than vote for the victor, the ballot is also invalid.

The prime minister then becomes president until a new election is held within four months. The position of prime minister is also held by Vladimir Putin.

fields.trailText: • Frontrunner Telecoms company Vodafone has once again regained the lead in the government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences. Vodafone has offered £764.8m for licence B, the one most attractive to the four incumbent mobile carriers who are restricted from bidding for the biggest licence A. Bids for the other three licences - which will allow the delivery of video and simple computing tasks on mobile phones - were all similar in price.
