webTitle: Cherie gives Blair paternity leave hint

fields.headline: Cherie gives Blair paternity leave hint
fields.trailText: Cherie Booth dropped a broad hint last night that she would like her husband, Tony Blair, to take a break from running the country and spend some time with her and their baby after it is born in May.
fields.body:
Cherie Booth dropped a broad hint last night that she would like her husband, Tony Blair, to take a break from running the country and spend some time with her and their baby after it is born in May.

She told lawyers and academics at King's College, London: "I am pleased to report that in 1998 the prime minister of Finland took advantage of his right to parental leave. He has done it again recently. I, for one, am promoting the widespread adoption of his fine example."

Delivering a lecture titled the Pan-European Vision of Labour Law in the Year 2005, she said: "It is time that men started to challenge the assumptions in the workplace that the nurturing of children has nothing to do with them. Our children need their male role models as well as their female ones if they are to grow up into well-rounded, well-balanced individuals.

Criticising the "long hours" workplace culture, she called on employers to help their employees, particularly women, strike a balance between work and family.

She said the lives of working women were made difficult and sometimes intolerable by the employment environment and its "inherent discrimination".

One form of discrimination, she said, was the day-to-day struggle faced by women as they attempted to balance their paid working lives and their unpaid working lives. The second, she said, was the discrimination which is "loudly and clearly spelled out by the pay gap".

The work environment, with rigid working hours, inflexible leave patterns, long hours and intolerance of career breaks, discriminated against women with families. But the legal system had not developed quickly enough to deal with this type of discrimination, said Ms Booth, a QC specialising in employment law.

But she believed this would change because employers would need to employ and retain women in the workplace. The success of the economy would depend on the skills that women excel at - project management, knowledge development, sharing, interpersonal skills and high standards of customer service.

Progress had been helped by legal rights coming mainly from Europe but "happily grasped with more vigour by the present government". These included improved maternity rights, parental leave, emergency leave for family crises and equal rights for part-time workers.

But part-time rights could be a double-edged sword, she said. The low status and low pay helped perpetuate the pay gap between men and women, who made up 83% of part-timers.

She called for a statutory right for women to return to work part time after having a baby unless the employer could justify requiring her to work full time. This would leave employers less vulnerable to claims and large pay-outs under the Sex Discrimination Act.

There is no protection from discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation under English law, but Ms Booth predicted that the Human Rights Act and powers in the treaty of Amsterdam would give gays greater rights by 2005.

She concluded: "The partial - and, if I'm being incredibly optimistic, total - closure of the pay gap will be achievable by 2005 if we all tackle it with the vigour that this form of outright discrimination against women warrants.

"I hope that we will see in 2005, for example, John, a gay man, having protection against discrimination on the grounds of his sexual orientation and Mary, a 34-year-old working mum, earning the same percentage on a part-time basis as John and having the right to request such part-time work from a full-time position, without fear of losing her job."

fields.headline: Iridium finds would-be rescuers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A group of American private investors yesterday made a last minute attempt to rescue the $5bn (£3.3bn) satellite telephone service Iridium, which was yesterday forced into liquidation.
fields.body:
A group of American private investors yesterday made a last minute attempt to rescue the $5bn (£3.3bn) satellite telephone service Iridium, which was yesterday forced into liquidation.

Iridium, which has Motorola as a shareholder and backer, was set a deadline of last Friday by the court to attract a buyer for its assets which include 66 satellites.

The company, which was widely regarded to have suffered from poor marketing, high charges and expensive, heavy handsets, failed to live up to the promise of vast mobile communities hooked up to large satellite networks.

It failed to attract a buyer and it was only yesterday that Merit Studios, a US software and e-commerce group, emerged as a possible white knight.

Merit sent an email to Iridium's lawyers saying it represented a group of private investors who wanted to use the satellite system to create an additional transmission network for data and the internet.

Merit, which would rename the company Meridium, proposes to collect a fee from message senders for the use of the satellite service.

New shares would be issued to Iridium's creditors, representing 30% of the company, as well as receiving 20% of the new profits for as long as it required to pay back Iridium's debts.

All Iridium shareholders would also get 30% of the new company while the private investors who are prepared to back the rescue would get 10% for investing £65m.

Randy Broukman, Iridium's chief operating officer, said he was "deeply saddened" by the court's ruling which will involved destroying the group's 66 satellites when they are sent back into the earth's atmosphere to burn up.

"I particularly regret the effect this will have on our customers," Mr Broukman said.

Iridium, set up in 1998 to provide a satellite mobile service anywhere in the world, has 55,000 customers. The company failed to meet subscriber numbers even after after slashing prices. It went into a voluntary bankruptcy in August.

Iridium thought it had the support in February of a group of investors, led by American telecommunications pioneer Craig McCaw, who agreed to provide £49m in interim financing for Iridium. The proposal was withdrawn.

Mr McCaw has long shared plans with his friend Bill Gates, the Microsoft chairman, to develop a network of satellites to connect mobile internet users. He switched his support ICO Global Communications, based in Hammersmith, west London, late last year when he joined in a £1.2bn rescue for the company.

Motorola said despite the collapse of Iridium it believed that satellite technology would continue to succeed. The company provided a list of satellite service providers including American Mobile Satellite Corporation, Globalstar and Inmarsat for Iridium's customers to switch to.

webTitle: MPs urge higher taxes on polluters

fields.headline: MPs urge higher taxes on polluters
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Higher taxes on petrol guzzling cars and lorries and the worldwide introduction of a large aviation fuel duty were demanded yesterday on the eve of the budget by MPs investigating the dangers of global warming.
fields.body:
Higher taxes on petrol guzzling cars and lorries and the worldwide introduction of a large aviation fuel duty were demanded yesterday on the eve of the budget by MPs investigating the dangers of global warming.

Gordon Brown and John Prescott were severely criticised by the Commons environment committee for failing to take tough enough action to cut back Britain's huge use of polluting fuels to power cars, heat homes and drive industry.

MPs also want new tax incentives - such as the halving of VAT for the installers of energy saving materials - following a decision by the French last year.

The MPs attacked ministers for failing to convey the right environmedtal message and for showing "lack of clarity" over government targets to achieve a 20% cut in carbon dioxide emissions by 2010 over levels experienced in Britain in 1990. "We do not believe existing publicity campaigns will be effective ... their profiles are low and their messages ineffective. A sophisticated and targeted approach is required to change people's behaviour."

They said the government "must provide a clear signal to individuals and industry alike of the need fundamentally to change practices and behaviour".

On car purchase tax, MPs recommended rebates to those buying fuel efficient cars "providing clearer signals to consumers about the need to reduce fuel use".

On annual car tax - where small engine cars already pay less road duty -the MPs said it could go much further with the aim of pushing the old polluting vehicles off the road. "There remains scope for a more radical and sophisticated system," said the MPs.

They also warned that the boom in air travel, which is increasing at 6% a year, will mean a rapid increase in pollution. "Progress at an international level on allowing taxation on aviation fuel has been extremely slow and will continue to be so," said the MPs.

They added: "It is essential that any measures are introduced at a global level."

The report revealed that MPs were divided over the contents of the document. Tom Brake, Liberal Democrat MP for Carshalton and Wallington, demanded a tougher report. James Gray, Conservative MP for Wiltshire, North, sought to stop the extra tax measures for aviation fuel being recommended.

He also attacked the government's decision to stop the escalator on fuel tax - introduced by former chancellor, Kenneth Clarke - and replace it with hypothecated taxes as "fundamentally flawed".

webTitle: Blair not trusted to keep his election tax pledge

fields.headline: Blair not trusted to keep his election tax pledge
fields.standfirst:
ICM poll: Even many Labour supporters disbelieve PM

New Labour in power: special reportBudget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Voters, including Labour supporters, do not trust Tony Blair to keep his election pledge not to raise the basic and higher rates of income tax, according to a Guardian/ICM eve of budget opinion poll published today.
fields.body:
Voters, including Labour supporters, do not trust Tony Blair to keep his election pledge not to raise the basic and higher rates of income tax, according to a Guardian/ICM eve of budget opinion poll published today.

This lack of trust on tax comes amid waning optimism amongst voters over the state of their own finances. Some 40% believe their financial position has got worse over the past 12 months and 34% believe it will get worse for them over the next 12 months.

The Guardian/ICM poll shows that above all else the electorate wants to see the chancellor, Gordon Brown, announce a significant cash injection into the NHS today, even it means cancelling the already announced 1p cut in the basic rate of income tax.

When the voters were asked to list their other priorities, pensioners came out second on the list ahead of further spending on schools.

The poll shows that when asked whether they think "the people you know" would prefer a tax cut in the shape of an extra £3 a week in their pocket or more money spent on the NHS, voters overwhelmingly by a factor of four to one say they are willing to forgo the tax cut in order to put more money into health.

But the answers to other "tax and spend" questions on the poll indicate that there are mixed feelings about tax amongst the electorate. When voters are given a choice of taxes that they would regard as acceptable sources of extra money for public services they say they would rather see the money raised by extra taxes on tobacco and companies rather than by raising income tax.

Even more unpopular sources of extra revenue would be raising petrol taxes, and increasing stamp duty, which is particularly unpopular amongst 18-24 year olds who have not yet got onto the property ladder.

One in four voters are also prepared to say that they believe that further cuts in income tax are more likely to win Labour the next election than announcing extra money for the NHS.

Perhaps the most startling finding though is the extent to which Mr Blair's pledge not to raise the basic and higher rate of income tax during this parliament is not trusted.

Even though he has so far kept this promise it is widely disbelieved. Even 47% of Labour voters do not think he will keep it. This may mean that voters do not discriminate between levels of personal tax covered by the pledge and the kind of rises in indirect taxation that have taken place since 1997 that were not covered.

The monthly Guardian/ICM opinion poll question on voting intentions shows that the row over Ken Livingstone's decision to stand as an independent candidate for London mayor does not appear to have damaged Labour's standing. The government remains on 44%, unchanged since last month; the Conservatives are up three points on 32%; the Liberal Democrats are on 16% (down two) and other parties are on 8 (down one).

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,207 adults aged over 18 by telephone between 17-19 March 2000. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Missed target means £10m fine for Railtrack

fields.headline: Missed target means £10m fine for Railtrack
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Railtrack last night admitted that it will be fined £10m next month for failing to meet a 12.7% improvement target set by the rail regulator last year.
fields.body:
Railtrack last night admitted that it will be fined £10m next month for failing to meet a 12.7% improvement target set by the rail regulator last year.

It said the improvement in track quality, broken rails and safety that affected punctuality, would only be between 9% and 10%. But it said that delivering its public service obligations was its top priority.

This will be its first fine, and could have a detrimental impact on its share price today. To make matters worse, it could face a new confrontation with the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, for failing to meet the 12.7% target.

Railtrack chief executive, Gerald Corbett, is insisting that if it cannot make up the 12.7% shortfall, the slate should be swept clean next year.

But in a letter to Mr Corbett, Mr Winsor, says that he has set a new 5% target for 2000-01, plus the shortfall.

Mr Corbett retorted that the target should not be affected by any failure of the company to meet its 12.7% target for this year. The tough target was set last year because Railtrack had fallen well short of a promise to improve performance.

Railtrack said that Mr Winsor's 5% target and the shortfall would be "a huge task". A revised 8% to 9% improvement for next year would be a big challenge, "as we have to present this against a background of growth delivering more trains on to the network and a big increase in investment".

Performance was not a matter of writing a cheque or having a plan. It was about thousands of staff getting thousands of details right 24 hours a day.

Railtrack said: "Our concern is that even with a 10% improvement this year, the regulator's fine will see it portrayed as a failure. There is a risk that this will be the same next year. But fine or no fine we will do our best."

Mr Winsor said: "The 5% target, plus catching up any shortfall in the current year, is fair and achievable. Railtrack needs to take this target as seriously as it is taking the current one."

Mr Winsor congratulated Railtrack on its efforts to meet the 12.7% target. "It has worked hard to achieve it and is doing well."

An industry source said last night: "If only the shadow Strategic Rail Authority enforced train company agreements with the same vigour, so that passengers do not suffer from the poor service and cancellations they do at present."

webTitle: British officials to check asylum claims in France

fields.headline: British officials to check asylum claims in France
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Passengers travelling from France to Britain on Eurostar are to be checked at French railway stations by British immigration officials as part of the government's crackdown on bogus asylum seekers, the Home Office said last night.
fields.body:
Passengers travelling from France to Britain on Eurostar are to be checked at French railway stations by British immigration officials as part of the government's crackdown on bogus asylum seekers, the Home Office said last night.

The measures are being introduced to deter illegal immigrants from using the high-speed Paris to London rail service under a new Anglo-French agreement, the home secretary Jack Straw said.

The government faces renewed controversy over its stance on immigrants, and the Foreign Office minister Peter Hain denied it was pandering to racism in its response to begging asylum seekers.

He told BBC radio: "Everybody understands that this tiny minority of asylum seekers who are taking their children on the streets in this way, when they have benefit enti tlements... are actually giving asylum seekers a bad name.

"If we sought to duck that, then I think the credibility of the British tradition of welcoming genuine refugees from political and other forms of repression would have been strained at the edge."

The new Eurostar controls mean that British immigration officers will carry out checks at French rail stations on passengers travelling to Britain, and French officers will operate similar controls at Waterloo station in London and at Ashford International station in Kent.

French police will also be able to remove inadequately documented travellers from Eurostar trains.

The controls are similar to those which already exist for vehicle passengers using the channel tunnel.

Asylum applications made at Waterloo, London's Eurostar terminal, increased from 3,997 in 1998 to 5,902 in 1999 - a jump of 46%.

Mr Straw said: "Recently, the Eurostar route has been the target for illegal immigrants and those who facilitate this traffic. This agreement is a powerful message to these people."

The government hopes that a combination of "voluntary detention" and swift decision-making will deter economic migrants from coming to Britain in the first place.

A fast-track centre for processing people suspected of lodging false asylum claims opened in Oakington, Cambridgeshire, yesterday.

Seven people were arrested for alleged obstruction outside the gates of the former RAF base in protest at the "voluntary detention" system.

fields.headline: Lost it by a whisker
fields.trailText: The government is considering adding the 23 national museums to the list of VAT-exempted organisations (VAT move lifts hope of free museums, March 17).
fields.body:
The government is considering adding the 23 national museums to the list of VAT-exempted organisations (VAT move lifts hope of free museums, March 17). Many councils are now seeking to run their museums through trusts which will no longer be able to claim back VAT unless they charge for entry. Amending the rules to cover all museums would enable the majority to continue to offer free admission to the many.
Ian Lawley
Group for Museum Directors

 It is disappointing you use the Tory phrase tax burden with all its negative overtones (Labour admits tax rises, March 15). Tax delight might be pushing it a bit, but how about something neutral like tax level?
David Malley
London

 If Elmo Jones (Letters, 20 March) thinks celebrities using cats to boost their image is worrying, he should check out Susan Kramer's mayoral website, part of which is written by her cat, Whittington. There is, of course, a cuddly photo of Susan with the nauseating cat, as well as gems such as "Whittington's Diary" which reveal his owner sings in the bath. This persuaded me not to vote for Ms Kramer. Ken's website is pet-free.
Sarah Bridge
London

 Re the fuss about who is eligible to play rugby for Wales (Report, March 15), surely since the game went commercial the only criterion that makes any sense is that the player in question is on the payroll of a Welsh rugby club.
David Thomas
Bridgend, Mid Glamorgan
dthcym@tesco.net

 Chris Smith may claim to love both science and the arts (Letters, March 18), but his use of phrases such as "baseline uplift" suggests he has it in for the English language.
Mark Pack
London
markpack@cix.co.uk

fields.headline: It beggars belief
fields.trailText: So Home Office minister Barbara Roche now condemns the "vile" use of children for begging by asylum seekers and suggests that harsh measures may be instituted - all in the best interests of the children, of course (Fast-track curb on beggars, March 20). How very brave of her to use children to cloak this government's cowardice in failing to confront the current media hate campaign against asylum seekers.
fields.body:
So Home Office minister Barbara Roche now condemns the "vile" use of children for begging by asylum seekers and suggests that harsh measures may be instituted - all in the best interests of the children, of course (Fast-track curb on beggars, March 20). How very brave of her to use children to cloak this government's cowardice in failing to confront the current media hate campaign against asylum seekers.

This belated concern for refugee children, I see, has yet to extend to ensuring the new asylum support system honours our obligations under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. Despite our duty to promote the welfare of all children, refugee children and their families will have to live on 70% of income support. How can we expect children in an asylum-seeking family of four not to suffer when it will only get £110 a week compared to a similar UK family on about £150 a week?
Vanessa Beck
University of Birmingham
vanessa@a-beck.swinternet.co.uk

 The east European Gypsies are part of the most persecuted and oppressed populations in the whole of Europe. Only a twisted media and a spineless political elite could turn them into oppressors, while the real victims apparently become the middle classes who trip over the beggars as they leave the opera.

Straw, Widdecombe, Roche and the rest are a disgrace; they know this media campaign is a cynical exercise in media manipulation. How does a beggar "aggressively beg" with a baby - hit people with it?
Steve Judson
London
sjudson@netscape.net

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Bad day
fields.body:
Bad day

E-commerce minister Patricia Hewitt. She has been having a baffling time with Whitehall's computer system. The minister has been forced to resort to faxing would-be emails to departments after missives began disappearing into cyberspace. The mix-up has reportedly been put down to incompatibility of different systems in government departments.

Good day

Trees. The Liberal Democrats are hailing the success of their new eco-friendly conferences. Not content with spreading the green word the party has taken to saving paper. Speeches at the spring conference in Plymouth at the weekend were printed on both sides of each piece of paper. Observers, although impressed by Charles Kennedy's endeavours have advised a more radical solution to ecological ruin - cutting down the length of the speeches.

Good day

Ramblers. Public access to the countryside on a scale "never before seen," was promised by environment minister Michael Meacher, opening second reading debate on the countryside and rights of way bill.

Today

Commons: Questions to Scottish ministers, advocate general for Scotland, lord chancellor's department, Commons leader and Commons commission. Budget statement, followed by debate. Lords: Powers of criminal courts (sentencing) bill, second reading. Financial services and markets bill, committee.

webTitle: Sorry, the hardest word - except perhaps for rupps

fields.headline: Sorry, the hardest word - except perhaps for rupps
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: There are various ways of apologising to the House of Commons. There is the anguished mea culpa coupled with much wringing of hands and the suggestion that it's the result of an abusive childhood (Ron Davies). Then there's the 30-second speech which implies by its brevity that the offence is of no importance, the apology a   mere technicality (Geoffrey Robinson).
fields.body:
There are various ways of apologising to the House of Commons. There is the anguished mea culpa coupled with much wringing of hands and the suggestion that it's the result of an abusive childhood (Ron Davies). Then there's the 30-second speech which implies by its brevity that the offence is of no importance, the apology a mere technicality (Geoffrey Robinson).

Yesterday Ken Livingstone adopted the latter approach. He was like a child who, on being told, "you will apologise to your little sister, now!" pouts crossly, then says, with much rolling of the eyes, "oh, all right then, sorr-ee."

He sat on his own. Not one of his former colleagues was there to offer moral support, or even the immoral kind.

When he was called, he rose and spoke hurriedly, swallowing his words and gabbling the message: "I ought to have made a comprehensive entry ... but I did not in fact do so. As soon as the issue was raised with me, I amended my entry in accordance with the rules."

The whole thing took one minute, the word "sorry" (or even sorr-ee ) did not cross his lips, and the instant it was over he vanished. (Ken's enemy, the leftwing MP Steve Pound, said afterwards: "He spoke for such a short time about so much money that he must have thought he was still on the lecture circuit.")

His swift departure meant that he missed the second reading of the countryside bill - fittingly, since Ken is such an urbanite that if he saw a sheep he'd think it was a trendy new mobile sofa.

He was lucky, since the bill - which allows the right to roam - is packed with exemptions and exceptions, which means that it's also packed with jargon.

"Expanding linear access," seems to mean allowing people to walk or cycle along paths. This includes "people with mobility difficulties" (or, presumably, nobility difficulties, when the earl shouts "get orff my land!")

Michael Meacher, the minister loves jargon. "Rupps!" he exclaimed, not as a result of too many fried onions at lunch, but meaning "roads used as public paths".

"Byways open to all traffic," are "boats". "Bridle paths" turned up frequently, though I heard "bridal" and imagined Posh Spice with cow pat on her white slippers.

A bridleway open to vehicular use would, presumably, be a "bova", and hikers would wear bova boots.

How different our literature would have been if these resonant words had been available to the poets. Gray would have spoken of the "rupps of glory", Shakespeare told us about "the primrose boat of dalliance". Goldsmith could have quoted Schedule 6, clause (1), subsection 118ZA, and titled his great work: The Extinguishmented Village.

Likewise a Victorian swain could have sung to his Daisy, "You'll look sweet, upon the seat, of an assisted pedal cycle of a class prescribed for the purposes of section 189 (1) (c) of the Road Traffic Act 1988, built for two."

But Mr Meacher was fortunate in his opponent. Archie Norman, the supermarket king who is the Tories' environment spokesman, was terrible. He droned drearily on and on, seemingly bored out of his mind. I was reminded of the headmaster of a minor public school whose history master has been suspended following an incident in the changing rooms, and who to his great annoyance has to give the lessons himself.

When he declared that Tories stood up "for minorities, yes, for minorities both rich and poor!" the Labour benches collapsed. "Did I say something wrong, Madam Speaker?" he asked plaintively, while Labour MPs hugged themselves - at last a Tory frontbencher who's even worse than John Prescott.

fields.headline: End welfare for business
fields.trailText: What with the Cruickshank report (Bank review 'explosive', March 18) and the disappearance of BMW from Longbridge, it's time to end government "welfare" support for big business, and to end the way that big corporates benefit from government handouts or monopolies.
fields.body:
What with the Cruickshank report (Bank review 'explosive', March 18) and the disappearance of BMW from Longbridge, it's time to end government "welfare" support for big business, and to end the way that big corporates benefit from government handouts or monopolies. They could make a start with a Community Reinvestment Act, along the lines of the one in the US, which tackles red-lining by forcing banks to reveal where they are lending money. The US version has released $1 trillion in loans for low-cost housing and small business since 1977.

Then how about an international agreement to end the waste of regional selective assistance to big corporates, which sees neighbouring regions competing to attract big international companies? We should instead provide local micro-credit finance.
Ed Mayo
Director, New Economics

 Since mid-1997 there has been an unspectacular but considerable leakage of industrial jobs in Britain, after an all-too-short period in which industrial employment was rising. The regime of rising interest rates and exchange rates under Gordon Brown's new monetary policy framework is clearly identifiable as the main causal factor at the macroeconomic level.
Dr Colin Crouch
Harrow Weald, Middx

 Given that the most profitable businesses in Britain are now asset-stripping and property development, what's the betting that in less than 10 years' time the whole of Longbridge, a brown-field heaven, will be covered with semi-detached houses or medium-rise social housing? Could someone work out from a map of the area what the return on such investment might be?
Gary Foskett
London

 When BMW bought Rover, the Guardian carried a leader about the gradual takeover of the British car industry by its foreign competitors and how this would mean these British subsidiaries would have to take the brunt of future cut backs. The last two sentences were: "That is why the future of the sole remaining British-owned and British-controlled motor manufacturer, Rover, will continue to be a matter for the government. Otherwise the British motor industry will find itself further down the cul-de-sac to extinction." That, you revealed, was a quote from a book written, in 1987 - by Michael Heseltine.
Dudley Turner
Westerham, Kent

fields.headline: High street heist
fields.standfirst: The case for a windfall tax on the banks
fields.trailText: As reports go, they do not come much more damning than Don Cruickshank's review of banking services in the UK. In all of the three areas of the market he investigated - including money transmission, personal services (like current accounts, mortgages and credit cards) and services to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) - he found that competition was ineffective.
fields.body:
As reports go, they do not come much more damning than Don Cruickshank's review of banking services in the UK. In all of the three areas of the market he investigated - including money transmission, personal services (like current accounts, mortgages and credit cards) and services to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) - he found that competition was ineffective. A few large banks were found to dominate the market for personal services to ordinary customers and SMEs. Many customers were unaware of even basic details of financial services, many of which were sold off the back of current accounts, the market for which was dominated by a few large firms squeezing monopolistic profits out of their privileged position. Cruickshank said that in 1998 three UK banks each made more profit than the five major quoted supermarket companies (which have themselves been accused of profiteering in the past).

His startling conclusion is that personal and small business customers are being ripped off to the tune of £3bn to £5bn a year - or between £40 and £400 for most households. This turns the whole thing into a macro-economic problem as well as a moral one. Since he is saying that the banks are overcharging by that amount, then clearly the malpractices should be ended. If they were stopped, then the equivalent of a cut of up to 2p in the pound in income tax would be delivered - with similar effects on the economy in terms of increased spending power. If, in addition, the banks had to pay back some of their excess profits from previous years, then the boost to consumer spending power would almost certainly be enough to overheat the economy to such an extent that the Bank of England would be forced to put interest rates up even more.

Is there an alternative? The chancellor, Gordon Brown, would be less than human if his thoughts did not stray to the possibility of levying a one-off surcharge on the banks: a kind of bankers' windfall tax. This would purge them of their guilt while, at the same time, resolving the central dilemma of Brown's budget: he needs to spend much more money on health and education to satisfy public expectations but cannot do it without raising taxes. Otherwise it could lead to economic overheating and higher interest rates.

But if the spending were financed by a comparable levy on the banks' profits (anything up to £5bn), then it could be done without loosening the chancellor's fiscal stance - the balance between taxes, spending and borrowing. This may sound like an (interventionist) Old Labour solution, but it is not. It is not a question of grabbing profits unjustifiably but of restoring to consumers money taken away by the abuse of a monopoly position. New Labour has already levied a windfall charge on the utilities to finance the government's New Deal. It proved very popular with the public and did not seem to do much damage to the utilities. The Conservatives would complain about stealth taxes - but should first remind themselves of their own budget in 1981 which contained a once-and-for-all charge of £400m (worth much more at today's prices) on the banks on the grounds that they had been doing much better than everybody else during a bad period for the economy as a whole. The financial secretary to the treasury at that time was one Nigel Lawson. If the chancellor were to force the clearing banks to atone for their misdeeds by paying for new hospitals and schools one can imagine only one reaction: dancing in the (high) streets.

fields.headline: Kennedy is no Ashdown
fields.standfirst: He is not yet up to making threats
fields.trailText: First it was Frank Dobson, now it is Charles Kennedy. Just days after Labour's candidate for the London mayoralty turned to Ken Livingstone hissing "Make my day", the Lib Dem leader is issuing some macho threats of his own - this time to the prime minister.
fields.body:
First it was Frank Dobson, now it is Charles Kennedy. Just days after Labour's candidate for the London mayoralty turned to Ken Livingstone hissing "Make my day", the Lib Dem leader is issuing some macho threats of his own - this time to the prime minister. At his party's spring conference at the weekend, Mr Kennedy threatened to walk away from the joint cabinet committee shared between Lib Dems and Labour unless Tony Blair makes a firm commitment on voting reform. Mr Kennedy, like every Liberal leader before him, wants proportional representation for the Commons; if Labour's manifesto does not promise a referendum, he will ditch the committee. In the alphabet soup so loved by the electoral reform crowd, Kennedy is saying No PR, no JCC.

Is this smart politics? It should certainly win favour with Liberal Democrat activists, many of whom are only lukewarm toward cooperation with Labour. Mr Kennedy could not easily cooperate for another term with a government that had no intention of honouring what is, for Lib Dems, holy writ. He has at least to be seen to be pressing for PR. Besides, he is right to call Mr Blair on a fact the prime minister might prefer to forget: the PM commissioned and received an admirable report from Roy Jenkins outlining improvements to the electoral system - and yet he has let that report gather dust for 18 months.

For all that, Mr Kennedy probably overplayed his hand. First, what threat can Mr Kennedy make to Mr Blair? If he stops cooperating with Labour in parliament, who suffers? Not Labour, elected with a 179-seat majority. The tacit collusion on the ground, in which Lib Dems and Labour agree not to fight each other too hard in seats the other party could win, is also as vital for Mr Kennedy's survival as it is for Mr Blair's. Put simply, the Lib Dems can walk out of the JCC - but where would they go?

One last warning to Mr Kennedy. He does not yet have the clout to make threats: he is, as too many Lib Dems sighed at the weekend, no Paddy Ashdown. He lacks the independent gravitas to issue demarches to Number 10. It is understandable that, a year or so before his first general election, the new leader wants to establish a distinct presence. But he needs to do that with an issue, rather than a macho gesture directed at the party that still represents his best chance of influence.

fields.headline: Keeping eyes on the spies
fields.trailText: Security intelligence agencies are notoriously sensitive to the actions of whistleblowers, but there is no need for a rerun of the 1980s' Spycatcher farce (Minister 'horrified' by attack on press over Shayler, March 20).
fields.body:
Security intelligence agencies are notoriously sensitive to the actions of whistleblowers, but there is no need for a rerun of the 1980s' Spycatcher farce (Minister 'horrified' by attack on press over Shayler, March 20). Shayler believes his allegations of incompetence and impropriety in the security agencies have not been taken seriously and slowly but surely, to the consternation of those authorities, they emerge in public.

But rather than apparently sharing the official distaste of Shayler's motives, the Intelligence and Security Committee, set up in 1994 to review "the expenditure, administration and policy" of MI5, MI6 and GCHQ should interview Shayler (abroad or with a grant of immunity) on the basis of his widely circulated document, ascertain what his precise allegations are, investigate their accuracy or otherwise and report accordingly.

While officials have no wish to encourage whistleblowing, it remains the fact that it is one of the few ways by which the public comes to learn of improper or illegal behaviour in the world of security intelligence.
Peter Gill
Liverpool John Moores University

 Of course the spooks have hacked into the Guardian's computers and regularly monitor all emails. They are just going through the motions of legal action because they think we are so naive as to believe them incapable of being so underhand.
Julian Dunn
Oxford
eisendora@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Blunkett's mixed messages on education
fields.trailText: In welcoming David Blunkett's announcement of city academies - made without consultation with councils or the Local Government Association - you imply (Leader, March 16) that most schools are controlled by local education authorities. This is not the case.
fields.body:
In welcoming David Blunkett's announcement of city academies - made without consultation with councils or the Local Government Association - you imply (Leader, March 16) that most schools are controlled by local education authorities. This is not the case. Councils, which are often blamed by the DfEE for failing schools, have no substantive power to intervene or, except where a school is in special measures, to direct additional resources to it. They cannot even insist that the school budget is spent on teaching. Local authorities, whose role is heavily circumscribed, would welcome being given the freedom and flexibility which are to be extended to unaccountable private-sector operators.

The latest proposals are likely further to fragment the education service and distance schools from their communities and the local services with which they should connect. What is needed to raise standards and to ensure sustained improvement is an effective partnership between local councils, schools, central government, the private and the voluntary sectors. What we appear to be moving inexorably towards is an education service controlled from London by the DfEE and increasingly administered through bodies appointed by and accountable to the Secretary of State. In the long term this will prove unworkable and undermines the very local democracy which, through its modernisation programme, the government seeks to enhance.
Cllr Sir Jeremy Beecham
Local Government Association

 The only factor that makes private education remotely compatible with the aims of public sector education is the existence of a private school such as Summerhill ('Free and Easy' Summerhill goes on trial, March 20) that does not seek an unfair competitive advantage for its children, but hopes simply to turn them into better and happier citizens. And now Blunkett and Woodhead want to close it.
Robert Brook
Shrewsbury

 So money is judged to be an effective persuader (£40 a week to stay at school, March 20). But university students are charged £1,000 a year to study. Does this imply that the government is trying to persuade fewer people to go?
Revd Dr John Ogden
Reading, Berks

fields.headline: Save, or else
fields.trailText: You roll out the old chestnut that tomorrow's pensioners will be better off on benefits (Low-cost plan may aid the rich, March 11). Our reform of Serps will cut the proportion of pensioners relying on income support from one in three to one in five.
fields.body:
You roll out the old chestnut that tomorrow's pensioners will be better off on benefits (Low-cost plan may aid the rich, March 11). Our reform of Serps will cut the proportion of pensioners relying on income support from one in three to one in five. Because they will not be heading for means-tested benefit when they retire, all these additional people will have an incentive to save while working.

This government is working hard to help those people who can't save to have a sufficient income in retirement. But the fact remains that those who are in a position to save should do so. If they don't, they will have only themselves to blame.
Jeff Rooker MP
Minister of state for Social Security

fields.headline: The Martha factor
fields.standfirst: Totting up the totty count
fields.trailText: All newspapers struggle with consistency. We do our best to make reasonable sense of a complicated world and often fail. Our system of checks and balances is not, alas, infallible. This may explain - though it certainly does not excuse - the discrepancy between last Friday's Guardian, which contained no fewer than four pictures of Martha Lane Fox, and yesterday's, which had none.
fields.body:
All newspapers struggle with consistency. We do our best to make reasonable sense of a complicated world and often fail. Our system of checks and balances is not, alas, infallible. This may explain - though it certainly does not excuse - the discrepancy between last Friday's Guardian, which contained no fewer than four pictures of Martha Lane Fox, and yesterday's, which had none.

We are aware that our readers are divided on this issue. Some argue that that four is too few, others that one is too many. Some feel passionately that Martha Lane Fox is a paradigm of the seismic shift occurring in the post-industrial, increasingly globalised business community: these readers cannot read too much about her. Others see her as the personification of an epic madness seizing the City which will soon end in an explosion that will make the South Sea Bubble seem like a tiny soap sud. These people cannot read too little about her.

It is on their record in reaching considered judgments on great issues such as this that newspapers are judged. We are a broad church and have so far allowed a diversity of opinion on Martha Lane Fox. Some have argued that Martha is a visionary. At the other extreme one of our respected contributors dismissed her last week as "netty totty".

We would like to state categorically that when pictures of Martha Lane Fox have appeared in the paper - either singly or in battalions - they were emphatically in connection with her vision rather than any Betjemanesque totty factor she may or may not possess. But we reluctantly concede that no issue of the paper has yet carried four pictures of Ms Lane Fox's business partner, Brent Hoberman. An editorial board is currently investigating this discrepancy. Meanwhile, we give an assurance that pictures of Martha Lane Fox will only be used when there is an overriding editorial imperative or when the public interest demands it.

webTitle: Pattern of violent assaults revealed in Kosovo

fields.headline: Pattern of violent assaults revealed in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Serb and Yugoslav forces frequently gang-raped Kosovo Albanian women during the Nato bombing campaign, although a claim by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, that they had set up "a rape camp" has not been confirmed, according to a Human Rights Watch report.
fields.body:
Serb and Yugoslav forces frequently gang-raped Kosovo Albanian women during the Nato bombing campaign, although a claim by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, that they had set up "a rape camp" has not been confirmed, according to a Human Rights Watch report.

After documenting 96 cases of rape, the New York-based organisation says this almost certainly understates the issue because victims were very reluctant to report the crimes. A pattern of rapes was recorded: in women's homes, while they were being herded along in refugee columns, or in detention centres.

Rapes often took place in front of victims' families or with senior officers on hand. "These are not occasional incidents committed by a few crazy men," said Regan Ralph, the executive director of Human Rights Watch's women's rights division. "Rape was used as an instrument of war."

Human Rights Watch takes issue with Mr Cook and Kenneth Bacon, the US Pentagon spokesman, for alleging that the Serbs set up rape camps. Mr Cook's allegation came the day after Nato was criticised for attacking a train in Serbia, killing 20 Serb civilians. "We are concerned that Nato's use of rape to bolster support for the war relied on unconfirmed accounts. Offering such accusations... suggests that those invoking the abuses may have been more concerned with pursuing certain political goals," the report said.

Human Rights Watch

webTitle: US offer lifts hopes of Israel-Syria deal

fields.headline: US offer lifts hopes of Israel-Syria deal
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton yesterday gave new impetus to the Syria-Israel peace process by announcing that he would meet Syria's leader to try to revive talks that foundered two months ago.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton yesterday gave new impetus to the Syria-Israel peace process by announcing that he would meet Syria's leader to try to revive talks that foundered two months ago.

"I don't want to unduly raise expectations, but I think that this is an appropriate thing for me to do to try to get this back on track so that our objective of having a comprehensive peace can go forward," Mr Clinton said, during a tour of south Asia.

The announcement, and the resumption today of stalled Israeli-Palestinian talks, give a reprieve to Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, who has been thwarted in his pledge to steer his country to peace with both Syria and the Palestinians by the end of the year.

Mr Barak has said that the coming weeks are crucial if Israel is to make peace with Damascus, and that the opportunity could soon be gone, with Mr Clinton entering the last days of his presidency, and the Syrian president, Hafez al-Assad, reported to be in fragile health.

Mr Barak is also operating under a self-imposed deadline to withdraw Israeli soldiers from south Lebanon by early July - a far more perilous undertaking if he fails to reach an understanding which would see Syria reining in the Hizbullah guerrillas in the region.

There have been recent reports of daily telephone calls between Mr Clinton and the two adversaries, during which the US president is believed to have resolved most of the outstanding issues. Many now believe that if Mr Clinton can find a formula to restart the talks, they could conclude speedily with a peace treaty.

"The announcement is important because this is the last chance for Clinton to get things moving, and maybe the last chance we have to reach an agreement," said Eyal Zisser, a Syrian expert at Tel Aviv University. "But it does not mean that there is an automatic agreement.

"We are very close, but I do not see any agreement yet -unless the Americans can do something miraculous."

The stumbling block remains Syria's insistence that Israel withdraw entirely from the Golan Heights. Mr Barak has tried to hang on to a strip of land by the Sea of Galilee, to safeguard Israel's security, and access to the lake that provides 40% of its water supply.

Mr Barak must also sell the deal to Israelis in a referendum, a prospect made more difficult by the rebellious nature of his coalition partners.

Syria's hostile statements in its state-run press will also make it hard to overcome domestic suspicion.
fields.bodyText: President Bill Clinton yesterday gave new impetus to the Syria-Israel peace process by announcing that he would meet Syria's leader to try to revive talks that foundered two months ago. "I don't want to unduly raise expectations, but I think that this is an appropriate thing for me to do to try to get this back on track so that our objective of having a comprehensive peace can go forward," Mr Clinton said, during a tour of south Asia. The announcement, and the resumption today of stalled Israeli-Palestinian talks, give a reprieve to Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, who has been thwarted in his pledge to steer his country to peace with both Syria and the Palestinians by the end of the year. Mr Barak has said that the coming weeks are crucial if Israel is to make peace with Damascus, and that the opportunity could soon be gone, with Mr Clinton entering the last days of his presidency, and the Syrian president, Hafez al-Assad, reported to be in fragile health. Mr Barak is also operating under a self-imposed deadline to withdraw Israeli soldiers from south Lebanon by early July - a far more perilous undertaking if he fails to reach an understanding which would see Syria reining in the Hizbullah guerrillas in the region. There have been recent reports of daily telephone calls between Mr Clinton and the two adversaries, during which the US president is believed to have resolved most of the outstanding issues. Many now believe that if Mr Clinton can find a formula to restart the talks, they could conclude speedily with a peace treaty. "The announcement is important because this is the last chance for Clinton to get things moving, and maybe the last chance we have to reach an agreement," said Eyal Zisser, a Syrian expert at Tel Aviv University. "But it does not mean that there is an automatic agreement. "We are very close, but I do not see any agreement yet -unless the Americans can do something miraculous." The stumbling block remains Syria's insistence that Israel withdraw entirely from the Golan Heights. Mr Barak has tried to hang on to a strip of land by the Sea of Galilee, to safeguard Israel's security, and access to the lake that provides 40% of its water supply. Mr Barak must also sell the deal to Israelis in a referendum, a prospect made more difficult by the rebellious nature of his coalition partners. Syria's hostile statements in its state-run press will also make it hard to overcome domestic suspicion.

webTitle: Victims of west's almost forgotten war in Iraq receive daily reminder that death is waiting

fields.headline: Victims of west's almost forgotten war in Iraq receive daily reminder that death is waiting
fields.standfirst: Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: Nasr Mazi, a farmer who grows dates and vegetables near the Euphrates river, went back into hospital yesterday to have shrapnel removed from his back, one of the latest victims of Britain and America's almost forgotten war along the Iraqi border.
fields.body:
Nasr Mazi, a farmer who grows dates and vegetables near the Euphrates river, went back into hospital yesterday to have shrapnel removed from his back, one of the latest victims of Britain and America's almost forgotten war along the Iraqi border.

Mr Mazi lives on the frontline, in an area that has been under siege for almost 10 years. The British and US governments say their argument is with President Saddam Hussein, not the Iraqi people. Mr Mazi would disagree.

His village, Al-Fade, near the town of Simawa, is quiet and poor, with a few idyllic touches such as the date palms that provide shade and colour in an otherwise desert area. Ducks, sheep, donkeys and children wander along the alleyways.

Sitting crosslegged in his courtyard Mr Mazi, who is 53 but looks much older from his days labouring in the hot sun, described how on March 10 he had followed his usual routine. "I watered the summer vegetables in the morning, went home for lunch and was walking back to the vegetables. There was a croak-croak. It was the planes. I was not worried. I heard them every day, near and far."

A minute later, he was knocked unconscious. The village had been attacked. The Iraqis blamed the US and British. Seven missiles were fired. Although only two exploded, they were enough to slice down rows of 100-year-old date trees, kill 10 sheep and a donkey, and injure six people.

Easy targets

One of those injured with Mr Mazi was Fadi Thamir, 35. Standing amid the fallen trees and the huge holes left in the ground by the missiles, Mr Thamir, also a farmer, said: "God save us: if it had gone off a little closer, we would have been killed. First came a humming, then a big explosion, and my hearing went. Fragments were flying all over. There was smoke. Bits of animals were flying up and down."

They were taken to hospital but Mr Thamir, suffering only superficial wounds, was allowed home quickly and helped clear up. "We fed the sheep and donkey to the dogs. Only the donkey's head is left," he said.

Mr Mazi was kept in, but allowed home for the weekend because it was a Muslim holiday. He was still in obvious pain as he stripped off his gown to show the puncture wounds from the shrapnel. He sent one of his two wives, Jamah Hatchem, into the house to bring out x-rays the hospital had allowed him to take home. He pointed proudly to the bits of metal embedded in his body.

When asked if he was angry with the US and Britain, he smiled. But his wife was outraged on his behalf. She had been in a room with her two children when the blast shook the house. "Why cannot the Iraqis have peace after all this time?" she asked.

The ancient villages and towns that line the Euphrates receive US and British sorties daily. It is the first populated area of Iraq to be reached by pilots flying north from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. The number of attacks is disputed, with the west claiming no more than a handful of bombings this year and the Iraqis claiming there are casualties every week.

A thorough look round the village showed nothing that could remotely have a military purpose. But the most likely targets of the recent attack were Sam missile launchers, which the Allies claim the Iraqis deliberately set up in civilian areas. Mr Thamir was adamant there were none: "How can you get anything military up that road? It is not good enough," he said.

There is no way of proving either way. He did, however, have some evidence from the attack. He put out a call and villagers went off to gather bits of missiles. One had a fragment which had the maker's serial number on it. Some of the letters and numbers were missing but what could be read clearly was "Product of roe auto 20 19350".

This stretch of Iraq - over which the US and Britain imposed a no-fly zone, saying it was necessary to protect dissident Shia Muslims opposed to President Saddam - is the hardest-hit of the conflict. It includes Basra in the east, and two big towns to the west - Nasiriya and Simawa - all of them desperate-looking.

Almost 10 years of bombing and economic sanctions have taken an enormous toll. Food is rationed, as is electricity. The whole place smells because the sewage system has virtually collapsed. Diseases that had been eradicated have returned. The cars are even more clapped-out than in Baghdad, with few newer than 1990, the year sanctions were imposed by the west.

Almost everyone in Iraq has to cope with sanctions but what makes life harder in the no-fly zone is that it was these towns that were subjected to the full onslaught of the Allied air attacks in 1991. The destruction remains much as it did then. Only half of Victory bridge over the Euphrates at Nasiriya remains and that is a mangled mess of light-green metal, pointing skywards. The bridge over the Euphrates at Simawa is still to be rebuilt, as is the electricity power station and much else of the infrastructure.

That first wave of bombing has left people psychologically scarred. They are constantly on edge in a way they are not in Baghdad. Amir Doshi, who teaches English to schoolchildren in Nasiriya, showing off his English, described life on the frontline as "a black comedy". But he was not laughing much. Driving along the Eu phrates, he reels off again and again the exact minute and date that each bridge was bombed and the number of people killed. At the point where the bridge over the Euphrates at Simawa used to be, he said: "Three-forty pm, 10th of February."

Mr Doshi is not unique. Council officials, doctors and others in the area, who struggled to recall events that had taken place only weeks or months previously, could speak in detail about 1991.

There are other legacies of the Gulf war. Uranium-depleted shells used by the Allies are strewn around. The British and Americans insist they are harmless, but the Iraqis say the uranium has seeped into the ground, presenting a severe health hazard.

And there are mines all over the area, which the Iraqis say were dropped by the Allies. A doctor at Saddam hospital in Nasiriya said that every day brought casualties of the mines, many of them children.

In one of the wards, Falh Mhil, a 15-year-old shepherd boy, lay covered in bandages. The bedlinen was filthy and the bed stank. Detergent is in short supply in Iraq, as well as medicines, both controlled by UN sanctions.

Taking sheep from his home at Al-nasr, about 37 miles (60km) north of Nasiriya, about a fortnight ago, Falh had seen his brothers, Abdullah, seven, and Faris, 10, throwing something to and fro. "It was bright red, the shape of a glass of water," he said. He was familiar with mines because there were so many in the area, but had not seen this type before. "My brother had taken the pin out and I tried to put it back. I fell down. It felt like a storm." He lost a hand and the sight in one eye.

In another ward was Adeba Ali, 13, a beautiful, dark-haired girl, a shepherdess. Last week, as she moved her flock to a pasture near her home at Basa, on the road to Basra, she triggered a mine explosion. "I was throwing stones at the sheep. It hit a yellow mine, about the-size of a bottle." She lost part of one of her heels.

Like Mr Mazi, Mr Doshi and Falh, Adeba is the victim of a war that is not being waged on the Iraqi people.

fields.headline: Fear of failure
fields.standfirst: How can parents help their children tackle SATs?  Eileen Tracy suggests some stress relief
fields.trailText: How can parents help their children tackle SATs? Eileen Tracy suggests some stress relief
fields.body:
Eleanor is nearly seven but she looks young for her age. I watch her skating around her parents' living room in her party frock. She's not sure who I am - I'm trying to make my visit informal, though I'm a little tense - but she's clearly dressed to impress. "So, Eleanor," her mother says, trying to hold her attention, "are you enjoying your SAT tests?"

She asks this for me because, back in 1996, the School Curriculum and Assessment Authority commissioned an evaluation of Standard Assessment Tasks (SATs), in which 11-year-olds showed "a high level of acceptance of the 1996 tests". As many as half said they enjoyed them.

Children of Eleanor's age are not thought to be stressed by SAT testing. The general view seems to be that, at six or seven, they're not very aware of what's going on and so SATs don't bother them much. But Eleanor is no fool. According to her mother, she has picked up on preoccupations at school about the level 2 target. And given how acutely aware she is of my presence, she's bound to notice when a supply teacher comes in to test her because her own class teacher is busy teaching another group.

Though she won't admit to any of this while I'm around; Eleanor steals one of her quick glances at me and declares loudly that yes, she's enjoying SATs. Her skating intensifies. Her mother raises an eyebrow at me. "And what are your teachers telling you to do?" "Be TIDY!" she shouts, stamping round the furniture.

Elaine Joyce of Tolworth Infants School in Kingston acknowledges that, unless handled sensitively, children can be stressed by the tests: "We tell parents it's important that their children have a good night's sleep and come to school, without giving the impression that SATs are the be-all and end-all." She pauses. "Though they may be for schools."

Certainly, tensions are rising now that teachers' pay is to be related to performance. Joyce agrees that where such tensions exist, children pick up on them, no matter how hard schools work to put them at their ease. It's true that the harder I try to make my interview with Eleanor informal, the more agitated she becomes.

I turn to Eleanor's 10-year-old sister, who is sitting quietly on the armrest of her mother's chair. Her sister's play irritates her. She tells me the tests are boring. She used to play herself - the piano - but she hasn't got time any more, because, being a promising child, she's been handpicked for government-funded level 4 SAT practice. This means she now works in her free time.

I dimly recall the theory behind SAT testing, in the days before estate agents started filling and emptying schools by displaying school league tables. And before the education secretary, David Blunkett, guaranteed that by 2001, 80% of key stage 2 pupils would reach level 4 in English (excepting pupils with special needs, who somehow don't count). Wasn't the theory something along the lines that SATs were "on the spot" tests?

The practice is somewhat different now: parent meetings organised to warn of oncoming tests; SAT predictions allegedly raised artificially year on year to satisfy Ofsted (regardless of the fact that results vary according to pupil intake and staff changes); rivalry between some teachers for best SAT scores, since no one exactly knows how else performance pay will be worked out; extra coaching to improve statistics; classwork, sometimes a year early, consisting mainly of SAT papers, and priority given to English, maths and science; scores benchmarked against test levels.

In this fearful climate, many parents worry about their children's grades, which is why the shelves of WH Smith are stacked with SAT booklets. SAT websites, like those provided by Freeserve and the BBC, receive anxious emails like, "My son is only getting level 3 in class work: how do you think he will perform come May?" Some schools even sell SAT papers to parents. Heads like Elaine Joyce abhor this practice, since it reinforces the idea that children should prepare for SATs.

And why should they? What exactly do children get out of all that hard work? Good SAT results benefit the government. They may even be an asset to certain schools and teachers. But apart from being streamed into different ability groups on government advice that "setting should be the norm in secondary schools", children's SAT results make no difference to their academic careers.

Raised standards in schools? Don't count on it. There's a world of difference between true learning and the parrot learning that enables children to score highly in SATs. The reason Tony Blair wisely said "education, education, education," not "tests, tests, tests" is that cramming and education are two different things - diametrically opposed, some would argue.

As Piaget, Neill, Montessori and other educators have pointed out, every time you tell a child about the world, you steal the thrill of discovery that is the key to an investigative mind.

No thrills for Adam, who at 13 must do his homework again tonight because it only scored 5B and he must get level 6. His results are pinned on the classroom wall, to humiliate him into working. In assembly, he is reminded of the need to maintain his school's high place in the league tables. He doesn't care about Shakespeare, or about why you spell "excited" with a c. He's feeling sick, and he's getting headaches and diarrhoea.

I have taught many pupils who were made to take exams too seriously. As Oliver James, author of Britain on the Couch, points out, today even children who are "winners" usually feel like "losers". And if, in the long run, the terror of not making the grade doesn't put them off their learning altogether, or make them ill, it usually makes them underperform, because fear restricts their thinking.

And yet. We have research that tells us children who do only occasional homework perform better than swots. The example of countries such as Denmark proves that children can do perfectly well starting school as late as seven. We have research that tells us good schools can improve pupils' performance a little, but not much, because psycho-social factors largely shape academic ability.

We have research that tells us that streaming doesn't improve grades and dampens children's morale. We have research that tells us children's minds develop through music and free play. We have research that tells us humans underperform when they are stressed. And we all know that teenagers rebel when they are sick of being ordered around.

But maybe a stressed education department finds it hard to take in all these findings. It's easier to fall for the attraction of crude policies, to prove to a demanding electorate that the government is making a tangible effort to raise standards in schools. So Blunkett introduces a blinkered, zero-tolerance, dare I say totalitarian regime, and simply tightens his grip on local education authorities, schools, teachers and, last of all, our children. The stress simply gets pushed down the rungs of the ladder.

As Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, praises rising standards and proposes further testing in schools, Eleanor had better watch out. Her skating days are numbered.

To keep your child calm

Do

 Keep SATs in perspective. They don't raise or lower your child's prospects: the results won't affect your child's transition to secondary school, and schools that stream children will tend not to do so on the basis of SAT results.

 Be aware that your child may be picking up on a certain amount of stress at school, if staff are tense or if classmates panic. Headaches, tiredness, feeling sick, not wanting to go to school or behaving disruptively are some ways in which children express frustration and anxiety.

 Talk with your child if he or she seems worried. Some anxiety is normal and can usually be overcome by talking about it. Help young children express their feelings by naming them (eg "you sound angry/worried/scared"). This is much more helpful than saying, "Don't worry".

 Encourage your child to look upon these tests as nothing more than exam practice.

Don't

 Make an issue of your child's SATs. Unlike GCSE and A levels, they can't be failed: they exist simply to measure standards in schools.

 Put pressure on your child to achieve a certain level. SATs are designed to be "on the spot" tests - despite the fact that many schools try to prepare children for them.

 Set too much store by the outcome of your child's SATs. Academic progress rarely follows a steady course: some children's work only matures in late adolescence, so SAT results don't necessarily predict future ability.

 Eileen Tracy is a study skills counsellor and lecturer. You can contact her on 0171-727 2118

Unlike GCSE and A levels, they can't be failed: they exist simply to measure standards in schools.  Put pressure on your child to achieve a certain level. SATs are designed to be "on the spot" tests - despite the fact that many schools try to prepare children for them.  Set too much store by the outcome of your child's SATs. Academic progress rarely follows a steady course: some children's work only matures in late adolescence, so SAT results don't necessarily predict future ability.  Eileen Tracy is a study skills counsellor and lecturer. fields.headline: The Perfect Journey?
fields.trailText: The Perfect Journey?
fields.body:
Michael Palin is one of the judges for the Guardian/ Piccadilly Press short story competition for young people (13-18), The Perfect Journey?

The prize for the best eight to 10 writers will be published in an anthology next autumn. This year's collection, The Perfect Love Story?, has already attracted favourable comment from Andrew Motion, Poet Laureate, so it is an ideal way for an aspiring writer to get noticed.

The journey does not have to be a holiday or even geographical at all - journeys of the mind, through time or of self-discovery are all welcome and the treatment is up to you - factual, funny, satirical or romantic. Make your story clear, on one side of the paper only - preferably typewritten. And remember to keep a copy, as manuscripts will not be returned. Only one entry per person. Length: no more than 3,000 words; deadline: April 30.

Entries should be sent to: The Guardian/Piccadilly Press Writing Competition for Teenagers, 5 Castle Road, London NW1 8PR.

The judges' decision is final and no correspondence will be entered into. All published manuscripts are edited. The competition is open to all residents of the UK and Eire between 13 and 18 years of age, except previous winners and employees of the Guardian or Piccadilly Press and their relatives.

Entry grants to Piccadilly Press Ltd the exclusive right to publish an entrant's story in all formats throughout the world for the full legal term of copyright. A copy of the form of the contract may be obtained on application to Piccadilly Press. By submitting an entry, an entrant agrees to be bound by the terms and to sign this agreement if called upon to do so. If not, no selected rights will be assigned.

fields.headline: A bit of exhibitionism
fields.standfirst: Richmond Museum's new exhibition is very unusual - it was put together by pupils from St Catherine's
fields.trailText: A bit of exhibitionism
fields.body:
The Museum of Richmond upon Thames is currently home to an unusual exhibition called "The Kid's War", an account of life during the second world war. But it is not the subject matter that makes this exhibition different. It is the fact that it was put together by 12 pupils, across the age and ability range, from St Catherine's School in Twickenham.

The project was made possible by Mary Sowell, head of history at the school, who thought that the weekly "activities lesson" could be an opportunity to do something outside the normal curriculum. In September, the girls visited the museum and discussed with the curator, Simon Lace, how museum displays are put together. They looked through the artefacts held in the stores and came up with their own idea for an exhibition that would provide a good contrast to the previous display, "What did you do in the war, Grandma?"

The girls called the shots, inspired by the enthusiasm of Sowell, and guided by the museum curators. They split into smaller teams, covering different aspects of both the display material and promotion of the exhibition.

Alice Hodgeson is in year 8, and worked on materials to do with living through the blitz. She enjoyed the work because it was different and more fun than school. However, she also discovered that "it's not as easy as you think" to put on an exhibition.

Lucy Harrison, in year 10, felt that the most interesting aspect had been interviewing local residents who had lived through the war and who "helped us to compare our lives now with their lives then, and how hard it must have been." She also commissioned someone to knit toys like those given to evacuees, using an authentic pattern from the time.

Camilla Cadier and Jane Dowridge, both in year 11, played a key role in publicising the exhibition, including the design and production of posters and invitations to the preview event, held at the museum on March 8.

It was opened by the BBC's community affairs correspondent, Geeta Gurumurthy, who was impressed by the girls' efforts and commented on how important it is "to try and make people understand the experiences of past generations". Her attendance at the event was due to the perseverance of the project editor, Elcca de Souza, in year 10.

Elcca played a key role in motivating the girls to have the exhibition ready on time, and in contacting celebrities, including Hugh Grant, Johnny Vaughan and Louise, in the hope of tempting them to the preview.

Both Elcca and Mary Sowell confirm that the girls have learnt more than just history - the whole process required them to develop research, interviewing, publicity, design and communication skills.

It also benefited the museum. Stephanie Kirkpatrick, assistant curator, says "we loved doing it - it's part of the museum's role". Working with St Catherine's on this exhibition has shown what can be done, and should the museum get planning permission for larger premises, they plan to do far more community projects. As Kirkpatrick will verify, "to put on a full, six-week exhibition is quite an achievement."

 "The Kid's War" is on from now until April 29 at the Museum of Richmond upon Thames, Whitaker Ave, Surrey TW9 1TP; tel: 0181-332 1141.
