fields.headline: Phoenix rising
fields.standfirst: Phil Revell reports on a school that seems to embody Blunkett's latest initiative. But all is not as it seems
fields.trailText: Phil Revell reports on a school that seems to embody Blunkett's latest initiative. But all is not as it seems
fields.body:
At first glance, Kings School in Wolverhampton is the very model of David Blunkett's new city academies. In serious trouble and heading for a critical Ofsted inspection, it has been turned round in partnership with a successful neighbour under a Church of England foundation. Could it be a blueprint for the kind of school the education and employment secretary has called on the churches, charities and businesses to set up and run in the inner cities and make them succeed where local authorities had failed?

As with most stories in education the truth is more complicated - the local authority played a big part, for a start - and it shows the government's "fresh start" policy in a less than flattering light. (That policy was rocked last week by the resignation of three high-profile "superheads".)

Four years ago Regis School, as it was then called, was in deep trouble. In the 70s, Regis had been a successful school, but with the coming of grant-maintained schools and parental choice in the 90s, middle-class parents abandoned the school and standards fell. By 1996, Wolverhampton's education department had already tried to support the school without success. An Ofsted inspection was imminent.

"It would have failed by break on the first day," says Peter Crook, head of the successful, neighbouring St Peters Collegiate School who was approached to become interim headteacher of Regis. The situation in the school was dire. Teachers came and went. One child had 13 maths teachers in her GCSE year. Attendance was 70% and truancy endemic. Local shopkeepers would make anguished calls to the school complaining about Regis pupils and demanding to know what was going on. The school's corridors teemed with children who had been thrown out of lessons or who had simply never turned up to where they were supposed to be.

Wolverhampton had run out of options. They approached Crook, whose school had been identified as one of the top comprehensives in the country, and asked him to take over Regis - to run it as a single, split-site school.

"I said no - it wasn't an attractive concept." What Crook would do was run the schools in partnership, under a Church of England foundation that would oversee both schools.

He was seconded in November 1996. What struck him forcibly on that first contact was the atmosphere of despair and defeat. One child said to him "I know why you're here - it's because we're rubbish." Asked why no one played soccer in the playground, the children told Crook that no one in their right mind brought a soccer ball to the Regis.

Throughout the winter, working groups hammered out the details of the new foundation. Lichfield diocese would buy the site and the buildings for £500,000 whilst the education department contributed £330,000 for essential health and safety work. Wolverhampton agreed to pass back the £500,000 to the school and to cover a deficit budget for its first few years of operation.

A new head, Tim Gallagher, was appointed a year later and the government declared Kings a fresh start school. The announcement took Crook and Gallagher by surprise.

"We were told we would be part of the fresh start initiative and we thought, 'What's that?' " Gallagher says.

Two years on, and they are still wondering. Attendance is up to 90% and last year's GCSEs saw a pass rate of 35% at grades A-C. There's a new uniform which nearly every child in the school was wearing on the first day and the disruption and chaos that characterised the school in the past has disappeared. In September, the Kings School will become a specialist school - an arts college, reflecting the progress teachers have made. Earlier this month, the foundation travelled down to see the education department.

"We're doing some good here," they said. "We've increased the roll from 570 to nearly 700 in 18 months. What are you doing?"

The answer is not a lot. The school has received no funding specifically targeted at its fresh start problems and essential building works are being delayed by Whitehall bureaucracy. Gallagher had a vision of a faith centre, to reflect the school's new Christian emphasis and the fact that many children come from other faiths.

"There's no sign of it," he says, "because the DfEE are sitting on the plans. We have tenders out, we know who's going to do it - all we want is for the DfEE to say yes. And we've no drama or arts facilities - despite the fact that those are major parts of our arts bid."

In its first year, the new school plunged £155,000 into debt, money that will have to be repaid to the local authority. "Had we been given the resourcing and support that other fresh start schools have received - and I hear figures of £8m for one school being bandied about - we wouldn't have these problems," says Gallagher. "In effect we were given a millstone when we started - not a fresh start."

Peter Crook is now the principal of the Lichfield Foundation and is evangelical about the concept of allowing schools to work in partnership.

"The notion of one school succeeding at the expense of another is alien to me," he says. The Wolverhampton fresh start could serve as a model in other areas and the involvement of the church, business and the local university is precisely the kind of community venture that Blunkett suggested this week.

But experience of the new Kings School also points up the fact that resourcing remains at the heart of the problem in many schools, and that solutions require more than a high-profile superhead. Peter Crook believes that a willingness to stay the course is essential.

"When you say 'This is what's going to be happening', parents' first thought is 'How long are you staying? because my child's staying five years'. You've either got the credibility or you haven't. I believe it's about people having faith that you are going to stay with it when it gets rough."

fields.headline: A Palin imitation
fields.standfirst: The traveller gives  Donald MacLeod  some tips on travel writing
fields.trailText: The traveller gives Donald MacLeod some tips on travel writing
fields.body:
Sunsets, volcanoes and deserts are high-risk areas when it comes to travel writing, confides Michael Palin.

The main thing is to be true to yourself, record your experiences in your own way and in your own voice.

As someone who followed in Hemingway's footsteps for his recent television series and book, he is also very aware of the need to avoid parodying your favourite author - though as he remarks: "I don't think Ernest Hemingway and I would have got along. I don't have that amount of competitive energy. I don't really care about catching more fish, or shooting more ducks or having more wives than anyone else. And comedy was never his strong point."

How did he set about travel writing - a venture that started with trying to retrace Phileas Fogg's route Around the World in 80 Days and proceeded to grow into a highly popular series? "The detail is what is important. It may be just how somebody moves. One of the most extraordinary sights is not a volcano or a glacier but how people walk through places like Africa. They may have to walk 10 miles a day, every day, to get water, and the way they hold themselves, their bearing - they're going about an everyday task but with an extraordinary dignity - it makes them almost military figures."

No one will become a good travel writer without being interested in human beings, he believes. "A certain humility is always in order when you are a travel writer. Travel is humbling - we are figures of fun when we travel - high and mighty westerners with knobbly knees," adds Palin, whose books have a pleasant vein of self-deprecating humour running through them. (Warning: Palin's books are easy to read but that does not mean easy to write - as you may discover when you come to try writing up your own perfect journey. That casual air takes a lot of work.)

"The best form of travel is when you're on your own. You soon realise you need to make friends and try to at least speak the rudiments of another language and eat food made locally. If you are with a large group of people you often find yourself on the equivalent of a viewing platform, looking at it all through plate-glass."

He was of course going around with a film crew, but they were skilful and discreet, did not set things up in elaborate ways or ask people to do things three or four times. "You know when you have lost people - they go quiet." But the Beeb's reputation does mean something in even the remotest spot, as Palin discovered while researching his Hemingway journey. "I'm from the BBC." Instant recognition. "Ah yes," said the skipper shaking my hand, "the Bahamas Billfish Championships."

There was also a back-up team to make the arrangements. But, as Palin records, despite their plans they ended up "bustling, hurrying, rushing, improvising to get ourselves home only by the skin of our teeth. And that's what made it worth doing. The smoother the journey, the duller it would have been."

fields.headline: Team tactics
fields.trailText: I used to associate talk about successful strategies with the likes of managers of football teams and captains of industry.
fields.body:
I used to associate talk about successful strategies with the likes of managers of football teams and captains of industry. But then the education world wised up to the idea that there might be something in it for schools where resources are limited but ambitions to improve standards and quality are great.

Governors have been given a key role of "providing a strategic view" for the school but sometimes have difficulty in understanding what that looks like in practice, and end up with an Ofsted report criticising them for their lack of strategic thinking.

One governor said to me recently, "I've read Ofsted's criticism of our lack of strategic planning, but my governing body doesn't know how that should work in practice!" To start with, governors may be more familiar with Alex Ferguson's strategies to create an incredibly successful football team. They wouldn't go far wrong applying some of the same principles.

The aims of the club are clear in terms of the team's performance; the manager communicates - as must a headteacher - what needs to be done to succeed and he's clear about the cost and how long it's going to take.

Well, in education we're not interested in the profit motive, but we are interested in accountability to the stockholder equivalent - the parents and the community. The governing body needs to make sure, having established the vision and direction of the school, that the strategy identifies what needs to be done to get there, knows what it will cost and, crucially, is clear about what success will look like. The challenge to a governing body is how it holds the school to account for the progress it makes or otherwise.

At this point in the year, most governing bodies are reviewing the progress of the school development plan, the vehicle for delivering the strategy, identifying its successes and any failures.

Harder evidence will tell you about academic attainment - SATs results, GCSE and A levels and any other testing or assessments the teachers have put in place. Other evidence will give a wider picture of the state of health of the school - attendance levels, incidents of bullying, number of complaints, involvement of pupils in the community and, conversely, the level of community and parental support for the school.

This review means you move towards the end of the financial year with a clearer picture of what the school's precious resources must support in the new financial year and beyond.

Note that the new School Regulations (1999) require the governing body, not a sub-committee, to approve the budget. That should give governing bodies a nice bit of joined-up understanding about strategy for the coming year and beyond, and how it can be funded. Governors must continue to check progress throughout the year and will come full circle again within the year to doing another complete review and again asking the leadership and staff to account for the successful delivery of the plan.

New governors could do worse than note the simple stages suggested by the Department for Education and Employment to check progress:

 Be clear about how well the school is doing

 Ask the head how your performance compares with similar schools

 Come to an agreement with the head about what more we should aim to achieve in the coming year(s)

 Ask what we must do to make it happen
 Set up systems that will provide everyone in the school with information and evidence about progress.

 Mary McKay undertakes governor training for Warwickshire LEA.

New governors could do worse than note the simple stages suggested by the Department for Education and Employment to check progress:  Be clear about how well the school is doing  Ask the head how your performance compares with similar schools  Come to an agreement with the head about what more we should aim to achieve in the coming year(s)  Ask what we must do to make it happen  Set up systems that will provide everyone in the school with information and evidence about progress.  Mary McKay undertakes governor training for Warwickshire LEA.

fields.headline: Church welcome
fields.standfirst: The case for city academies
fields.trailText: The case for city academies
fields.body:
Most Church of England secondary schools are turning away large numbers of potential pupils, for no other reason than lack of space. Numbers applying have grown significantly in the past decade. And there are large parts of the country where a Church of England secondary education is not even an option. The church has recognised the need to plan for the provision of more secondary places and commissioned Lord Dearing to lead a review to propose how it should be done. So David Blunkett's announcement last week that the government wanted to work with the church in response to our initiative was welcome.

The Church of England has some positive experience of fresh start schools and of city technology colleges. The King's C of E High School in Wolverhampton rose from the ashes of Regis School, has improved beyond recognition and has now been recognised as an arts college. Bacon's, a city technology college in Rotherhithe, London, sponsored by the Church of England 10 years ago, rose from the ashes of Bacon's C of E High School in Bermondsey and is one of the most improved schools. Clear and agreed aims for a school, based on a Christian understanding of education, should produce positive results, at least in terms of added value.

Diocesan boards of education work hard at the partnership with local education authorities and often find good understanding and support for the church's aims. But Lord Dearing's review group and individual diocesan authorities will look carefully to see what opportunities there are in the latest announcement for developing Church of England secondary education. The church will plan to provide education, based on clear Christian beliefs and values, for families who want it for their children, without the sometimes unseemly jockeying for places and the current large-scale rejection of 11-year olds.

 Canon John Hall, general secretary, Church of England Board of Education.

fields.headline: Colour of money
fields.standfirst: Universities are still failing their ethnic minority staff
fields.trailText: Universities are still failing their ethnic minority staff
fields.body:
Universities have come under increased pressure to reform their "deplorable" employment record after revelations that black and Asian academics are paid significantly less than their white counterparts. Ministers have already expressed concern about the unequal treatment of women staff in higher education.

Yesterday Malcolm Wicks, minister for lifelong learning, met representatives of the higher and further education funding councils to hammer home the government's "deep concern" about the unsatisfactory situation. He told the meeting, attended by the lecturers' union Natfhe, which has been campaigning on the issue, that barriers to equal opportunities must be identified and removed. Discussions have gone on for years in universities and colleges, but ministers have become frustrated with the lack of progress, as David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, has made clear.

"Higher education has not made sufficient progress in equal opportunities for its employees in the past - in fact the situation is frankly deplorable. Pay discrimination is widespread and institutional leadership is totally unrepresentative of wider society," he said recently.

A survey of more than 500 academic economists by Jeff Frank, of Royal Holloway, University of London, and David Blackaby, of Swansea, found ethnic minority staff received about 13% lower pay than their white counterparts - an average of £2,500 to £3,000.

Far from being bastions of liberal employment policies, universities were no better than companies and organisations in the country at large. "It is not that universities are evil but we have a system under very great stress and they try to minimise expenditure. If you can get a black or woman economist for less money, a vice-chancellor will do that. Nobody is meaning to discriminate, but under stress good employment practices tend to disappear," said Frank.

Glaring differences remained even after they adjusted for the fact that black and Asian economists tend to be younger. Women, too, fare worse than average when it comes to pay and the researchers were surprised to find single women were paid less than married colleagues.

After adjusting for age and productivity, married women suffered an earnings gap of 9% relative to men, compared with a gap of 14% for unmarried women. The image of the single academic sacrificing family for an academic career needs re-examining. Frank speculated that single women were seen as more of a threat than married women when it came to promotion - which if true would certainly constititute discrimination.

Lord Desai, a distinguished economist who heads the London School of Economics' centre for global governance, said economists in the UK were poorly paid in general but black and Asian academics had encountered difficulties in promotion. "Offhand I cannot think of a single black professor of economics in the UK." University procedures are so opaque that it is difficult to prove discrimination.

The Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals said that over the past five years they had worked with trade unions on a number of equality initiatives. The Equal Opportunities Advisory Service, currently being piloted, involves 10 universities. The pilot will be evaluated this summer with a view to being fully launched in the autumn.

fields.headline: Fighting to win
fields.standfirst: After 18 years heading the NUS, Labour Students are not putting forward a candidate for a presidential election dominated by fees
fields.trailText: After 18 years heading the NUS, Labour Students are not putting forward a candidate for a presidential election dominated by fees
fields.body:
The threat of top-up fees looms large on the horizon for a student movement still reeling from the abolition of the grant and introduction of tuition fees.

These issues will be on the agenda at this year's National Union of Students conference, to be held in Blackpool between 3-6 April. For the first time in 18 years, Labour Students are not fielding a candidate for NUS national president, the most powerful and influential position in the 3m-strong union, and one that they have held for almost two decades.

Andrew Pakes, the current Labour Students president of the NUS, wants to see Labour Students focusing on building the grassroots of their organisation and winning the next general election for the Labour Party, rather than expending energy onwinning the leadership of the student movement. However, Labour Students are still fielding candidates for four out of six of the full-time NUS positions. Many students believe that fear of defeat is a more likely explanation for Labour Students' decision not to field a candidate for president.

The group has been condemned by much of the student movement for the role they played in capitulating to the Labour party's anti-grant policy in the run-up to the 1997 general election. At the time, Labour argued that grants were unrealistic in a fiscally prudent world, and that the NUS should concentrate on preventing the introduction of tuition fees.

In reality the NUS gave an inch and the government took a mile, capitalising on the student movement's compromise with the long-held principle of free education to abolish the grant and introduce fees.

Labour Students might also be unwilling to lead the NUS now that top-up fees are back on the agenda. Number 10 is sympathetic to calls for the introduction of top-up fees from the Russell group of research universities, and have announced that a higher education funding review will take place in 2002.

However, it is likely that the government will allow top-up fees to be introduced in some universities soon after the general election which, if it is held next spring or summer, would put a new Labour Students president in conflict with the Labour government.

The next president of the NUS will inherit a divided student movement. From October Scottish students will be enjoying the fruits of devolution, in the form of means-tested bursaries and the replacement of tuition fees with a graduate contribution. Meanwhile, English and Welsh students will continue to be charged tuition fees and rely on loans for their maintenance. The next president of NUS will face pressure to win the Scottish concessions for English and Welsh students.

The past two years have seen a rise in direct action, including mass non-payment of fees, occupations and rent strikes. The new president will be under pressure to support such action, particularly if it is endorsed by local students' unions.

So who will the new president be? There are three candidates vying for the top job at this year's annual conference. Alison Angus, current NUS Black Students officer, Owain James, current NUS national secretary, and Mark Tweedale, a member of the NUS national executive committee.

Whereas previous years have seen an acrimonious fight between Labour Students and the hard left for the presidency, this year the race is likely to be between James, an independent, and Angus, an independent left candidate leading the left's United for Education slate.

The politics of the student movement appear to be narrowing. Whereas Labour Students supported the abolition of the grant in 1997, they now advocate its restoration for the poorest students. This brings them closer to the position of the traditional left in the NUS, who support universal grants.

All three of this year's presidential candidates advocate the abolition of tuition fees, oppose top-up fees and believe that the minimum wage should be increased to at least £5 per hour for all employees.

There is also a shared conviction that the NUS must improve its campaigns and level of student participation if it is to avoid becoming irrelevant to students.

This narrowing of the political ground within the NUS will make the race for Labour Students' successor a closely run contest. Labour Students are already finding it difficult to take a back seat, with Andrew Pakes arguing that the issue is now "whether students want to see the NUS lurch to the left or remain mainstream".

However, the direction the student movement will take after 18 years of Labour Students leadership is now in the hands of some 1,200 student delegates meeting in Blackpool next month.

Cast your vote

Alison Angus, currently NUS Black Students Officer, is standing as part of the "United for Education - Free and Equal" slate, which includes the Campaign for Free Education, Socialist Worker Students' Society and left independents. An "independent left" candidate, she describes herself as a socialist and a feminist, but has no party political affiliation. Angus says the slate includes "people who have a track record of fighting for free education".

On student grants: "There should be a full living grant available for all students. We need to move away from the current situation where some students are working 40 hours a week outside their studies."

On top-up fees: "Top-up fees are an attack on students and must be ruled out by the government, to avoid a two-tier education system. We need to remind Tony Blair that he promised to widen access to higher education."

On direct action: "Direct action has proven itself to be an effective tool in making change where other forms of protest have been ignored. For example, NUS should stand side by side with Cambridge students, who have withheld thousands of pounds in rent from their university since rents were increased last October."

On non-payment of tuition fees: "If it wasn't for some students voluntarily withholding their fees there would be nobody standing up for those who never went to university, or dropped out early, because they couldn't pay."

On NUS reform: "Students are tired of the status quo in NUS. They want an open and inclusive union. We must end the current attitude of 'Labour Students good, non-Labour Students bad."

Message to the government: "If I am elected NUS will become a national union that really campaigns on student issues. Rather than capitulating to the government, we will put pressure on them." www.alisonangus.fsnet.co.uk

Mark Tweedale is a member of the NUS national executive and has a background as an activist in the further education sector. He is standing as a "genuine independent" and does not have a party political affiliation. His priority is to highlight what he sees as corruption and factionalism in NUS.

On the student grant: "The grant should be restored and students should not have to rely on loans of any kind. The system in England and Wales should come into line with the new system in Scotland. The general principle should be that grants return and are increased in line with inflation each year. Housing benefit for students should also be restored."

On top-up fees: "Colleges are increasingly cash starved, so top-up fees will be an issue. We should fight for increased funding to be allotted to the education sector and the government should stop playing one sector off against the other."

On direct action: "Direct action is not a means in itself as some people see it, but is a tool that students should keep in their armoury for when it is appropriate."

On NUS reform: "The national union is being run in the interests of the factions and not its membership. It is in need of root-and-branch change from the ground up. The powers of the national president need to be curbed. Too much power and control rest on the unilateral say of one person."

Message to the government: "After 18 years the NUS will no longer be run in the interests of the Labour Party."

Owain James is NUS national secretary. He is standing as an independent and is a member of the Labour Party. He wishes to see NUS become more powerful again, to involve students and turn it around from a factional battleground to an organisation that wins and changes things for students.

On the student grant: "If there was a certain amount of money we could win from the government, we should try and target that money at students who most need it. What I'm interested in is a campaign that changes things."

On top-up fees: "We need to run a mass campaign. We need to take the campaign to the public who, in a general election, the Labour Party will fear. A PR-obsessed government can be defeated by a united student movement."

On direct action: "If a student union democratically decided to go into occupation, that's something that the national union should support."

On non-payment of tuition fees: "There's a difference between students who aren't able to pay and those who choose not to pay. We need something that will bring all students together rather than using methods that haven't succeeded."

On reform of NUS: "We are at a crossroads. Do we try to involve students, or do we go back to factions?"

Message to the government: "They're no longer going to be able to get away with treating student funding as a piggy bank to raid."

fields.headline: Global vision
fields.standfirst: Howard Newby reports on America's strides towards internet-based learning and argues that Britain must follow suit
fields.trailText: Howard Newby reports on America's strides towards internet-based learning and argues that Britain must follow suit
fields.body:
While globalisation is well advanced on the research side of most universities, it is less prominent so far in teaching and learning. However, the global spread of IT and the English language are now providing the conditions for the development of a truly global market in teaching and learning in higher education.

It is possible now, for example, to sit at a terminal anywhere in the UK and undertake an MBA Course from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). The market for higher education through distance learning has been estimated at $300bn worldwide - and this is growing. As we move more and more into a knowledge-driven economy, there is no reason to believe that the higher education market will not rapidly become globalised. In the US some of these tendencies are already well advanced.

There has been a range of responses amongst higher education institutions in North America, many of which give an indication of how matters may develop in the UK. At one extreme, for example, there is the University of Phoenix, a for-profit organisation which is owned by Apollo Communications Inc. Students who enrol with the University of Phoenix not only have access to their courseware over the internet, but also are able to enlist the support of course assistants in their local study centres.

So far, the university has concentrated on the professional qualification-end of the higher education market, most notably MBAs and higher degree qualifications for school teachers. However, it is expanding rapidly and has plans to move into the European market. Another initiative is Unext.com, an Anglo-American consortium of business schools - including the London School of Economics - offering MBAs and other related qualifications online.

Further along the spectrum, a number of the major American research-led universities such as UC Berkeley, Michigan and Columbia have held discussions with major knowledge providers in the private sector such as Time-Warner, Disney Corporation, Microsoft and Cisco. Their aim is to form partnerships which will develop the appropriate courseware and support needed to attack the global market in higher education in the 21st century.

While the universities provide most of the academic expertise and, crucially, the "branding" necessary for market credibility, the partners provide production facilities, distribution and marketing, as well as much of the underlying technology, so the whole operation can actually function on a global scale. The universities have access to the necessarily large amounts of funding needed to invest in the development and maintenance of courseware, while the private-sector partners have access to the quality-control procedures, accreditation and status of some to the most prestigious universities in the US.

Until now there have been few signs in the UK that these kinds of partnerships are being brought to gether, despite the excellent quality of British higher education and the undeniably outstanding creative talent in the UK media sector. Higher education, of course, remains a social, and not just a cognitive, experience. Students want more than to sit in front of computer screens. Nevertheless for certain, and growing, parts of the market, such distance learning - provided it can be of high quality - satisfies an important need.

This particularly applies to what one might call the continuing professional development end of the market. This also happens to be a particularly profitable area of higher education in the UK. But in the future, why should a mature, part-time student enrol on a mediocre MBA course at the University of Poppleton when he or she could, possibly supported by their employer, take an MBA from Harvard or MIT over the internet?

These possibilities will also be assisted by changing patterns of student demand for teaching and learning. The conventional three-year, full-time, residential course was based upon what might be called a "just-in-case" philosophy of learning. In the majority of subjects, most knowledge gained from a university course is not used directly in a student's later career.

More recently, the increasing flexibility of access to higher education in the UK has provoked a shift to more "just-in-time" forms of delivery - lifelong learning and all that. In future the trends may well produce a further shift towards "just-for-you" learning, in which students can access within a vast array of courseware the elements required to meet their particular needs at a particular time. While there will remain a market for a conventional three-year, full-time, residential degree, it may well be smaller than at present, and institutions may well increasingly have to choose their niche in the market.

The developments exemplified by the University of Phoenix, then, represent both an opportunity and a threat to higher education in the UK. At present we seem to be rather like the British motor industry in the 1960s - on the brink of participating in a global market, but poorly organised to take advantage of the opportunities available.

One reason these trends have escaped our attention in the UK is that we have been consumed by internally derived changes in the structure and function of higher education. The rapid shift from an elite to a mass system of higher education need hardly be laboured here.

Many of these issues were only briefly touched upon in the Dearing report on higher education, which did not take a longer-term view. Dearing, therefore, produced a short-term political fix, but left a long-term policy vacuum. Nevertheless he did establish the outlines of his "compact", to provide a set of aims and objectives for higher education in the 21st century. Among them were lifelong learning, creation of a learning society, regional economic regeneration and development, pure research and scholarship across and within disciplines, technological innovation, social cohesion and public accountability.

Dearing recommended no structural change. Mass higher education was to proceed via an institutional structure designed for elite higher education. So the key question to ask about the Dearing compact is not whether certain elements are desirable. The key question is: should all universities seek to achieve all these things equally? The answer is clearly no.

There are insufficient resources in the system to allow all the universities to achieve all of these goals with equal facility. So if it is impossible for all universities to seek to achieve all these goals equally, then how is a sensible division of labour to be organised? In particular, is collaboration to achieve these aims easier to achieve between institutions or within them? Dearing is silent on these issues.

There is little doubt that structural change will emerge as a key policy issue. What will be novel, however, is that the future structure of higher education in Britain will need to be oriented to global, and not simply national, policy agendas.

 Professor Howard Newby is vice-chancellor of the University of Southampton and the first president of the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals. He is a former chairman of the Economic and Social Research Council, and taught at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, US.
 Education Futures is the first joint publication of the RSA and the Design Council posing challenging questions about the UK education system. Education Futures is free and is available by calling Helen Obi at the Design Council on 020 7420 5241.
fields.bodyText: While globalisation is well advanced on the research side of most universities, it is less prominent so far in teaching and learning. However, the global spread of IT and the English language are now providing the conditions for the development of a truly global market in teaching and learning in higher education. It is possible now, for example, to sit at a terminal anywhere in the UK and undertake an MBA Course from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). The market for higher education through distance learning has been estimated at $300bn worldwide - and this is growing. As we move more and more into a knowledge-driven economy, there is no reason to believe that the higher education market will not rapidly become globalised. In the US some of these tendencies are already well advanced. There has been a range of responses amongst higher education institutions in North America, many of which give an indication of how matters may develop in the UK. At one extreme, for example, there is the University of Phoenix, a for-profit organisation which is owned by Apollo Communications Inc. Students who enrol with the University of Phoenix not only have access to their courseware over the internet, but also are able to enlist the support of course assistants in their local study centres. So far, the university has concentrated on the professional qualification-end of the higher education market, most notably MBAs and higher degree qualifications for school teachers. However, it is expanding rapidly and has plans to move into the European market. Another initiative is Unext.com, an Anglo-American consortium of business schools - including the London School of Economics - offering MBAs and other related qualifications online. Further along the spectrum, a number of the major American research-led universities such as UC Berkeley, Michigan and Columbia have held discussions with major knowledge providers in the private sector such as Time-Warner, Disney Corporation, Microsoft and Cisco. Their aim is to form partnerships which will develop the appropriate courseware and support needed to attack the global market in higher education in the 21st century. While the universities provide most of the academic expertise and, crucially, the "branding" necessary for market credibility, the partners provide production facilities, distribution and marketing, as well as much of the underlying technology, so the whole operation can actually function on a global scale. The universities have access to the necessarily large amounts of funding needed to invest in the development and maintenance of courseware, while the private-sector partners have access to the quality-control procedures, accreditation and status of some to the most prestigious universities in the US. Until now there have been few signs in the UK that these kinds of partnerships are being brought to gether, despite the excellent quality of British higher education and the undeniably outstanding creative talent in the UK media sector. Higher education, of course, remains a social, and not just a cognitive, experience. Students want more than to sit in front of computer screens. Nevertheless for certain, and growing, parts of the market, such distance learning - provided it can be of high quality - satisfies an important need. This particularly applies to what one might call the continuing professional development end of the market. This also happens to be a particularly profitable area of higher education in the UK. But in the future, why should a mature, part-time student enrol on a mediocre MBA course at the University of Poppleton when he or she could, possibly supported by their employer, take an MBA from Harvard or MIT over the internet? These possibilities will also be assisted by changing patterns of student demand for teaching and learning. The conventional three-year, full-time, residential course was based upon what might be called a "just-in-case" philosophy of learning. In the majority of subjects, most knowledge gained from a university course is not used directly in a student's later career. More recently, the increasing flexibility of access to higher education in the UK has provoked a shift to more "just-in-time" forms of delivery - lifelong learning and all that. In future the trends may well produce a further shift towards "just-for-you" learning, in which students can access within a vast array of courseware the elements required to meet their particular needs at a particular time. While there will remain a market for a conventional three-year, full-time, residential degree, it may well be smaller than at present, and institutions may well increasingly have to choose their niche in the market. The developments exemplified by the University of Phoenix, then, represent both an opportunity and a threat to higher education in the UK. At present we seem to be rather like the British motor industry in the 1960s - on the brink of participating in a global market, but poorly organised to take advantage of the opportunities available. One reason these trends have escaped our attention in the UK is that we have been consumed by internally derived changes in the structure and function of higher education. The rapid shift from an elite to a mass system of higher education need hardly be laboured here. Many of these issues were only briefly touched upon in the Dearing report on higher education, which did not take a longer-term view. Dearing, therefore, produced a short-term political fix, but left a long-term policy vacuum. Nevertheless he did establish the outlines of his "compact", to provide a set of aims and objectives for higher education in the 21st century. Among them were lifelong learning, creation of a learning society, regional economic regeneration and development, pure research and scholarship across and within disciplines, technological innovation, social cohesion and public accountability. Dearing recommended no structural change. Mass higher education was to proceed via an institutional structure designed for elite higher education. So the key question to ask about the Dearing compact is not whether certain elements are desirable. The key question is: should all universities seek to achieve all these things equally? The answer is clearly no. There are insufficient resources in the system to allow all the universities to achieve all of these goals with equal facility. So if it is impossible for all universities to seek to achieve all these goals equally, then how is a sensible division of labour to be organised? In particular, is collaboration to achieve these aims easier to achieve between institutions or within them? Dearing is silent on these issues. There is little doubt that structural change will emerge as a key policy issue. What will be novel, however, is that the future structure of higher education in Britain will need to be oriented to global, and not simply national, policy agendas.  Professor Howard Newby is vice-chancellor of the University of Southampton and the first president of the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals. He is a former chairman of the Economic and Social Research Council, and taught at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, US.  Education Futures is the first joint publication of the RSA and the Design Council posing challenging questions about the UK education system. Education Futures is free and is available by calling Helen Obi at the Design Council on 020 7420 5241.

fields.headline: Profit or loss?
fields.standfirst: Suzanne Zima  reports from Jordan, where the boom in private higher education has done wonders for many investors' pockets
fields.trailText: Suzanne Zima reports from Jordan, where the boom in private higher education has done wonders for many investors' pockets
fields.body:
In the offices of the Higher Council of Education, a bureaucrat throws his hands into the air - he has lost count of the number of applications. "Everyone wants to open a university in Jordan," he says with a sigh. "There is an endless line."

Most hopefuls have been rejected. But there is a burgeoning list of applicants who have succeeded, mirroring the regional trend to privatising higher education. In the past decade, 12 new private universities have opened their doors in Jordan, reflecting a sea change in higher education. "It is a new experience - something within the last ten years in the Arab world - and the governments are trying to find what is the best way to guarantee that the profits are not at the expense of quality," says Marwan Kamal, head of the Arab Union of Universities.

Until the past decade, universities in the Arab world have almost without exception been state-subsidised public institutions. Explains Kamal: "People expected that the governments would take care of the education of their children. But now it is becoming difficult for the governments to do this."

Jordan, tottering near bankruptcy, cannot sustain a state university system that subsidises two-thirds of the actual cost of tuition - nor expand places to meet a student demand growing 2%-4% a year. Competition is keen for the available university places, with public universities admitting only those with the highest scores in the college entrance exams. Even then, competition for the field of one's choice is difficult, with many students turned away or forced to study disciplines they don't choose.

Jordanians, along with Gulf and Palestinian expats, are increasingly turning to the option of private "for-profit" universities in Jordan.

The new universities have succeeded so spectacularly that higher education has become big business. "It is the best investment in the country now - they are making millions," said Adnan Abu Odeh, member of the royal court and a life-time advocate of higher education.

Other observers were less kind, referring to the businessmen-turned-chairmen of private universities as a "mafia", and terming the profit margin obscene. Insiders say one small Irbid university with a student enrolment under 3,000 netted a profit of $3m last year.

Several years ago, the businessmen's lust for profit, versus the government's need to safeguard the university system, resulted in a crisis. Ahmed Husban, secretary-general of the Council of Higher Education, says: "We discovered that the major hurdle... is the conflict between academic and financial management." The battle was joined over who would hold sway in the running of universities - professional, dedicated educators or hard-nosed investors - often with little formal education themselves.

The upshot was a freeze on applications for private for-profit universities and stricter regulation of those already existing. But it is a battle not always resolved. "This effect has been reduced a lot, but is still there. There is still some conflict," said Husban. And he admits: "It is hindering academic progress."

According to Adnan Abu Odeh, special advisor to King Abdullah and lifelong advocate of higher education, the freeze was intended also to address the issue of classical versus vocational education, and pressure the private sector to invest in vocational programmes needing expensive equipment. Says Odeh: "The issue is the quality and type of human resources we are producing. The government doesn't want to see more people coming to the labour market with degrees screaming for jobs - while there are other vacancies that need people. [But] the private universities don't go into the areas that are needed because it's expensive."

Yet the analysis of private for-profit education is not all negative. Adnan Badran, a respected educator and president of the private Philadelphia University, wants the field open to the private sector, with regulatory safeguards: "I strongly believe that the market should be open to competition and competition will lead to [the point] where good universities will survive while bad universities will vanish. Leave it to the marketplace." He says private universities can respond more easily than the public sector to changing needs: "This is why I am against the expansion of any more public universities, which are a burden on the taxpayer."

Badran faults the existing "free" public system: "People will study [anything] because it costs nothing. Taxpayers and the government are paying for graduating boys and girls in disciplines not needed any more."

The newest venture in higher education is an attempt to establish private "non-profit" universities. Three hopefuls with initial approval are trying to meet the government's conditions. But the problem is finding donors. According to Badran, the tax system does not help - there are neither tax incentives nor inheritance-tax exemption.

Adds Kamal: "For non-profit universities, you have to find the donors to put up the money with no expectations of financial returns. And philanthropy for education is a new experience here."

fields.headline: Funding alarm for post-16s
fields.standfirst: Colleges warn that they must cut student intake or abandon reforms
fields.trailText: Colleges warn that they must cut student intake or abandon reforms
fields.body:
Curriculum 2000, the post-16 reforms due to be launched this autumn, faces disaster unless more cash is found to fund it, colleges warn.

The provisional sums recently allocated to institutions by the Further Education Funding Council mean that many will have to cut student numbers or abandon the new programmes, say principals.

Malcolm Wicks, the minister for lifelong learning, tried to reassure the sector that there would be enough resources to implement the reforms. He said he had the funding council's assurance that it would revise its figures and pipe more cash to colleges predicting increased numbers of students for the new programmes.

But colleges are not merely concerned about larger student numbers. Some are anxious that even if recruitment stays static, they will lack funds to support the extra classes and teaching sessions that the new curriculum will need.

Under Curriculum 2000, students will be encouraged to pursue more than the three subjects routinely taken at A level. They will be urged to prepare for four or five A/S levels in the first year of their course, and then they can concentrate on completing three A levels in the second year. There will be three new key skills taught: information technology, use of English and "application of number".

The government is is not earmarking discrete lumps of cash to fund the new curriculum. The funding council has announced that it is finding £35m extra from its existing allocations to fund the first year of the new curriculum - 2001-02 - and £90m for year two.

In the past couple of weeks, colleges have been notified of their "provisional allocations" for next year by the funding council. They can apply for more money from the council before the April 14 deadline.

One anxious sixth-form college principal said: "The problem is that it is being assumed that we can find extra places for students to do their fourth and fifth subjects simply by making the existing groups bigger."

That is not feasible in institutions where the average group size ranges from 17 to 20 students, the principal added.

Nor is it likely that students will plump for minority subjects for their extra course, as one minister suggests. "Most colleges have largely recruited next year's intake. The reality is that students are picking popular subjects: psychology, business studies, English and so on."

If a college takes in 1,000 students, and 750 of them take the two extra A/S level courses, that would be the equivalent of 750 extra A levels, he said.

"That's what a beefy school sixth form of 250 pupils provides, but nobody would dream of running a new sixth form without proper funding."

A tertiary college principal said that if the funding council did not satisfactorily revise colleges' allocations, many would have to withdraw offers to next year's intake.

"They will have to knock off the new A/S levels, and might even have to abandon the key skills."

A spokesperson for the Association of Colleges said it hoped the funding council would come up with revised sums to the colleges' satisfaction. But members fear this will mean slashing other parts of the council's allocations for the sector.

"Our view is that there could well be a problem - and if there is, we expect government to do something about it."

fields.headline: Moral stand
fields.standfirst: Paul Donovan on the growing consensus among students that universities should invest ethically
fields.trailText: Paul Donovan on the growing consensus among students that universities should invest ethically
fields.body:
Paul Davies completed his masters degree in business and administration at Cambridge University last summer but has yet to graduate. His outstanding debt of £14.50 for a kitchen charge at Selwyn College, which he refused to pay after learning of its investments in arms companies, means that under the university rules he cannot receive his degree.

Before taking up his course he had worked with landmine victims in Cambodia and then for the Manchester based de-mining charity the Mines Advisory Group, so he was horrified to discover his college held investments in arms companies like British Aerospace (now BAE Systems) and GKN.

"My one remaining debt to the college was the kitchen fixed charge, so I decided I would not pay this bill until there was a formal decision by the college to adopt an ethical policy that does not include investments in the arms trade," says Davies. "I still feel absolutely shocked that an educational institution should have so little interest in even exploring the possibility that ethical investment is a good thing."

Sally Brinton, the bursar of Selwyn College, responds: "The position is that the student body has asked the college to look at the investment policy. The college is looking at the policy, it is not saying no. Mr Davies has chosen to make a stance, but the university rules say that no student can take his degree if he or she is in debt to the college or university."

The action taken by Davies comes at the time of an apparent groundswell of student action across the country against educational institutions that retain investments in arms companies. A report recently released by the Campaign Against the Arms Trade showed educational institutions retaining some large share portfolios in seven leading arms companies.

In response to pressure from the group People and Planet (formerly Third World First), the Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS) - which is the third largest pension fund in the country, with assets of nearly £20bn and more than 153,000 members - has adopted an ethical investment policy. Amongst its share portfolio are holdings of 10.5m shares in British Aerospace, 10.6m shares in Rolls Royce and 3.4m shares in Racal.

The campaign began two-and-a-half years ago and included students, academics and USS staff. Jess Worth, a campaign coordinator at People and Planet, recalled that at first the fund was not keen to engage in dialogue, but last October that changed.

"We produced a proposal that set out in detail an ethical investment policy they could adopt. It was based on active investing, which means using the power of a major shareholding to exert pressure on a company to clean up its act," said Worth. Rather than sudden disinvestment, the policy involves the fund using its portfolio to engage the companies in discussions about the ethics of their activities.

"It is a major victory for us, and a major precedent in the pension-fund sector for such a huge fund to have taken such a significant step," said Worth.

For its part, USS seems to believe that a sound ethical and environmental stance is crucial to any 21st-century public company. "Today, no properly run public company, or fund manager, should be unaware of the importance of public opinion and ethical issues. They ignore the subject at their peril," said David Chynoweth, chief executive of USS. At the University of East Anglia the council responded to demonstrations and a 2,500 strong petition by setting up a working party which is expected to recommend that an ethical policy be adopted in stages.

Sarah Kyle, a founding member of Not in Our Names, said: "We never expected it to move so fast. In a year we've got a third of the university involved and created the biggest thing seen on campus, even before tuition fee marches." The People and Planet group at Leeds has held two "die-ins" and marched an "army" on campus to get the university to sell its 300,000 shares in British Aerospace and 30,000 in GKN.

The finance committee has briefly discussed the subject but declined to take action. While many at Cambridge University admire the stand taken by Davies, some think such a confrontational approach is not the best.

A year ago the 15,000 strong Cambridge Students Union began a campaign to get disinvestment from arms companies by initiating a dialogue with the colleges, which each control their own investments. Ter Klevnos, green officer at Cambridge Students Union, said colleges were afraid an ethical policy would not be economically viable.

"But I don't want my education paid for by others' suffering. It gets very emotional at times, such as when we saw what happened in East Timor. There were tanks produced by Alvis and GKN, armoured vehicles sold by GEC and the hawk jets all being used on civilians. It is unconscionable that I should be benefiting from this for my education."

At Oxford, Sasha Blackmore has also tried the softly softly approach with her college, Balliol, speaking at seminars on ethical investments and presenting a paper to the college's governing executive committee: "It is essential in Oxford to build the support of the college behind you, working through the channels of communication that do exist and showing the positive reasons for ethical investment, as well as the negative potential consequences of holdings in arms companies."

fields.headline: Candied camera
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock's college video gives a rose-tinted impression of the place
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock's college video gives a rose-tinted impression of the place
fields.body:
Our first college promotional video looks very dated and lacking in pace. In fact, it is lacking in most areas, including being able to sustain the interest of its target audience. The second attempt a few years later comes across like a Labour party election broadcast - glossy and clever, but difficult to believe. But now we have College Video 3, coming to a year 11 parents' meeting near you soon.

This is the product we are pinning our recruitment hopes on. This feature will see them flocking through the doors come September - unless, of course, our rivals come up with something better.

It's a cruel marketing world out there. Big budgets, high production values and casts of thousands are all part of a frenzy of video-making. There are hours of local access cable TV time to fill. Yet we didn't realise this until last term when Patty, our newly appointed head of corporate communications, arrived to drag us into the exciting world of Brand Integration Management.

Before Patty came into our lives with her MBA and industry experience, we were a working party united by the fact that we all disagreed with each other. If a camel is a horse designed by a committee, then the struggle to produce a video can only end up with a turkey - over-cooked, stuffed full of excess and difficult to digest. It was Patty who saved me from the kind of meetings that went like this:

"What we want is a shot of the debating society in full flow with a voiceover of the principal welcoming everyone to the college."

"And I suppose you want a silver band playing Jerusalem," someone from performing arts would quip.

"What about narrative time and space?" Clive from media studies was always saying.

Patty was a breath of fresh air. Like Listerine to halitosis she set about the college video project with an antiseptic precision that left many a working party member gasping. She could do things with Power Point software that left me in awe. She dissolved her treatment into her production brief and then animated part of a storyboard.

"And that," she said, "is how it will be." She stroked some keys on her laptop and invited questions. I glanced at Clive. Even he had succumbed to her seductive presentational discourse.

Once Patty was in control, she drove us on with studied efficiency, and soon we were tossing shooting scripts about. fields.headline: A brave new world
fields.standfirst: For  Francis Beckett, college opened a new world of freedom, sex and self-discovery
fields.trailText: For Francis Beckett, college opened a new world of freedom, sex and self-discovery
fields.body:
In 1962, I was, mercifully, asked to leave my Jesuit boarding school, where I had been incarcerated for what seemed like a lifetime, beaten regularly, and force-fed snobbery, religious bigotry and the sort of ravioli that puts you off pasta for life.

That's how I found myself in further education, at the City of Westminster College, which in those days was a barn of a building off Victoria Street in Westminster, just behind Army & Navy. So I was a pioneer - one of the first people to discover how much more civilised it was to study for A levels in a college than in a school, where the teachers, however well-meaning, could never forget what a grubby little tyke you were when you were 13.

English was taught by NF Simpson, who revived my love of literature, and whose marvellously lunatic plays One Way Pendulum and A Resounding Tinkle were just beginning to gain him the reputation that I imagine must soon afterwards have enabled him to give up the day job. (You know the sort of script - Mrs Paradock: There's someone at the door wanting you to form a government. Mr Paradock: What does he look like? Mrs Paradock: He says he's working through the street directory.)

History was taught by Dr Warren, a stout man with a wonderful accent that I couldn't place at the time. I now realise that his passion for history, which he communicated with genius, was the same that engages intelligent mid-European Jews who have seen persecution first hand.

FE colleges in those days were full of rebels. I teamed up with Nigel, who had been expelled from public school when his girlfriend became pregnant, and had fled to Gretna Green to marry her, and with Eric, who had left Holland Park Comprehensive in the wake of many sexual liaisons. They seemed the best companions for someone who had been locked up in an all-male community, and was hungry for experience.

Eric was a remarkable young man. He was a good friend and a witty and entertaining companion. He could draw and paint, and spoke several languages. He had a black beard, dark glasses, huge dark eyes and magnetic charm. Women were drawn to him. There was always the prospect that one might pick up the crumbs from his groaning table.

I had come out of a stifling public-school atmosphere to find London and the 60s. It was a new world, fairer, fresher, freer and infinitely more fun. I saw Beyond The Fringe and revelled in its irreverence. I went to parties and smoked illegal substances. I danced and smooched to the Beatles, and fell in love three times. Proud of having overcome the prejudices and inhibitions of school, I thought there was little else to conquer.

The City of Westminster College was where I formed the view that all school sixth forms should be closed and their pupils sent into further education, where they could be shown that learning was fun and where they could learn how to live.

A few months after I left, Nigel called me at my hall of residence. The previous Saturday Eric had organised a party - something he could do with rare brilliance - at which a gatecrasher had hit him over the head with a beer bottle and killed him.

fields.headline: The talent war
fields.standfirst: Bosses must train, train and train again to keep their best staff, says  Christopher Ball
fields.trailText: Bosses must train, train and train again to keep their best staff, says Christopher Ball
fields.body:
A new war is raging - a war for talent. Recent studies show this is becoming a priority among nine out of 10 chief executives. They define the attraction and retention of talented individuals as their major concern. It is a war, and there will be more losers than winners.

Businesses are trapped in a vicious circle: faced with constantly increasing competition, they adopt a short-term focus and undertake only disposable learning (aimed solely at teaching specific product or tool skills). This generally hits productivity and deadens innovation, thus worsening the situation.

Fear of poaching and a lack of understanding of the development needs of individuals exacerbate the problem. All this leads to a loss of potential talent and an over-reliance on recruitment as the means to compete, combined with increased job-specific training, simplification of jobs, so almost anyone can do them, and the automation of customer interaction whenever possible. Thus the downward spiral continues.

To solve their internal skills shortage, most companies develop more and more powerful recruitment and retention mechanisms to get "the right people" on board and identify the best performers. The problem with this short-term model is that it does nothing to prevent the exodus of the rest and merely raises the temperature of the battle. It assumes a world with an unlimited external supply of talent - talent that does not mind working in businesses where the development of "disposable" skills is the priority.

The Talent Foundation, which we launched yesterday to help business resolve these issues, suggests that most training and development is largely wasted. Business is not taking advantage of research into learning styles or to new findings from the world of brain science. Training is still based on traditional academic models that only suit a small proportion of people. There is too high a concentration on teaching specific tactical skills (such as how to browse the web).

The development of more permanent skills such as emotional intelligence and learning to learn very quickly benefits businesses and individuals through developing more confident, motivated, fulfilled (and therefore loyal) and valuable employees. The irony is that there is indeed an unlimited supply of talent, but it is not "out there": it is stored as potential in each individual. Talent is within.

Employees now see personal development as the key element of their work: more than 70% placed personal development above salary as most important to their jobs in a recent study. The Talent Foundation recognises that businesses have pressing tactical needs that must be addressed, but our research shows that investment in personal development has an immediate and direct effect on the uptake and application of skills developed. If businesses are to develop the highly skilled, flexible workforces they need to succeed, they must pay attention to developing talent at an individual level within their organisations.

Headed by Dr Javier Bajer, a specialist in organisational learning who was formerly with Andersen Consulting, the foundation is a global initiative sponsored by the private and voluntary sectors to provide learning solutions and pragmatic answers to questions of attraction, retention and organisational culture through innovative learning. Only in developing and nurturing the talent within, and creating an environment in which talent will flourish, can businesses successfully face this challenge.

The foundation will not only conduct its own research, but it will also act as a bridge between the world of work and the latest research and academic study on the science of learning. We will provide practical advice and solutions to implement effective solutions in the business environment and to act as a centre of excellence in this field. The foundation will also provide access to a network of networks connecting interested parties in a global community dedicated to improving the world of work.

 Sir Christopher Ball is chancellor of the University of Derby and a patron of the National Campaign for Learning.

fields.headline: Beastly pursuits
fields.standfirst: John Crace joins the hunt to track down the elusive Beast of Bodmin
fields.trailText: John Crace joins the hunt to track down the elusive Beast of Bodmin
fields.body:
You can always tell if it's been a slow news day in the south-west by the number of column inches devoted to the Beast of Bodmin. Over the years, there have been countless sightings of this legendary cat, but despite the odd, sometimes very odd, photograph and the occasional pawprint, there is no hard evidence of its existence.

All this could change this Friday at a debate in Plymouth, co-hosted by two college lecturers, to which people are invited to bring their beast paraphernalia for scrutiny.

Paul Crowther, lecturer in photography at Plymouth College, will be a hard man to convince. "I happen to know that one of the pictures that is used time and again in the press as conclusive proof of the beast was faked by one of my students in the college darkroom," he says.

"All he did was to cut out a black silhouette and glue it to an appropriately non-descript background that gave no clue to location or scale. He gave the animal a ridiculously long tail to avoid charges of criminal deception and, as a final flourish, nudged the enlarger to make the print fuzzy."

Crowther admits that cast-iron proof is difficult. The computer software Adobe Photoshop allows any image to be faked, so most film, particularly digital film, shot after 1995 is liable to be disqualified. He is also suspicious of single images. "If you saw a puma and you had a camera with you, you'd shoot the whole film," he says.

Crowther, though, is not a committed disbeliever. He photographed a large feline pawprint in a bunker at the Chinafleet Golf & Country Club after a reported sighting six years ago.

One man who should not take much convincing is John Downes, director of the Centre for Fortean Zoology. The reason for this is simple: he has seen one. "I was driving along a lane near Belventor on Bodmin Moor on 9 May 1997 when I saw a half-grown female puma 30 yards ahead of me," he says.

Downes sees no problem with the fact that no one has yet captured the beast. "Even in areas where pumas are known to exist, they are seldom seen," he says. "On one island off the west coast of America, where no pumas had been seen for 70 years, a human chain discovered 28."

No one is suggesting that pumas have been with us undiscovered for centuries. "The most likely explanation for their presence in this country was the closure and regulation of private zoos," says Chris Moiser, zoology lecturer at Plymouth. "There were 32 zoos that had pumas in the 70s and don't have them now."

It wasn't until 1981 that it became a criminal offence to release any animal into the wild, and Moiser believes that a number of pumas may have escaped or been let loose and slowly gravitated to the more remote areas of the country."

Moiser is more than open to the possibility of the Beast's existence, but then he ought to be - it was he who identified the bunker pawprint as belonging to a medium-sized cat.

fields.headline: More of the same
fields.standfirst: The birth of the first cloned piglets is another step towards farming human organs
fields.trailText: The birth of the first cloned piglets is another step towards farming human organs
fields.body:
It is National Science Week and across the country we are being encouraged to question scientific research and debate key scientific issues. It is timely. Cloning is back in the news, thanks to the scientists who brought us Dolly the Sheep. Now they have managed to clone the first litter of pigs.

They are claiming that this breakthrough could mean an end to the world shortage of healthy organs for organ transplants. They are confident that soon it will be possible to use the hearts, kidneys, livers and lungs from genetically altered pigs in human operations and waiting lists will vanish. But are we really about to enter a brave new world and should we trust the scientists?

How do they make a clone?

In an adult creature the cells have long decided what they want to be - a part of the skin or a bone or a nerve, whatever. And until recently that was it. A cell's identity was fixed like a CD capable of playing just one track. This is fortunate because when we cut ourselves we want new skin cells growing back and not anything else. But scientists recognised that every cell also contains other information - genetic instructions from which a whole creature can be formed. In order for the ordinary cell to do a single job, these instructions have to be blocked. What scientists have discovered is how to lift that blockage. They make the grown-up cell "totipotent" - in that condition it can be used to create clones.

What happens next?

You take the DNA from the totipotent cell. DNA is the basic genetic building block, the chemical plan that all living things contain. This is then injected into an egg cell from a female of the species you wish to clone. This receiving egg cell has already has its DNA removed. The new DNA is fused into the egg cell using a tiny electrical jolt. The egg cell is placed back in the female in order to grow in the usual way only the baby that results is a genetic copy of the original creature and has none of the "mother's" DNA.

Is a clone just a genetic copy?

Yes, because it will have different experiences and develop in a different environment from the original creature. In order to make a clone identical to its "parent", you would have to make the clone live an exact replica of the parent's life!

What has been cloned?

So far, mice, cattle and sheep, and there is talk that the first cloned cat is just around the corner. It is possible that cloning will in time help preserve endangered species and even recover some extinct animals - though not dinosaurs. What makes the scientists so excited about cloning pigs is that their organs are very like human organs in size and make-up, and may one day be used in transplant operations. At the moment there is a huge shortage in healthy human organs available for donation. About 50,000 people in Europe are waiting for livers, kidneys and hearts.

Why can't pigs be used now?

The membrane or surface of pig organs contains sugars that would cause a human being's system to reject it if it was introduced into the body, killing the organ and the patient. The hope is that it will be possible to create genetically modified pigs in which these sugar genes have been switched off. Suddenly there would be a limitless supply of organs for harvesting.

Who could object to this?

There are several big causes for concern. First, there are people who disagree with cloning on moral grounds. They feel it is dangerous for scientists to play God. People who hate the idea of using animals for experiments are also against the idea. They feel that it would be terrible to turn animals into living organ factories. There is also the fear that pig organs may contain a hidden virus - or "retrovirus" - like HIV. These could pass to humans, with terrible consequences. Any tests involving humans receiving pig organs would need to be under the most incredible control and this in itself raises certain moral issues.

The government is advised by the Xenotransplantion Regulatory Authority (UKXIRA) and, so far, permission has never been granted to conduct animal organ transplants into humans. There is also the objection that such knowledge should be owned by commercial companies. The process that produced the cloned pigs is the property of a company called PPL Therapeutics. They estimate that the market for organs could be worth $6 billion.

Cloning magazine is produced by the Roslin Institute.

ppl-therapeutics.com and newscientist.comalso have useful articles
