fields.headline: Homework blues
fields.trailText: Homework is a constant battle between me and my son...
fields.body:
Homework is a constant battle between me and my son, a year 10 student facing lots of GCSE coursework. I have offered to help, but how much help should I give him? He wants to go to college to study for his A levels in the future - I'm worried he won't even pass his GCSEs at this rate.

Alwyn Morgan is a trainer and education department consultant in "out of school hours" learning, and series editor for Letts Educational Limited.

The first thing to do is talk to the school. Find out if your concern about your child's attitude is shared by teaching staff. Home and school should work together on this. A visit to the school will also help you to discover how homework is being managed by teachers. Homework - and thus coursework - must be seen as relevant by students, and its integral role in learning understood. This achieved, students are often more motivated to complete it.

Schools that manage homework well will have done so by making sure parents/guardians know about programmes of study. If they are aware of the different GCSE modules, coursework requirements and syllabuses, they can be much more supportive.

Whilst most schools use homework diaries or planners to help students keep a record and inform guardians about the homework set, several schools are piloting new schemes that you may like to suggest as examples of good practice to your school.

Two schools, one in Bristol and one in Wales, have set up a homework hotline. Parents/guardians may ring up and raise any homework concerns they have, knowing someone will investigate and get back to them. There is also a recording of everything that has been set that day - all years, all subjects - so students can no longer get away with claiming not to have any homework!

A school in Bishops Stortford has given its students and parents/guardians access to the school intranet so they can keep in touch with all aspects of the school's life. Moreover, they can see exactly what homework tasks have been set and for when, and are advised how they can help their child search for additional sources of information. This has been pioneered with all year 8s, with box-tops provided to students without PCs.

A Northumberland school sets all its homework for the term in advance and for certain tasks or subjects in year 9, parents/ guardians are given mark schemes so they can actively take part in their child's learning by going through the work with them.

The projects enable the school to show that it values homework; and the parents/guardians are asked to work together with the school to create a positive climate in which homework is done. Traditionally, primary schools have forged close relationships with parents/guardians to help educate children, and therefore there is a great deal of openness and two-way communication, but in general, secondary schools still have some way to go in this area.

If a parent/guardian tries to enforce a homework regime in isolation from the school, conflict will often result. Being concerned and interested in your child's educational progress is, of course, understandable, but a successful strategy for helping a child to fulfil their potential can only be achieved in harmony with the expectations and advice of the school.

Alwyn Morgan's tips

Try to get to the bottom of why your child is not motivated to do homework. Keep the lines of communication open with the teachers. Speak to the school and find out if they share your concerns, and work together to plan how to support your child - remember that you cannot force your child to do their homework, but you can try to create a supportive climate to help them achieve their full potential.

Further advice and information

Next week's query

My four-year-old started at primary school last September and I recently attended my first parent/governors meeting. Quite frankly, the attitude and behaviour of the chairman of the governors towards parents shocked me. He was extremely rude to any parent who dared express an opinion, but also made derogatory comments about parents who hadn't come to the meeting. It was clear that he regards the school as his personal fiefdom as he has been chairman for nearly 10 years and shows no sign of wanting to step down. How can we get rid of him?

fields.headline: Probation work
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: Probation work
fields.body:
What do probation officers do, then? Why don't you ask yours? Aaaergh!

Sorry, your eye seems to have slipped on to my elbow. I'll repeat the question. No, please, don't bother. Probation officers work as part of the criminal justice system, dealing with offenders before, during and after their cases come to court. The Probation Service in England and Wales is now split into 54 local service areas funded by the home office and local government.

But what do they actually do apart from write reports? Probation officers cover a wide range of work from court work to supervising community service orders to dealing with offenders released into hostels.

What qualities are required? Ability to work and communicate with a wide variety of people is essential.

What are you incinerating? Insinuating? Me? Nothing.

OK. What else? Patience and objectivity are required at all times. The ability to develop trust and confidence with offenders is a necessary part of the job.

Sounds pretty straightforward to me. Hardly. My booklet says it's very demanding and... um...

What? You're not going to get cross?

Who, me? Well, it says that contact with sometimes violent or difficult people occurs on a regular basis, so the officer has to be able to manage stressful situations. Yeeuch!

Sorry. Elbow slipped again. Tell me, how does a geezer get into this? Since1997, when the Probation Service was reorganised, there's been a trainee scheme with specific qualifications geared towards the job. The qualification is the Diploma in Probation Studies, which combines NVQ Level 4 and degree-level components in community justice. The NVQ programme is a work-based placement while the academic side is undertaken at university. It takes two years to complete.

Can anybody become a probation officer? There is a minimum age limit of 22 and, as the course takes two years, the minimum age for applicants is 20.

What about if you have a bit of form, so to speak? Previous convictions or cautions do not necessarily bar entry, but this would be at the discretion of the local panel.

And exams? Under 21 the academic qualifications are generally two A levels and 3 GCSEs (A-C) or three A levels and one GCSE; between 21 and 25, 5 GCSEs; over 25, no formal qualifications are required, but applicants would have to demonstrate academic ability usually by producing a piece of written work to be assessed.

Is there any useful experience? Previous voluntary work such as prison visiting or hostel work carries lots of Brownie points. Community Service Volunteers and other voluntary organisations have information on a range of pre-course placements.

 For selection, recruitment and training in England and Wales, contact one of nine regional probation consortia.

 Useful voluntary work contacts

National Association of Voluntary Hostels: 0171-731 4205

National Council for Voluntary Organisations: 0171-713 6161

Home Office Probation Training Unit: 0171-273 3718

National Association of Probation Officers: 0171-223 4887

CCETSW Scotland: 0131-220 0093

 learndirect (0800 100900) may be able to give further information and advice on courses

fields.headline: Special needs
fields.trailText: In many schools, around a fifth of children will have special educational needs (SEN) at some point during their education.
fields.body:
In many schools, around a fifth of children will have special educational needs (SEN) at some point during their education. If you doubt that figure, take a look at the government's performance tables, which list the number of children with an SEN statement.

Thanks partly to greater awareness among parents, the number of children with statements has grown by over a third since 1992.

Chris Abbott, who lectures and researches in ICT and SEN at King's College London, advises parents to have a look at the website of the organisation specialising in their child's needs.

"The strength of the web is special-interest groups, such as those for dyslexia. I'd be wary of saying it's the place to go for everything, although in the future, when we've got more interactive possibilities, that may change." Links to a number of these sites are listed in the secial needs section of Education Unlimited's Netclass and at the National Association for Special Educational Needs.

Happily, as this article goes to press, the government is preparing to launch a new site on March 23 dedicated entirely to SEN. Inclusion will be aimed initially at those who support SEN pupils, but will expand late this year to include learners themselves.

A more specialised site, mostly relevant to SEN professionals, is already online - if you live in Scotland, the support pack should be helpful too. If you're working with visually-impaired learners, read the advice on good web design.

Creating web material for SEN learners is a challenge that both Abbott and David Ware of Little Heath, a special school in Essex, are working on. Ware admits the medium is not particularly accessible for children with SEN. "But we find sites that are appropriate for use in special projects."

In association with a San Diego school, Little Heath has pioneered the online worksheet in the form of Netlinks.

All pupils at Little Heath have an email address, helping projects like Spikelink. Spike is a teddy bear who has flown out to the San Diego partner school. As Little Heath envoy, Spike writes an online diary and responds to emails from pupils. Spikelink, Ware says, encourages confidence in pupils. "It's using the technology to find out about another part of the world." What the web excels at.

fields.headline: Literacy
fields.trailText: Literacy
fields.body:
Literacy Trust
****

Aimed at: parents and teachers

The Trust is a charity which promotes literacy for everyone, including adults, and is an excellent starting-point for teachers working on the literacy hour. The National Year of Reading activities which featured in this column two weeks ago have since been moved to the archive section. As a source of links and authoritative research on literacy, the NLT is unparalleled.

EnchantedLearning
**

Aimed at: teachers and parents

Little Heath special school recommends this "dictionary" site for children with learning difficulties; it would also be useful for KS1/2 pupils. The dictionary is like an interactive wallchart. Children click on a word to find out more: "acid rain", for example, produces pictures and suggested activities. Mac users may find the site very slow to download.

Hearing Your Child Read
****
Aimed at: parents

Ten pieces of advice which will seem obvious to teachers - and to parents, once they've read them - but which are nonetheless invaluable.

Cockroft's Resources
***
Aimed at: teachers

Sixty-three basic lesson plans, most suitable for the literacy hour. Nothing startlingly new, but the information is easy to download. Take the opportunity to visit Edleston Primary School's inspirational site while you're here. It has lots of impressive story pages and project work.

DfEE Standards
***

Aimed at: teachers and parents

Visit this to understand the department stance on literacy, and how it defines a "literate person". It sets out what is expected of teachers and provides activity resource sheets. These are "working ideas and suggestions", to be used "selectively as an additional support to teachers' planning." Not for Ofsted inspection week, then.

A little reading
*
Aimed at: parents

Both the literacy and numeracy strategies have emphasised that children can practise these skills everywhere. What this site tries to do is remind parents of these opportunities for reading. But the tone can be patronising, the ideas self-evident.

Becta Literacy Time
*****
Aimed at: teachers and parents

Much more colourful and engaging than the DfEE Standards Site, Becta offers plenty of literacy-hour activities. Examples are a retelling of Little Red Riding Hood for Year 2 and two texts on foxhunting for Year 6. It has practical guidelines on organising the hour, free software, and lots of reading suggestions. Highly recommended.

English Teaching Ideas
***

Aimed at: teachers

Some excellent ideas and worksheets, some of which practise "English" skills and those of the literacy hour. If this site gets bigger it will be even more useful to primary teachers.

fields.headline: Cooperation is the key
fields.standfirst: The case against city academies
fields.trailText: The case against city academies
fields.body:
Pragmatically, what matters is what works (or might work), but concerns about city academies cannot justly be dismissed as cynicism.

The government claims that its approach is "based on firm principles and on the evidence". The academy model is an amalgam of city technology colleges, promoter-led, grant-maintained schools and American charter schools. But none of these, on the basis of principle or evidence, can be claimed to have solved the problems of inner-city schools struggling with a complex cocktail of factors militating against success.

CTCs - legislative powers for which underpin city academies - previously failed to attract sponsors. They also exert an unquantified detrimental effect on neighbouring schools, creaming off motivated and well-supported pupils through selection by interview, albeit across a range of ability. Promoter-led, grant-maintained schools simply failed to happen. And charter schools are not only unproven, but include features (like admission by lot in the event of oversubscription) that seem too radical for acceptance here.

The overwhelming evidence of the CTC and grant-maintained experience was of divisiveness. A world of difference lies between a system where schools "tackle common problems" and one where they tackle them together. The root cause of much of the present situation is that certain schools are left to tackle a concentration of problems that others evade - an effect of the market created in education provision.

This solution is bound to generate resentment. It changes the rules under which such schools operate, and sidelines those responsible - yet they are being judged to have failed whilst required to labour under the old rules. That resentment will undermine the cooperative endeavour which, on the basis of principle and evidence, is necessary to underpin success in achieving the government's laudable objectives.

 Martin Rogers, coordinator, The Education Network

fields.headline: Counting fun
fields.trailText: Learning to count is just as important as learning to read, and with Alan Newland's selection of counting books it can be just as much fun
fields.body:
Every book ever written has something to do with maths. Counting, measuring, time, money, shapes, patterns - they're all in there somewhere! Maths Year 2000 wants everyone to know that learning to count is as important as learning to read. If you use them with thought and enthusiasm, counting books can be a rich source of fun.

Count on Goz
Steve Weatherill
Frances Lincoln, £4.99

This flap book features a baby gosling looking for his gander. Ask what's behind the flap before you lift it. "Oh look, Goz is upside down! And now he's right side up!" Talk about what's on the next or previous page, what's first, last, in front, behind, to right and left - all increase spatial awareness.

As Goz searches for the other goslings he comes upon other farm animals. Before you turn the next flap, ask: "Now, how many kittens do you think the cat will have?" Give your child plenty of time to ask questions and make their own discoveries.

Over on the Farm - A Counting Picture Book Rhyme
Christopher Gunson
Picture Corgi, £4.99

The enchanting pictures with a summer glow accompany a text so rhythmic you will not be able to stop your child clapping or singing. Sing the rhythm or tap it out with your child's fingers. Count the animals on each page or try counting in twos for ears or eyes. Is the ladybird the same one on each page? How can you tell?

I Can Count
Ray Gibson, iIlustrated by Amanda Barlow
Usborne Playtime, £3.99

This book shows you and your child how to make counting artistic. It explains how to make potato prints of "1 whale, 2 penguins, 3 birds, 4 frogs". Each page has accompanying figures of identical number just to add to the amusement, such as four spots on each of the frogs or five petals on each of the five flowers. And for those of you with hyperactive children, there are pages of animals in tens, twenties or fifties that will keep them painting all summer!

Number Parade - A Wildlife Counting Book
Jakki Wood
Frances Lincoln, £4.99

Charming drawings and alliteration make this a counting book to enjoy. Set your child some teasers: "If half the ostriches ran away, how many would be left?" or "Double the number of monkeys who come swinging by - how many are there now?" Large numbers fascinate children even if they can't count them.

Fruits - A Caribbean Counting Poem
Valerie Bloom, illustrated by David Axtell
Macmillan Children's Books, £4.99

The sweetness of these fruits exudes from every page. This is a funny book too, the story of a girl whose eyes are bigger than her belly. Ask how many fruits big sis has eaten (and don't forget the half pawpaw!). How much was left for her poor little sister? And try playing with this one: "Let's make a fruit salad and take the oranges, bananas, paw-paw and red apples. How many fruits have we got?" Don't be afraid that this poem is written in dialect (if you don't speak it); enjoy the evocation of Caribbean village life and the education of naming and recognising tropical fruit.

Six Dinner Sid
Inga Moore
Macdonald Young Books, £4.99

Sid is cat who lives in six houses and gets six dinners from six owners. He thinks he is the smart one, until he is found out! Discuss Sid's first house, his second dinner, his third owner, his fourth bed and so on. Talk about first and last, once, twice, sixes, twelves, twenty-fours. And ask how many dinners Sid has had in a week!

Six Dinner Sid Inga Moore Macdonald Young Books, £4.99 Sid is cat who lives in six houses and gets six dinners from six owners. He thinks he is the smart one, until he is found out! Discuss Sid's first house, his second dinner, his third owner, his fourth bed and so on. Talk about first and last, once, twice, sixes, twelves, twenty-fours. And ask how many dinners Sid has had in a week!

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Men, tut, etc. According to research commissioned by the organisers of the Orange Prize into the impact of gender on reading habits, men still shy away from books they perceive as too feminine.
fields.body:
Men, tut, etc. According to research commissioned by the organisers of the Orange Prize into the impact of gender on reading habits, men still shy away from books they perceive as too feminine. A prettily pastel cover or an emotional reference in the title is likely to send male readers straight to the True Tales Of Motor Maintenance section, whereas we ladies get quite wet at the sight of yet another floral-hued dust jacket, with an alluringly alliterative title such as The Kitten-Heeled Hen Night Of Jemima Jenkins And Her Cashmere Twinset. It also goes to show that there is more to this genetic determinism business than meets the eye. A five-year scientific investigation, undertaken in Sidelines' garage, found that men indeed had ickle Apache helicopters and Black and Decker cordless drills sewn into their chromosomes (doubtless by their mums). Which explains why Doris Lessing just doesn't cut it.

 Perhaps it's just another moody Tuesday but, no, it's the same gripe every day. Sidelines is over those two Ready2shop.com lassies. Apologies to readers who have yet to suffer the nauseating visual assault that is Trinny Woodall and Susannah Constantine in the buff, displaying a variety of bags and bootees ... but you're bound to clock the ads soon and you'll be glad you've been forewarned. Get dressed (ideally in the privacy of your own homes).

 So female footie is finally going professional. The FA has pledged to set up a full-time pro league of women's teams within three years. "At last!" I hear, er, some of you cry. Presumably now the world of football (like the world of work, natch) will become entirely feminised and men who practise drop-kicks on their partners' heads will no longer be hailed as heroes. Or is that a wee bit too professional?

 Becks' crewcut, eh? He Who Matches Posh is to needless talking points as Kate Winslet is to lovely, natural, lovely naturalness. What would a crewcut look like on Brooklyn/the Queen/Frank Dobson/ a badger? Can I go home now?

webTitle: It's a tough life on civvy street

fields.headline: It's a tough life on civvy street
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston finds out why the army is so keen to get the troops online
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston finds out why the army is so keen to get the troops online
fields.body:
"Are you tough? If so get out. I need buggers with intelligence." In his book A Traveller's Tale, the writer Eric Newby recalls seeing this warning in wartime Alexandria, printed on the desk of the man who founded the Special Boat Section.

It ran counter to an old assumption that persists in civvy street today, that the brain is not the soldier's most important tool.

This popular notion that servicemen and women are simply trained to follow instructions mindlessly, even though modern warfare is a high-tech business, is one that the army is intent on shifting.

As civilian society becomes infested with jargon about transferable and key skills and lifelong learning, the army feels it has to persuade the world beyond the barrack gates that soldiers are eminently employable. And it needs to convince the troops themselves that they are picking up the right sorts of skills in their service careers to enhance their chances of getting work in civilian life.

The Army's Educational and Training Services (ETS), the former Royal Army Educational Corps, believes the answer lies in changing the ethos of service life. It wants to persuade all ranks of the benefits of learning, of using some of the time spent hanging around waiting for action in bettering themselves.

"An awful lot of life in the army is 'hurry up and wait'," says Brigadier Patricia Purves, the army's director of education and training, and its highest-ranking woman. "Hours and hours and hours are spent on stand-by duty, waiting to go out on patrol, for instance.

"If there's an internet connection in the room, or if access to decent laptop computers with distance learning packages on them, some soldiers will make use of them."

Brigadier Purves is not proposing an end to the soldier's traditional attachment to beer. But she is convinced that if the right opportunities are provided, soldiers will not just spend their free time in idle consumption or "lying on their bunks fully kitted out watching some TV programme while waiting to go out on the streets on patrol".

Her hunch is supported by the enthusiastic use the Grenadier Guards made of five internet terminals during a recent tour of duty in Dungannon. They racked up a £500 phone bill for the quarter - and, no, not on mucky sites. The army also has opened a cybercafé at its base in Larkhill, in Wiltshire.

Computers and high-quality learning packages hold the key to change, says Lieut Col Tim Moore, one of her staff officers.

"We're very interested in what the University for Industry [learndirect] is going to do," he says.

In fact, this autumn the 35 army education centres in Britain and around the world will become learndirect "spokes" around a "hub" at Darlington College.

Also by the end of the year, the ETS aims to set up a network of trained "personal development" officers to advise all staff on career progression, including suggested study course.

It is the intention that much more core military training will be delivered by computer. The same machines would be used to deliver everything from basic skills to higher education - anything soldiers want to learn. There will be no prescription, although Lt Col Moore stresses that anything the army puts its name to must be "gold-plated".

"Our vision is that wherever a soldier is in the world, he will be able to get access to a system that will link him into whatever type of learning he's interested in."

Some soldiers have always studied. Long before the present government came up with Individual Learning Accounts, the army provided cash support to personnel who wanted to take courses. One unofficial estimate suggests that 10% of troops are pursuing studies of one sort or another, from art appreciation to zoology. The Open University enjoys a fair take-up.

Army life, however, makes conventional study difficult. Last year, when Kosovo was blowing hard, 47% of the army was at some stage of preparation for active service.

It can be near-impossible to complete a college course and take an exam if you are suddenly posted overseas at short notice, says Brigadier Purves. Online learning gets round this obstacle.

"We want individual soldiers to improve their employability," says Lt Col Tim Moore. "It's not just altruism. It makes good corporate and individual sense."

Purves and Moore also play down the altruistic intent. The purpose of it, they say, is to produce a force best able to defend the nation. But behind these assertions you sense lurking the educator spirit, that people should learn for the sake of learning.

Officers and other ranks are quitting the army at an alarming rate. From last April to January, 11,204 - 4,270 of them in the infantry - left the army, whose full strength on January 1 was 109,831.

Part of the "outflow", as official military statistics call it, is down to a concern among soldiers who might be otherwise enjoying military life that the longer they stay in, the weaker their prospects become of finding cilvilian employment.

A recently published Ministry of Defence document setting out the armed forces' staffing strategy makes clear that they are not just committed to providing their people with a stimulating few years under the colours, but aim to lay the "foundation of a second career on leaving the services".

As in civvy street, part of the knack is repackaging. What is it that can be extracted from core military training that can be matched to the sorts of skills that employers are always droning on about.

"How in heaven's name do you explain to a civilian employer what an infantryman is?" asks Brigadier Purves. "Trained killer? Not a lot of call for that." Much better to highlight the problem-solving, decision-making and teamwork of soldiering.

Brigadier Purves curtly dismisses as myth the notion that soldiers don't need to use their noddles. "I want a soldier with a rifle on a checkpoint to be a thinking individual, not an automaton.

"He's got to know what his standing orders are, but he's also got to be able to make decisions - life and death decisions.

"We ask these young men and women in Kosovo to take decisions every day that could have serious political consequences."

fields.headline: Testing, testing, one, two, three
fields.standfirst: Week 16
fields.trailText: Week 16: The AFP, Double or Triple test measures the amount of alphafetoprotein in your blood. Done at around 16 weeks of pregnancy, this can give you a likelihood of Down's syndrome or spina bifida in the baby.
fields.body:
I started worrying about hitting 35 as soon as I got over the trauma of 30. If 30 was a deadline for achieving a great career, a grown-up house and, especially, a stable relationship with an owner of all of the above, then 35 was definitely the babyline, the point at which, I vaguely understood, all your eggs went off overnight and conception became miraculous. I spent my 30th birthday semi-employed in London Zoo with my parents. In The Twilight World of the Small Mammal, actually, as it was raining. So I was rather smug when I managed to conceive a baby with a due-date just nine days before my 35th birthday. And it's been a bit denting, frankly, to discover that 35 isn't a deadline at all.

I've found out, for instance, that between 30 and 35, your chances of having a Down's syndrome baby go up from 2 in 1,000 to just 3.1 in 1,000. And that women under 35 actually give birth to more Down's syndrome children because they don't take so many tests. And, outrageously, that older sperm contribute to Down's syndrome, too. Now, why is this medical risk not touted and tutted over every time an elderly film star starts a third family with a nymphette?

Even the medical profession doesn't seem pleased that I'm under 35. In fact, all it seems to mean is that I had to pay for my own AFP test and personally post off a little phial of my still-warm blood to the testing centre.

Oh yes, AFP. After a few weeks immersed in pregnancy books, it is hard to remember that the world does not know what these initials mean. The AFP, Double or Triple test measures the amount of alphafetoprotein in your blood. Done at around 16 weeks of pregnancy, this can give you a likelihood of Down's syndrome or spina bifida in the baby.

The result is expressed as a percentage and you have to take a calculated risk from that of whether you want to proceed with your pregnancy, or have a further, more precise test - amniocentesis. This takes another three weeks and has a 1% chance of miscarriage.

The percentages and numbers are both fascinating and horrible. They remind me of the Moral Dilemma cards I used with teenagers when I had to teach citizenship class. Under what circumstances should Amanda have an abortion? When: a) She doesn't want a baby to spoil her figure? b) The baby is slightly handicapped? c) The baby has Down's syndrome?

Teenagers are terrible prigs. They generally thought Amanda should be allowed an abortion only if she had been multiply raped by close relatives and was carrying a baby with horns.

I was always defending Amanda's right to choose. I have always maintained that I would not carry a handicapped child. And, like any woman who has used contraception, I've already offed dozens of potential babies. But this moral dilemma is for real. The abortion would be real, too. By the time they've done an amnio, very real: induced labour, a recognisable foetus, and you might have felt it kick.

During the week's wait, I found myself thinking all sorts of things and doing all sorts of surreal, nightmarish sums. I thought of the torture women who do have amniocentesis go through, or women who know they carry a rogue gene. I wondered if modern science were helping me here, or if I could go through just as much doubt for superstitious or religious reasons.

I started wishing that I had done as the books suggest and told no one I was pregnant until I was sure the baby was staying. And I thought, over and over again, well, if I do have an abortion, I can always just say it was a miscarriage and no one will ask any more questions.

I found, in short, that even when slightly, imaginatively, briefly challenged, I was unwilling to stand up for what I believed in. I couldn't imagine actually admitting that my marriage, my work, my time, my happiness, were more important to me than the potential life of a handicapped child. It seemed suddenly selfish, unmotherly, unwomanly. I wanted to be like Amanda, a guiltless victim. I was a hypocritical teenager at heart, too.

Another hazard of being 34 and posting your own AFP test is the Royal Mail. I rang the testing centre for my result in the end, posing as a receptionist. I got the result most women get: that the odds against any handicap were very, very long. But you knew that anyway, didn't you? Or I wouldn't have written this article in the first place. I'm not that brave.

fields.headline: Lord chancellor's 'flawed' dual role
fields.trailText: A government-funded report yesterday backed calls for the post of lord chancellor to be scrapped because of a conflict between his roles as politician and head of the judiciary.
fields.body:
A government-funded report yesterday backed calls for the post of lord chancellor to be scrapped because of a conflict between his roles as politician and head of the judiciary.

The report by Diana Woodhouse of Oxford Brookes University, which was funded by the economic and social research council, said the "high political profile" of the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, had magnified the tensions inherent in the post.

The study adds to a growing body of opinion which argues that the lord chancellor, as a powerful politician with a leading role at the heart of government, should no longer sit as a judge in the House of Lords.

But Lord Irvine is determined to go on hearing cases as long as government interests are not involved.

Last May a working party of the law reform group Justice - made up of seven legal peers and a professor of law - said his dual role was "inherently flawed" and created an appearance of bias. It said reform was "not a luxury but an urgent practical necessity".

The lord chancellor, apart from sitting as a judge and heading the judiciary, presides over the second chamber of parliament and fulfils responsibilities as a cabinet minister, including appointing judges.

Professor Woodhouse criticises as "dubious" any justification for keeping the minister of justice - in effect the lord chancellor's main role - isolated from the "rough and tumble" of the House of Commons.

She recommends that the post of lord chancellor should be abolished, and his responsibility for the legal system be transferred to a minister of justice or minister for legal affairs. The lord chief justice would become head of the judiciary, and a judicial commission would be set up to appoint judges.

The report notes that Lord Irvine enjoys "considerable influence at the centre of government".

He has had a central role, for example, in pushing through controversial legal aid reforms. Yet in theory he also has to protect judges from political influence.

Noting the lord chancellor's "closeness to the prime minister", Professor Woodhouse writes: "Lord Irvine's position at the centre of government raises questions about his role as head of the judiciary and as judge."

Lawyers believe that Lord Irvine's position will become increasingly difficult once the Human Rights Act comes into force in October, bringing the European convention on human rights into English law.

The English courts will have to take into account the case law of the European court of human rights, which recently decided that a man whose case was heard by the bailiff of Guernsey who, like the lord chancellor, sits as as judge and presides over the legislature, was denied a fair hearing.

fields.headline: Teacher barred over TV outburst
fields.trailText: A teacher has been suspended after admitting on TV that he did not want his son to be taught at his school because he would be in a white minority.
fields.body:
A teacher has been suspended after admitting on TV that he did not want his son to be taught at his school because he would be in a white minority.

Richard Smith, who has taught languages at Denbigh high school in Luton, Bedfordshire, for 21 years, sparked a race row after claiming that his son, Daniel, would not benefit from being in a school where 92% of the youngsters were Asian.

Mr Smith, 48, was filmed on ITV's School Days documentary about Icknield high school in the town when he appealed against the school's decision to refuse his 11-year-old son a place.

Mr Smith told the programme that as Denbigh school had a 92% Asian intake he did not think Daniel's social development would benefit. "Having to lay out the reasons why I wouldn't want my son to go there, and at the same time working there, is obviously a little bit tricky because I am not trying to bite the hand that feeds us, but there's far too much of a bias towards the Asian community within that school," he said.

A Luton council spokesman said Mr Smith had been suspended pending the outcome of an investigation. A date for hearing his case at the school has yet to be fixed.

But yesterday Anita Smith defended her husband. "My husband is no racist," she insisted. "He has taught at the school for 21 years - how could he be? His comments have been edited to present an unfair picture. It is simply that we don't live in that community and are not part of it. It is wrong for the government to tell us there is choice. We don't have any. Since my husband has been suspended he has received letters and cards of support from children at the school wanting him back."

Daniel and his parents live in the catchment area for Luton's Stopsley high school. But after applying and being turned down by Icknield school they were told Stopsley high school was over-subscribed and that Daniel would have to attend Denbigh instead. He now attends a school in Hertfordshire.

The commission for racial equality declined to comment on the case pending the result of the inquiry. But it said that it had this month sent a copy of racial equality standards to every head teacher in the country, setting out guidelines and advice on race policies.

We don't have any. Since my husband has been suspended he has received letters and cards of support from children at the school wanting him back." Daniel and his parents live in the catchment area for Luton's Stopsley high school. But it said that it had this month sent a copy of racial equality standards to every head teacher in the country, setting out guidelines and advice on race policies.

fields.headline: School attacks Ofsted 'vandals'
fields.standfirst: Blunkett's inspectors accused of bias in Summerhill court fight
fields.trailText: The closure of an internationally renowned independent school on the basis of an "incompetent... biased and illogical" inspection report would be an act of vandalism, the high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The closure of an internationally renowned independent school on the basis of an "incompetent... biased and illogical" inspection report would be an act of vandalism, the high court heard yesterday.

Zoe Readhead, the proprietor and headteacher of Summerhill, a progressive boarding school where attendance at lessons is optional, is appealing against a notice of complaint issued by David Blunkett, the education secretary, after an Ofsted inspection team found that the school was failing to maintain proper standards.

The inspectors complained that accommodation at the school in Leiston, Suffolk, was inadequate and that efficient and suitable instruction was not being provided.

Summerhill was founded in 1922 by AS Neill, Ms Readhead's father, to allow children to "develop free from fear". Pupils decide which lessons to attend, school rules are democratically decided at meetings with staff and no dossiers on pupils' progress are kept.

Geoffrey Robertson QC, acting for Ms Readhead, told the independent schools tribunal, sitting at the high court, that far from being an ailing establishment Summerhill was "a great school" and the victim of an Ofsted campaign to close it.

"Our evidence in this appeal is that Neill's legacy is a living one; that the system he devised to nurture humanity in children so that they fulfil their real potential in adult life works as well as it ever did, and is for some children the best education they could possibly have," he said.

"It is necessary that it should flourish as an alternative to state and independent systems which have not found a way of combating racism and bullying and sexual abuse, which are straitjacketed by a narrow curriculum and undermined by large classes.

"In any intelligent education system Summerhill would be viewed as a precious resource. Sadly, Ofsted's inspectors have demonstrated ignorance, a lack of professionalism, and even... a degree of persecution in the demands they have made on Summerhill."

All 59 pupils, aged between six and 16, as well as the dozen staff who run the school, were in court to hear the opening statements.

Mr Robertson told the tribunal that the school had been inspected nine times in 10 years, and that despite receiving "a clean bill of health" in 1998 had been visited by seven inspectors the following year, leading to the critical report which prompted Mr Blunkett's notice of complaint.

The inspectors, he said, were preoccupied with the lack of attendance in class, and did not look at the learning that went on in the evenings and at weekends, where children voluntarily took up music, sport and reading.

Only once in a decade did an inspector attempt to find out what children did instead of attend class, and no mention was made of the fact that teacher-pupil ratios seldom exceeded one to five, Mr Robertson told the tribunal.

Alison Foster, counsel for Mr Blunkett, said the secretary of state did not wish to see the school close.

"He is not intent on enforcing compulsory lessons on Summerhill pupils nor on compelling the abandonment of the general philosophy of education propounded by AS Neill," she said.

Mr Blunkett had said that Summerhill should change consistent with its ethos, and had emphasised the need for the school to make lessons attractive to encourage attendance without compelling it, Miss Foster said.

Mr Robertson, however, said that such a stance was "intellectually dishonest" and that to compromise the freedom unique to Summerhill was tantamount to closing the school.

"It's freedom or nothing. If it's not freedom, it isn't Summerhill. If you insist that it is negotiable, that will be the end of Summerhill."

He added that of 110 former pupils questioned, only two said they were dissatisfied with the education they received, and that the vast majority of former pupils went on to successful careers.

"The only significant occupations which are not represented, and this may be to the school's credit, are politicians and school inspectors," he said.

In a significant climbdown, Mr Blunkett withdrew from his complaint a demand that the school's toilets be labelled for the use of staff, boys or girls. They will remain unisex.

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Four in court on bomb charge
Four men charged with possessing nearly 500lb of home-made explosives were remanded in custody yesterday when they appeared at Lisburn magistrates court, in Co Down.
fields.body:
Four in court on bomb charge
Four men charged with possessing nearly 500lb of home-made explosives were remanded in custody yesterday when they appeared at Lisburn magistrates court, in Co Down.

Three of the men were arrested on a road outside Hillsborough, Co Down, last Wednesday. The fourth man was arrested later.

Boy killed by father's car
An 18-month-old boy died in hospital after a car driven by his father reversed over him at a farm near Maidenhead, Berkshire, police revealed yesterday.

The incident is believed to have happened after the boy strayed in front of a garage. Police are treating it as a "tragic accident".

Flying monk's dummy run
The flight of an 11th century Benedictine monk, who broke both legs after launching himself off Malmesbury abbey, in Wiltshire, wearing a pair of makeshift wings, is to be re-enacted with a dummy.

The monk, named Eilmer, covered 660 feet before crashing. The re-enactment will form part of the town's carnival in September.

Fever victim 'getting worse'
Doctors treating a British aid worker suffering from highly infectious Lassa fever said his condition had deteriorated yesterday.

Ian Janeck is fighting for his life at the infectious diseases unit at Coppetts Wood hospital in north London. He caught the virus while working in Sierra Leone.

Three men hunted on rape
Police investigating the rape of a woman aged 20 in St Leonards, East Sussex, on Friday night are hunting three men.

The woman was seen being dragged along a street by one of her attackers, all of whom are described as being of eastern European appearance.

Woman's guard dog stolen
A woman who spent £200 on a rottweiler after her Middlesbrough home was burgled three times has had the dog stolen.

Angela Haggas, 25, who has three children, bought Satan after the third raid in 12 months.

fields.headline: National round-up
fields.trailText:
Liver bird book now worth £5m
One of the oldest and most-prized books in a Liverpool library, bought in 1861 for £165, is now thought to be worth £5m.
fields.body:
Liver bird book now worth £5m
One of the oldest and most-prized books in a Liverpool library, bought in 1861 for £165, is now thought to be worth £5m.

John James Audubon's four-volume Birds of America is at the city's central library. A similar collection of Audubon's work was auctioned by Christies in New York last week for $8m (£5m).

"I think it is fair to say it was a good investment," said Tim Parrott, reference service manager at the library.

"The book is one of our oldest volumes and it is kept in the rare books section of the library. We were aware of how much we could get for it and the auction at Christies confirmed what we thought. We have no plans to sell it. We are here to safeguard the heritage of the people of Liverpool."

Around 200 copies of the book were completed, but only 100 have survived.
 Helen Carter

NHS curbs managers' pay rises
Almost 100,000 low paid health workers will get a bigger percentage pay rise than hospital managers under an edict issued by Sir Alan Langlands, NHS chief executive.

Hospital and community trusts are being instructed their pay bill for chief executives and senior managers must rise no more than 3.25% in the next financial year.

The lowest paid NHS staff will get a rise of up to 3.7% as part of a three-year deal for 350,000 workers not covered by pay review body awards.

Sir Alan's order came in a letter to trusts and health authorities, which are technically free to set their own terms for managers.

Chief executives of the bigger hospital trusts can now expect to be paid comfortably in excess of £100,000 a year, while the average is £74,000.

The letter said there were no specific problems recruiting or retaining managers. "It is therefore important that equity is maintained across the service."

Trusts and authorities will be required to show they have not exceeded the 3.25% cash limit, Sir Alan said, although they will have room to vary individual rises.

The three-year deal for other workers, including ambulance crews, scientists and clerical workers, is the first of its kind. In 2000-01, the rise will be 3.25% or £300, whichever the greater, and some 90,000 staff, mainly ancillary workers, are expected to benefit from the flat rate.

The increase for 1999-2000 will be 3% or £250, whichever the greater, and for 2001-02 a minimum of inflation plus 0.5%.
 David Brindle

Sex case head freed on appeal
A former preparatory school head had his convictions for sexually abusing former pupils quashed as unsafe at the court of appeal yesterday.

Lawyers for Robert "Rory" O'Brien, who served two months of a three-year jail sentence, are to seek compensation and to have his name removed from the sex offenders' register.

Mr O'Brien, 57, who is married with five children, was head of St Mary's hall which sends boys to the Roman Catholic public school Stonyhurst college, in Lancashire.

He was arrested in October 1998 by detectives investigating claims of child abuse spanning 30 years at the two schools. He was jailed at Preston crown court on five counts of indecently assaulting pupils, aged 10 and 11, in 1972 and 1998, but yesterday Lord Justice Rose, Mr Justice Klevan and Mr Justice Jackson ruled that the judge had been wrong in ordering that the events in the 70s and 90s should be tried together.

They also refused the crown's application for a retrial on the 70s charges, saying it would be "oppressive" considering the length of time Mr O'Brien had "had these matters hanging over him".

Mr O'Brien was head of St Mary's from 1990 until he was suspended in 1998 and took early retirement.

The police investigation began after a former pupil accused Mr O'Brien of sexually assaulting him in the 70s. Mr O'Brien was acquitted but convicted of the other counts which followed police interviews with hundreds of former and present pupils.

The allegations from the boys who went to St Mary's together in the 1970s "emanated from a desire for revenge", according to the defence.

Madonna with child once more
The pop star and actress Madonna revealed yesterday that she is pregnant with her second child.

A statement issued on behalf of the 41-year-old singer and Guy Ritchie, 31, who she has been dating for a year, said that they were "happy to confirm rumours" that they were expecting a child at the end of the year.

Mr Ritchie, who directed the hit gangland film Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, said: "We would be grateful if the media would kindly allow us some privacy at this special time and we thank you all for your good wishes."

The baby will be a sibling to three year old Lourdes, Madonna's daughter by her fitness instructor Carlo Leon.

webTitle: Scientists unlock the secret of exam nerves

fields.headline: Scientists unlock the secret of exam nerves
fields.trailText: Psychiatrists think they have found out why some people's minds go blank the moment they see an exam paper. Blame it on the stress hormone cortisol, which jams the memory.
fields.body:
Psychiatrists think they have found out why some people's minds go blank the moment they see an exam paper. Blame it on the stress hormone cortisol, which jams the memory.

Researchers at Zurich University took 36 people and asked them to memorise 60 German nouns, the journal Nature Neuroscience reports. They asked them to recall the words immediately and then 24 hours later.

That set the "normal" performance level. Then the researchers piled on the stress by giving some of the volunteers cortisone, which turns to cortisol. None of the subjects felt stressed - cortisol is a product of stress and not its cause - but the result was the same as if they had experienced exam nerves. The cortisone tablets affected the recall of words 24 hours after they were shown.

webTitle: Couple jailed for neglect of five children

fields.headline: Couple jailed for neglect of five children
fields.standfirst: Judge attacks 'despicable' parents cleared last year of triple murder
fields.trailText: A couple who were acquitted last year of murdering three infants were jailed yesterday for wilfully neglecting five of their children, in what has been called the worst child abuse case Sussex has seen.
fields.body:
A couple who were acquitted last year of murdering three infants were jailed yesterday for wilfully neglecting five of their children, in what has been called the worst child abuse case Sussex has seen.

The mother, 26, and father, 38, who cannot be named for legal reasons, from Brighton, East Sussex, were described by Judge Anthony Scott-Gall at Lewes crown court as despicable.

The woman was convicted on March 7 of five charges of wilfully neglecting children, and was jailed yesterday for two and a half years. The man was jailed for two years for the five wilful neglect charges, which he had admitted at an earlier hearing, three and a half years after being convicted of six rapes involving his sisters when he was a teenager, and six months for threatening to kill a social worker. The sentences are to run consecutively, making a total of six years.

The neglect charges concerned the couple's 17-month-old son, who died, and four of their other children, who were aged six, three, two and one when taken into care. Their last child was taken into care at birth in April 1998 following the parents' arrest.

The court had heard the children's beds were left soiled with excrement, their hair was infested with lice, food had been walked into the carpet, and the bedrooms of the house were full of flies. But the jury was not told that three children in the couple's care had died.

Judge Scott-Gall said the couple "did not deserve children and should never have them again".

Detective Inspector Malcolm Bacon, who led the three-year inquiry, said after the sentencing: "It was a very traumatic investigation.

"When I went to the house it was awful. It was the house from hell.

"There was food in the carpet and urine on the floor. It was a house in the 1990s but it could have been the 1890s.

"Every opportunity was there for them but it was ignored. It was the worst case of neglect I have seen."

The couple were cleared last summer at Lewes crown court of smothering their sons, aged 17 months and six weeks, and their five-week-old nephew. The boys died in the couple's care between 1994 and 1997, and it was initially thought that two of them were cot death victims.

Mr Justice Moses ordered the jury to return not guilty verdicts after ruling that, even if the boys had been murdered, there was not enough evidence to prove which defendant, if either, was guilty.

He added there was not enough evidence to support a case for joint enterprise, as it could not be shown that both defendants were present when the children died.

As the couple had been jointly charged, it was better to acquit both than wrongly convict either one, he directed.

That case prompted Sussex police authority to write to the Home Office calling for an offence to be introduced making both parties in such cases responsible, even if only one committed the crime.

Alan Bowman, chairman of the area child protection committee, which brings together the police, social services and health authorities in Sussex, said yesterday: "A great deal was done for this family but there are lessons to be learned.

"An inquiry has taken place, recommendations made, shortcomings have been identified and [the recommendations] put in place. All the actions have been carried out by all the agencies. It would be difficult to see what more could have come from the inquiry.

"I am pleased the judge has seen fit to give such serious sentences. It will assist us in sending the message out that neglect is something we will not tolerate.

"Three children in the care of these parents died and I remain concerned that their deaths are unexplained.

"The neglect in this case is not unfamiliar to health workers across the country.

"What is different is that when situations like this are identified the intervention of the police usually secures children's welfare - in this case support was wilfully disregarded and the abuse did not stop."

webTitle: Lone oarsman left all at sea as satellite link goes bust

fields.headline: Lone oarsman left all at sea as satellite link goes bust
fields.trailText: A lone oarsman crossing the south Pacific fears he could be made a virtual castaway after a satellite communications network went bankrupt last weekend.
fields.body:
A lone oarsman crossing the south Pacific fears he could be made a virtual castaway after a satellite communications network went bankrupt last weekend.

Father of five Jo Le Guen, 52, embarked on the 4,500 mile (8,350km) journey from New Zealand on February 3, in an attempt to raise awareness of ocean pollution. He is relying on a satellite telephone for communications, including information on the weather, from his nine-metre boat.

But Iridium, the Washington-based satellite network on which Mr Le Guen's equipment relies, announced on Friday that it was cutting off its 55,000 customers after it failed to put together a rescue package to help it overcome debts totalling $4.4bn (£2.75bn).

Last night Mr Le Guen was still more than 2,800 miles from Cape Horn, where he hopes to make landfall in May. Phillipe Tuffigo, a member of Mr Le Guen's Paris-based support team, said he feared the network would cut off its most vulnerable customer

"Jo could still use his phone this morning," said Mr Tuffigo, "but May is far too long a time away. We have heard that communications are still available for people in delicate situations, and conservationists. But it is costing so much to keep the constellation of satellites up, and nobody seems willing to pay."

webTitle: Paracetomol linked to high incidence of asthma

fields.headline: Paracetomol linked to high incidence of asthma
fields.trailText: The overuse of paracetamol tablets could be a factor in the alarming increase in the numbers suffering from asthma in the UK, according to a study published today.
fields.body:
The overuse of paracetamol tablets could be a factor in the alarming increase in the numbers suffering from asthma in the UK, according to a study published today.

The authors of the study in the medical journal Thorax suggest that people who take paracetamol tablets on a daily or weekly basis are more likely to be prone to asthma than those who do not. While they stress that their findings "should be interpreted with caution", they argue that there is a case for asthmatics cutting down.

The study, by Seif Shaheen from the department of public health sciences at Guy's, King's and St Thomas' school of medicine in London, looked at the use of aspirin and paracetamol in 664 asthmatics and 910 people without the disease over a year. The subjects were from 40 general practices in south London and their risk factors for asthma, such as smoking habits, were taken into account.

Those who took paracetamol weekly were almost 80% more likely to have asthma and those who took the tablets every day were over twice as likely. Some of the most frequent users had the more severe forms of asthma.

The authors say taking aspirin was not linked with increased rates of asthma. Nor were asthmatics taking paracetamol to relieve their asthma symptoms, which could have skewed the results.

The paper suggests that paracetamol, taken frequently, may restrict the amount of the antioxidant glutathione in the body, which is found at high levels in the lining of the air ways and the nose. This antioxidant is thought to protect the lungs from damage caused by pollutants and free radicals which act in asthmatics to inflame the lungs.

Exchanging paracetamol tablets for aspirin is not the answer, say the scientists, because aspirin and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen can cause dangerous sensitivity reactions in asthmatics and must not be given to children because they can cause Reye's syndrome - a rare but potentially fatal condition.

"However there may be scope for some individuals who take paracetamol on a daily or weekly basis to reduce their frequency of usage," they say. "Furthermore, in a recent survey, 3% of adult analgesic users reported regularly taking more than the recommended dose."

webTitle: Brown to clamp down on banks

fields.headline: Brown to clamp down on banks
fields.standfirst: Pledge to break Big Four's massive overcharging
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will today pledge a better deal for millions of bank customers when he uses his Budget to back a crackdown on overcharging which is costing customers up to £400 a year.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will today pledge a better deal for millions of bank customers when he uses his Budget to back a crackdown on overcharging which is costing customers up to £400 a year.

Following the publication yesterday of the treasury-inspired Cruickshank review of high street banks, the chancellor will support proposals for a new watchdog to monitor cash machines and other payment systems, and a tightening up of banking supervision to stop banks being able to "write their own rules".

The review document sets out 53 recommendations predominantly aimed at breaking the stranglehold the big banks have on current accounts, the provision of services to small business, and the way money is transmitted around the system behind the scenes.

Sixteen months in preparation, the 344-page review concluded that "neither personal or small business customers are getting a fair deal from banks".

The head of the review team, the former telecoms regulator Don Cruickshank, said the UK public was paying between £3bn and £5bn a year too much for banking services, which amounted to between £40 and £400 per household.

Yesterday, ministers were quick to act on one of his key recommendations - that there should be a full investigation into the way banks treat small businesses because there is "little prospect of effective competition" in this area. The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said the provision of banking services to small and medium-sized firms was being referred to the competition commission.

Mr Cruickshank called on the government to increase transparency and competition in the banking industry.

Some of his harshest criticism was reserved for the way the big banks control and operate the UK's payment systems, which include everything from cash machine net works to cheque clearing. Cash machine charges were "excessive" - he has said customers should pay no more than 30p - while, despite the recent advances in technology, cheques still typically took three days or more to clear, and retailers were paying too much for the facility of accepting credit card payments, which impacts particularly on smaller stores and pushes up prices across the economy as a whole.

The big banks' hold over money transmission systems was hitting new and smaller banks and made it difficult for them to compete on a level playing field when it came to current accounts. The "big four" banks - Barclays, Lloyds TSB, HSBC and NatWest - hold almost 70% of current accounts.

Mr Cruickshank recommended that banks wishing to be part of a payment system such as a cash machine network should have to obtain a licence from the Treasury. He called for the creation of a new independent regulator, PayCom, to monitor this new regime.

Other recommendations include:

 Better information made available to help people compare products.

The Financial Services Authority, the main City watchdog, should be given powers to collect and publish information on prices so that people could see who offered the best deal;

 Giving the 3m people who do not have a bank account access to basic banking services;

 Strengthening complaints handling procedures, with "clear and objective standards" for banks to be judged against.

The report comes days after it was announced that the "big four" banks made profits of more than £13bn between them last year.

The banks said that they needed time to study the report but insisted they were competitive.

"It remains our view that the British banking industry is both effective and competitive, and delivers customers good value for money," said Tim Sweeney, director general of the British Bankers' Association.

How cash is extracted

Cash machine charges
Excessive in many cases. Lloyds, TSB and Abbey National charge disloyalty fee of £1.50 for using another bank's machines. Transaction costs 15-30p

Overdraft costs
Nearly 5m of 12m with overdrafts pay monthly fee of about £5 on top of high interest rates. Of big four, only HSBC has no monthly charge. A Lloyds TSB customer overdrawn by £200 for five days a month would pay £65 a year fees and interest

Poor interest rates on deposit accounts
Big four current account holders receive 0.1% interest on credit balances. Smile, the Co-operative internet bank, pays 4.85%

Low savings rates
While internet banks Egg and First-e are paying 6.3% and 6.81% respectively, millions of people have accounts paying next to nothing. Abbey National's Instant Plus account pays 0.1% on £50 plus; its Instant Saver pays 0.7% on balances up to £2,500

Hefty small business charges
Some banks waive charges for the first year or two but these can kick in with a vengeance later

webTitle: Gallagher pips Robbie Williams in hellraisers' list

fields.headline: Gallagher pips Robbie Williams in hellraisers' list
fields.trailText: He may have bragged that he could duff up Liam Gallagher in a boxing ring, but Robbie Williams has lost out to his rival in a new chart of rock and roll hellraisers.
fields.body:
He may have bragged that he could duff up Liam Gallagher in a boxing ring, but Robbie Williams has lost out to his rival in a new chart of rock and roll hellraisers.

The Oasis frontman comes fifth in the rock weekly Melody Maker's poll of pop star excess, with Williams, the former member of boy band Take That, in sixth.

But both these young pretenders trail behind Kurt Cobain and the Who's Keith Moon (both dead), Richey Edwards from the Manic Street Preachers (disappeared) and Shaun Ryder from the Happy Mondays (just about alive, the last time anyone checked).

Cobain, the lead singer of Nirvana famed for mindboggling heroin abuse and a spectacular suicide in 1994, comes in at number one. His wife, Courtney Love, the frontwoman for Hole, keeps it in the family in eighth place.

Though Cobain has a certain pedigree, some thought Keith Richards's seventh place a mite low.

"It's good to be here," the Rolling Stones guitarist told the audience at a Sheryl Crow concert last year, "but then it's good to be anywhere."

Mark Sutherland, editor of Melody Maker, said last night: "In light of the recent spat between Robbie and Liam, we thought it would be fun to look at the most infamous hellraisers in rock history.

"Their antics read like a litany of sexual deviance, drug-fuelled escapades, self-abuse and mutilation."

The top 20 is crammed with rockers of the guitar band variety, though Dave Gahan from Depeche Mode comes in at number 17 for turning weedy synthesiser pop into a narcotic, gothic hell.

Cerys Matthews, the lead singer of Catatonia, who shines in the drinking stakes, is the only British woman in the list, at 19.

webTitle: Guidelines aim to end abuse of elderly people

fields.headline: Guidelines aim to end abuse of elderly people
fields.trailText: Abuse of elderly people and other vulnerable adults will be put under the same searchlight as the abuse of children, after the government yesterday issued new rules for health and social care agencies.
fields.body:
Abuse of elderly people and other vulnerable adults will be put under the same searchlight as the abuse of children, after the government yesterday issued new rules for health and social care agencies.

Ministers promised there would be no hiding place for abusers under the guidelines, which follow a series of scandals involving elderly people, mentally ill people and those with physical and learning disabilities.

An inquiry report, released on Friday, found there had been "degrading and cruel" treatment of dementia patients at a hospital in Carlisle, Cumbria. Yesterday, three senior managers involved in the inquiry were suspended.

The guidelines, entitled No Secrets, are aimed at preventing sexual and physical abuse and neglect and discrimination, in all settings - including people's own homes.

The strategy involves all care agencies, but social services directors are being given responsibility for ensuring its implementation by the end of October next year.

The government's social services inspectorate will monitor progress.

Measures include tightening recruitment checks on care workers, putting in place formal procedures for raising concerns and introducing specialist training for managers and investigators.

John Hutton, the social care minister, said: "Abuse of people in any setting is unacceptable. The government is taking strong measures to ensure that this cannot and does not happen in the future. We must treat vulnerable citizens with the respect that they deserve."

Social welfare charities welcomed the guidelines as a watershed in terms of recognising the problem of abuse of adults, but said still more needed to be done.

Richard Kramer, the head of campaigns at the learning disability charity Mencap, said the strategy failed to address the information needs of those at risk.

"There remains a yawning gap in the training and education of vulnerable adults in understanding abuse," he said.

The North Lakeland NHS trust, responsible for the hospital in the Carlisle scandal, said it had suspended, pending further investigation, its personnel director, training manager and locality manager for the Carlisle district. The roles of other individuals were under scrutiny.

The trust's chief executive, Alan Place, has been suspended since last August. Its chairwoman, Mary Styth, was dismissed by Alan Milburn, the health secretary, on publication of the inquiry report.

fields.headline: Young novelist on Orange list
fields.standfirst: Cambridge graduate in line for £30,000 fiction prize with multicultural celebration
fields.trailText: Zadie Smith, the Cambridge graduate who won a reported £250,000 advance for her first two novels at 24, yesterday became one of 20 authors in line for the £30,000 Orange fiction prize, the biggest in Britain.
fields.body:
Zadie Smith, the Cambridge graduate who won a reported £250,000 advance for her first two novels at 24, yesterday became one of 20 authors in line for the £30,000 Orange fiction prize, the biggest in Britain.

Her novel White Teeth, celebrating two generations of multicultural family life in north London, is on the long-list for the award, which is open to women only. The winner will be announced in June.

Her theme is not untypical of an entry dominated by "stories of migration from one culture to another", according to the judges' chairwoman, Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee.

"At least nine of the books are about this", she said, "It's a tremendous wellspring for tension and imagination.

"After reading them all, you look at mothers begging with babies in their laps - Romanians or whatever - and you think, those kids are going to write a book some day."

Long-listed authors include Leila Aboulela, Anita Desai, Laura Hird, Sunetra Gupta, AL Kennedy, Shauna Singh Baldwin and Eilis Ni Dhuibhne. Themes range from Sudanese, Indian, Pakistani or Irish migration to Jewish emigrants in postwar Palestine.

However, male readers will be apt to judge these books not by their stories but by a quick look at titles and covers, according to a survey on gender conducted by Orange.

They are likely to buy Ms Smith's White Teeth only if they mistake it for a thriller about sharks: Ms Baldwin's What the Body Remembers if they think it is a sex manual; and Barbara Ewing's The Dangerous Vine if they expect it to be a detective story about wine growing.

For them, the long-list's safest bet is Julie Leigh's The Hunter because it sounds like a thriller.

"If they talk about emotions, depression, understanding oneself - that's for women", said one of the men among the 200 regular literary fiction readers interviewed in the survey.

A woman reader said: "Men haven't the slightest idea how to write about women. They are all stereotypes, either sluts or mothers".

The sample was shown 20 already-published books, some of them modern classics. The men tended to relegate 12 of them to a "female reads only" category.

These included Michael Ondaatje's The English Patient, which some of them are likely to have taken by its title as a nursing romance; Iris Murdoch's The Sandcastle (bringing up kids), Angela Carter's Wise Children (ditto); Anne Tyler's Ladder of Years (sewing); George Eliot's Middlemarch (provincial romance) and John Fowles' s The French Lieutenant's Woman (Napoleonic romance).

Ian McEwan's Enduring Love was rated firmly in the "female reads" camp by 78% of men but only 38% of women. Fewer than 30% of men said they would be interested in reading it - partly, the survey suggests, because of its pink cover. Some 57% of women were interested.

Only 13% of men, compared with 70% of women, would consider reading The English Patient.

For Wise Children, the figures were 29% and 69%. Middlemarch scored better, with 50% of men compared with 75% of women.

The book that scored highest as a male read was Nick Hornby's High Fidelity.

Several books were seen as "neutral reads" not specially for men or women.

These included Dickens's Great Expectations, perhaps because it was assumed to be about money; Beryl Bainbridge's Every Man for Himself because of its title and adventurous cover showing the Titanic; and Pat Barker's Regeneration, for its war theme and because the author was assumed to be a man.

The survey verdict is that "men are far more biased towards books written by men than women are to books written by women."

This year's judges are Ms Toynbee, Claire Beaumont of Waterstone's, the novelist Bonnie Greer, Ffion Hague, the wife of the Conservative party leader, and the writer and historian Amanda Foreman.

They are likely to buy Ms Smith's White Teeth only if they mistake it for a thriller about sharks: Ms Baldwin's What the Body Remembers if they think it is a sex manual; and Barbara Ewing's The Dangerous Vine if they expect it to be a detective story about wine growing. For them, the long-list's safest bet is Julie Leigh's The Hunter because it sounds like a thriller. "If they talk about emotions, depression, understanding oneself - that's for women", said one of the men among the 200 regular literary fiction readers interviewed in the survey. A woman reader said: "Men haven't the slightest idea how to write about women. They are all stereotypes, either sluts or mothers". The sample was shown 20 already-published books, some of them modern classics. The men tended to relegate 12 of them to a "female reads only" category. These included Michael Ondaatje's The English Patient, which some of them are likely to have taken by its title as a nursing romance; Iris Murdoch's The Sandcastle (bringing up kids), Angela Carter's Wise Children (ditto); Anne Tyler's Ladder of Years (sewing); George Eliot's Middlemarch (provincial romance) and John Fowles' s The French Lieutenant's Woman (Napoleonic romance). Ian McEwan's Enduring Love was rated firmly in the "female reads" camp by 78% of men but only 38% of women. Fewer than 30% of men said they would be interested in reading it - partly, the survey suggests, because of its pink cover. Some 57% of women were interested. Only 13% of men, compared with 70% of women, would consider reading The English Patient. For Wise Children, the figures were 29% and 69%. Middlemarch scored better, with 50% of men compared with 75% of women. The book that scored highest as a male read was Nick Hornby's High Fidelity. Several books were seen as "neutral reads" not specially for men or women. These included Dickens's Great Expectations, perhaps because it was assumed to be about money; Beryl Bainbridge's Every Man for Himself because of its title and adventurous cover showing the Titanic; and Pat Barker's Regeneration, for its war theme and because the author was assumed to be a man. The survey verdict is that "men are far more biased towards books written by men than women are to books written by women." This year's judges are Ms Toynbee, Claire Beaumont of Waterstone's, the novelist Bonnie Greer, Ffion Hague, the wife of the Conservative party leader, and the writer and historian Amanda Foreman.
