webTitle: Terrorist case collapses after three years

fields.headline: Terrorist case collapses after three years
fields.trailText: An unprecedented three-year terrorist case dramatically collapsed yesterday when an MI5 informant refused to appear in court after evidence which senior ministers tried to suppress revealed that Algerian government forces were involved in atrocities against innocent civilians.
fields.body:
An unprecedented three-year terrorist case dramatically collapsed yesterday when an MI5 informant refused to appear in court after evidence which senior ministers tried to suppress revealed that Algerian government forces were involved in atrocities against innocent civilians.

In a case that has implications for the terrorism bill now going through parliament, Judge Henry Pownall ruled at the Old Bailey that evidence of MI5's source was vital to the defence.

Without it, he said, there would be no admissible evidence to back up the defendants' claims. The alleged terrorists, their lawyers argued, had sent material to Algeria in self-defence against Algerian government forces.

The prosecution - which earlier admitted that the security services had bugged a conversation between the three Algerian defendants and their lawyer at the Belmarsh top security prison in south-east London - offered no further evidence.

The judge formally entered a not guilty verdict against Sofiane Kebilene, 33, Farid Boukemiche, 29, and Sofiane Souidi, 33, accused of being supporters of the Armed Islamic Group.

They were arrested by the police in London in the summer of 1997 after a five-month surveillance operation by MI5. Ken McDonald QC, leading defence counsel, said they were arrested after contacts between Algerian interior ministry officials and officials at the British embassy in Algiers.

They were charged with possessing "chemical containers , radio equipment, manuals, documents, credit cards and sums of money, in circumstances which give rise to a reasonable suspicion that the articles were in their possession for a purpose connected with the commission, preparation or instigation of acts of terrorism".

It was the first time charges have been laid under section 16a of the prevention of terrorism act described a year ago by Lord Bingham, the lord chief justice, as undermining "in a blatant and obvious way, the presumption of innocence". Almost identical clauses appear in the new terrorism bill.

Lord Bingham said that by reversing the burden of proof the section almost certainly contravened the European convention on human rights. Despite his judgment, backing up an earlier ruling by Judge Pownall, the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, was determined to press ahead.

The prosecution pursued the case despite secret documents showing British intelligence believed the Algerian government was involved in atrocities, contradicting the view the government was claiming in public.

Three cabinet ministers - Jack Straw, Geoffrey Hoon and Robin Cook - signed public interest immunity certificates in an attempt to suppress the evidence.

When secret documents, mainly from the Foreign Office, were produced on the orders of the trial judge - 18 months after the defence asked for them - they were in marked contrast to the government's publicly-stated view, expressed by the Foreign Office in 1998, that there was "no credible, substantive evidence to confirm" allegations implicating Algerian government forces in atrocities.

Nigel Sweeney, prosecution counsel, admitted yesterday that an MI5 source had secretly testified that he had "frequently seen people suspected of being members of the GIA (the armed Islamic group) and the FIS (the Islamic Salvation Front) beaten up, abducted and killed by the army."

He said the Algerian army and police had "written authority to do whatever necessary against suspected members of the GIA and FIS".

Documents the ministers wanted to suppress but read out earlier in open court revealed that Whitehall's joint intelligence committee stated that "responsibility for violence cannot be conclusively laid in one place... There is no firm evidence to rule out gov ernment manipulation or involvement in terrorist violence".

Sources had privately said some of the killings of civilians were the responsibility of the Algerian security services, one document said.

Another document, dated January 1997, reports a British source as saying "military security [in Algeria] would have... no scruples about killing innocent people... My instincts remain that parts of the Algerian government would stop at nothing".

Other documents referred to the "manipulation" of the GIA being used as a cover to carry out their own operations. A US intelligence report - also read out in open court - said there was no evidence to link 1995 Paris bombings to Algerian militants, suggesting that one killing at the time could have been ordered by the Algerian government.

One Whitehall document says that its suspicions about the activities of Algerian government forces "if revealed could open us to detailed questioning by NGOs [non government organisations, such as human rights groups] and journalists".

An estimated 100,000 people have been killed in Algeria since 1991.

Mr McDonald told the court last month that it would be an "affront to the public conscience to proceed". The defence argued that it was impossible to get witnesses to give evidence about the security situation in Algeria - something Judge Pownall ruled was needed in the interests of justice. Determined to press ahead with the trial, the prosecution last month trawled through Home Office immigration files looking for an Algerian dissident who would give evidence on behalf of the defence.

After the MI5 source refused to be identified, the prosecution sought a deal whereby he would answer questions put to him by an independent solicitor. The source still refused insisting the risks to him and his family were too great.

During the course of pre-trial hearings - held in open court but which could not be disclosed until now - the security services admitted bugging a conversation between the defendants and their lawyer at Belmarsh.

The judge said the principle that such conversations were privileged was important but there was evidence it happened only in a "single incident" and may have been "wholly innocent".

Gareth Peirce, lawyer for the defendants, said later that the law under which they were tried "should not exist". The case had demonstrated the problems of trying people in Britain on charges relating to the nature of foreign regimes such as Algeria's - a difficulty Mr Sweeney acknowledged, but he insisted there was strong prime facie evidence that the three men were guilty.

The men are applying for political asylum , though Kabilene and Boukemiche are awaiting sentencing on charges of deception, which they admitted.

webTitle: Cherie Booth helps victim of machete attack

fields.headline: Cherie Booth helps victim of machete attack
fields.trailText: Cherie Booth QC has offered to represent a young machete-attack victim for free after a review panel increased the seven-year-old girl's compensation by just £150.
fields.body:
Cherie Booth QC has offered to represent a young machete-attack victim for free after a review panel increased the seven-year-old girl's compensation by just £150.

The prime minister's wife agreed to waive her fees in the case of Francesca Quintyne, who was badly injured by a man who went berserk during a playground picnic at St Luke's school, Wolverhampton. Francesca, four at the time, lost part of an ear and her jawbone was shattered. A nursery nurse, Lisa Potts, was awarded the George Cross for bravery in protecting children.

Ms Booth is to lodge an appeal after a review by the state-funded criminal injuries compensation board raised an initial £7,950 offer to £8,100.

The QC, who met Francesca at a Downing Street reception, intervened after an appeal by her mother Sheridon Quintyne.

Ms Quintyne said last night: "The sum offered is derisory and will not help Francesca overcome what happened in the playground. As well as the physical scars, she still gets nightmares.

Under the criminal injury compensation board's tariff system, payments are capped well below the sums awarded by courts in civil cases. A girl suffering Francesca's injuries in a road accident could expect to win around £100,000 compensation in a civil case.

Horrett Campbell, a paranoid schizophrenic, was sent to a secure mental hospital indefinitely after being convicted of attempted murder following the attack in 1996.

Ms Potts, 24, who is awaiting a final offer after an initial £8,000 award, said: "I cannot believe they are treating Francesca like this. She should have been properly compensated." A spokesman for the board said it did not comment on individual cases.

webTitle: Mother joins Met in Lawrence killing plea

fields.headline: Mother joins Met in Lawrence killing plea
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: Doreen Lawrence is to make a fresh appeal tonight for information about the murder of her son Stephen along with the officer in charge of the investigation into the racist killing of the teenager seven years ago.
fields.body:
Doreen Lawrence is to make a fresh appeal tonight for information about the murder of her son Stephen along with the officer in charge of the investigation into the racist killing of the teenager seven years ago.

She will join deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, who is head of the Metropolitan police's racial and violent crimes task force, on the BBC's Crimewatch UK programme to ask for further help in bringing her son's killers to justice.

Mr Grieve is expected to tell viewers that there is still hope of prosecuting the gang of white youths who stabbed the 18-year-old A-level student to death at a bus stop in Eltham, south-east London in April 1993, because he believes "allegiances change over time".

Mr Grieve will say: "Seven years have passed since the racist murder of Stephen Lawrence, but we know several people out there can turn the keys to locking up those responsible. Allegiances change over time.

"We nearly have the full picture and I am relying on Crimewatch viewers to help complete it.

"Crimewatch has always generated a nugget of gold for us. I'm sure tonight will be no different."

Last night Mr Grieve was confirmed as a special advisor to the police inquiry into the hangings of two black men in Telford, Shropshire.

Mr Grieve will advise Peter Hampson, chief constable of West Mercia police, on the inquiry into the deaths of Harold McGowan and his nephew Jason, 20 last year.

Mrs Lawrence's appeal on Crimewatch is the first time that the programme has featured her son's murder and it is hoped that it will lead to new developments in the case.

It is not the first time Crimewatch has been used in an attempt to track down clues in other racist attacks. Last year the programme showed secu rity footage in an attempt to gain information into the death of Asian student Ricky Reel.

Mr Reel was on a night out in Kingston upon Thames on October 14, 1997, when he and his friends were attacked by white racists and scattered.

He was never seen alive again and his body was pulled from the Thames a week later.

The programme has also highlighted the death of Michael Menson, a musician who was attacked and set on fire on his way to Chase Farm hospital, Enfield, north London, to receive an injection he needed to control his schizophrenia.

Police initially thought that he had set fire to himself, but later decided that he had been the victim of a racially motivated attack.

He later died in hospital and an appeal on the programme last year led to new information that helped the police track down his attackers.

While no one has been convicted for Stephen's murder five men have at various times been arrested, and a private criminal prosecution brought against three of them collapsed.

The appeal on Crimewatch comes as Stephen's parents Neville and Doreen press ahead with a compensation claim against the police officers involved in the bungled murder investigation.

They are suing 42 police officers who range from the rank of constable to superintendent, including the former Metropolitan police commissioner Sir Paul Condon

Under writs issued in December the officers are being sued under section 20 of the Race Relations Act, which refers to discrimination on grounds of race.

The Stephen Lawrence inquiry report published in February 1999 found that it was a fully justified conclusion to say that racism played its part in the investigation.

Duwayne Brooks, who was with Stephen when he died, issued writs against 15 officers in August.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Budget Special | The King Of Edge Hill | The Men Who Made Hollywood
fields.body:
The Budget Special runs from 3.0pm on Radio 5 Live and Radio 4 Long Wave. Radio 4's FM frequencies continue with regular programming.

Karen Brown's afternoon play, The King Of Edge Hill (2.15pm, Radio 4 FM), tells the odd story of Joseph Williamson, the businessman responsible for those fascinating Liverpool tunnels. Having married the boss's daughter, he took over her family's tobacco factory and built a fortune. A subsequent housing project was transformed first into an employment scheme for troops returning from the Napoleonic wars and later into the city's maze of superfluous tunnels.

The second of Michael Freedland's tales about The Men Who Made Hollywood (9.0pm, Radio 2) deals with Sam Goldwyn, who really did start the film business there. He arrived in 1912 to make a Western and never left. He was famous for two things - his films-of-the-book and suchcarefully-contrived aphorisms as "A hospital is no place to be sick".

fields.headline: Cut and lose
fields.standfirst:
William Hague's plan to fight the next election on a low-tax platform could backfire. He is out of touch with what voters want

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: We are now effectively into the election campaign. The two issues which the Tories are going to develop over the next months are Euroscepticism and taxation. These allow them to take a distinctively different position from New Labour. At the moment Euroscepticism is the more salient of the two. In MORI's January poll, voters ranked Europe as the fourth most important issue facing the country, whereas taxation ranked only 15th.
fields.body:
We are now effectively into the election campaign. The two issues which the Tories are going to develop over the next months are Euroscepticism and taxation. These allow them to take a distinctively different position from New Labour. At the moment Euroscepticism is the more salient of the two. In MORI's January poll, voters ranked Europe as the fourth most important issue facing the country, whereas taxation ranked only 15th.

However it is early days yet, and since taxation is thought to have worked well for Tories in the past, William Hague is going to push it hard. Last week's speech making a "moral" case for low tax is a sign of things to come. He will also have been encouraged by the government's admission that the tax burden has increased since 1997 as a percentage of GDP. Stand by for an aggressive response to today's Budget.

But there are dangers for the Tories in tax. Look at the British election survey data in the chart. In 1997 more than two-thirds of voters believed that taxation had increased during the previous five years, during John Major's tenure at Number 10. Nearly a third believed that taxes had increased a lot. About three-quarters of Liberal Democrat and Labour voters thought the tax burden had increased, with nearly 40% of the latter thinking it had increased by a lot. Even among Tory voters a solid majority believed the tax burden had increased on Major's watch and only a fifth thought it had declined. Thus voters are not likely to believe promises from the Tory leader about reducing taxation, given the record of the Tories in the past.

One way round Hague's problem would to convince voters the increased tax burden was somehow not the Tories' fault. However, in the same 1997 survey, when respondents were asked if tax increases were the responsibility of the Major government, no less than 89% thought that they were, and only 9% thought that tax increases occurred for other reasons. Thus John Major's government was not able to escape its responsibility.

Another interesting but little noticed feature of the tax debate is that in recent years the Tories have been moving more and more out of step with public opinion. In both the 1992 and 1997 election studies, voters were asked to place themselves along an 11-point scale to measure their attitudes to taxation and spending. If they gave themselves a score of one on this scale it meant that they felt very strongly that both taxation and spending should be increased. If they gave themselves a score of 11 it meant that they strongly supported cuts in both taxation and spending. A midpoint score of six meant that they opted for the status quo. They were also asked to score the policy positions taken by the parties on the same scales.

In 1992 the average score for voters as a whole was 3.9 which indicated that they preferred tax and spending increases to cuts. By 1997 it had shifted to 3.7, showing that support for tax and spending had increased a tiny amount. Most interesting were the scores which voters assigned to the political parties. In 1992 they gave Labour an average score of 2.8 which showed that it was perceived as very much a "tax and spend" party. By 1997 this score had shifted to 3.6, which almost coincided with the preferences of the average voter. Labour had literally moved to the middle ground on this issue in the minds of the electorate.

The equivalent figures for the Conservatives tell a different story, however. Their 1992 score was 4.8, but by 1997 it had jumped to 6.9. Rather than moving closer to the preferences of the average voter, the Tories had moved further away from them. The Liberal Democrats scored 3.7 on both occasions, which in 1997 coincided exactly with the views of the average voter. Given this, the Liberal Democrat pledge to increase income tax by 1p in the pound in 1997 probably helped rather than harmed their campaign.

Thus a future Tory election campaign based on promises of tax cuts faces two problems. On the one hand, they are perceived to be out of touch with voters on the issue and William Hague's high-decibel campaign is likely to make that worse rather than better. Secondly, they are perceived to have failed to deliver on the cuts they promised when they were in power. At the moment it appears that Michael Portillo has a much better sense of the electoral possibilities of this issue than does his boss.

To make taxation stick, William Hague has to do two things. Firstly, he has to raise its salience in the minds of the public. In the MORI survey only 5% of voters saw it as important. Second, he has to convince the electorate that the Tories under his leadership would do things differently from last time around. This is going to be a tough task since the MORI survey indicates that only 19% of the electorate think that he is doing a good job as leader of the opposition (56% think the opposite). In contrast 53% of voters think Tony Blair is doing a good job as prime minister (38% disagree).

New Labour is neurotic about tax, given its experience at the 1992 election. It should relax. While it is true that there is little support for swingeing tax increases, it is also true that there is little support for swingeing tax cuts. The party is now located close to where the voters want to be on this issue. Providing Labour maintains a reputation for economic competence, it should be able to see off a tax-cuts campaign without too much difficulty.

 Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at Sheffield University

But there are dangers for the Tories in tax. Look at the British election survey data in the chart. In 1997 more than two-thirds of voters believed that taxation had increased during the previous five years, during John Major's tenure at Number 10. Nearly a third believed that taxes had increased a lot. About three-quarters of Liberal Democrat and Labour voters thought the tax burden had increased, with nearly 40% of the latter thinking it had increased by a lot. Even among Tory voters a solid majority believed the tax burden had increased on Major's watch and only a fifth thought it had declined. Thus voters are not likely to believe promises from the Tory leader about reducing taxation, given the record of the Tories in the past. One way round Hague's problem would to convince voters the increased tax burden was somehow not the Tories' fault. However, in the same 1997 survey, when respondents were asked if tax increases were the responsibility of the Major government, no less than 89% thought that they were, and only 9% thought that tax increases occurred for other reasons. Thus John Major's government was not able to escape its responsibility. Another interesting but little noticed feature of the tax debate is that in recent years the Tories have been moving more and more out of step with public opinion. In both the 1992 and 1997 election studies, voters were asked to place themselves along an 11-point scale to measure their attitudes to taxation and spending. If they gave themselves a score of one on this scale it meant that they felt very strongly that both taxation and spending should be increased. If they gave themselves a score of 11 it meant that they strongly supported cuts in both taxation and spending. A midpoint score of six meant that they opted for the status quo. They were also asked to score the policy positions taken by the parties on the same scales. In 1992 the average score for voters as a whole was 3.9 which indicated that they preferred tax and spending increases to cuts. By 1997 it had shifted to 3.7, showing that support for tax and spending had increased a tiny amount. Most interesting were the scores which voters assigned to the political parties. In 1992 they gave Labour an average score of 2.8 which showed that it was perceived as very much a "tax and spend" party. By 1997 this score had shifted to 3.6, which almost coincided with the preferences of the average voter. Labour had literally moved to the middle ground on this issue in the minds of the electorate. The equivalent figures for the Conservatives tell a different story, however. Their 1992 score was 4.8, but by 1997 it had jumped to 6.9. Rather than moving closer to the preferences of the average voter, the Tories had moved further away from them. The Liberal Democrats scored 3.7 on both occasions, which in 1997 coincided exactly with the views of the average voter. Given this, the Liberal Democrat pledge to increase income tax by 1p in the pound in 1997 probably helped rather than harmed their campaign. Thus a future Tory election campaign based on promises of tax cuts faces two problems. On the one hand, they are perceived to be out of touch with voters on the issue and William Hague's high-decibel campaign is likely to make that worse rather than better. Secondly, they are perceived to have failed to deliver on the cuts they promised when they were in power. At the moment it appears that Michael Portillo has a much better sense of the electoral possibilities of this issue than does his boss. To make taxation stick, William Hague has to do two things. Firstly, he has to raise its salience in the minds of the public. In the MORI survey only 5% of voters saw it as important. Second, he has to convince the electorate that the Tories under his leadership would do things differently from last time around. This is going to be a tough task since the MORI survey indicates that only 19% of the electorate think that he is doing a good job as leader of the opposition (56% think the opposite). In contrast 53% of voters think Tony Blair is doing a good job as prime minister (38% disagree). New Labour is neurotic about tax, given its experience at the 1992 election. It should relax. While it is true that there is little support for swingeing tax increases, it is also true that there is little support for swingeing tax cuts. The party is now located close to where the voters want to be on this issue. Providing Labour maintains a reputation for economic competence, it should be able to see off a tax-cuts campaign without too much difficulty.  Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at Sheffield University

webTitle: PM drawn into row over Shayler

fields.headline: PM drawn into row over Shayler
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday was drawn into Whitehall's attempt to force the Guardian and Observer newspapers to hand over any documents they may have relating to the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, when the International Press Institute urged him to stop the action.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday was drawn into Whitehall's attempt to force the Guardian and Observer newspapers to hand over any documents they may have relating to the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, when the International Press Institute urged him to stop the action.

Describing the legal moves as chilling, Johann Fritz, director of the Vienna-based editors' organisation told the prime minister in a letter: "It is a given duty in every press code in every democratic country that journalists have an obligation to protect their sources - not for their own sake, but to ensure the free flow of information on which journalism depends.

"Those duties are further reflected in international agreements, including the European convention on human rights.

"Indeed, it is our firm belief that the Observer and the Guardian would win an appeal in the European court of human rights if they decided to pursue that avenue.

"It is the worst possible signal for the British government to seek to override these obligations in a case where no new information of substance is even concerned.

"It is bound, in its implications, to cause fear amongst the vital sources of journalism in future."

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why.
fields.body:
Funny ha-ha... Well, with Oscar night fast approaching, the usual hordes of Hollywood flotsam and jetsam will be far too busy perfecting their looks of flabbergasted humility to bother pumping up their latest product over here. But fret not, as the funniest man in modern film-making, Peter Farrelly, co-creator with sibling Bobby of such scatological comic delights as There's Something About Mary and Dumb And Dumber, is bucking the trend during a week-long sojourn plugging his semi-autobiographical Tinseltown satire The Comedy Writer. Having already visited the NFT last night, he's now embarked on a tour of the country's Borders Bookshops, with Leeds today, Brighton tomorrow, and a return to London on Thursday...

When worlds collide... Meanwhile, on an altogether higher intellectual plane, Susan Sontag arrives on Thursday to regale the nation's press in promotion of her latest novel, In America. Whether this means the woman responsible for some of the greatest works of critical theory ever written will get to meet the man responsible for immortalising Jeff Daniels suffering a seismic bout of diarrhoea somewhere in the bowels of Heathrow remains, as yet, unclear.

La Vida Loca... And armchair postmodernists of an ad agency persuasion will no doubt already be aware that this week finds the UK playing host to mix'n'match nabob Beck, who pitches up later this week for shows in support of his latest album Midnite Vultures. For those with a yen for such matters, he plays Wembley on Thursday, Manchester Friday, and Glasgow this Saturday. Which leaves time to mention the assorted heads of Cypress Hill, arriving imminently with their metal-inflected brand of bong-hop to entertain the London Astoria on Friday. Altogether now - Insane in the membrane/insane in the brain (etc)...

fields.headline: The quiet revolutionary
fields.trailText: Omnibus: One Bright Light | Equinox: The Rise And Fall Of GM
fields.body:
Just after Sidney Poitier moved from the Bahamas, where he grew up, to the United States where he grew into one of the leading actors of his generation, he was a dishwasher. "And", he said, "I became quite good at it." This was typical Poitier: dignified and measured, not self-important but self-assured. As one of the contributors noted in Omnibus: One Bright Light (BBC1), Poitier carried pride and enlightenment with him, wherever he went. No surprise then that this profile of the first black actor to become a Hollywood star was quietly inspirational, quite uplifting.

From his first film, No Way Out, in which he played a doctor, through Cry, The Beloved Country, In The Heat Of The Night and Guess Who's Coming To Dinner, Poitier redefined how black people saw themselves in America and how others saw them. He was determined not to play the clown, the servant or the entertainer - as so many black actors had done before him - and with a few notable exceptions like Porgy And Bess, he carved a career which fulfilled that desire.

Understanding the power of the movies and the repression inherent in their demeaning representations, he was politic in his choice of films. And as the intelligent and impressive line-up of talking heads - including Denzel Washington and Norman Jewison - affirmed, his contributions to both acting and the advancement of black Americans were immeasurable. The Poitier who emerged from the testimony of others was one exemplary human being.

Through his life story, Omnibus also charted a path through a history of black America, from segregation to liberation, and this was the other major achievement of the documentary, painting the bigger picture through an intimate portrait. Like the man himself, there was enlightenment here.

Enlightenment of a different kind came in Equinox: The Rise And Fall Of GM. It's not every day that you find you have something in common with women who bare their breasts in public and have "Dyke Mom!" written on their backs. The penchant for public nakedness and bodily graffiti notwithstanding, these brave - and perhaps cold - women embodied the uneasiness most of us share about genetically modified foods. Demonstrating at the World Trade Organisation meeting in Seattle, they articulated what people like me only fret about silently while tucking into a bowl of GM cereal - the steamroller of globalisation and the power of multinational corporations. While normally such strident campaigners fight losing battles, these women, along with some altogether less-in-the- altogether others, are winning the war for the public's hearts and minds as far as genetically modified foods are concerned.

Frankenstein foods are evil and wrong and should we ever contemplate unleashing GM crops into the environment, they will surely adapt, become super-intelligent and take over the world. This, we know because everyone - apart from the multination als who obviously lie all the time - tells us so.

In a programme inevitably spawning headlines and Letters to the Editor, Equinox questioned every preconception you could possibly have about GM and put Western, affluent liberalism on the spot, not so much arguing but more just pointing out that genetic modification could be used for good. It could stop a lot of people dying in the Third World, for example.

While Lady Caroline Conran and her Holland Park chums talked about the joys of organic cheese and how simply wonderful it was to shop in delightful little shops and not the nasty big supermarket, they assured us that farmers in Africa didn't want GM crops. Cut to African farmer who seemed more than a little keen to sow some crops that didn't wither on the vine or rot in transit.

Whatever this epic documentary's aim, it was a hugely challenging piece of television and one which contained perhaps the best ever use of music in a factual programme. From Mexican guitar-and-bongo combos to Sinatra and The Flintstones' theme tune, it was clever and unsettling. Much as it goes against the grain, as it were, it was hard not to feel a bit sorry for all the vilified men in white coats. Equinox didn't so much advocate genetic modification or defend multinational biotech companies as illuminate how little we know about GM, how our gut reaction is all we consider in its debate. Perhaps that is all we need, but maybe that's because our bellies are full.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Afterglow | Homegrown | Cape Fear | Le Samourai
fields.body:
Afterglow

(Alan Rudolph, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

A painfully comic study of two failing marriages. Jonny Lee Miller is an ambitious twentysomething sure that everything is fine at home; but his frustrated wife Lara Flynn Boyle is far from happy and attracted to philandering repairman Nick Nolte, husband of Julie Christie's fragile ex-movie actress.

Homegrown

(Stephen Gyllenhaal, 1998)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

In the space of minutes the lives of three inept dope growers are transformed, when they see their boss murdered. Gradually it occurs to them that the situation could be turned to their advantage. So solid but not-too-bright Jack (Billy Bob Thornton), bandana man with girl problems Carter (Hank Azaria) and inarticulate teen Harlan (Ryan Phillippe) set out to harvest and sell the precious crop themselves. A comedy about cannabis that can't quite sustain believability long enough, it's none the less a rarity in American movies - a film that likes dope growers.

Cape Fear

(Martin Scorsese, 1991)

10.05pm, Sky Cinema

A screaming remake of J Lee Thompson's 1962 thriller. Robert De Niro is way over the top as Max Cady, the ex-con seeking vengeance on the lawyer responsible for putting him away. Cady, a rapist, attacks Sam Bowden (here's Nick Nolte again) through his wife and daughter (Jessica Lange, Juliette Lewis), sadistically working on the family's pressure points.

Le Samourai

(Jean-Pierre Melville, 1967)

4.10am, FilmFour

In the annals of cine-cool, Alain Delon's silent hitman, in trenchcoat, fedora, and the shadows, is an icon. His Costello, having committed murder in a nightclub, is hounded by police and double-crossing villains, a cold anti-hero made human only by a samurai-like adherence to his code of honour. Delon's then wife, Nathalie, plays his girlfriend and alibi; Cathy Rosier the witness to the crime and François Périer the cop and nemesis. A Melville masterpiece.

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Jack Docherty
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Jack Docherty
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? Jack Docherty is a pseudonym (my real name is Juan Do'uarte, which is some kind of Spanish hors d'oeuvre).

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? I recently visited the Highlands with Saga Tours, passing myself off as a sprightly 67.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? The key here, I think, is to undersell. So a rank, scrofulous, palsied midget.

What was the last illegal thing you did? I suppose most people come over all big and clever with something about drugs. Not me. The last illegal thing I did was sexual.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? Helped an old lady across the road (she didn't want to cross, but I insisted).

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? Georgy Season.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? JL (Got it? Used to partner DM. No? Was very good in TKOC with RDN, directed by MS).

Has a critic ever made you cry? Do you suppose the Manchester United team is upset by the views of the Darlington players?

What would you advertise without a fee? My forthcoming project, which is blah blah blah blah blah

What would you never advertise? Any book, TV show or film written by, starring or directed by any of my close personal friends.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning? Nothing.

What takes you to a "happy place"? Spinning my children until they're sick.

Jack Docherty stars in The Strangerers (tonight, 9pm, Sky1)

Lucy Barrick

fields.headline: Right here, right now
fields.standfirst: Having lost Home And Away to Channel 5, ITV is planning to launch the first home-grown soap opera of the millennium. How can it capture the imagination of today's net-savvy, information friendly generation?  Meg Carter investigates
fields.trailText: Having lost Home And Away to Channel 5, ITV is planning to launch the first home-grown soap opera of the millennium. How can it capture the imagination of today's net-savvy, information friendly generation?
fields.body:
ITV, sore from the embarrassing loss of Home And Away to the upstart Channel 5, is desperately seeking a new, home-grown soap. The call has gone out to producers from across the land to come up with an idea for an original, home-produced, youthful alternative. A new national viewing institution could soon be born. But what recipe will best suit today's internet-literate viewing tastes?

More than any other programming genre, a successful soap must be truly in tune with its time. Key ingredients for success, along with pacey plot, are recognisible characters, and situations the viewer can easily identify and empathise with. But it must also be in tune with its audience's aspirations.

Britain's first TV soap, Coronation Street, was born into an era of working class values. BBC1's long overdue response, EastEnders, was the first child of the 80s with its own resident yuppie in the form of Ian Beale (whose Thatcherite ideals endure).

Both Corrie and EastEnders owe their longevity in part to the community spirit each conveys. Even if not all of us fancy the idea of living next door to a Dot Cotton, at least these neighbours talk to each other. Their staying-power has also been helped by the subtle evolution which has seen various additions over the years, including wine bars, night clubs, gyms - even a nanny.

By the end of the decade, Eldorado had tried tapping into the boom times with a sun, sea 'n' sangria mix featuring ex-pats on the Costa del Sol... and failed. More recent entrants, however, have found greater success closer to home. Hollyoaks' early preoccupation with teenage party-going and who's-snogging-who storylines established a firm following (before the recent arrival of grittier themes, such as last week's look at male rape). And then there's Dream Team - set around the loves and lives of the friends, families and players at a local football club.

But what about the first new soap of the millennium? What setting, themes and storylines will prove themselves to be most in tune with the mood of today? ITV Network Centre is eagerly discussing ideas with the half-dozen or so producers designated "preferred suppliers" who will put forward their ideas for the network's new soap in coming weeks.

For the time being, at least, the brief remains pretty open - although insiders say the dream ticket will be one able to deliver a far younger audience profile than network stalwart Coronation Street. As the nation awaits the puff of white smoke from ITV programme director David Liddiment's office, leading figures from across the industry have some strong ideas about how a new soap will find a niche in today's overcrowded schedules.

Brian Park, former Coronation Street producer and executive producer of ITV prison drama Bad Girls 2, which airs in April, feels a new soap has to capture the mood of the nation if it has any chance of finding a loyal audience.

"There is an appetite for something with a younger skew," he says. "Look at the zeitgeist now and the taste is for rough 'n' ready - right here, right now, to paraphrase Norman Cook. The 'net generation' is already used to greater accessibility. Any new soap would also have to appeal to growing generations no longer hide-bound to being in a job from apprentice at 16 to silver clock at 65. The feeling of seizing the future would have to be central.

"Over and above that, you'd need characters with baggage to unravel over time, and a setting where worlds can collide. Which points to a metropolitan soap with traditional versus alternative, middle age versus youth."

Corinne Hollingworth, Channel 5 director of programmes and one-time executive producer of EastEnders feels a new soap can't make the mistake of trying too hard to copy existing favourites: "The current 'big three' are all fairly nostalgic - looking backwards to a world dominated by family and the community, being able to leave your back door open all day, which just isn't true to life any more.

"Now people choose where they live rather than staying where they grew up. With over 50 per cent of us middle class, working-class values do not prevail anymore.

"For all that, any new soap would have to be all about character, which, in itself, is pretty timeless. And I would caution against a four or five times a week soap set in the workplace. You have to be able to get to know the characters' background - go home with them.

"You have to start by thinking what you can provide that is not already there. My advice would be: 'don't do it'."

Verity Lambert, originator of former BBC1 soap Eldorado and founder of production company Cinema Verity, feels a new soap would have to look beyond traditional boundaries.

"They could do worse than revise Eldorado - even though I got my fingers burned on that one at the time. It's about Europe, and it addresses other current issues, such as people moving away in search of work.

"Otherwise, well, running for London mayor would surely make a good backdrop for a new TV soap. Or, equally topical: something based around life in a focus group."

And then there's Dream Team - set around the loves and lives of the friends, families and players at a local football club. But what about the first new soap of the millennium? What setting, themes and storylines will prove themselves to be most in tune with the mood of today? ITV Network Centre is eagerly discussing ideas with the half-dozen or so producers designated "preferred suppliers" who will put forward their ideas for the network's new soap in coming weeks. For the time being, at least, the brief remains pretty open - although insiders say the dream ticket will be one able to deliver a far younger audience profile than network stalwart Coronation Street. As the nation awaits the puff of white smoke from ITV programme director David Liddiment's office, leading figures from across the industry have some strong ideas about how a new soap will find a niche in today's overcrowded schedules. Brian Park, former Coronation Street producer and executive producer of ITV prison drama Bad Girls 2, which airs in April, feels a new soap has to capture the mood of the nation if it has any chance of finding a loyal audience. "There is an appetite for something with a younger skew," he says. "Look at the zeitgeist now and the taste is for rough 'n' ready - right here, right now, to paraphrase Norman Cook. The 'net generation' is already used to greater accessibility. Any new soap would also have to appeal to growing generations no longer hide-bound to being in a job from apprentice at 16 to silver clock at 65. The feeling of seizing the future would have to be central. "Over and above that, you'd need characters with baggage to unravel over time, and a setting where worlds can collide. Which points to a metropolitan soap with traditional versus alternative, middle age versus youth." Corinne Hollingworth, Channel 5 director of programmes and one-time executive producer of EastEnders feels a new soap can't make the mistake of trying too hard to copy existing favourites: "The current 'big three' are all fairly nostalgic - looking backwards to a world dominated by family and the community, being able to leave your back door open all day, which just isn't true to life any more. "Now people choose where they live rather than staying where they grew up. With over 50 per cent of us middle class, working-class values do not prevail anymore. "For all that, any new soap would have to be all about character, which, in itself, is pretty timeless. And I would caution against a four or five times a week soap set in the workplace. You have to be able to get to know the characters' background - go home with them. "You have to start by thinking what you can provide that is not already there. My advice would be: 'don't do it'." Verity Lambert, originator of former BBC1 soap Eldorado and founder of production company Cinema Verity, feels a new soap would have to look beyond traditional boundaries. "They could do worse than revise Eldorado - even though I got my fingers burned on that one at the time. It's about Europe, and it addresses other current issues, such as people moving away in search of work. "Otherwise, well, running for London mayor would surely make a good backdrop for a new TV soap. Or, equally topical: something based around life in a focus group."

fields.headline: Pledge on care insurance
fields.trailText: The Treasury started backtracking last night at a private meeting with Labour peers, agreeing there was a strong case for regulation of the rapidly growing market for long term care insurance. Ministers have been under pressure to regulate the industry following scandals over pensions and mortage misselling.
fields.body:
The Treasury started backtracking last night at a private meeting with Labour peers, agreeing there was a strong case for regulation of the rapidly growing market for long term care insurance. Ministers have been under pressure to regulate the industry following scandals over pensions and mortage misselling.

Last year's royal commission on long term care recommended the financial services authority oversee the potentially exploitative new branch of the insurance industry. A similar recommendation was made by a committee of both houses chaired by Lord Burns, former Treasury permanent secretary and author of the financial services bill, enshrining new powers for the FSA.

The Treasury economic secretary, Melanie Johnson, yesterday told rebel peers she was sympathetic to the case for regulation and planned to assemble a more detailed government response before the report stage of the financial services bill later this month.

Her remarks bought off a potential rebellion. Ministers, after successive defeats in the Lords, could ill afford another reverse, especially one led by normally Labour-voting peers, including Lord Borrie, the former director general of the office of fair trading. Ms Johnson told the rebels that ministers had set up a working party to examine regulation, and promised its work would be speeded up.

At the time of the royal commission only 23,000 long term care policies had been sold, but the figure has already risen to 30,000. The industry will grow vastly if, as expected, the government recommends in its response to the commission that wealthier people must pay privately for their long term care.

Supporters of regulation say the elderly are at their most vulnerable when they need to enter private long term care institutions, making them prey to poor insurance products.

fields.headline: Livingstone's 'grudging' apology to MPs
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday offered the Commons a perfunctionary apology over his failure to disclose £158,000 worth of income from speech making and newspaper articles to the MPs register of interests.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday offered the Commons a perfunctionary apology over his failure to disclose £158,000 worth of income from speech making and newspaper articles to the MPs register of interests.

The former GLC leader - who has been suspended from Labour party membership for standing as an independent candidate for mayor of London - took just one minute to tell colleagues he was sorry for not making a comprehensive declaration of his earnings.

Mr Livingstone made his statement from the back corner of the back row of the government benches - the most difficult part of the house for TV cameras.

It prompted his leftwing critic and fellow London MP, Stephen Pound, to call it "the most grudging apology since the emperor Hirohito" apologised for Japan's role in the second world war. Mr Livingstone was "not so much Dick Whittington as a fat cat", he said - though there is little evidence that it has yet hurt his Teflon candidacy.

Mr Livingstone's appearance had the effect of overshadowing another initiative from his main rival, Labour's Frank Dobson, who is struggling to overhaul the Brent East MP's daunting popular lead by persuading London voters that the mayor's job is "a serious challenge", not a joke.

To generate funds for the capital's poorer neighbourhoods - which do badly from the distribution of national lottery funds - the ex-health secretary announced plans to raise at least £50m a year from a London lottery.

He promised that voters would get a chance to say how the lottery would work - a daily draw or a weekly £1m one, for example - and how profits should be spent.

Mr Dobson suggested they could include affordable homes for teachers and nurses, as well as skills training for young people and CCTV cameras for crime-ridden areas. The lottery is justified because local services in London cost more than elsewhere.

As usual Mr Dobson took a sideswipe at the front runner when he told reporters that his rival's plans for congestion charges of up to £5 per car per day do not add up and they would "throw London's transport system into chaos" - and not generate the funds to cover Mr Livingstone's many promises.

Later Mr Livingstone made his apology at the customary hour, 3.30pm. He told MPs: "When I was first elected to the house in 1987, I checked with the authorities that income from earnings paid into my firm Localaction Ltd did not need to be individually declared in the register.

"Following the new code of practice, I wrote in 1996 to the parliamentary commissioner for standards to clarify the position. My outside earnings then developed in such a way that my registered entry was no longer adequate.

"I ought to have made a comprehensive entry covering all the services I provide through Localaction, but I did not in fact do so.

"As soon as possible after the issue was raised with me by the present parliamentary commissioner, I amended my entry in the register in accordance with the rules."

As usual during personal statements the remarks were heard in total silence.

The Dobson camp admits the underhand way in which the £158,000 non-declaration was put in the public domain has deadened its impact, but believe voters are realising Mr Livingstone is "just another politician, not Robin Hood".

webTitle: Former UKIP leader quits 'bitterly divided' party

fields.headline: Former UKIP leader quits 'bitterly divided' party
fields.trailText: The crisis within the anti-European UK Independence party took a further serious turn last night when the former leader, Michael Holmes MEP, resigned from the party over the continuing in-fighting.
fields.body:
The crisis within the anti-European UK Independence party took a further serious turn last night when the former leader, Michael Holmes MEP, resigned from the party over the continuing in-fighting.

Mr Holmes, 61, one of three UKIP MEPs elected in last summer's European elections, had already been forced to stand down as leader after falling out with his two fellow MEPs, Nigel Farage and Jeffrey Titford - who is now set to succeed him.

Last night the pair called on him to stand down as an MEP. "UKIP is conscious that our voters in the south west have been badly served and calls upon Mr Holmes to resign as an MEP in order that our supporters are properly represented," they said in a statement.

Mr Holmes, who had been planning to stand for the leadership again, said the party was so "bitterly divided" that he had changed his mind.

The UKIP won 7% of the vote last summer and has since been riven with internal disputes, leading to the removal of the ruling executive.

Mr Holmes said he was pushed out because an MEP should not be party leader.

fields.headline: Abdeen Ismael
fields.standfirst: Campaigner for democracy in Sudan
fields.trailText: The Sudanese lawyer and sometime ambassador to London, Abdeen Ismael, who has died aged 84, won a place in his country's history in 1964 during the uprising against the then military dictatorship of General Ibrahim Abboud, which had overthrown Sudan's post-colonial democracy in 1958.
fields.body:
The Sudanese lawyer and sometime ambassador to London, Abdeen Ismael, who has died aged 84, won a place in his country's history in 1964 during the uprising against the then military dictatorship of General Ibrahim Abboud, which had overthrown Sudan's post-colonial democracy in 1958.

As chairman of the powerful lawyers' association, Ismael, together with the Chief Justice Abdul Majeed Imam, led a protest calling for the resignation of the junta and the restoration of democracy, following the shooting of a student at the University of Khartoum. Surrounded by armed riot police, he fearlessly called for civil disobedience. The resulting strikes led to a transitional government replacing the dictatorship.

Ismael became local government minister, a post which did not do justice to his pivotal role in the "October revolution". A year later, Ismael, a radical and lifelong critic of Sudan's quasi-aristocratic families, had the task of supervising the Queen's visit to Sudan. He did the job well.

Born in Khartoum, he had studied in Cairo in the late 1930s, and became one of the first Sudanese to practise law. Strong family and clan connections helped him establish a reputation as a lawyer who would seek justice, even if the client was too poor to pay.

The 1964 government brought in representatives from all parties, including the communists and the Muslim Brotherhood. There were many reforms, including full voting rights for women, a lowering of the voting age to 18 and an attempt to do justice in southern Sudan.

But Ismael's dilemma remained unresolved. There was no left-of-centre party for thousands of Sudanese intellectuals, who either felt obliged to collaborate with religious fanatics or the extreme left. The only other alternative was to join one of the two main parties, the Ashiqa or the Umma, where religion and politics are now increasingly inseparable.

After the 1964 revolution, Ismael formed the Socialist Congress party, encouraging his wife, Safiyya, to become a member of its executive committee. But the SCP, without funds or popular appeal, sank without trace.

By the late 1960s, Ismael had become frustrated by the lack of recognition of his talents. Impressed by the radical agenda put forward when a second military coup toppled the Umma government in May 1969, he accepted the offer of its leader, Colonel Gaafar Nimeri, to become Sudanese ambassador to London.

Thus did the restorer of democracy of 1964 arrive in London in 1970 representing a military regime. Back in the Sudan, Nimeri announced, that November, a plan for a federation of Egypt, Sudan and Libya. In July 1971, opposition to the scheme led to an abortive, three-day coup, backed by Sudanese communists. It coincided with the presence in London of two of the 1969 coup leaders - a Sudanese Communist party member and a Marxist.

During those three days press conferences were held at the embassy and Nimeri's photograph was removed from the embassy walls. The two men set off for Khartoum, but en route Libya's Colonel Gadafi had their plane forced down and its occupants arrested. Nimeri, meanwhile, regained power in Khartoum and had the two men - and many others - shot. Ismael, their host, had better luck; he was only recalled and dismissed.

Having had enough of political ambitions and public life, he concentrated on his legal practice until his death. He is survived by his wife, two daughters and five sons.

 Abdeen Ismael, lawyer and diplomat, born 1915; died January 3 2000

fields.headline: Dobson plays the red card
fields.standfirst:
Ginger elite not amused

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: It was meant to be a witty put-down to ginger-haired broadcaster and DJ Chris Evans, who announced at the weekend he was donating £100,000 to Ken Livingstone's campaign to be mayor of London.
fields.body:
It was meant to be a witty put-down to ginger-haired broadcaster and DJ Chris Evans, who announced at the weekend he was donating £100,000 to Ken Livingstone's campaign to be mayor of London.

"I am somewhat relieved really, because my mum always told me to steer clear of redheads," Mr Livingstone's chief rival, Frank Dobson, told a press conference yesterday, as his aide and fellow MP Jim Fitzpatrick chuckled appreciatively.

But like Mr Dobson's earlier gaffe about the "toffee-nosed people" who were forced to queue for hours outside the Millennium Dome on New Year's Eve, the joke fell uncomfortably flat.

Even when asked how many red-headed voters there were in London, Labour's official candidate seemed to fail to grasp the danger of toying with superstitions about red-haired people that stretch back to ancient Egypt.

But as news of the slight reached redheads around London - a city with more than its share of flame-haired Celts - the carrot-top backlash in favour of Red Ken began in earnest.

Patsy Palmer, the actor who played Bianca in EastEnders, was apoplectic, according to her mother. Pat Palmer, who is also Patsy's spokeswoman, said neither of them were politically inclined, but Mr Dobson's slur on redheads had swung their votes for his rival, Ken Livingstone.

"Patsy's very proud of the colour of her hair. It's incredible that a politician would say such a stupid thing. Find out how many redheads there are in London and stick that up Frank Dobson's nose - they certainly won't be voting for him."

A spokeswoman for the orange-topped Charles Kennedy said the Liberal Democrat leader was "extremely proud of his ginger roots and Celtic fringe" and predicted Mr Dobson would find he had lost votes by the bucketful by offending the red-haired minority.

Redheads have had to put up with centuries of prejudice about their supposed impetuosity and untrustworthiness. Judas was reputed to have been russet-haired, and French women with red hair have even found it necessary to set up a Proud to be Red association to defend themselves.

Mr Dobson's supporters can take some comfort from the fact that estimates of London's red-haired population vary from around 10% to as little as 1%, depending on the definition of redness.

But red-haired New Labour cheerleaders - such as Simply Red frontman Mick Hucknall and European Commissioner Neil Kinnock - were keeping a low profile last night.

And the most supportive response that a friend of the ginger-haired and ginger-bearded foreign secretary, Robin Cook, could manage yesterday was: "As somebody who defended Frank Dobson's beard, Robin takes the remark in the spirit in which it was intended."

fields.headline: Alexander Young
fields.standfirst: Tenor whose interpretation of The Rake's Progress delighted Stravinsky
fields.trailText: The tenor Alexander Young, who has died aged 79, adorned both the stage and the concert platform with his skills as a tenor and an interpreter.
fields.body:
The tenor Alexander Young, who has died aged 79, adorned both the stage and the concert platform with his skills as a tenor and an interpreter. For more than 20 years he was in demand in opera as a Handelian, Mozartian and Rossinian of distinction. On the oratorio circuit he sang in all the major works from Bach to Britten, his innate musicianship and reliability seconding his silvery, keenly produced tenor. Although he was small of stature, he always held an audience's attention by virtue of the artistry of his performances.

His credentials as an interpreter of 20th-century music were established when he sang Tom Rakewell in the first performance in Britain of The Rake's Progress, on a BBC Third Programme broadcast in 1953. Eventually, he took the role on stage, when it was presented at Sadler's Wells in 1962, with Colin Davis in the pit.

Subsequently, Stravinsky chose Young to sing the title part when he recorded the work. Young caught both the raffish, and then the pathetic, side of the role in a beautifully sung and executed account. He under- took it again, for Scottish Opera, at the 1967 Edinburgh Festival.

At Sadler's Wells, he was a noted Orpheus in both Monteverdi's and Gluck's operas based on the legend, not to forget Offenbach's. In the Gluck work, he easily encompassed the high tenor part predicated by the composer's French version of his opera. In Mozart, he sang the taxing part of Belmonte, in The Seraglio, with ease and elegance. His Handel readings included Jupiter and Xerxes with the Handel Opera Society at the Wells.

But nothing there suited him better than the part of Rossini's Count Ory. His amusing, deftly sung portrayal of the libidinous Ory was a delight from start to finish. Hardly less admirable were two other Rossini parts, his Count Almaviva and his Ramiro (which he always sang opposite Patricia Kern's delightful Cinderella).

Young's sweet tone and comprehensive technique were deployed in a variety of Handel oratorios on both the concert platform and disc. In choral works by Bach, Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven, and eventually as Elgar's Gerontius, Young was always to the fore with his keen, fine and clear diction. That was also a feature of his interpretation of song. He had a large repertory of British works, many of which he committed to disc, and was also accomplished in lieder.

Young was born in London and studied at the Royal College of Music. After war service, he made his professional debut in opera as Scaramuccio, in Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos, at the 1948 Edinburgh Festival, with Thomas Beecham conducting. At Covent Garden, he made his debut as Vasek, in The Bartered Bride, in 1955.

In 1961, he undertook Gonzalve in Peter Ustinov's staging of Ravel's L'heure espagnole, and he was admired as the hapless Matteo when the Covent Garden company first gave Strauss's Arabella in 1964, conducted by Solti. The next season he sang a lyrical Lysander, in Britten's A Midsummer Night's Dream. Abroad, he sang Almaviva and David (Die Meistersinger) in San Francisco and Los Angeles in 1965.

In retirement, Young became head of vocal studies of the Royal Northern College of Music, from 1973-86. He is survived by his wife, a son and a daughter.

In choral works by Bach, Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven, and eventually as Elgar's Gerontius, Young was always to the fore with his keen, fine and clear diction. That was also a feature of his interpretation of song. He had a large repertory of British works, many of which he committed to disc, and was also accomplished in lieder. Young was born in London and studied at the Royal College of Music. After war service, he made his professional debut in opera as Scaramuccio, in Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos, at the 1948 Edinburgh Festival, with Thomas Beecham conducting. At Covent Garden, he made his debut as Vasek, in The Bartered Bride, in 1955. In 1961, he undertook Gonzalve in Peter Ustinov's staging of Ravel's L'heure espagnole, and he was admired as the hapless Matteo when the Covent Garden company first gave Strauss's Arabella in 1964, conducted by Solti. The next season he sang a lyrical Lysander, in Britten's A Midsummer Night's Dream. Abroad, he sang Almaviva and David (Die Meistersinger) in San Francisco and Los Angeles in 1965. In retirement, Young became head of vocal studies of the Royal Northern College of Music, from 1973-86. He is survived by his wife, a son and a daughter.  Alexander Young, tenor, born October 18 1920; died March 5 2000

fields.headline: Harry Webster
fields.trailText: The theatrical pedigree of the genial Dubliner Harry Webster, who has died aged 84, went back to the Abbey Theatre of Sean O'Casey and WB Yeats, and to gruelling and fun days of the pre-television touring theatre that enlivened Irish rural life. One of life's natural character actors, he came to London in the mid-1950s and was regularly in work until a few years before his death.
fields.body:
The theatrical pedigree of the genial Dubliner Harry Webster, who has died aged 84, went back to the Abbey Theatre of Sean O'Casey and WB Yeats, and to gruelling and fun days of the pre-television touring theatre that enlivened Irish rural life. One of life's natural character actors, he came to London in the mid-1950s and was regularly in work until a few years before his death.

Born into a professional family, Harry was lost to the medical profession when the Dublin college of surgeons sent him, as a student, to the Abbey Theatre to learn communications skills. He then shared a small house with Cyril Cusack, Denis O'Dea and Liam Redmond.

Having toured America in repertory, he worked with John Ford in Hollywood. Back in Europe, he worked with director Carol Reed in the Ireland-based James Mason thriller, Odd Man Out.

The raw stage remained his first love. His companionship backstage became as valuable to the company's morale as his dependability on stage. He helped nervous newcomers with stage anecdotes - such as how he spent a day in a pub with Laurence Olivier. He toured frequently, notably in the 1960s production of Brendan Behan's The Hostage, in which he played Pat, the brothel-keeper, a role he compared to that of a theatre manager.

In between tours and film stints, he lived for many years in a small flat in Notting Hill Gate, west London, where he helped found the Gate Theatre in 1980. At his wake, held at the Gate, and attended by the likes of Stephen Rea, David Halli-well and Brenda Fricker, a favourite line of Harry's was read, from the poet FR Higgins: "With whom he is one under yew branches/ In a graven silence no bird breaks."

fields.headline: Cab Kaye
fields.standfirst: Musician who enlivened the British jazz scene and rediscovered his African roots
fields.trailText: Cab Kaye, who has died aged 78, was an exciting jazz performer whose significance went further than the ability to deliver an effervescent song while playing stride piano in the style of a latter-day Fats Waller.
fields.body:
Cab Kaye, who has died aged 78, was an exciting jazz performer whose significance went further than the ability to deliver an effervescent song while playing stride piano in the style of a latter-day Fats Waller. A singer with echoes of Billie Holiday in his voice, he also played guitar and drums, travelling widely during an extraordinary life, yet never losing his place in the British jazz psyche. His presence served as a link between the local jazz community and the music's African past.

He was born in St Giles High Street, an area where London's black West-enders congregated after the first world war, when his mother, a music-hall artist, married Caleb Jonas Kwamlah Quaye, an African drummer from the then Gold Coast. Known professionally as Mope Desmond, Quaye worked with American musicians such as the clarinet virtuoso Sidney Bechet, but his two children never knew him. He died in a rail accident when Cab was four months old, and the family moved to Portsmouth.

Kaye's African pedigree resonated with music. His paternal grandfather had been the organist at Accra's Methodist church; his great-grandfather played drums for a company of Asafo warriors.

Kaye himself started in showbusiness as a teenager. At 14, he frequented the Shim Sham and the Nest, nightclubs that welcomed black entertainers, and got to know such figures as the American trombonist Ellis Jackson, who worked with Billy Cotton's showband. Cotton hired the youngster to sing, their recording of Shoe Shine Boy launching his career. At 18, he married Theresa Austin, the daughter of a Barbadian seaman, who sang with his later bands. Their three children include noted guitarist Caleb and singer/percussionist Terri Quaye.

The onset of the Blitz found Cab singing and sharing Ivor Kirchin's drumseat at Tottenham Court Road's Paramount dancehall, with Steve Race on piano; later, he joined Ken "Snakehips" Johnson's West Indians at the Café de Paris. Military service saved him from the bomb that fell on the café, killing Johnson, but he was injured while in the Merchant Navy. Shipwrecked and torpedoed, he was then badly hurt in a plane crash, necessitating an operation in New York. While recuperating, he played with an extraordinary roll-call of jazzmen, including the trumpeter Roy Eldridge,

In 1946, with Leslie "Jiver" Hutchinson's band, Kaye travelled to India to entertain the forces, returning to play host at Feldman's Sunday Oxford Street sessions, introducing Jamaican arrivants, such as saxophonists George Tyndale and Sammy Walker, to an audience eager for new jazz ideas. To African seamen who went to Feldman's to dance, Kaye was a totem, an admired fellow-African. He occupied a similarly inspira tional role for burgeoning local modernists like Ronnie Scott and bebop guru Dennis Rose, both of whom played in his band.

Kaye worked and recorded with many prominent jazz musicians and dance bands - including Tito Burns and Ted Heath - but often employed fellow black Britons. In 1953, he formed a double-act with the singer/dancer Josie Woods, and led a trio with the Liverpudlian drummer Tommy Jones and Trinidadian bassist Brylo Forde. During a long stay in Holland, Kaye met Charlie Parker, then established himself in Paris, where he became a regular at the fabled Ringside Club.

Through increasing contact with the new black settlers, Kaye's confidence, and sense of himself as an African, developed, and he dropped his anglicised stage-name. At home in East Finchley, he would dress in Ghanaian kente cloth and, although he never used it professionally, revived his Ga name, Nii-lante.

When Ghana achieved independence, Kaye was working with Erie Delaney and Humphrey Lyttelton. He was soon offered a post as entertainments manager in his father's homeland, although the job ended abruptly when the country's first ruler, Kwame Nkrumah, was deposed. A Nigerian sojourn followed, interspersed with a 1964 visit to New York; then, in 1970, Kaye returned to Britain with Evelyn, his Nigerian wife.

In London, he attempted to rekindle the excitement of an earlier era, but encountered changes. He found a happier mileu in Amsterdam, where he opened a piano bar, and, in 1979, remarried. He is survived by his third wife, Jeanette, and their three children; the three children of his first marriage and another son, the singer Finley Quaye.

 Augustus Kwamlah (Nii-lante) Quaye, singer, pianist, entertainer, born September 3 1921; died March 13 2000

fields.headline: Kenneth Hudson
fields.standfirst: Intrepid champion of industrial archaeology
fields.trailText: "I think we've appointed a one-off," said a BBC editor after Kenneth Hudson, who has died aged 83, was made the corporation's first Bristol-based industrial correspondent at the beginning of the 1960s - and that he proved to be.
fields.body:
"I think we've appointed a one-off," said a BBC editor after Kenneth Hudson, who has died aged 83, was made the corporation's first Bristol-based industrial correspondent at the beginning of the 1960s - and that he proved to be. Until then a BBC talks producer, Hudson went on to write 54 books, virtually invent industrial archaeology and become internationally known for his influence on museums.

For long director of the European Museum Forum, set up under the auspices of the Council of Europe in 1977, he became its president last November. He was still on the jury of the European Museum of the Year award. By encouraging the competitive enhancement of museums and enlarging the recorded history of industry, its buildings and products, he won a Europe-wide reputation.

"There should be more to that than steam trains," he said - but then 30 years ago, industrial archaeology did not extend much further. For its first two years, Hudson was editor of the Journal of Industrial Archaeology - at a time when electricity, plastics and early computers were having an impact worth recording. Universities would create academic departments in recognition of the idea of industrial archaeology but, even in the 70s, Hudson's call "not to forget the 20th century" was needed.

As a talks producer in the 1950s, he worked on Woman's Hour and produced an early Reith lecture series with Sir Leon Bagrit - then wrote a book with him. He saw his role as industrial correspondent as reporting "the good things of industry, not the bad" - covering strikes was not to his taste. In 1966, he left the BBC to enlarge closed-circuit television in Bath's new university. His books spanned the industrial history of southern England, the industrial archaeology of Europe, a Cambridge guide to the museums of Europe, ship wrecks, biography, a history of the Bath and West agricultural show and a study of the postwar growth of Swindon.

Hudson had begun with a degree from the extra-mural department of Bristol University, plus a linguistic talent that extended to Anglo Saxon. His awards included the OBE; he was too busy to get to Buckingham Palace and received it by post in 1996. He is survived by his wife Hope, a son and two daughters.

 Kenneth Hudson, writer, born July 4 1916; died December 28 1999

webTitle: French take aim at lax gun laws

fields.headline: French take aim at lax gun laws
fields.trailText: The French parliament has sent a fact-finding mission to Britain to gauge the success of gun control measures introduced after the Dunblane massacre because a shocking report suggests that as many as 20m firearms may be in circulation in the country.
fields.body:
The French parliament has sent a fact-finding mission to Britain to gauge the success of gun control measures introduced after the Dunblane massacre because a shocking report suggests that as many as 20m firearms may be in circulation in the country.

According to new figures from the interior ministry, more than a fifth of all French households now possess at least one firearm. The probability of murder or manslaughter in such homes is four times higher than the national average, while suicides are five times more likely.

"It is only a matter of time before France witnesses an American or a Dunblane-style schoolyard massacre," said Bruno Le Roux, an MP who has tabled a bill which aims to simplify the country's complex and tangled firearms legislation. "It is an issue that has to be addressed immediately, before it is too late."

Of some 1,000 murders committed in France each year, about half involve firearms. Police are particularly alarmed by the ease with which young people obtain guns: a survey of 1,171 high-risk housing estates last year showed the number of fatal shootings involving teenagers had doubled to 16 since 1993, while the number of injuries from pistols, rifles and shotguns rose by 100 to 247.

"Firearms are quite clearly far, far too easy to get hold of for far too many kids," said Gilles Laffont, a Paris police inspector. "There is an urgent need for us to revise our gun laws, especially so that we can keep some kind of track of the weapons that change hands each year."

The concern among police and parliamentarians follows some recent grisly armed killings involving young people.

Abdelraouf Hassouna, a 20-year-old from Paris suburb of Créteil, was hit in the back at point-blank range by two shots from a pump-action shotgun after he ventured on to a neighbouring estate to retrieve a stolen moped.

In another incident, a 15-year-old shot dead a tobacconist because she refused to sell him a packet of cigarettes, and two boys aged 16 and 17 killed a classmate in Marseille. They told police they had executed their victim, identified only as Marc, because he had teased one of them about a former girlfriend.

Mr Le Roux wants the dozen or so decrees and directives that govern the sale of guns in France - including some which date back to the early 1900s - unified into a single piece of legislation.

Anti-firearm campaigners have long complained that France's outdated gun laws, which classify firearms into eight largely redundant categories, are so complex that even gun merchants do not understand them.

The confusion has allowed gun ownership to flourish almost unrestricted in France. According to the interior ministry figures, for example, some 140,000 people own firearms because they belong to shooting clubs, whereas the French Shooting Federation recognises only 40,000 active members.

Similarly, France's 1.6m hunters over the age of 16 are entitled to buy guns on presentation of their identity papers. Hunting rifles and shotguns are now involved in 82% of all armed crimes - from murder to robbery - committed in France.

Mr Le Roux's proposed legislation, due to be debated before parliament's summer recess, will also oblige gun owners who bought their weapon legally to notify authorities whenever it it is sold, stolen or destroyed - in the same way as car owners must register the status of their vehicles.

"Pump-action shotguns were banned in France in 1998, 20 years after it became clear they were a serious threat to society," the MP said. "There is now a whole range of firearms on open sale that are equally dangerous. We cannot, yet, ban guns outright like in England - but are we going to have to wait for a catastrophe before we wake up?"
