webTitle: Backlash at young pupils for inventing sex claims

fields.headline: Backlash at young pupils for inventing sex claims
fields.standfirst: Teacher goes from villain to hero as harassment tale proves false
fields.trailText: A new issue is catching fire in American schools - a fear of pre-teenage girls who make false accusations of sexual harassment against teachers.
fields.body:
A new issue is catching fire in American schools - a fear of pre-teenage girls who make false accusations of sexual harassment against teachers.

The case which has made this the latest panic issue in the US is that of a sports teacher, Ronald Heller, 54, who nearly lost his job and his reputation when six children aged 11 and 12 accused him of touching them.

Five weeks ago, Mr Heller, described by colleagues as a disciplinarian of the old school who has taught sports and physical education for 32 years, was called to the principal's office in his school at Germantown in Maryland. He was told that the six girls and one boy, all aged 11 and 12, had named him in written accusations of sexual molestation.

The allegations said that Mr Heller had been seen several times in the girls' changing rooms, that he had hugged one girl in her underwear, had slapped another on her behind and had addressed another as a "hot sexy momma".

"I did not do this," Mr Heller told authorities at Roberto Clemente middle school. "This is a lie." But he was suspended immediately on full pay and given 15 minutes to leave the premises. No one from the school was allowed to talk to him, and he had to get police permission whenever he wanted to leave his home.

For nearly a month, Mr Heller lived under virtual house arrest, while his child accusers stuck to their stories in interviews with investigators. Finally, two weeks ago, the boy confessed that all the tales had been invented. The six girl accusers then recanted one by one.

This was the point at which Mr Heller's experience went from being just another sad local ordeal to become an American national phenomenon.

Last Tuesday, Mr Heller was fully exonerated and was reinstated in his job. He returned to an avalanche of flowers, cards, e-mails, letters and greetings from colleagues.

That was just the start. Within a couple of days, Mr Heller had become a national celebrity victim. Newspapers and TV stations from around the US began to cover the case - and Mr Heller got the ultimate accolade: being interviewed on NBC's Today breakfast programme by the most popular TV host in the US, Katie Couric.

At the same time Mr Heller has found himself at the centre of an outcry from teachers who fear that any physical contact, like a comforting arm around the shoulders, may become a career-threatening mistake. The Maryland state teachers' union says that not a day goes by without a false sexual accusation being made against one of its members.

The outpouring of sympathy for Mr Heller is matched by the public vindictiveness directed at his young accusers. Last week, the six girls were arrested by police and charged with making false statements. All the girls and the boy have been suspended from school.

Radio call-in shows in Maryland and elsewhere have taken dozens of calls from people calling for revenge against Mr Heller's accusers. The Germantown school's e-mail system has been flooded with attacks on the children involved.

"We're not going to put them in jail," said Douglas Gansler of the state prosecutor's office. "But we're going to seek some form of community service, perhaps having them work with sexual assault victims so they understand what it is they've accused this teacher of."

Asked what lessons he draws, Mr Heller's answer yesterday was sober. "Never be alone with a student. Always keep the door open if you're in an office. And try to have another student there with you, or an adult."

webTitle: German party barons pick a woman to save them

fields.headline: German party barons pick a woman to save them
fields.standfirst: Conservatives see easterner Angela Merkel as Ms Clean
fields.trailText: After months of hesitation, the bosses of Germany's embattled conservatives yesterday grasped the nettle, choosing as their preferred nominee for party leader a woman representing a radical break with the past.
fields.body:
After months of hesitation, the bosses of Germany's embattled conservatives yesterday grasped the nettle, choosing as their preferred nominee for party leader a woman representing a radical break with the past.

Angela Merkel's endorsement by the executive of the Christian Democrat Union (CDU), assures her of winning the party chairmanship at a conference next month. An executive member said that the final vote was unanimous.

Ms Merkel, 45, breaks the mould of Germany's main opposition party in important ways. She is a woman in a movement overwhelmingly dominated by men: only one in six of the MPs representing the CDU and its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), is a woman.

She is also a protestant - the daughter of a pastor - in a movement in thrall to Roman Catholics since the second world war.

And she is an easterner - the epitome of an "Ossi", with her disregard for image and glamour. Frequently she appears as party secretary general in public sporting baggy trousers and without a dab of make-up, though she put on lipstick and a suit yesterday.

For 25 years, until 1998, the CDU was led by Helmut Kohl, chancellor from 1982 to 1998. His era only really ended last month when his chosen successor, Wolfgang Schäuble, announced he was leaving to give the party a "new start".

Ms Merkel promises just that. As far as anybody knows, she is free of involvement in the interlocking power and party funding scandals that ruined Mr Kohl's reputation and destroyed Mr Schäuble's career. One of her supporters among younger conservative leaders, Christian Wulff, recently listed her qualities as "authenticity, credibility and truthfulness".

Her homely, unassuming manner is wholly at variance with the testosterone-fuelled arrogance and vigour of Mr Kohl. Comparisons were being drawn yesterday with the rise of Margaret Thatcher but in many respects Angela Merkel is more of a John Major. She has already given up the key that let Mr Kohl and Mr Schäuble ride the lift to the chairman's office without having to meet party workers.

The irony is that Ms Merkel's rise was as a Kohl protegee. After reunification in 1990, he put her in his cabinet although her only experience of high office was as spokeswoman for East Germany's first freely elected government.

But as evidence mounted of the sleaze Mr Kohl had tolerated she became the first leading Christian Democrat to break the taboo of loyalty to Mr Kohl. At first she was repudiated by the party barons.

But the tide of voter approval for her stand could scarcely be ignored by a party haemorrhaging support. In a call-in poll organised this month by the hugely influential tabloid, Bild, Ms Merkel got the support of almost two-thirds of those who took part. Her sole rival, Volker Rühe, stood down soon after.

webTitle: Security fears dog start of Clinton tour

fields.headline: Security fears dog start of Clinton tour
fields.trailText: The first visit by a US president to Bangladesh turned into an embarrassment yesterday as security officials cancelled two showcase events because of an apparent threat from Islamic extremists.
fields.byline: Luke Harding  and  Arshad Mahmud  in Dhaka
fields.body:
The first visit by a US president to Bangladesh turned into an embarrassment yesterday as security officials cancelled two showcase events because of an apparent threat from Islamic extremists.

President Clinton, on the first leg of his tour of south Asia, called off a trip to the village of Joypura, where he had intended to highlight attempts to improve life in rural Bangladesh. Following the cancellation, many of the villagers were driven to Dhaka where they met the president.

Playing host to Mr Clinton was Bangladesh's prime minister, Sheikh Hasina Wajed, with whom the president held 40 minutes of talks.

Mr Clinton signed two lucrative contracts to exploit Bangladesh's vast gas reserves and announced an aid package covering food, clean energy and forest preservation.

Sheikh Hasina urged the US to extradite three renegade army officers convicted two years ago of assassinating her father, Bangladesh's independence leader Sheikh Mujibur Rahman. The 1975 coup also claimed the lives of most of the prime minister's family.

The White House national security adviser Sandy Berger said said Mr Clinton told the prime minister the cases were pending in the American legal system and suggested the US and Bangladesh negotiate an extradition treaty to speed up such matters.

Mr Clinton further dismayed his hosts by cancelling a visit to a mausoleum outside the capital, where he had been due to lay a wreath to Bangladeshi soldiers who died in the 1971 war of independence from Pakistan.

The president arrived in Delhi last night for a five-day tour of India, which begins today with talks with the prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Six held over shooting in Iran
fields.body:
Six held over shooting in Iran

Six men have been arrested over the shooting of the reformer Saeed Hajjarian on March 12, Iran's Supreme National Security Council announced yesterday.

The council said one of the men had confessed. There was no indication of the suspects' identities.

Mr Hajjarian, 46, an adviser to President Mohammed Khatami, was in a coma following the shooting, but has since regained consciousness. AP, Tehran

Ex-paramilitary leader killed

A prominent underworld figure was shot dead in front of a Belgrade hotel yesterday in the latest in a series of gangland-style killings, Beta news agency reported.

Branislav Lainovic was believed to control the crime network in the city of Novi Sad. He was also a former commander of the Serb Guard, a paramilitary group. AP, Belgrade

New president for Senegal

Thousands took to the streets of Senegal's capital after the president, Abdou Diouf, conceded defeat yesterday to Abdoulaye Wade, of the Senegalese Democratic party, following the election at the weekend.

Mr Diouf's Socialist party had been in power since independence from France in 1960. AP, Dakar

Mourning by mobile

A woman unable to travel from Greece to a village west of Tbilisi attended her father's funeral by mobile phone, Georgian newspapers said yesterday.

The woman placed a call to a mobile phone which was hooked up to a speaker and performed a ritual in which relatives scold the deceased for abandoning them. Reuters, Tbilisi

webTitle: Uganda asks why cult was still legal

fields.headline: Uganda asks why cult was still legal
fields.trailText: Seventy-eight children burnt to death in the apparent mass suicide by members of the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God cult in western Uganda, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Seventy-eight children burnt to death in the apparent mass suicide by members of the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God cult in western Uganda, it emerged yesterday.

The inspector general of police, John Kisembo, said 330 bodies had been counted, 78 of them children, and there were more to recover. Mr Kisembo said he believed the final toll from Friday's fire could reach 400, most of them women who made up the bulk of the cult followers.

But counting the dead is next to impossible. The bodies have been charred beyond recognition and many have been reduced to ash. Only two have so far been identified: one of the cult leaders and the manager of the church farm.

Police have also discovered five decomposing corpses in a pit latrine in a building in the church compound.

Labourers have begun digging a mass grave for all the dead, and the burial will take place today. District officials will then have to decide what to do with extensive church grounds, including banana plantations, grazing cattle and classrooms for the children of cult followers. Cult leaders deposited the title deeds with local authorities last week.

It is still not known for certain if all the leaders of the cult were among the dead. However, police believe that the overall head of the movement, self-styled prophet Joseph Kibwitere, probably died along with his four principle aides - two defrocked Roman Catholic priests and two former nuns.

Mr Kibwitere - a former Roman Catholic religious teacher, aged 68 - was at the church all last week. He reportedly wrote a letter to his wife on the day before the fire, asking her to carry on his work, because "we are going to perish".

His group, which was established in the late 1980s, had long preached the end of the world in 2000, and predicted there would be a new generation who would live on an earth "where sorrow and misery are absent".

The events leading up to the killings are still emerging, but there is a consensus that cult members were preparing to die. A number of followers from branches across western Uganda were bussed in to the camp in recent days. Members sold off property at very low prices, and some told family and friends that on March 17 the Holy Spirit was coming to take them to heaven.

Police said there was only one eyewitness, a woman who was visiting her mother at the church headquarters. The woman said she saw some of the children leave the church to play, but the leaders herded them back inside the building. She then heard an explosion and shouts, and ran out to find the church burning. She told police she peered through one of the boarded up windows and saw "people in agony".

Uganda has cracked down on cult activity in recent years, and in 1999 banned two cults, claiming they were a danger to themselves and to their followers. However, the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God appears to have slipped through the net - largely because it had done everything above board.

The group was registered as a non-governmental organisation and received funding from individuals as far afield as Australia and Italy. Members were liked by the local community who described them as polite and disciplined. By the time of the fire the group had an estimated 4,000 members in branches across western Uganda.

The internal affairs minister, Edward Rugamayo, said the government would be reviewing registration of all religious groups.

webTitle: Waco reconstruction clears us, claims FBI

fields.headline: Waco reconstruction clears us, claims FBI
fields.trailText: FBI officials said yesterday that an elaborate weekend simulation of the end of the 1993 Waco siege substantiated consistent US government claims that nobody fired at members of the Branch Davidian sect as their ranch compound burned to the ground seven years ago, killing up to 80 men, women and children.
fields.body:
FBI officials said yesterday that an elaborate weekend simulation of the end of the 1993 Waco siege substantiated consistent US government claims that nobody fired at members of the Branch Davidian sect as their ranch compound burned to the ground seven years ago, killing up to 80 men, women and children.

But lawyers for relatives of the Davidians drew precisely the opposite conclusion: they said the film of the reconstruction showed just the contrary of the FBI interpretation.

They repeated their long-standing accusation that the reason everybody in the sect complex perished at the end of the 51-day siege was that US government agents fired at the compound, preventing escape.

The claims are at the centre of a legal and political controversy between relatives and supporters of the Davidians - who contend that the FBI, and by implication the Clinton administration, have the victims' blood on their hands - and the US government, which says that the deaths at Waco on April 19 1993 were caused by some Davidians who were bent on an apocalyptic end. The long siege had started on February 28 when federal agents arrived at the complex to arrest the sect leader, David Koresh, on weapons charges.

To try to resolve the opposing claims a federal judge ordered a unique simulation exercise. It took place on Sunday at the largest military base in the US, Fort Hood in Texas. Lawyers for both sides were there, along with special investigators and government and FBI officials.

The three-hour exercise was conducted far from the public gaze but reports say it involved eight US army marksmen firing a variety of weapons from various positions in a debris strewn area of the base that had been arranged to approximate to the Branch Davidian compound at Waco, Texas, at the time of the siege.

As the soldiers fired their weapons, they were recorded by a hired Royal Navy Lynx helicopter equipped with heat-sensing infra-red cameras identical to those with which the FBI recorded the original siege. The exercises were repeated four times, officials said.

Flashes recorded on the original video are at the heart of the Davidian camp's assertion that the FBI fired more than tear gas into the compound in 1993. The question is whether the flashes reveal people, heated debris, sunlight reflections or shots.

While the FBI and the Davidian relatives differ on what the reconstruction proved, a British specialist company has the job of making an independent finding. Vector Data Systems Ltd of Peterborough is meant to complete its analysis within 30 days.

Its conclusions will play a key role in two separate proceedings arising out of the Waco siege - a civil damages suit brought by the relatives against the US government, which goes to court on May 15; and the official inquiry into the ending of the siege, which is taking place under a former Republican senator, John Dan forth of Missouri. It was he who asked for the simulation.

Infrared experts from both sides of the argument have been given the preliminary evidence - probably including digital copies of the tapes - from Sunday's exercise.

The FBI side was the first to make a public claim yesterday that the exercise had vindicated its position that no shots were fired. "We are very pleased with the results we have seen so far," said Mike Bradford, one of the government legal team in the case.

"There are some particular matters that we think are important in confirming our position," he continued. "And we believe we will clearly demonstrate that, through the comparison of these materials to the tapes."

Lawyers for the Branch Davidian side responded by sticking to their version of events. The new video "clearly supports" the case made by the relatives, lawyer Michael Caddell said in Houston, insisting: "It clearly demonstrates that there was government gunfire."

fields.headline: The truth laid bare
fields.standfirst:
Edmund White was one of the first gay writers to explore his sexuality explicitly in fiction. His latest book details the death of his lover from Aids and, as Stephen Moss finds, he remains disarmingly honest
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Edmund White was one of the first gay writers to explore his sexuality explicitly in fiction. His latest book details the death of his lover from Aids and, as Stephen Moss finds, he remains disarmingly honest.
fields.body:
Edmund White's books deal with the great issues - life, death, art, love, guilt. He has immortalised his life and loves in print, chronicled a gay generation annihilated by Aids, and likened himself to the final musician left on stage "still squeaking away on my violin". You might expect a tortured soul; you would be wrong.

White is charming, modest, matter of fact: an intellectual with rare patience; a teacher (professor of creative writing at Princeton) always ready to listen. He ponders the anonymity of writers in New York, where he now lives, and the press attention they get in London, and says it's because Britain has so few film stars. The absence of ego may account for the strength of his work: he does not seek to judge but to report.

When White's novel, The Farewell Symphony, appeared in 1997, the irresistible hook in all the interviews was that the narrator (clearly based on White himself) had had sex with 3,120 men. This was held up as some sort of defining fact, but White simply mocked the figure - "Is it enough?" - and implied that three partners a week over 20 years wasn't really so shocking. It is typical of his disarming style: his subject matter can be raw and painful - his new novel, The Married Man, details the death of his lover from Aids - but he refuses to emote.

The novel is a memorial to a young French architect called Hubert Sorin, who died in 1994. The odd fact has been altered, but in essence the novel records their life together in Paris and the US, and Sorin's death in Morocco. White was diagnosed as HIV positive in 1985, and Sorin moved in with him in 1989 believing he would have to nurse him through his inevitable decline. But White did not decline - he knows now that he has a rare non-progressive form of the infection and his condition is stable. Instead, Sorin was diagnosed as having Aids (not contracted from White) and it was the author who had to do the nursing over the five years they lived together.

But why novelise what is so obviously a memoir? "This is a terribly personal book," says White, "but I found that by writing in the third person I was able to look at myself in a more satirical way. When you write in the first person, you're expected to be presenting a kind of apology for your life. People assume that this is you at your best, as though you are St Augustine showing your progress towards your present point of moral superiority, whereas in fact you have a fairly rounded and satirical view of yourself. The third person gets you off the hook; it makes it seem as if you're writing about someone out there, objectively."

That remorseless truth-telling is typical of White. "There will be people who say The Married Man deals with Hubert harshly," he says, "but I felt that if I didn't deal with him honestly, it wouldn't be a good book. So much of the Aids literature I've read is lachrymose and sentimental, with the couple shown as very noble from beginning to end. There is that side to Julien [Hubert's name in the novel], but there's also a lot of anger, which to me seems normal to someone who is in his early 30s, terribly ambitious and has his life taken away."

White, who is 60, is now so well established, and gay writing so much a part of the literary landscape, that it is easy to overlook the struggle that characterised the early part of his career. He was one of the first gay writers - Christopher Isherwood was his hero and literary role model - to want explicitly to explore his sexuality in fiction. But he suffered more than 20 years of frustration before the publication of his breakthrough book, A Boy's Own Story, in 1983.

"I wanted to write about gay life, but people didn't want to publish it," he says. "I wrote a number of books that still exist in my archive at Yale, which were never published. But I think they were rejected not because they were low in literary quality but because they were so explicitly gay."

Is there a danger that, as a writer of gay fiction, he might be marginalised? "I had already published two avant-garde artistic novels when I started writing gay fiction, and people said to me, 'Oh, you're going to ruin your career.' I remember reading a Paris Review interview with Saul Bellow in which he said that when he first started writing Jewish fiction all of his friends told him the same thing - nobody wants to read about Jews, it's too small, you should write about universal themes."

White worked as a journalist and editor in the 60s and 70s (he wrote The Joy of Gay Sex and a book called States of Desire about America's gay communities), and lived the cruisy gay life in New York documented in The Beautiful Room is Empty and The Farewell Symphony. Those books are, in part, elegies to a pre-Aids world, but he defends the hedonism of those times.

"It was very mandarin in one way - dedicated to the highest, most abstract notion of culture - but it was also highly sexual," he says. "New York in the 70s was like the last gasp of the old bohemian spirit. People weren't materialistic; they were interested in the idea of living in a cold-water flat and being a great artist. I wanted to show that cultured world, too - people who were intellectual but also very sexual. The stereotype is that you are either one or the other, but you can be both."

White's trilogy - A Boy's Own Story, The Beautiful Room is Empty, and The Farewell Symphony - is an attempt to record the history of a gay culture (he once called himself "Everyfag"). He is, against all the odds, a survivor, and feels it is his duty to honour the generation wiped out by Aids. "I believe that in another 20 years someone will sit down to write the history of New York in the 70s, and it will turn out to be one of the great periods of creativity in American life. Gays played an enormous role in that and sexual licence was part of the package."

Does he feel guilty that he lived? "People who are HIV positive don't have much survivor guilt," he says. "They feel that they are going to be victims soon enough. But now that I seem to have entered this category of non-progressives, I do feel some degree of guilt. It's also hard not to feel numb, and the worst thing for a writer is to feel numb. Your natural tendency is to want to forget; but your deepest sense of duty and obligation is to history and to the people you knew and loved."

 The Married Man is published by Chatto & Windus at £16.99.

The odd fact has been altered, but in essence the novel records their life together in Paris and the US, and Sorin's death in Morocco. White was diagnosed as HIV positive in 1985, and Sorin moved in with him in 1989 believing he would have to nurse him through his inevitable decline. But White did not decline - he knows now that he has a rare non-progressive form of the infection and his condition is stable. Instead, Sorin was diagnosed as having Aids (not contracted from White) and it was the author who had to do the nursing over the five years they lived together. But why novelise what is so obviously a memoir? "This is a terribly personal book," says White, "but I found that by writing in the third person I was able to look at myself in a more satirical way. When you write in the first person, you're expected to be presenting a kind of apology for your life. People assume that this is you at your best, as though you are St Augustine showing your progress towards your present point of moral superiority, whereas in fact you have a fairly rounded and satirical view of yourself. The third person gets you off the hook; it makes it seem as if you're writing about someone out there, objectively." That remorseless truth-telling is typical of White. "There will be people who say The Married Man deals with Hubert harshly," he says, "but I felt that if I didn't deal with him honestly, it wouldn't be a good book. So much of the Aids literature I've read is lachrymose and sentimental, with the couple shown as very noble from beginning to end. There is that side to Julien [Hubert's name in the novel], but there's also a lot of anger, which to me seems normal to someone who is in his early 30s, terribly ambitious and has his life taken away." White, who is 60, is now so well established, and gay writing so much a part of the literary landscape, that it is easy to overlook the struggle that characterised the early part of his career. He was one of the first gay writers - Christopher Isherwood was his hero and literary role model - to want explicitly to explore his sexuality in fiction. But he suffered more than 20 years of frustration before the publication of his breakthrough book, A Boy's Own Story, in 1983. "I wanted to write about gay life, but people didn't want to publish it," he says. "I wrote a number of books that still exist in my archive at Yale, which were never published. But I think they were rejected not because they were low in literary quality but because they were so explicitly gay." Is there a danger that, as a writer of gay fiction, he might be marginalised? "I had already published two avant-garde artistic novels when I started writing gay fiction, and people said to me, 'Oh, you're going to ruin your career.' I remember reading a Paris Review interview with Saul Bellow in which he said that when he first started writing Jewish fiction all of his friends told him the same thing - nobody wants to read about Jews, it's too small, you should write about universal themes." White worked as a journalist and editor in the 60s and 70s (he wrote The Joy of Gay Sex and a book called States of Desire about America's gay communities), and lived the cruisy gay life in New York documented in The Beautiful Room is Empty and The Farewell Symphony. Those books are, in part, elegies to a pre-Aids world, but he defends the hedonism of those times. "It was very mandarin in one way - dedicated to the highest, most abstract notion of culture - but it was also highly sexual," he says. "New York in the 70s was like the last gasp of the old bohemian spirit. People weren't materialistic; they were interested in the idea of living in a cold-water flat and being a great artist. I wanted to show that cultured world, too - people who were intellectual but also very sexual. The stereotype is that you are either one or the other, but you can be both." White's trilogy - A Boy's Own Story, The Beautiful Room is Empty, and The Farewell Symphony - is an attempt to record the history of a gay culture (he once called himself "Everyfag"). He is, against all the odds, a survivor, and feels it is his duty to honour the generation wiped out by Aids. "I believe that in another 20 years someone will sit down to write the history of New York in the 70s, and it will turn out to be one of the great periods of creativity in American life. Gays played an enormous role in that and sexual licence was part of the package." Does he feel guilty that he lived? "People who are HIV positive don't have much survivor guilt," he says. "They feel that they are going to be victims soon enough. But now that I seem to have entered this category of non-progressives, I do feel some degree of guilt. It's also hard not to feel numb, and the worst thing for a writer is to feel numb. Your natural tendency is to want to forget; but your deepest sense of duty and obligation is to history and to the people you knew and loved."  The Married Man is published by Chatto & Windus at £16.99.

webTitle: Timely move: Booming French Connection sets sights on watches

fields.headline: Timely move: Booming French Connection sets sights on watches
fields.trailText: French Connection silenced critics of its controversial Fcuk advertising campaign yesterday by posting a 52% increase in pre-tax profits and announcing plans for a big increase in spending on marketing.
fields.body:
French Connection silenced critics of its controversial Fcuk advertising campaign yesterday by posting a 52% increase in pre-tax profits and announcing plans for a big increase in spending on marketing.

With new year sales up a further 10%, the fashion retailer will spend $2.5m (£1.6m) this year compared to $1.5m last time, while promising that a new campaign in the autumn will surprise everyone.

The French Connection brand will also be stretched later this year with a move into watches through a partnership with Timex - already having established a successful line in spectacles.

The company's commitment to jumbled marketing lines, such as "sex my football or with mates girlfriend with my" is one of the reasons why profits hit the £15.8m mark, according to chairman and chief executive Stephen Marks, pictured above at the Kensington store during a big refit.

Business has been booming particularly in the United States, where profits rose 130% on the back of a near 60% increase in sales. North American operations were also boosted by the opening of its Nicole Farhi brand flagship store in New York.

French Connection also made its first foray into continental Europe with the December opening of a Cologne branch and is looking at other sites in Germany as well as opening in Paris before the end of this year.

Mr Marks said: "We are making French Connection a global brand with one message. We used to have one or two outlets in the US through department stores such as Bloomingdales - now we have 54 there."

French Connection has only been using advertising heavily for 18 months but its Fcuk slogan, the brainchild of Trevor Beattie's advertising agency TBWA GGT Simons Palmer has had mixed reactions.

In a summary trial last December to prevent a consultant using the website name fcuk.com, the judge described the Fcuk campaign as tasteless and obnoxious. He refused to give an injunction.

Yesterday shares soared by about 7.5% in early trading and closed up 75p at 875p.

Joan Dollier, retail analyst at Deutsche Bank, said it all looked promising for French Connection and she is pencilling in profits of £18.5m for the current 12 months.

Last year turnover rose from £117.3m to £156m, while operating margins in the 12 months ending 31 January 2000 increased to 10.4%. Earnings per share rose from 34.0p to 47.4p while the dividend was increased 29% to 5.50p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
BNFL plans to cut jobs
About a third of the 4,500 jobs at the Atomic Weapons Establishment plants at Aldermaston and Burghfield in Berkshire could go under the new management due to take over on April 1, according to trade unions.
fields.body:
BNFL plans to cut jobs
About a third of the 4,500 jobs at the Atomic Weapons Establishment plants at Aldermaston and Burghfield in Berkshire could go under the new management due to take over on April 1, according to trade unions.

BNFL and US aerospace company Lockheed Martin are expected to cut 400 jobs in the first six months under a Ministry of Defence plan.

The plans for job losses are temporarily frozen while a review is carried out of BNFL's safety record. The timetable for the new management consortium to take over the plant was put on hold after disclosures that BNFL employees had falsified safety data at its Sellafield reprocessing plant in west Cumbria.

The DTI is carrying out the review and a decision on the consortium's future will be made in about a month.

Storehouse talks ended
Iceland, the frozen food chain, will today announce that it has ended talks with Storehouse and has no intention of bidding for the group.

Iceland made tentative overtures to Storehouse, whose chairman Alan Smith has put together a deal to put 100 Iceland foodhalls inside its Bhs stores. But Malcolm Walker, Iceland's founder and chairman who has become a leading light in the campaign for GM-free food, has decided to walk away.

That leaves a management team including former Tesco boss, Lord MacLaurin, and Nigel Whittaker, the one-time Kingfisher director, as the frontrunner to seize control of the beleaguered group. Brown & Jackson, the discount retailer, is also believed to have made an approach.

Corporate role for Howells
Kim Howells, the minister who has sought to protect consumers against unscrupulous businesses including car dealers and travel agents, has been handed the task of making all of business act more responsibly.

The newly-created post of minister for corporate social responsibility has been added to his portfolio, which covers competition, company law and corporate governance as well as consumer affairs.

Mr Howells has played a key part in the government's campaign against "rip-off Britain". Last year he called for an official inquiry into soft drink prices in pubs, and also likened mortgage misselling to the pensions scandal.

webTitle: Raise half a glass of Krug to Cruickshank

fields.headline: Raise half a glass of Krug to Cruickshank
fields.standfirst: Bank report now needs action
fields.trailText: Ploughing through competition in UK banking, a report to the chancellor of the exchequer, by Don Cruickshank, things begin to look up halfway down page 220.
fields.body:
Ploughing through competition in UK banking, a report to the chancellor of the exchequer, by Don Cruickshank, things begin to look up halfway down page 220.

A sub-clause in the section on the disaggregation of returns suddenly cuts off from tackling the difficulty of measuring banks' return on equity and declares: "The author would like to offer a bottle of Krug champagne to the first reader to send an email to the review's website citing this paragraph. The usual conditions apply. Closing date March 31 2000."

The winner was an analyst at HSBC. But of course it should have been Gordon Brown, since he commissioned the tome, or maybe one of the banks themselves, since they had early sight on Sunday. Then again, by page 220, most traditional bankers were probably in need of something substantially stronger.

Take the raw, private words of one man close to the top of what we used to refer to as a member of the big four. "It's a pantomime which has been running for 15 months. I don't know why we bothered since he has just stuck with his original flawed assumptions. He has ignored all the information. In some parts, such as the £5bn on over-charging, he's made the figures up entirely. The moves on money transmission amount to nationalisation by the back door."

So, a result then, perhaps? In short, "yes" but with so many qualifications that enjoyment of the traditional sport of bank-bashing is all but lost.

The report is smart in segregating the treatment of personal customers (where new technology is boosting competition and therefore raising standards of customer care) from the treatment of small businesses and also the cartel-like control of the money transmission network (where new technology has not changed anything). And all the recommendations on tackling the financially excluded make as much sense as they always have.

Also, Mr Cruickshank has clearly had some fun poking the regulatory nest, questioning the relationship between the industry, the Bank of England and then going on to suggest keeping a formal watch on the City watchdog, the FSA.

But then we were promised something "explosive" during pre-publication briefings, and yet the reaction in the market yesterday was that bank shares went up. There is a suspicion that Mr Cruickshank prefers playing politics to solving problems and is happy to see the established end of the industry slide slowly into a bureaucratic swamp of payment systems commissioners, licences, review bodies and the like.

Perhaps Mr Brown, having missed the bubbly, will be bolder this afternoon.

Where next?

On the face of it the planned merger of the Brussels, Paris and Amsterdam bourses looks a useful step forward as the traditional exchanges seek to meet the competitive threat posed by newer exchanges like Nasdaq, Jiway and Tradepoint or electronic networks.

The three-way deal with its single platform offers cost savings across the board - though whether they turn out to be "huge" is another matter. And as the London exchange noted, mergers rather than the clumsy concept of a pan-European market structure are the best way of ensuring consolidation carries liquidity with it.

That said, however, Euronext may reinforce divisions rather than bring greater cohesion. By putting mergers back at the top of the agenda the question of governance - fudged under the existing eight exchange alliance programme - returns, as intractable as ever, to the centre of the debate.

On what basis should ownership of merged exchanges be decided? Among Brussels, Amsterdam and Paris it is not hard to work out which is going to be the dominant factor. But neither London nor Frankfurt would accept a secondary role in a full pan-European merger. Neither, though with less reason perhaps, would Paris. It could be argued that, post demutualisation, the issue will become academic as exchanges' share registers increasingly contain the same names - but that is likely to happen too slowly to have a decisive impact.

What happened yesterday is that Amsterdam and Brussels allied themselves with a stronger player; Paris gained a tactical advantage in the manoeuvring for position among the big exchanges because Euronext will give it more clout.

Greater leverage for one player, however, will make the question of control more difficult than it already is. London and Frankfurt now have to decide whether to go along with Euronext - either directly via a merger or through the existing, much looser, alliance - in the hope that the governance issue can be solved; revive the original Anglo-German alliance or go it alone. Old rivalries die hard.

webTitle: Liffe asked to join exchanges merger

fields.headline: Liffe asked to join exchanges merger
fields.standfirst: Liffe
fields.trailText: Three of Europe's national stock exchanges yesterday detailed plans for merger and gave a clear invitation to London's derivatives market, Liffe, to sign up as well.
fields.body:
Three of Europe's national stock exchanges yesterday detailed plans for merger and gave a clear invitation to London's derivatives market, Liffe, to sign up as well.

Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels said their plans to form Euronext, which they are billing as the first European exchange, would not affect plans for a planned eight exchange pan-European stock market.

"Euronext will remain a partner in the European exchange alliance," said Jean François Théodore, the chief executive at the Paris bourse who will be chief executive of Euronext.

The merger, the first between independent national exchanges in Europe, marks a move towards consolidation in the face of developing competition from newer exchanges and electronic networks. But it may make progress towards completing the alliance more complicated because it shifts the debate back towards a series of stock market mergers rather than the current concept of a pan-European structure built around the individual national markets.

At a press conference in London the three exchanges said Euronext would have a single order book and single clearing and settlement system. "It will be completely integrated; a single platform from trading to settlement," said Mr Théodore.

Though the three exchanges have chosen which electronic system will be used in the cash market they have not yet picked a system for their derivatives business - leaving the way open for them to choose Liffe's Connect system. "We are considering the existing systems we will consider Connect because Liffe could be a partner,especially in the field of fixed income derivatives," Mr Théodore said.

Liffe, which is understood to have been briefed about the proposal late last week said it would be "delighted" to talk to the Euronext partners.

Later Mr Théodore said the London stock exchange and the London clearing house would be "very exciting partners."

The LSE said guardedly that the plan for Euronext confirmed its view that consolidation within Europe was best achieved by merger, rather than alliance.

Euronext, which will be based in Amsterdam, will be the largest exchange by both market capitalisation and the number of listed companies in the single currency zone - though it still lags behind London on both counts.

The partners are looking to complete the merger this autumn with a stock market listing planned for the end of the year - though they have not yet decided on which exchange to list. Full integration is planned for the first three months of next year.

fields.headline: S&N snap up Kronenbourg
fields.standfirst:
Brewer embarks on global expansion

Centre Parcs
Pontins
fields.trailText: Scottish & Newcastle yesterday broke out of the pregnant pause which has overtaken the British brewing sector by agreeing to buy a majority stake in Kronenbourg, a European beer company, from its French owner Danone.
fields.body:
Scottish & Newcastle yesterday broke out of the pregnant pause which has overtaken the British brewing sector by agreeing to buy a majority stake in Kronenbourg, a European beer company, from its French owner Danone.

The deal will put Britain's biggest brewer to the forefront of beer making in Europe and is expected to act as a platform for a global expansion.

A spokesman said that even though the beer market in many countries was regarded as mature, S&N was confident of its ability to increase market share and raise profits. "The argument that beer is a dead market might suit our competitors who want to get out of the business," said one S&N executive. "But this is not a market where it is difficult to grow earnings. It is a huge market not a dying one and we are carving a stronger position."

S&N's domestic rivals, Bass and Whitbread, have signalled an intention to withdraw from brewing even though a recent McKinsey report forecast that world beer sales will rise from $18bn (£11.5bn) today to $28bn in 10 years.

Shares in Bass, best known for Carling Black Label, rose by 7p to 714p yesterday, while Whitbread's shares climbed 29p to 515p in hope the group will attract a buyer for its business which brews Boddington as well as Stella and Heineken under licence.

S&N, which already brews Kronenbourg under licence in Britain, intends to pay for the acquisition by selling off its leisure business, the under cover Center Parcs resorts and Pontins holiday camps, which analysts believe could raise between £700m and £1bn.

The purchase of Kronenbourg will cost S&N an initial £470m. The brewer is also giving the French company about £100m worth of shares, which slipped 12p to 391p.

The deal is being structured as the creation of a joint venture brewing group to enable the French group to continue enjoying some benefit from Kronenbourg's cash flow as well as avoiding an unnecessarily large tax bill. If Danone decides not to retain a 25% stake in the joint venture, S&N's expenditure on the deal will rise to about £700m in three years.

Danone's other brewing in terests in Spain and China are outside the deal although this might change and S&N says there should be immediate gains from pushing its other brands such as Foster's through Kronenbourg's European distribution chain.

S&N, which controls a third of the British beer market as well as 2,700 pubs, has decided to stick to brewing and expand internationally in contrast to its British rivals which have decided to withdraw from the lacklustre beer business and concentrate on leisure interests.

S&N and Whitbread recently fell out of the benchmark FTSE 100 index because shareholders preferred to put their money in high technology stocks and Whitbread is now reported to be considering taking itself private.

It is not only British beer groups which are consolidating. South African Breweries, now listed in London, has said it is interested in acquisitions and is believed to be running a slide rule over Bass' beer division.

Both Interbrew, which owns Stella, and Heineken are sizing up acquisitions - one or other is expected to pounce on Whitbread.

It is not only British beer groups which are consolidating. South African Breweries, now listed in London, has said it is interested in acquisitions and is believed to be running a slide rule over Bass' beer division. Both Interbrew, which owns Stella, and Heineken are sizing up acquisitions - one or other is expected to pounce on Whitbread.

webTitle: Yes Television float to raise up to £200m

fields.headline: Yes Television float to raise up to £200m
fields.standfirst:
Warner Bros
Buena Vista
fields.trailText: Yes Television, the video-on-demand company which recently signed a joint venture to pipe films down British Telecom wires, yesterday announced plans for a flotation which will value the business at around £600m.
fields.body:
Yes Television, the video-on-demand company which recently signed a joint venture to pipe films down British Telecom wires, yesterday announced plans for a flotation which will value the business at around £600m.

The company is expected to raise £150m-£200m in the offer, which will be used to fund the national roll out of its ven ture with BT. As part of the flotation, two of the companies largest suppliers of movies, Warner Bros and Buena Vista, Disney's distribution arm, will take stakes.

"Their decision to take a stake in the business is a strong endorsement," said Yes Television chairman Thomas Kressner. "They are saying this is a real product that is here and working. It also says they are pleased with the way their content is being presented."

Mr Kressner, a former Morgan Stanley stockbroker who holds some 25% of the company, will become a multi-millionaire.

BT-Yes Television is being tested in 400 homes in west London using ADSL technology which upgrades existing copper wires for high bandwidth applications such as internet access and broadcasting.

The service called Total Television aims to offer hundreds of movies, kids channels, education, music videos and TV programming all of which can be viewed at any time. The service has the functionality of a video recorder allowing pause or rewind. It will also offer internet access via the TV and e-mail.

Video Networks, Yes Television's chief rival in the video-on-demand market is also considering a flotation. Like Yes Television, Video Networks uses ADSL technology to send films and TV programming down existing copper wire lines and has 1,500 subscribers.

BT has announced targets of upgrading 6m homes to ADSL by the end of this month and 75% of the population within three years.

Both Video Networks and Yes Television will be competing for the same customers, as BT is forced to offer the service wholesale to rival companies. The local network is entirely opened to competition in the middle of next year.

webTitle: Profile Confined - until the time is right

fields.headline: Profile Confined - until the time is right
fields.trailText: Three years after the collapse of his £1.4bn bid for the Co-op, Andrew Regan is still living with the consequences. He cannot leave Monaco because he is wanted by the Serious Fraud Office. Even the local Marks & Spencer, down the coast in Nice, is out of bounds. Regan's friends are appalled by his predicament. The SFO alleges that Regan stole £2.4m from shareholders of Hobson, a company he controlled in 1994. The money was used in the renegotiation of a supply contract with the Co-op - the SFO reckons it found its way into the hands of Co-op staff.
fields.body:
Three years after the collapse of his £1.4bn bid for the Co-op, Andrew Regan is still living with the consequences. He cannot leave Monaco because he is wanted by the Serious Fraud Office. Even the local Marks & Spencer, down the coast in Nice, is out of bounds. Regan's friends are appalled by his predicament. The SFO alleges that Regan stole £2.4m from shareholders of Hobson, a company he controlled in 1994. The money was used in the renegotiation of a supply contract with the Co-op - the SFO reckons it found its way into the hands of Co-op staff.

Regan's friends fiercely deny the charges. His camp maintains that the Co-op bid was essentially sound, but failed because it became too personalised - Regan was demonised as the man out to destroy a long-standing institution.

Regan lives the high life in Monaco - he eats in the best restaurants and drinks in the best bars.

He still surrounds himself with friends from his Derbyshire upbringing but his six young children go to school with Monte Carlo's rich kids.

Regan is keeping his head down but he will be back. He does not consider himself a dot.com expert and will avoid that area of business, but he is intrigued by the number of bombed-out food and drinks companies on the London market. It is just a question of choosing the right time, and then "bish, bash, bosh", to use a favourite Regan phrase.

webTitle: A home from home for the reclusive empire builders

fields.headline: A home from home for the reclusive empire builders
fields.trailText: If it's lunchtime and the Barclay brothers are in town you'll probably find them having a quiet drink at their usual table in the bar of the Hotel de Paris. David and Frederick, the super-rich and reclusive twins, are creatures of habit according to regular drinkers.
fields.body:
If it's lunchtime and the Barclay brothers are in town you'll probably find them having a quiet drink at their usual table in the bar of the Hotel de Paris. David and Frederick, the super-rich and reclusive twins, are creatures of habit according to regular drinkers.

Smartly suited and with slicked-back hair they talk to few people save each other and close business associates. Last year they backed fellow Monaco resident Philip Green's bid to break up the Sears retail chain.

Today much of their time is spent in the Channel Islands where they are building a castle. Close friend and a controversial former Monaco resident David "Spotty" Rowland moved north around the same time. The two families both have sons on the board of Jellyworks, a listed internet investment company.

Today the Barclays' business empire spans the Scotsman and Sunday Business newspapers, the Ritz Hotel in London and a variety of internet investments. Most of their interests are now handled by David's son Aiden, who was on the board of January Investments, the vehicle used to bid for Sears.

Howard, Aiden's younger brother, is on the board of Jellyworks. Former Sunday Times editor Andrew Neil is the editor-in-chief of the brother's newspaper empire.

webTitle: Life beyond the grasp of Gordon Brown

fields.headline: Life beyond the grasp of Gordon Brown
fields.standfirst: An hour's flight from the City lies Monaco. While most Britons fear what the Budget might bring today, here the biggest worry of expatriate tycoons is what company to buy tomorrow
fields.trailText: The Square Mile will go quiet at 3.30 this afternoon. Almost everyone in the City will be glued to the television to find out the contents of Gordon Brown's red box.
fields.body:
The Square Mile will go quiet at 3.30 this afternoon. Almost everyone in the City will be glued to the television to find out the contents of Gordon Brown's red box.

Everyone, that is, who actually lives here. A growing number of influential British businessmen are choosing to base themselves in Monaco - where the chancellor's speech is unlikely to distract diners from their daily ritual of champagne and caviar at the Café de Paris.

The tiny city-state of 60,000 inhabitants contains 5,000 Britons, nearly all of them very wealthy. Many are multi-millionaires and a great number run or control slices of Britain's biggest companies. A stroll around town offers a host of sightings of well known entrepreneurs, who prefer the tax-free sunshine of Monaco to the greyness of London.

For the genuinely rich and sometimes the famous, Monaco represents one of the safest, sunniest and glamorous tax-free havens in the world. "Nowhere else in the world compares," said one long term British tax-exile. "Monaco has style, grace and charm - Marbella does not. Besides, where else is there to go? Switzerland is too cold, the Bahamas too far."

Creatures of habit

Many of the British residents are creatures of habit, who enjoy the same routine nearly every day. You don't have to look hard to find them. For example, sitting in the bar at the Hotel de Paris most lunchtimes are the Barclay brothers - owners of the Scotsman newspaper and the London Ritz hotel. In their blue pinstriped suits, they choose the same table every day, rarely talking to anyone as they sip coffee or aperitifs. Entertainment is provided by the hotel's pianist, who has a repertoire of funereal Frank Sinatra numbers and easy-listening hits from the 1940s.

Next door at the famed Monte Carlo casino, flamboyant corporate raider Philip Green enjoys rather more upbeat entertainment. Having failed in his recent attempt to bid for Marks & Spencer, Mr Green has been consoling himself at the blackjack tables, often gambling with chips worth 50,000 francs (£5,000) each. A devout Tottenham fan, Mr Green is sometimes seen with Irving Scholar, the former property tycoon who once chaired Spurs and has a home in Monaco.

On the other side of the Golden Square of the Place du Casino - the heart of Monaco's glamour district - lunchtime company at the Café de Paris includes metals dealers Simon Reuben and his brother David, enjoying a leisurely glass of vintage wine and a plate of the finest fois gras. Multi-millionaire racehorse owners Michael Charlton and Michael Tabor often sit at tables nearby, keeping in touch with the latest racing results from Cheltenham via mobile phone.

Behind the café is the Metropole hotel - slightly downmarket of the Hotel de Paris, but still beyond most folk at £150 a night. The hotel is home to Andrew Regan, the man who tried to buy the Co-operative Wholesale Society three years ago. Mr Regan is now wanted by the serious fraud office for allegedly stealing money from shareholders. He is unable to leave Monaco's square kilometre, for fear of arrest and extradition.

Mr Regan lives with his former-model wife Nikki and their six children, a floor above the residence of car parks millionaire Stephen Tucker - who sold his Europarks business in 1990 to National Car Parks for £5m.

Mr Regan and Mr Tucker like dining at Rampoldis - a smart Italian restaurant below the hotel which despite the £15 starters and impressively thick wine list is decked out like an upmarket Aberdeen Steak House, all red couchettes and dim lights. The food comprises meats and fish with rich sauces, the conversation is relaxed and the maitre'd cannot do enough for his regular diners.

Other Rampoldi customers include Nigel Robertson - one of the founders of online directories business Scoot.com who still holds more than £100m worth of shares - and former copper dealer Ashley Levett.

Mr Levett lives down the hill in an apartment block on a wide boulevard called Avenue de Princesse Grace. Just a gear change from the grand prix track it enjoys panoramic views over the sea.

Mr Levett was cleared by the authorities after an investigation into the Winchester Commodities copper scandal five years ago. His business partner at the time was Charlie "Copperfingers" Vincent, another Monaco resident who still deals on the copper market. Further along Avenue de Princesse Grace is a block called Houston Palace, home to another clutch of former City names including Ronnie Reeves - best known for selling investment business Eastern & General to Legal & General for £150m in the 1980s.

Mr Reeves is a friend of Gary Amos, a broker still active on the London market who is famed for the shrewd timing of his deals.

The most popular drinking venue on the Avenue de Princess Grace is Sass Café, a strange mixture of cabaret, disco and a band playing Abba covers. There the Brits mingle with a steady stream of Italian and Middle Eastern businessmen, grand prix drivers and ageing pop stars. Prince Albert, heir to the throne, occasionally drops in with a date.

Besides the sun and low taxes, businessmen generally list security as the state's biggest asset. It is said that if you were to drop your wallet in the street it would be handed in at the local police station, complete with contents, within minutes. At Jimmy'z, Monaco's biggest and most popular nightspot, there is not a single bouncer on the door, just a glamorous female attendant taking entrance money.

Low-grade crime is simply not an issue. Monaco has more police per head than any other country in the world - one bored policeman for every 67 residents. Discreet closed-circuit television cameras monitor many of the public areas, even phone calls are routinely monitored.

It's the way the wealthy like it. One British resident says: "You don't have to keep looking over your shoulder. You don't stand out here if you're a millionaire - the next man along could be a billionaire."

There are few signs of the social exclusion that dogs other capitalist nations. The poor are discouraged through a series of strict, often authoritarian, rules. Walking shirtless on is prohibited and begging on the daily-scrubbed streets is unheard of.

"People think nothing of walking around in fur coasts and diamond neck laces that would make them an instant target in Nice or Cannes," one resident said. "Being stopped by the police and asked for identity papers can be a pain but at least it's safe."

However, just a short walk from the exclusive Hotel de Paris stands a grim reminder that even a fabulously wealthy police state can breed paranoia.

The burnt out remains of the harbourside home of the late billionaire banker Edmond Safra are surrounded by scaffolding. Last December a fire gutted the building and suffocated the founder of Republic Bank of New York. The tragedy shook Monaco to the core, particularly because Safra was obsessive about security.

When they saw the building alight, many paranoid millionaires rushed for the phone to check that their funds were safe in the bank downstairs. Initial rumours that the Russian mafiosi who populated Monaco for a while in the mid 1990s were to blame fuelled the sense of unease. But the police soon announced that a member of Safra's staff had confessed to starting the fire. Some of Monaco's more paranoid residents whisper that the manservant was not wholly responsible.

A younger breed of British entrepreneurs is moving to the principality and Monaco doesn't want to lose them.

Some Britons - such as multi-millionaire tax avoidance expert Michael Charlton - have been in Monaco for decades but a recent influx of younger tax exiles has pushed up the profile of the place. Part of the reason has been a relaxation in attitude on the part of the government.

Mr Charlton says: "They used to be quite sniffy if you turned up and said you were 37-years-old and retired. But they've eased up a lot on that - I think they realised there was a need for a more youthful population."

The basic requirements for residence are that applicants have no criminal record, are not bankrupt and can support themselves. Residency requires that people live in Monaco for at least half the time, entitling them to an entirely tax-free lifestyle, other than paying hefty VAT in the shops.

Until recently a popular ruse was to rent an apartment in Monaco but spend most of your time across the French border in your cliff-top villa at Antibes or Cap Ferrat, but a clampdown by French authorities has greatly reduced the number of people flouting Monaco's residency rules. The demographics of the British expatriates are changing. A decade ago most of the British residents had made their money and were moving south to put their feet up. But the likes of Messrs Regan, Tucker, Green and Levett are still working hard and playing an active role back in the UK. The exact nature of most of their plans remain sketchy. A typical response is: "I'm investing in a few dot.com companies but then, aren't we all?"

Others will only admit they have "interests" which they would rather keep private. When they do reluctantly say what they are doing it is usually on a strictly "off the record" basis.

Of those plans that are in the public domain, Stephen Tucker is finalising plans to take control of Storehouse, the retailing group, and he emerged recently as the main backer of New Capital Invest - an AIM-listed internet vehicle.

Philip Green pops up with regular retail deals - his last big coup was buying and breaking up Sears, the owner of Freemans, Warehouse and Miss Selfridge. The Barclay brothers provided much of the financial firepower.

Mr Regan intends to keep his head down until his disagreement with the serious fraud office is settled. Then, friends hint, he could be interested in looking at undervalued businesses such as the bombed out brewing and pubs sector.

Mr Vincent, who turned 40 last week, and Mr Levett still trade the metals market. After moving to Monaco he spent a financially bruising few years as owner of Richmond rugby club. Last summer he threw in the towel and wrote off a £5m loan the club owed him. His current interests include the Hotel de Vin chain, a partnership with Body Shop founders Anita and Gordon Roddick, and, inevitably, some internet investments.

That Monaco is just over an hour's flight from London and a helicopter ride from Geneva, Rome and Paris is an added bonus. "Monaco is a phenomenal base from which to travel," said one financier who spends almost as much time in the air as he does at home.

But it is not everyone's idea of the perfect place to bring up children. "I don't want my kids growing up thinking every parent drives a Porsche or a Ferrari and Prada are the only people who make school satchels," one businessman said. Instead his children are being educated at leading public schools in the Home Counties.

Attracted attention

Mr Regan has certainly attracted the Monégasque authorities' attention - the presence of a fugitive from the serious fraud office does little for the area's reputation. Friends of his admit that "discussions have taken place" involving Prince Albert himself on the issue of whether he should be allowed to remain. They say simply that the prince has "taken a view" on the case.

One associate of Mr Regan remarked: "They don't like foreign authorities here and they certainly don't like the UK authorities. The only ones who carry any weight are the French - they inevitably have some power."

For now Mr Regan is taking a low profile, ferrying his kids too and from the local school, eating takeaways at the homes of friends and keeping out of the limelight. Others, like Philip Green, enjoy Monaco to the full.

On a typical afternoon in the casino square last week, three Ferraris were parked alongside a purple Lamborghini, a gold Rolls-Royce and host of BMWs and Mercedes. Philip Green's wife Christina had left her blue Bentley Azure outside the Hotel de Paris. Her husband is reputed to moor one of the largest yachts in the harbour. Immacutely reconstructed women walk perfectly groomed dogs from the shops to the cafés, Valentino and Gucci bags in hand.

In the spring, a common pastime is to take an 18-minute helicopter ride up to the mountains on the Italian border for a morning's skiing, then nip back down to the coast for an afternoon of waterskiing in the sunshine.

Each year, another clutch of names emerges from Monaco. The latest is Fred Woollard - an Australian businessman who is masterminding an attempt to "carpetbag" Standard Life. By forcing a vote on demutualisation, he reckons he could trigger windfalls of up to £6,000 for each of the insurance group's 2.3m policyholders. Mr Woollard, 37, has been living in Monaco since 1991 but says he is not part of the British-dominated "Monaco mob".

He says: "I occasionally see them in restaurants. But the Standard Life plan was hatched by me sitting by myself with a laptop, reading boring documents."

Mr Woollard claims that "the tax angle" has never been his primary motivation for living in the city-state - a statement which puts him firmly in a minority. He insists: "Monaco's a really lovely place to live - the streets are clean, there's low crime and it's one of the few places you can feel totally safe."

The other reason, which nobody mentions, is that Monaco is becoming an excellent place to network.

Mr Woollard says he does not frequent millionaire haunts such as the Café de Paris or Rampoldis. "That's not my style," he says. "I'm sadly a rather boring character who works too hard and spends too much time with my family."

The Barclay brothers provided much of the financial firepower. Mr Regan intends to keep his head down until his disagreement with the serious fraud office is settled. Then, friends hint, he could be interested in looking at undervalued businesses such as the bombed out brewing and pubs sector. Mr Vincent, who turned 40 last week, and Mr Levett still trade the metals market. After moving to Monaco he spent a financially bruising few years as owner of Richmond rugby club. Last summer he threw in the towel and wrote off a £5m loan the club owed him. His current interests include the Hotel de Vin chain, a partnership with Body Shop founders Anita and Gordon Roddick, and, inevitably, some internet investments. That Monaco is just over an hour's flight from London and a helicopter ride from Geneva, Rome and Paris is an added bonus. "Monaco is a phenomenal base from which to travel," said one financier who spends almost as much time in the air as he does at home. But it is not everyone's idea of the perfect place to bring up children. "I don't want my kids growing up thinking every parent drives a Porsche or a Ferrari and Prada are the only people who make school satchels," one businessman said. Instead his children are being educated at leading public schools in the Home Counties. Attracted attention Mr Regan has certainly attracted the Monégasque authorities' attention - the presence of a fugitive from the serious fraud office does little for the area's reputation. Friends of his admit that "discussions have taken place" involving Prince Albert himself on the issue of whether he should be allowed to remain. They say simply that the prince has "taken a view" on the case. One associate of Mr Regan remarked: "They don't like foreign authorities here and they certainly don't like the UK authorities. The only ones who carry any weight are the French - they inevitably have some power." For now Mr Regan is taking a low profile, ferrying his kids too and from the local school, eating takeaways at the homes of friends and keeping out of the limelight. Others, like Philip Green, enjoy Monaco to the full. On a typical afternoon in the casino square last week, three Ferraris were parked alongside a purple Lamborghini, a gold Rolls-Royce and host of BMWs and Mercedes. Philip Green's wife Christina had left her blue Bentley Azure outside the Hotel de Paris. Her husband is reputed to moor one of the largest yachts in the harbour. Immacutely reconstructed women walk perfectly groomed dogs from the shops to the cafés, Valentino and Gucci bags in hand. In the spring, a common pastime is to take an 18-minute helicopter ride up to the mountains on the Italian border for a morning's skiing, then nip back down to the coast for an afternoon of waterskiing in the sunshine. Each year, another clutch of names emerges from Monaco. The latest is Fred Woollard - an Australian businessman who is masterminding an attempt to "carpetbag" Standard Life. By forcing a vote on demutualisation, he reckons he could trigger windfalls of up to £6,000 for each of the insurance group's 2.3m policyholders. Mr Woollard, 37, has been living in Monaco since 1991 but says he is not part of the British-dominated "Monaco mob". He says: "I occasionally see them in restaurants. But the Standard Life plan was hatched by me sitting by myself with a laptop, reading boring documents." Mr Woollard claims that "the tax angle" has never been his primary motivation for living in the city-state - a statement which puts him firmly in a minority. He insists: "Monaco's a really lovely place to live - the streets are clean, there's low crime and it's one of the few places you can feel totally safe." The other reason, which nobody mentions, is that Monaco is becoming an excellent place to network. Mr Woollard says he does not frequent millionaire haunts such as the Café de Paris or Rampoldis. "That's not my style," he says. "I'm sadly a rather boring character who works too hard and spends too much time with my family."

webTitle: Stand back when Green is on the attack

fields.headline: Stand back when Green is on the attack
fields.trailText: Philip Green is known to his friends as Conan the Barbarian, because "if you get into a fight with him, you'll lose an arm".
fields.body:
Philip Green is known to his friends as Conan the Barbarian, because "if you get into a fight with him, you'll lose an arm".

The multi-millionaire entrepreneur is renowned for his aggression - his usual tactic is to pounce on a struggling retailer, shred it into tiny pieces and sell the components at a profit.

His past purchases include Sears, Owen Owen, Olympus Sportswear and Shoe Express.

Some of these deals have been financed with the help of David and Frederick Barclay - the reclusive brothers who live alongside Green in Monaco.

Green was born into north London's Jewish community. He left school with few qualifications and moved from the family property business into the rag trade.

Green is confident and often outspoken. and has a reputation as a maverick.

He was embroiled in controversy recently when he tried to put together a takeover of struggling Marks & Spencer. It emerged that his wife, Christina, had shares in the company and this was used as ammunition against his bid. Green stormed that the furore was "unjustified".

Green splits his time between London and Monaco, where he is often to be found at the casino. He is perhaps the highest profile member of the British business community in the state.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Trading in London was relatively quiet ahead of Budget day here and the meeting of the Federal Reserve's open markets committee in America. But the trend was firm, with the FTSE 100 index stepping 66.5 points higher to 6624.5, and there was a notable rebound among some the big telecoms and media stocks.
fields.body:
Trading in London was relatively quiet ahead of Budget day here and the meeting of the Federal Reserve's open markets committee in America. But the trend was firm, with the FTSE 100 index stepping 66.5 points higher to 6624.5, and there was a notable rebound among some the big telecoms and media stocks.

So Reuters stood out with a jump from £12.94 to £14.88 - partly reflecting a jump in the price of its Nasdaq-quoted networking associate, Tibco. BSkyB, meanwhile, added 61p to £19.09 and Pearson managed to climb 201p to £23.52.

In the telecoms sector, movements were rather more mixed, with Vodafone climbing 11p to £380p, but British Telecom easing 19p to £12.21, although Marconi (the reborn and renamed GEC) jumped from 807p to 874p and cable group Telewest Communications advanced 26p to 449p.

Many of the purer technology and internet companies had a tough session, continuing that strange phenomenon of Footsie newcomers stumbling on their first day. Freeserve fell from 596p to 531p, Baltimore Technology fell 474p to £103.51 and Thus gave up 31p to 660p.

Other Footsie debutantes under pressure included Nycomed Amersham, off 31p at 544p, and Emap, down from £14.10 to £13.50.

Elsewhere, engineering concern McKechnie surged 22p to 250p after weekend reports that its underperformance this year is likely to attract the attention of a predator. GKN, off 8p at 836p, was mentioned as possibly making a move.

The market in Lastminute.com remained nervous, with investment bank adviser Morgan Stanley still clearly supporting the shares in the market. The price closed 1p higher at 392p.

On the AIM market there was evidence that whatever the recent nervousness, new floats pitched at penny punters can still fly. Advanced Financial Network, which operates a financial website (advfn.com) and is 76% owned by On-Line, soared from a placing price of 10p to 59p at the close. On-Line, meanwhile, added 35p to £12.85, having come up from a low of 12p last year.

Internet-based graduate recruitment firm World Careers Network, which also arrived on AIM yesterday, jumped from a placing price of 110p to 230p. But the new issue excitement did not spread to digital radio. Radio First, which is teaming up from Aston Villa, Chelsea and Southampton football clubs to develop club-dedicated radio stations, dipped from its 235p opening price to close at 215p.
