fields.headline: Fending off unwelcome advances
fields.standfirst: News Analysis: Is Border Television fighting for independence or fattening the turkey?
fields.trailText: When Paul Corley was in charge of factual programming at the ITV Network one of his better known commissions was Neighbours from Hell, the show which documented real life disputes between people living next door to each other.
fields.body:
When Paul Corley was in charge of factual programming at the ITV Network one of his better known commissions was Neighbours from Hell, the show which documented real life disputes between people living next door to each other.

Yesterday he was recollecting the series with a smirk as he noted that he has found himself in his own version of the Carlton-produced show.

Now chief executive of Border Television, Mr Corley is fending off the unwanted attentions of neighbouring Scottish Radio Holdings, which stuck its nose over the garden fence with a £116m takeover bid last week.

SRH has a clutch of radio assets throughout Scotland and is keen to get its hands on Border's stations across the north of England and the midlands.

Wrapped up in the hostile approach is the fate of one of the last remaining independent ITV companies in Britain, the others being Ulster Television and Channel Television, which broadcasts to the Channel Islands.

Bid from SRH, launched last week, caused a number of other potential buyers to emerge. Border has long been considered a takeover target and Chrysalis, Capital Radio, Kelvin Mackenzie's Wireless group and Scottish Media Group are all understood to have come forward. There is speculation that Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian newspaper and employer of Border's former radio chief John Myers has also taken a long look at the company.

For each of the likely bidders the key at traction is Border's radio assets - a market where advertising revenues are forecast to grow at between 10%-13% this year. Border has four stations, including three on air under the Century brand and Sun FM in Sunderland, which together have a potential audience of 9.2m adults and are regarded as some of the most potentially lucrative franchises in the country.

About 40% of Border's revenues come from radio, up from 20% two years ago. "There's plenty more growth to come," Mr Corley said in rejecting the bid. "Scottish Radio is a very good company but their stations are all mature businesses. Our north-west station is the biggest outside London and has been up for only 18 months."

Although a minnow compared to the big three ITV groups of Granada, United News & Media and Carlton, Border is consistently among the best performing regions and has an average market share in peak time of 43% compared with the 38% of the rest of the networks.

Its influence as a programme maker has waned. Throughout the 1980s under Melvyn Bragg and when Mr Corley was director of programming, Border was still an active producer for the ITV network. The growing firepower of the big three and the introduction of a quota on the amount of airtime which has to be filled by independent producers has however squeezed Border out. Today it produces just between five and six hours a week, largely of local news.

The station has an agreement with Granada to supply transmission and national advertising sales.

Border's origins though could still play a decisive part in the outcome of what is likely to develop into a bidding war. The Border TV business, which reaches its 40th birthday next year, came into being only on the intervention of a group of local media barons when the old Indepen dent Television Association was carving the nation up.

The Border region was to have been subsumed into the surrounding conurbations but they argued the case for a separate franchise focusing on the largely rural borders between England and Scotland, Cumbria and the Isle of Man. The CN Group, then run by the late Sir John Burgess, was one of the Border founders and remains one of its largest shareholders with a stake just below 14%.

The timing of Scottish Radio's bid is significant. The group is up against a consortium of Border, Chrysalis and Daily Mail & General Trust for the valuable second digital radio multiplex in London. Each multiplex can support eight stations one of which would introduce the Century brand to London.

Border's position in that contest also increases the stakes for Chrysalis which insiders say is keen not to lose its partner in the process to an opposing bidder.

Richard Findlay, chief executive of Scottish Radio, suggests his group has better depth of experience through its 15 radio stations and calls on Border to be "realistic" about its future independence. "They have to accept that the media world is changing and if they want to survive they have to be part of a bigger group. They will lose their independence at some point and we hope they will talk to us because we have more to bring to the party than another buyer."

Mr Corley's argument that there is more value to come was borne out by the performance of the group's shares since Scottish Radio made an aborted offer two years ago at £4 a share.

Scottish Radio's present bid is 10 shares for every 17 in Border, at yesterday's prices about £11 a share, or a cash alternative of £10.25.

Despite Mr Corley's insistence that the company wants to keep its freedom it's hard to escape the sense that the Border directors are simply fattening the turkey. A key argument is that the upcoming Broadcasting Act is likely to lift limits on both radio and ITV ownership making Border a target for a broader base of potential buyers and adding to its value.

fields.headline: MFI
fields.trailText: The struggle to put together an MFI wardrobe or kitchen unit pales into insignificance alongside the gargantuan task facing John Hancock, the chief executive who is trying to put the entire group into some semblance of order.
fields.body:
The struggle to put together an MFI wardrobe or kitchen unit pales into insignificance alongside the gargantuan task facing John Hancock, the chief executive who is trying to put the entire group into some semblance of order.

Yet yesterday's results from the company - still Britain's biggest furniture group - held out the prospect that some headway is being made.

Mr Hancock was able to lift market spirits with the news that sales since Christmas are roughly 30% ahead of internal targets and 23% higher on a like-for-like basis.

Profits for the 36 weeks to Jan 1 came in at £9.1m against a loss of £2.9m the year earlier. The group has changed its year end to December from April and pro-forma figures show a profit of £29m for 1999 against estimates of about £25m from market analysts.

A new kitchen range - the company owns the Schreiber and Hygena brands - has helped to boost performance, lifting shares to a high for the year at one stage yesterday. The price fell back to close 2.25p off at 67.75p but this looked like a solid performance given that Mr Hancock is refusing to reveal details of his strategy before a research project into the group's brands is completed. The market has clearly decided to indulge the request of Mr Hancock and the team he has put in place to be allowed the first six months of this year to come up with a blueprint for MFI's future.

Teasers from the research suggest the oft-ridiculed MFI brand name is not as badly regarded as the chattering classes like to think. Some 80% of those questioned felt positive about the brand name and most of those who did not were not users of the company's shops. This means the name may not be discarded. Mr Hancock is considering of fering Hygena and Schreiber equipment to other retailers and also expansion of small high street outlets specialising in kitchens and bedrooms. Selling on the internet is, of course, another option.

He faces questions about how to go upmarket, but with Britons inspired to the point of frenzy by TV home makeover shows, he could hardly be operating against a more benign backdrop.

webTitle: The royal flush at Monte Carlo

fields.headline: The royal flush at Monte Carlo
fields.trailText: Of the thousands of foreign tourists who flock to Monaco each year only a few are likely to have ever heard of Société des Bains de Mer, yet most will contribute to its coffers.
fields.body:
Of the thousands of foreign tourists who flock to Monaco each year only a few are likely to have ever heard of Société des Bains de Mer, yet most will contribute to its coffers.

SBM, listed on the Paris bourse with a market capitalisation of £117m, is the undisputed king of the principality's entertainment sector. Prince Rainier owns two thirds of the stock.

SBM's prized asset is the Hotel de Paris, the grand 19th century hotel situated on the Golden Square of the Place du Casino. Its other jewels - the Hermitage Hotel and the Casino - are both linked to it by underground tunnels. Then there is the Cafe de Paris, Jimmy'z nightclub, the Monte Carlo Beach Hotel, the Opera inside the Casino and the Counthe sporting club. The list goes on. Around one 12th of Monaco's surface area is covered by SBM property.

Yet SBM has had more than its share of problems. It posted losses during much of the mid-90s when gambling revenues, which traditionally account for half of the total, fell sharply.

The company does not have much room for manoeuvre. Its assets incur heavy fixed costs and management has resolutely refused to cut back on staffing numbers and luxurious fittings. The prince has decreed that the image of wealth must be not be tampered with.

In the 1960s when Greek shipping magnate Aristotle Onassis attempted to build a controlling stake in SBM, Rainier simply passed a law that issued him with enough new shares to permanently hold a majority position.

The past two years have witnessed something of a turnaround as economic conditions improved. In the year to March 1999 SBM posted a pre-tax profit of 19m euros (£11.8m) on total sales of 305m euros.

webTitle: Beck's Futures is a new British art prize that's bigger than the Turner. But is it better?

fields.headline: Beck's Futures is a new British art prize that's bigger than the Turner. But is it better?
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones on the highlights of the ICA's shortlist
fields.trailText: British art is currently languishing in obscurity, sustained by little more than the opening of two new Tate galleries and countless newspaper articles. And so the launch of Beck's Futures, a new British art prize with more money and a bigger shortlist than the Turner, is a necessary intervention in an art scene dying for want of limelight.
fields.body:
British art is currently languishing in obscurity, sustained by little more than the opening of two new Tate galleries and countless newspaper articles. Young artists toiling in garrets are hurting; attention must be paid. And so the launch of Beck's Futures, a new British art prize with more money and a bigger shortlist than the Turner, is a necessary intervention in an art scene dying for want of limelight. When you add that Beck's Futures is at the ICA, which refuses to engage in shallow cultural rhetoric, you just know this is an event destined to wield authority.

Beck's Futures is not just any prize, but one that claims to define the new wave in British art. Again. The ICA wants to displace the Turner Prize as Britain's definitive art event. The Turner, it claims, is given to people who are already established. Beck's Futures is for genuinely new, unestablished or under-recognised figures. It has a shortlist of 10 and everyone will get some money, while the ultimate winner gets £24,000 - £4,000 more than the Turner booty. Instead of being pitted against each other in separate spaces like the Turner nominees, the artists in this show are hung together in a complementary fashion. It's less aggressive, man, and more in tune with the way artists collaborate when they organise group shows.

Michael Bracewell's catalogue essay is a manifesto claiming these artists represent the post-YBA new wave. They epitomise a tendency in art you might call Ostentatious Nerdism, if you were desperate. The 10 shortlisted artists all vaunt a contempt for the starriness they ascribe to the YBAs. They dress down, talk quietly, are dowdy, studious.

The quintessential artist of this tendency is Martin Boyce. His arrangement of fluorescent lights hang vertically from the ceiling as you come in, the chains that are supposed to suspend the white tubes dangling free. At first I thought a beer-sodden ligger had pulled a light down. Then you realise it is abstract art. It is a homage to the De Stijl movement of which Mondrian was a part, and is titled After Rietveld, a tribute to the De Stijl designer Gerrit Rietveld.

This Dutch modernist movement dreamt of a world where material forms dissolved in abstract space. Boyce has made a lament for that dream. In the ICA corridor he has painted a spectacular black and white slanting grid, like the skyscraper windows in the opening titles of Hitchcock's North by Northwest. This is art for the Bauhaus groupie who spends Sundays looking for the perfect Marcel Breuer chair.

Boyce will come close to the big prize. His work is a nicely expressed elegy for modernism, but so what? It's all very well making art that presses buttons for people who know about Gerrit Rietveld, but the best British art of the past 10 years has been determined to engage people who don't - most of us. This is not shallow, it's courageous.

The trouble with Beck's Futures is that it seems to be rejecting big brash art for art about art. A blurred photograph is scrawled with a felt pen message in which the author explains how much silence he needs to write his poetry. Another juxtaposes lists of "What should have held your attention", including an "amazing firework display lasting for hours" and "Citizen Kane", with "What did hold your attention", including a "clothes peg hanging from a piece of string" and "old carpet".

If the ICA want this prize to succeed they should shortlist more artists of this stature and intelligence who are a bit too maverick for the Turner, instead of trying to map out some grand theory of the next big thing. If they want to be taken seriously, they have to give this year's prize to the one artist who addresses a world beyond the little one we set aside for "art".

David Shrigley doesn't care if his work appears on a gallery wall or in a newspaper (as it happens, the newspaper that sponsors Beck's Futures has just sacked him as a cartoonist). A collaged cut-out skeleton looms out of the bin - the corpse of dead ideas. Another photomontage suggests some terrible chaos and disaster you can't quite name: it includes a house on fire, a bulldog grimacing, and a sunflower with a sad face drawn on it. Shrigley is brilliant. He keeps to these homely, recognisable images of horror. Your house is on fire. Your art is rubbish.

fields.headline: Silence is golden
fields.standfirst: But who'd play Mother Courage's mute daughter?  Lyn Gardner finds out
fields.trailText: But who'd play Mother Courage's mute daughter? Lyn Gardner finds out.
fields.body:
Hayley Carmichael's family will probably not be coming to see her in Mother Courage. This is not because they are estranged from Carmichael or don't support her in her chosen profession. It is simply that they all find it too distressing to watch her die.

Carmichael has died regularly and quite beautifully on stage. Last year in the surreal devised show I Weep at My Piano she played Lorca, a tiny figure in baggy trousers, facing death by firing squad with a matter-of-fact radiance. As Cordelia she expired in the arms of Kathryn Hunter's King Lear, another small figure in an over-size coat whose boyish good looks completed that 1997 production's trans-gender motif.

This week she opens in the latest production of Mother Courage, playing the mute Kattrin, criss-crossing Europe in the wake of her profiteering mother, played by Hunter, who firmly believes that war is always good for business. It doesn't turn out to be good for Kattrin, who pays the price.

The careers of Hunter and Carmichael are entwined like a knot. Both have come to the classics from the world of physical theatre. It was Hunter's first shot as a director, a superbly funny production of Mr Puntila and His Man Matti at the Traverse at the 1998 Edinburgh festival, that first brought Carmichael to wider attention, although she'd been around for some time working with both Theatre de Complicite and Told by an Idiot, the company she founded with John Wright and Paul Hunter in the early 90s.

Playing the small but significant role of Eva, Carmichael got critics reaching for the superlatives and describing her as - surprise, surprise - the next Kathryn Hunter. Carmichael went almost overnight from well-kept secret to star. Not that the self-effacing Carmichael, who doesn't read reviews, was aware of it. All she knew was that she was suddenly very popular in the Traverse bar. It is Hunter to whom Carmichael gives the credit for her success: "She kept on telling me to be more extreme."

Since then Carmichael has won a TMA award for best actress for her role as Egle, one of four youngsters brought up in seclusion in Marivaux's The Dispute, in a co-production between the RSC and the Lyric. She has also spent months touring the country with Told by an Idiot's absurdist drama Happy Birthday, Mister Deka D. From the sublime to the ridiculous.

One of the refreshing things about Carmichael both on stage and off is that there is nothing of the actress about her. In fact, if she were faced with the choice of playing a good part in a production in which she had no interest and working behind a bar with a team of people she respected, she'd choose the bar every time.

"When you start getting major roles you become anxious about being good," she says. "You have to remember that is not the point at all. Your job is just to tell your part of the story. When you do that it is liberating." For her, one of the best things about acting is not having to hide the "dirty, dark, crap, clumsy, ridiculous sides of yourself".

There is something frighteningly honest about Carmichael on stage. There is a freshness about her, but also a nakedness that makes her seem vulnerable. When she played Leka in Mr Deka D you wanted to hug this woman who weeps today for the unhappiness that will happen tomorrow.

Playing the mute Kattrin holds no fears: her background in physical theatre means she's spent years on stage not saying very much. "If I had a doubt in my mind, it was that I might be going into too familiar territory: would it be challenging? But it has been. The struggle is to find my place, that beat of response from a woman who can't talk."

To prepare for the part, Carmichael has spent days without speaking, to the bemusement of some people and the irritation of others. "It's very interesting," she says. "It makes you much more alert and other people much more fascinating. And it changes the space you give them. If you want to communicate with them you have to move all your energy forwards."

It's this physicality that is likely to pay off in a role that, according to some actors and directors, is a completely actor-proof part. Carmichael clearly hasn't heard this theory and finds it a bit disconcerting. "That's very reassuring to hear," she says with just the tiniest touch of irony. Whatever happens, it is very unlikely that Hayley Carmichael will need that bar job.

fields.headline: Mummy dearest
fields.standfirst: Mother Courage is one of the greatest roles an actress can tackle - as demanding and fulfilling as King Lear is for men. As Kathryn Hunter follows in the footsteps of Diana Rigg, Judi Dench and Glenda Jackson, she talks to  Veronica Lee
fields.trailText: Mother Courage is one of the greatest roles an actress can tackle - as demanding and fulfilling as King Lear is for men. As Kathryn Hunter follows in the footsteps of Diana Rigg, Judi Dench and Glenda Jackson, she talks to Veronica Lee
fields.body:
Diana Rigg once famously described Bertolt Brecht's Mother Courage as "a female Lear with songs" and, like Lear, it is a role that attracts performers of a certain age and a definite star quality. Other great names associated with it are Judi Dench, Glenda Jackson and now Kathryn Hunter. But then, if you are a star actress and want to tackle a demanding role, you may as well choose a play by Bertolt Brecht. The inventor of "epic theatre" was the first modern playwright to give women big leading roles, many written for his wife, Helene Weigel. And Mother Courage is certainly a big role - the actress playing her is offstage for only one of the 12 scenes, and she must pull a cart around for much of her time on it. And she has to sing.

Brecht wrote Mother Courage and Her Children in 1939 while living in exile in Denmark after fleeing Nazi Germany. It follows the travails of Mother Courage, who sells her wares from her famous cart to soldiers and camp followers during the Thirty Years' War - the conflict that devastated central Europe during the first half of the 17th century - and who changes sides (from Protestant to Catholic) at least twice. It is an allegory of the horrors of modern war, and makes clear the complicity of many characters who are caught up in it. Mother Courage is in no way an innocent onlooker - on the contrary, she makes a living from the conflict. Yet by the end of the drama that she is transformed into a victim of the war, having lost her three beloved children to it in various ways.

It is easy to see why Mother Courage is such a tough part. How do you make an audience empathise with this appalling woman without making it sentimental? The only one of the list to have tackled both King Lear and Mother Courage is Hunter, who did an acclaimed Lear in 1997 and is about to star in Lee Hall's version of Mother Courage in Oxford. Is she a glutton for punishment? "It's another very big role, yes, but the good thing about Lear is that it didn't have many props," says Hunter, despairing at all the stage business that must be done with Mother Courage's cart and its contents. "But Brecht, much like Shakespeare, does ask you to find the tragedy and high farce and to be able to move very deftly between the two."

Does she agree with Rigg's Lear parallel? "There's not the journey towards madness that happens in Lear, but at the end when she has lost her three children, something snaps. There's certainly that huge emotion, but the hardest task is serving Brecht. He doesn't want her presented as a heroine, yet what he has written calls for empathy.

"There is this constant pull between her wanting to be the best mother in the world and get her three children through the war unscathed, but also wanting to be the best businesswoman in the world and make as much money from it as possible. The two strategies are incompatible and that clash has to be operating all the time."

Why has she taken it on? "I like the challenge and it is a mountain to be climbed." Is it an Everest for actresses, then - it's there, so they have to climb it? "Yes, perhaps," says Hunter. "I had always had a fantasy about playing it, and when [director Nancy Meckler] proposed it I was delighted. But the basic reason for doing it is that Brecht is the most extraordinary dramatist."

While Rigg and Hunter can see the Lear parallel, Glenda Jackson doesn't entirely agree. The actress- turned MP made the role her swan song from the stage before she entered politics, performing it at the Glasgow Citizens in 1990. "It's a huge role - you're in practically every bloody scene - but I'm not quite sure it has the range of Lear. Although I suppose the great emotions, in that she is passionate about her children and suffers great loss, might suggest that. The challenge for the actor, though, is trying to not make her heroic. That was not Brecht's idea at all."

Although all the actresses agree that the role should be within the range of a talented young actress, Rigg believes that it's one, like Lear, that only middle age can fully illuminate. "Mother Courage's age is never stated, but she has three grown children, so she must be at least 40. She has clearly lived a long time," says Rigg. "I did it in my mid-50s and it's that 'encrustation' that comes with living a few years that informs the part."

When Rigg played Mother Courage at the National in 1995, part of the attraction was the chance to overturn standard perceptions of her. "I have this image as a rather grand leading lady, and I came on stage as a working-class woman with broad Yorkshire vowels. David Hare [who did the adaptation] knew I come from Yorkshire, so he decided to use that."

Rigg's performance was described as Bet Lynch-meets-Marxist dialectic and she clearly had fun in what is regarded as A Very Serious Play. "The humour is there; it just needs to be brought out. I must say it was a joy to do, but bloody hard work - pulling that blessed cart around for three hours every night."

Judi Dench played the role with the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1984. She wasn't aware of these details when she took the part, which she accepted without even reading the script - as is her practice - relying on Brecht's reputation for writing great roles for women. "When the director, Howard Davies, told me the story of Mother Courage, he didn't tell me she was on stage so much and he didn't tell me I had to pull round this enormous cart. So on the first day of rehearsal I thought, 'Fuck this. I never have a scene off.' I was so angry. But it was my own stupid fault, of course."

While Rigg enjoyed playing with her image, Jackson was just grateful for a part to get her teeth into. "God knows, there are few enough roles for women anyway, but ones this good are exceedingly rare. And this is a great role in a great play. It's a popular myth that there are great roles in lousy play - there aren't, quite simply. I feel privileged to have played her."

Hunter, meanwhile, is still getting to grips with the role, but is heartened when I say I have an interesting anecdote to pass on from the MP. "Helene Weigel said she based her characterisation of Mother Courage on Broadway singer Ethel Merman - it was that big, blousy aspect that attracted her. I personally found that an illuminating way to get into the role."

"Ah," says Hunter. "That's fascinating. I wonder what she meant. But I've still got a mountain to climb."

 Mother Courage and Her Children is at Oxford Playhouse (01865 798600) from today, then at Brighton, Leeds and Sheffield before opening at New Ambassadors, London WC2 (0171-836 6111), on April 25.

Is it an Everest for actresses, then - it's there, so they have to climb it? "Yes, perhaps," says Hunter. "I had always had a fantasy about playing it, and when [director Nancy Meckler] proposed it I was delighted. But the basic reason for doing it is that Brecht is the most extraordinary dramatist." While Rigg and Hunter can see the Lear parallel, Glenda Jackson doesn't entirely agree. The actress- turned MP made the role her swan song from the stage before she entered politics, performing it at the Glasgow Citizens in 1990. "It's a huge role - you're in practically every bloody scene - but I'm not quite sure it has the range of Lear. Although I suppose the great emotions, in that she is passionate about her children and suffers great loss, might suggest that. The challenge for the actor, though, is trying to not make her heroic. That was not Brecht's idea at all." Although all the actresses agree that the role should be within the range of a talented young actress, Rigg believes that it's one, like Lear, that only middle age can fully illuminate. "Mother Courage's age is never stated, but she has three grown children, so she must be at least 40. She has clearly lived a long time," says Rigg. "I did it in my mid-50s and it's that 'encrustation' that comes with living a few years that informs the part." When Rigg played Mother Courage at the National in 1995, part of the attraction was the chance to overturn standard perceptions of her. "I have this image as a rather grand leading lady, and I came on stage as a working-class woman with broad Yorkshire vowels. David Hare [who did the adaptation] knew I come from Yorkshire, so he decided to use that." Rigg's performance was described as Bet Lynch-meets-Marxist dialectic and she clearly had fun in what is regarded as A Very Serious Play. "The humour is there; it just needs to be brought out. I must say it was a joy to do, but bloody hard work - pulling that blessed cart around for three hours every night." Judi Dench played the role with the Royal Shakespeare Company in 1984. She wasn't aware of these details when she took the part, which she accepted without even reading the script - as is her practice - relying on Brecht's reputation for writing great roles for women. "When the director, Howard Davies, told me the story of Mother Courage, he didn't tell me she was on stage so much and he didn't tell me I had to pull round this enormous cart. So on the first day of rehearsal I thought, 'Fuck this. I never have a scene off.' I was so angry. But it was my own stupid fault, of course." While Rigg enjoyed playing with her image, Jackson was just grateful for a part to get her teeth into. "God knows, there are few enough roles for women anyway, but ones this good are exceedingly rare. And this is a great role in a great play. It's a popular myth that there are great roles in lousy play - there aren't, quite simply. I feel privileged to have played her." Hunter, meanwhile, is still getting to grips with the role, but is heartened when I say I have an interesting anecdote to pass on from the MP. "Helene Weigel said she based her characterisation of Mother Courage on Broadway singer Ethel Merman - it was that big, blousy aspect that attracted her. I personally found that an illuminating way to get into the role." "Ah," says Hunter. "That's fascinating. I wonder what she meant. But I've still got a mountain to climb."  Mother Courage and Her Children is at Oxford Playhouse (01865 798600) from today, then at Brighton, Leeds and Sheffield before opening at New Ambassadors, London WC2 (0171-836 6111), on April 25.

fields.headline: Summary of budget measures
fields.trailText:
Tax
 Basic tax down by 1p to 22p in the pound from April 6.
 Capital gains tax from April 6 to be cut for business from 40% to 35% after one year, 30% after two years, 20% after three years and 10% after four years.
 Inheritance tax threshold raised from £231,000 to £234,000.
 40% small and medium business capital allowances to be made permanent.
 All employee shareholders to benefit from 10% capital gains tax rate.

Tax
 Basic tax down by 1p to 22p in the pound from April 6.
 Capital gains tax from April 6 to be cut for business from 40% to 35% after one year, 30% after two years, 20% after three years and 10% after four years.
 Inheritance tax threshold raised from £231,000 to £234,000.
 40% small and medium business capital allowances to be made permanent.
 All employee shareholders to benefit from 10% capital gains tax rate.

NHS
 NHS spending to grow by 6.1% per year above inflation - £2,800 per household to be spent on the NHS by 2004.
 10,000 more nurses.
 Extra £2bn for the NHS from April. Health spending will be £54.2bn in 2000/2001.

Education
 £1bn for education.
 All primary schools to get extra cash - minimum of £3,000 - for books. The money to go direct to heads.
 Every secondary school to get at least £30,000 for books.
 Extra money for 16-year-olds in education.

Families
 More help for single parents.
 Take home pay rising for typical family with a real terms improvement of 10%.
 Maternity grant increased to £300 and review into maternity pay and parental leave.
 Child benefit maximum payment up to £50 a week, including an extra £4.35 a week for the poorest children.
 Working family tax credit up from £200 to £214 next year.
 Children's tax credit up £26 to £442 a year.

Employment
 Unemployment at lowest for 20 years.
 New deal extended to long-term adult unemployed from April 2001.
 Over 50s long-term unemployed to get guaranteed income.
 Tougher penalties for fraudulent social security claims from 1January 2001 and confidential phone line to start in May.

Tobacco and alcohol
 Beer up 1p a pint.
 Spirit duty frozen.
 Wine up 4p a bottle.
 Tobacco duty up 25p a packet - revenues to be spent on health funding.
 New measures to act on tobacco smuggling.

Transport and fuel
 £280m for transport.
 Fuel duty up 2p a litre - no real terms increase. Ultra low sulphur petrol duty to be set at 1p below other petrol from October 1.
 Vehicle excise duty for all cars frozen to 1 March 2001.
 New lower rates for cars up to 1200cc.

Crime
 Extra £285m to be spent on fight against crime.

Pensioners
 Pensioners' tax allowance increased to £5,790 and for those over 75 to £6,050.
 Reforms to mean 6m pensioners will not pay tax.
 Cut-off point for income support for pensioners raised to £12,000 of savings.
 New pensioners credit to be developed.
 Free TV licences for pensioners.
 Winter fuel allowance for pensioners will be raised from £100 to £150.
 Pensioners guaranteed £82 a week income - £172 for couples.

IT
 E-commerce and IT companies will be able to write technological investments off against tax for the next three years.
 Work permit rules relaxed for skilled IT workers.
 £1bn for regional development: new enterprise funds for poor areas and a regional innovation fund to promote hi-tech clusters.
Share option incentives of £100,000 to be offered for up to 15 essential employees by high-tech firms.
 £150m for new research and development tax credit and tax reductions for small businesses investing in technology.

Charities
 Tax reforms to make it easier to give money and time to voluntary organisations and charities.
 From April 6, the government will add an extra 28p for every pound given by a taxpayer to charity. For every pound contributed through pay packets, the government will add up to 50p worth of tax relief.
 To encourage corporate giving, any company can from next month receive tax relief on the full amount of any donation.
 VAT abolished on charity events.

Savings
 ISA ceiling to stay at £7,000 for 2000-2001.
 Banks invited to work with Post Office to offer basic banking service to all.

Stamp duty
 Stamp duty raised to 3% on property sales above £250,000 and 4% for sales above £500,000. No change for properties under £250,000.

Flights tax
 Air passenger duty on flights from Scottish Highlands and Islands abolished and cut on economy flights within the UK.

Economic indicators
 Economy grew by 2% in 1999.
 2000 surplus forecast to be £17bn.
 Budget is in surplus by £12bn.
 Surplus next year forecast to be £14bn.
 Growth is forecast to rise to 2.75%-3.25% this year and 2.25%-2.75% for the next two.
 Inflation is currently at 2.2%; in line with government target for three years.
 The inflation target is reafffirmed at 2.5% over the next three years.
 Social security spending is down by £3bn.
 Debt repayments are down £4bn a year, and will be £12bn in 2000.
 Public spending up by 2.5% a year for three years from 2001.

webTitle: Tony Cragg - A New Thing Breathing

fields.headline: Tony Cragg - A New Thing Breathing
fields.standfirst:
Tate Gallery, Liverpool
Rating:***
fields.trailText:
Tate Gallery, Liverpool
Rating:***
fields.body:
This is daft work, but not daft enough by half. A New Thing Breathing, the Tate Gallery Liverpool's "major spring" exhibition, shows recent work by Tony Cragg, the British sculptor who climbed to international fame alongside colleagues Richard Deacon, Richard Long and Bill Woodrow in the 80s.

His first junk constructions were acclaimed for their slightly irreverent grandeur, recycling the non-biodegradable contents of dustbins into droll affronts to the Thatcherite ethos of commercial self-interest. The 90s saw him fashioning more purist abstractions from bronze, stone, fibreglass and ceramics. But the results, as seen here, are Henry Moore meets Mr Blobby. Cragg comes across all seriously metaphysical in his exploration of the lumpy secretions of primal nature and invites nothing more profound than giggling at the back of the gallery.

Towering whirligigs of stone look like limp corkscrews or wobbly pots thrown by a drunk. There's a peppermint-tinted three-legged bugaboo, complete with rude appendages. Everything is sanded down and smoothed off in the simplistic assumption that nature abhors a sharp edge. Even the bronzes masquerade as conch fragments, their rhythmical intricacies blunted by a soporific sea. There's a lolling, sap-green tongue and a squashed dolphin nose. Such zoomorphic cliches are far from innate to the genre: in the same magnificent top-floor galleries some time ago Richard Deacon imbued organic semi-abstractions with a chill and wildly celebratory frisson of otherness.

Occasionally Cragg goes back to piling up recognisable things like he used to, but now the objects are cleaned-up, collectable things. His pyramids of coloured glass bottles would hardly look out of place in Habitat. Things get much more intriguing when he does something weird with his found objects. Thousands of black-and-white dice are glued to a massive sculptured pile of polystyrene, and at last Cragg connects to the more precise physics of mathematical wonderment. One can only question why on earth he doesn't do this kind of thing more often.

Something similarly odd does come to life when he sculpts what looks like a Buddha figurine shot through with holes out of sand blasted ceramics and places it to gaze silently out of the gallery window. I stand next to this ghostly spiritual sieve and gaze out too. The timeless mucky old Mersey chugs past, utterly oblivious.

 Till June 4. Details: 0151-702 7402.

fields.headline: BMW faces strike threat
fields.standfirst:
Unions to try for 'constructive' approach before taking action

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Union leaders yesterday threatened to take strike action to block BMW's sale of parts of Rover to Alchemy Partners, the London venture capital group.
fields.body:
Union leaders yesterday threatened to take strike action to block BMW's sale of parts of Rover to Alchemy Partners, the London venture capital group.

Senior national officers of the four unions representing Rover workers agreed at a meeting in Coventry to try to find an alternative buyer for Rover. They plan initially to approach BMW, other carmakers and the government to find another business to take on the ailing British car company.

But the union officials said that if this "constructive" approach failed, they would be prepared to consider demonstrations, boycotts and strike action to prevent the break-up of Rover. "There was a unanimous vote to oppose what BMW has done," a spokesman for the Transport and General Workers Union said.

Downing Street, however, sought to cool public anger over BMW's decision. In an attempt to avoid accusations of encouraging what one minister described as lingering "racist sentiment" in Britain, the prime minister's office took a neutral line on calls for a BMW boycott. "It is not the government's job to say to people what they should or should not do with their hard-earned cash when it comes to buying a car," the No 10 spokesman said.

Tony Woodley, the T&G's chief motor industry negotiator, said the unions were not prepared to accept the loss of up to 60,000 direct and indirect jobs in the industry as the result of Alchemy's plans to turn Rover into little more than a niche manufacturer of MG sports cars.

Rover workers fear that BMW will start to axe jobs long before the Rover Longbridge plant in Birmingham is sold to Alchemy.

A team from Alchemy met senior executives at Rover yesterday but the deal is not expected to be completed for at least six weeks.

Rover workers believe that BMW has nothing to lose and everything to gain from starting to run down Longbridge production now that it has agreed to dispose of the business.

The plant is already making more Rover 25 and 45 models than it can sell. Alchemy has indicated these models do not feature in its plans for Longbridge where it wants to built a new range of MG sports cars.

Rover officials yesterday tried to play down the number of jobs likely to go at Longbridge. A spokesman said that the plant only had about 4,500 car production workers out of a total workforce of 9,000.

fields.headline: Apocalypse now
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia Orchestra/ Leonard Slatkin
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia Orchestra/ Leonard Slatkin
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Despite the controversy which surrounded the work at the time of its premiere, Anthony Payne's completion of Elgar's Third Symphony (or "Elaboration of the Sketches", to use Payne's own phrase) has won a permanent place in the repertory - so much so, that Elgar's other symphonies have tended to slip from view of late.

It's already been recorded twice. Many British conductors have championed the work. American Elgarian Leonard Slatkin conducted the New York premiere last year. This was his first performance of it in the UK.

Having presented Payne with honorary membership of the Royal Philharmonic Society, Slatkin gave us an interpretation which was predictably different from many we've heard before, though equally valid. In place of an emotional pattern of energy and collapse, grandeur and exhaustion, Slatkin takes his cue from the fact that some of Elgar's sketches derive from a projected oratorio about the last judgment, and drives the symphony with a nervous, terrifying vigour. The result is scarily apocalyptic. Even the muted trumpet and clattering tambourine of the scherzo have an ominous chill. The whole culminates in a relentless march into oblivion, which is disquieting in the extreme.

Slatkin brackets it with James MacMillan's Sinfonietta, a brief spiritual odyssey from heaven to hell and back again. There were plenty of fabulous textures here - ethereally squeaking saxophones, pellucid strings, clangorous brass. Slatkin also emphasised the work's debt - intentional or otherwise - to Wagner's Parsifal. It's powerhouse stuff, emphasising MacMillan's inspirational decline of late.

Sandwiched between these two was Sibelius's Violin Concerto with Joshua Bell as soloist, fine-toned, technically staggering, yet somehow failing to get to the dark heart of the work's drama. The overall effect was of a romantic reverie. Sibelius's concerto needs more ferocity than Bell can supply.

fields.headline: Electric conductor
fields.standfirst:
London Symphony Orchestra/ Riccardo Chailly
Barbican, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
London Symphony Orchestra/ Riccardo Chailly
Barbican, London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
The only disappointment about the LSO's spectacularly fine concert under Riccardo Chailly on Sunday evening was the scattering of empty seats. The Barbican should have been full to bursting; not only is Chailly one of the greatest living conductors, with few equals at the moment, but his programme was drawn from the very heart of his concert repertory.

Perhaps it was the 15 minutes of Varèse, nestling between two of Debussy's Nocturnes and Mahler's First Symphony, that deterred some people. Yet no one should have been discomfited by the first of the two works, Un Grand Sommeil Noir. The piece is a setting of Verlaine from 1905 which, with its Pelléas-like prosody and static harmony, is in thrall to Debussy more than anyone. The captivating Mireille Delunsch sang it in an orchestration by Antony Beaumont, which mirrored the scoring for the settings of Latin American texts in Offrandes, which Chailly delivered with wiry intensity.

The two Nocturnes had been given a luminous definition, stealthily suggestive in "Nuages", deliriously extrovert in "Ftes". What set his Mahler apart too, was the high level of characterisation brought to every instrumental and emotional detail. With top-flight orchestras, like his own Concertgebouw in Amsterdam and the London Symphony, he produces electrifying results.

This was a spinetingling account of the First Symphony, relishing the raw colours - the spiky clarinet interjections in the first movement, the reptilian crawl of double bass, tuba and bassoon in the funeral march - just as much as the touch of schmaltz in the hushed stillness of the second subject of the finale. But the grandeur was there too, delivered in a blazing vision that had been unerringly targeted from the opening bars an hour earlier.

Riccardo Chailly conducts the LSO again at the Barbican on Thursday, in a programme that includes Stravinsky's The Rite of Spring. Box office: 0171-638 8891.

webTitle: House price rises starting to wane

fields.headline: House price rises starting to wane
fields.trailText: House sales jumped by a 10th in the last three months following a rush to complete purchases ahead of feared rises in stamp duty in today's Budget, according to figures from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.
fields.body:
House sales jumped by a 10th in the last three months following a rush to complete purchases ahead of feared rises in stamp duty in today's Budget, according to figures from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

But booming house prices in the south have tempted homeowners to put their houses on the market in growing numbers, producing a levelling off in prices.

The north-west and Wales are now overtaking the south as the "hot spots" in the housing market and recording the steepest rises in prices, according to RICS.

fields.headline: Dialog touts its 'secret' saviour
fields.trailText: Dan Wagner finally convinced the City yesterday that he has a plan in place that will release his software and computer group Dialog from its crippling debt obligations.
fields.body:
Dan Wagner finally convinced the City yesterday that he has a plan in place that will release his software and computer group Dialog from its crippling debt obligations.

Its shares soared 48p to 230p as the former advertising man outlined how he was in "advanced discussions" to sell Dialog's information services division to an unnamed third party.

It is a badly kept secret that Thomson Corporation is bailing Mr Wagner out from a £160m debt burden that had driven the share price down to a low point of 55p and left wags in the City calling the company "dial-a-dog".

The disgraced City Slickers in the Daily Mirror had repeatedly tipped Dialog as a turnaround stock but most analysts gave up covering it in frustration after a series of false dawns.

Yet Mr Wagner was a bit of a visionary in his day. He was one of the first to realise the benefits from packaging electronic information and data for scientists, librarians and other specialists. He formed his first company, Maid, in 1982 to do that and floated it on the London stock market in 1994, with a listing on Nasdaq to follow 12 months later.

But his mistake came two years ago when he bought the Knight Ridder Information business for $420m (£267m), which left the newly named Dialog struggling to make $30m a year in interest repayments. But the agony appears to be over.

Thomson, which has sold all but two of its newspapers to concentrate on electronic media, will take over the information services division, which accounts for more than 90% of Dialog's revenues.

A cash contribution would pay off all Dialog's debt but the deal will involve a strategic alliance plus an equity holding by Thomson. Meanwhile, Mr Wagner will slip away with the tiny e-commerce and web solutions units, which will re-establish themselves under a new name Bright Stations.

This new enterprise will set up a new division to invest in and advise internet start-ups helped by a further equity injection from a third party, said a statement.

So should investors be rushing up to board Mr Wagner's new venture? It might be wise to wait for the financial train to leave the Bright Station and establish a decent track record first.

webTitle: My firm's pouring money down the drain

fields.headline: My firm's pouring money down the drain
fields.trailText: My colleague responsible for the £10m loss is heading for another promotion. I can't do anything about him, but I'd really like to leave both the project and my reputation intact.
fields.body:
The problem

For many years I have provided technical support for a project that has been a complete money pit. I've tried explaining why we should drop the technology but my bosses say I'm negative.

In contrast, the person responsible for the £10m loss is heading for another promotion. The business will probably be allowed to fold and his successors will carry the blame. I can't do anything about him, but I'd really like to leave both the project and my reputation intact so I can rebuild a career in which integrity is valued. Is this possible?

The solution

This is a classic example of poor person-environment fit. Your working environment seems to demand 'yes' people who wax lyrical about pie-in-the-sky schemes and ambitious projects.

Your bosses want people to share their (unfounded) enthusiasm and help them build lofty dreams - without considering the possibility of those dreams collapsing.

They don't want negativity - and anything that suggests that their hastily-constructed plans may be wobbly will be viewed as negativity. You, on the other hand, are a realist who wants to see results and isn't afraid to point out mistakes where appropriate. You are playing a role akin to a biblical prophet, warning of the dire consequences of failing to act. Like the prophets of old, so many of whom were ostracised for their prophecies of doom, you too are becoming a scapegoat for people who don't want to hear your warnings.

My advice? Either keep your thoughts to yourself or find another company where you will find a better person-environment fit. Look for companies that encourage dissenting views and that seek opinions from employees and customers (companies with feedback systems or suggestion boxes). Organisations which encourage debate, for example, through newsletters, would be better suited to your personality. You will also be much more valued and will thus retain not only your integrity but your sanity too.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Banks face further cartel inquiry
fields.standfirst: Byers backs Cruickshank call for action on banking services to small business
fields.trailText: The government moved immediately yesterday to back a key plank in the Cruickshank banking review when it ordered a competition commission inquiry into the way small and medium-sized businesses are treated by Britain's leading high street banks.
fields.body:
The government moved immediately yesterday to back a key plank in the Cruickshank banking review when it ordered a competition commission inquiry into the way small and medium-sized businesses are treated by Britain's leading high street banks.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, announced the move after the 344-page report voiced serious concern about the near-monopoly of services for small businesses enjoyed by the four main banks.

"The health of small and medium-sized firms is crucial to the success of the economy and the employment of many people", said Mr Byers. "The provision of banking services is an important influence on their prospects for growth and success in the future."

In his report, Mr Cruickshank, the former telecommunications regulator and managing director of Virgin, said that the share of business services accounted for by the big four - NatWest, Barclays, HSBC Midland and Lloyds TSB - stood at 83%, much higher than for personal customers.

As well as calling for a reference of small business banking to the competition commission, Mr Cruickshank said some parts of the major banks' business banking networks might have to be broken up to create local competition. Without direct government intervention, the prospect of reform was remote.

"The result of this market structure is high profits and high prices, in particular for money transmission services," Mr Cruickshank said. "The market dynamic seen in personal banking services is absent.

"There is little prospect of effective competition. Some behavioural remedies will help, but an urgent complex monopoly investigation, with the possibility of of structural remedies, is needed."

Small businesses - which have long complained of the deal they have been receiving from the banks - responded positively to news of the competition commission inquiry.

"We are increasingly concerned that the concentration of banking services in a small number of banks is restricting choice in the small business sector. Government must also recognise that limited competition and issues such as charges on cash machines have a knock-on effect on small local traders," said Ian Peters, deputy director general of the British Chambers.

Donald Martin, banking spokesman for the Federation of Small Businesses said: "This report vindicates everything we have been saying. In particular we welcome the acknowledgement of lack of effective competition between the banks, lack of ease of changing banks and the lack of transparency in calculating charges, in particular interest charges."

However, the big banks said the referral to the commission was unnecessary.

The British Bankers' Association hit back at the report, saying many of its conclusions were questionable, tenuous and unsubstantiated. "Spin-doctor numbers should not be the basis for government policy," said the BBA director-general Tim Sweeney.

A spokeswoman for Lloyds TSB said: "We continue to believe that there is no reason for yet another competition inquiry but we have nothing to fear. We believe that the small business banking sector is competitive."

A spokeswoman for HSBC said: "We welcome competition. The financial services sector, including small business banking, is already very competitive in the UK."

webTitle: The major Budget changes to personal finance

fields.headline: The major Budget changes to personal finance
fields.trailText: Stamp duty
fields.body:
Stamp duty

People buying properties costing more than £250,000 will face a larger bill from April 6.
Homes costing more than £250,000 will attract a stamp duty levy of 3 per cent, up from 2.5 per cent.
For properties costing more than £500,000, the duty will rise to 4 per cent, up from 3.5 per cent.

Nevertheless, 95 per cent of homebuyers will remain unaffected by the change. For those buying a house for less than £60,000 there will be no stamp duty to pay. For homes worth between £60,000 and £250,000 the rate is 1 per cent.

People buying homes in London and the south east will be worst hit by the move, which is designed to cool down the booming housing market without the Chancellor raising interest rates.

Savings

There was good news for investors as Gordon Brown announced that the £7,000 allowance for Individual savings accounts (Isas) will remain for the new financial year in April 2000 to 2001.

When Isas were launched last year the Chancellor announced the allowance would fall to £5,000. Now private investors will be able to put up to £7,000 worth of stocks and shares into a maxi Isa - £2,000 more than previously expected.
The mini Isa limit for stocks and shares remains at £3,000 as does the mini Isa limit of £1,000 for insurance.

However, savers wanting to put their funds into a mini cash Isa will now be able to salt away £3,000 from April. The cash limit was to have dropped to £1,000.

Child benefit

Parents should receive a cash boost thanks to a shake-up in child benefits.
Child Benefit will rise to £15.50 from April next year.

The £28 weekly ceiling will be raised to £50.
Poorer families will also be given an extra £4.35 a week through the Working Families and Disabled Person's Tax Credits.
There will be a further cash injection of £8.50 a week in a new Children's Tax Credit scheme launched in April 2001.

The moves are designed to bring families with one child and one person in work up to the £214 a week minimum guaranteed income by April next year.

fields.headline: A glimpse at possibilities
fields.standfirst:
Cay Hop and Grape
Manchester/ touring
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Cay Hop and Grape
Manchester/ touring
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Anet Mook's voice immediately commands attention. Even on record, she hoarsely screams and reaches rare levels of catharsis. Comparisons with Courtney Love have abounded but for sheer visceral impact it's not fanciful to describe Mook as a half-pint sized, female Black Francis.

Her fellow band members are no slouches either. Cay's debut album, Nature Creates Freaks, combined granite riffs with the unorthodox tunings of Sonic Youth and hinted at the influence of post-rock maestros Slint. So there was considerable expectation as they ambled on stage and launched into a blistering Princes and Princesses. Mook was in fine form, presumably having swallowed a cocktail of ground glass, absinthe and 200 Park Drives in preparation.

It was the perfect soundtrack for the moshpit to collect bruises as limbs collided and drinks were thrown in the air. During Nature Creates Freaks, however, Mook jerked away from the microphone and Nicky Olofsson cast off his guitar as the song hobbled to an untidy conclusion. A stage-diver had spilt beer on their equipment.

The interruption fatally punctured Cay's impetus. A batch of new songs displaying their sound's increasing subtlety were not ideal for the occasion, and were hindered by a lack of stage presence: Olofsson cut a statuesque figure and Mook shuffled undemonstratively around the stage. Bare-chested drummer Mark Bullock, attacking his kit as if fulfilling a serious vendetta, provided a more dynamic focal point.

They belatedly regained inspiration with the concluding Reasonable Ease in Chilled Out Conditions. Guitars raged then, displaying their grasp of light and shade. The song shifted to contemplative mode as Mook gasped "and when we both come down/and when we're both worn out". It seemed an apt reflection on a night which could have been a triumphant reaffirmation of rock's transcendental qualities but instead offered only fleeting glimpses of Cay's capabilities.

Cay play the Cavern Club, Exeter (01392 495370), tonight, then tour.

fields.headline: Party pieces
fields.standfirst:
Disco Relax
Toynbee Studios, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Disco Relax
Toynbee Studios, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
It's time to party again with Forced Entertainment. We've been here before, of course, down in the bowels of the disco pub amid the lurex and the tinsel, knee-deep in cigarette butts, booze and piss, like a never-ending Christmas party. Tomorrow there will be regrets.

But for now, the talk flows like the drink. Two women talk into microphones confessing, accusing, joking, threatening, their mouths an O-gape of smeared lipstick. A guitarist strums a tune. A man in a mask and a party hat lolls drunkenly. Around his neck, a sign proclaims "drunk twat." He peers at a video screen upon which a small boy does magic tricks and talks about the sinking of the Titanic. The masked man stares blindly as if he's searching for something he lost.

Not the women. One glances idly in the direction of the child. "Cunt," she mouths idly. There is something extraordinarily shocking about this. But then Forced Entertainment's 18th show lays everything bare. Alcohol leaves these people naked, with nowhere to hide as the prejudices, aggression and limp jokes pour forth like vomit. The women have a running gag about a courtroom, oblivious to the fact that it is they who are on trial.

It is not an easy show to like. It lacks the flashes of tenderness that illuminated previous shows. It makes boredom into an art form. Yet there is something compelling about it too. Brutal and ridiculous at the same time. Like watching a disaster unfolding before your eyes in which none of the participants realise that they are the catastrophes. "I'm leaking," giggles one of the women. The whole ship is going down. The music plays on, another bottle is opened. Just life as usual stretching into an infinity.

 Disco Relax is at the Arena Theatre, Wolverhampton (01902- 321321), tonight and tomorrow, and at Phoenix Arts, Leicester (0116-255 4854), on Friday.
